LEAD: NEARLY seven months after the shooting death of a Mexican immigrant and the wounding of his brother by an off-duty police detective here, a quiet revolution is taking place in this city of 42,000 people. Hispanic residents are beginning to organize and demand a voice in government, police affairs and even the naming of streets that is more in line with their numbers, which account for at least 40 percent of the population.

LEAD: There are four of them, and they dress in a manner best described as bristling: hair close-cropped, heavy boots with trousers bloused, black leather jackets and epaulets. They wear ties, and the look is neat, but a little Germanic, circa 1939. Two have earrings, but they say that is not part of the look, the skinhead look.

LEAD: Magazine readers may have to search harder to spot their favorite title on the newsstand. Within the past year a number of well-known consumer and trade journals redesigned their styles and formats. The year 1988 marked the redesign of Ms. (February), Esquire (March), H.G.(March), Mademoiselle (May), Good Housekeeping (July), Glamour (July), Fortune (August) and most recently, Self (December) to name a few.

LEAD: As foreign trade goes, the loss of $130 million a year in exports is a minor matter. But beef industry executives and Federal agriculture officials say the stakes are far higher in a shrill trade dispute that has erupted with Europe over the presence of hormones in American beef.

Obviously, if one of the most powerful investment banking firms in
LEAD: AS rising interest rates gather momentum, many business executives would expect Connecticut's light manufacturing and service-oriented economy to slow down proportionately.
LEAD: A KIND of cultural brainstorming will take place in the county in the next two weeks as seven public meetings are held across Westchester to gather ideas for improving community cultural life.

LEAD: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, Jennifer Ann Chamberlain, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Monroe Chamberlain of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Thomas Gibson Olsen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Olsen of Pound Ridge, N.Y. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony.

LEAD: In an Olympics mired in controversy and riddled by scandal, Greg Louganis held tight to this ideals, kept his goals in focus and successfully completed the task at hand. His ability to continue after a near-tragic accident and capture the gold medal is a testament to his desire, discipline and, most of all, his courage.

LEAD: In one of history's ironies, Serge Prokofiev died on March 5, 1953, the same date as Stalin. The Soviet press, of course, played up the dictator's demise to the virtual exclusion of the composer's. Even in death, Stalin and his Bolshevik state cast a shadow over Prokofiev's career - as, indeed, they did over all Soviet composers' lives.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Jack H. Faber of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Gail Faber, to Charles Michael Flock, a son of Mrs. Charles Flock of Garden City, L.I., and the late Mr. Flock. Miss Faber, a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at Columbia University, and her fiance, a principal of Cone Software in Upland, Pa., plan to marry in May.

LEAD: Years of frustration, second-class citizenship and a sense of anonymity will end for one of two teams today at Orchard Park, N.Y.

LEAD: The stormy politics of South Africa since the emergency decrees of 1985 reaches most of us in single, incendiary images from news reports. Yet the reality of life under apartheid is far more complex than simple distinctions like black versus white, writes David C. Turnley, a photojournalist, in WHY ARE THEY WEEPING?

LEAD: The engagement of Elizabeth Davis Jaroslow to Marc Allen Lipsett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Lipsett of San Francisco, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Fred Jaroslow of Sands Point, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: WHEN my wife and I retired to Florida from Long Island 10 years ago, we reassured our married daughter who lives in Woodmere that we would always be there for her, just a phone call away, should she ever need us. A decade later she called in her marker.

LEAD: UNDERCOVER: The Secret Lives of a Federal Agent. By Donald Goddard. (Times Books, $19.95.) Michael Levine was a big, tough, streetwise kid from the Bronx. With a penchant for settling arguments with his fists, he could easily have found a permanent home in one of New York's finer penal institutions.

LEAD: Class, that useful word for a combination of wealth, position, education and style, is one of the dirty nonsecrets of American life. We are flattered by Alexis de Tocqueville's observation on his first visit to America that ''the entire society seems to have melted into a middle class.'' Yet, who can fail to see the unmeltable divisions within the great middle class itself?

A June 24 wedding is planned. Miss Carpenter, a graduate of the National Cathedral School in Washington, graduated from the University of Virginia, where she expects to receive a master's in May from the School of Education.

LEAD: The 1989 Bob Jones Award winner for distinguished sportsmanship, determined by the United States Golf Association, is Chi Chi Rodriguez, who won eight tournaments on the PGA Tour and is now a star on the senior tour. He started and still supports the Chi Chi Rodriguez Youth Foundation, a Florida center which helps abused and disadvantaged youths.

LEAD: REFLECTIONS ON THE WAY TO THE GALLOWS: Rebel Women in Prewar Japan. Translated and edited by Mikiso Hane. (University of California/Pantheon, $22.50.) In the Japan portrayed in this book, from the late 19th century up to World War II, young girls work 12-hour shifts in textile factories, poor farmers sell their daughters to brothels, police arrest anyone suspected of socialist sympathies and women are prohibited by law from participating in political activities.
LEAD: IN the small kitchen of the Restaurant du Village in Chester, meat juices sizzled on the stove, the air smelled of herbs, and several men were talking and laughing. And cooking.

LEAD: A judge has declined to become involved in a dispute over the election of a Communist as a student leader at the University of Massachusetts.

LEAD: If one of your New Year's resolutions is to get back into the market, you might want to consider joining - or even starting - an investment club. Generally organized by 15 or so friends in the form of a partnership, the clubs offer a way to pool investment money and knowledge while at the same time lessening the anxiety level.

LEAD: YEARS ago, many children learned about the symphony orchestra while squirming through an occasional Young People's Concert somewhere. Others were dragged to a Friday afternoon subscription concert, where the jangling of bracelets often drowned out the ringing of triangles. Either way, it was a nonparticipatory experience and often a boring one.

LEAD: The Soviet Union is facing the brightest holiday on its calendar in the grimmest mood anyone can remember, primarily because of food and consumer-goods shortages that seem to grow more acute by the day.

LEAD: WHEN the National Association of Business Economists reported recently that its members were pessimistic about near-term business growth and fearful that inflationary pressures were building, they confirmed something that the Quality Plumbing and Heating Company in St. Paul, Minn., had been feeling for months.

LEAD: WHAT do Westchester business leaders see in store for the New Year? In contrast to the national uncertainty about the strength of the economy, Westchester observers are anticipating that this year the local business climate will favor economic growth in the county. There is concern, however, that the lack of affordable housing and of adequate public transportation and the shortages of entry-level workers may pose problems.

LEAD: NEW JERSEY, the most densely populated state, is also one of the most fragmented. This is one reason why so much attention is being paid to the state's attempts to coordinate the activities of all 567 towns and cities and devise a comprehensive vision of the state's future.

LEAD: A last-minute agreement by Governor Kean with Senate and Assembly leaders on a two-year extension of New Jersey's Uncompensated Care Trust Fund has averted a crisis for many inner-city hospitals. This trust fund helps pay the hospital bills of poor and uninsured people by spreading the cost among the 89 acute-care hospitals in the state through a surcharge on all hospital bills.

For the Harlem Third World Trade Institute, which produced the booklet, placing the proposed International Trade Center in New York City clearly was not as important as identifying it with what has become, for many parts of the third world, an unofficial capital.

LEAD: Most of the skiing fatalities in Vermont in the last 10 years were due to head injuries and might have been prevented if the skiers had been wearing helmets, a state medical examiner says.

Before the parties sat down to negotiate under prodding from Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein, the Long Island Weekly asked several people for suggestions on ending the Shoreham problem.

LEAD: THE communal basement storage room - the apartment dweller's version of the attic - is undergoing a radical transformation. The traditional mountain of worn trunks, rusty bicycles and other household ephemera is giving way to a neater, more carefully supervised alternative - the personal storage bin.

LEAD: Trailer 24, on the back lot of Paramount Studios, is an exciting place to work these days. The modular office block, headquarters of ''The Arsenio Hall Show,'' fairly vibrates with optimism: confident-looking executives navigate its stark corridors; lanky, black-sneakered comedy writers wisecrack happily as they shamble, in convoy, from production meeting to production meeting; the office walls of Marla Kell Brown, the show's producer, are papered on three sides with dozens of 5-by-7 index cards, each bearing the famous name - Barbara Walters, Clint Eastwood, Oprah Winfrey, etc.

LEAD: ''Painting in Renaissance Siena: 1420-1500'' at the Metropolitan Museum is a glorious affair. Even in a season that has seen one great exhibition after another, worldwide, this one is a nonpareil. Moreover, the art that we see there is in the highest degree an unstandardized art - one that keeps us continually on the alert, thinking new thoughts, dreaming new dreams and on fire with speculation.

Yet, the parents of this child are financially responsible for it until said child reaches 21.

As the Shakespearean scholar Anne Barton points out in the New Penguin edition, Mozart sketched out an opera based upon it, Hollywood plundered its story for a science fiction film (''The Silent Planet''), T.S.

LEAD: If you have friends and would like to keep them, try never to talk about movie endings. No greater breach of cinema-related etiquette exists, unless it's recommending a comedy by retelling its jokes. Endings are sacrosanct for obvious reasons, and also because a viewer's opinion of a film is usually formed long before the ending comes along.

LEAD: EVERY Sunday afternoon, at our weekend place in North Haven, just outside of Sag Harbor, my wife and I ask each other the same question. Should we return to Manhattan later that afternoon or leave early Monday morning? This question and the discussion surrounding it involves a variety of factors - the weather, our fatigue, and our adherence to a well-known principle of physics -that a body at rest tends to remain at rest.

LEAD: The engagement of Susanna Natalia Gioia to Anthony Giordano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Giordano Jr. of Bernardsville, N.J., has been made known by her parents, Iris Gioia and Emilio Gioia, both of New York. A May wedding is planned.
LEAD: JACK GANCE By Ward Just. 279 pp. Boston. A Richard Todd Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

LEAD: THE world is coming apart in the Hudson River Museum, at Yonkers. Its fragmentation is the result, not of an explosion, but of the search by 22 artists for another angle on reality. The findings by these artists, called ''The World Is Round: Contemporary Panoramas,'' were organized for the museum by a guest curator, Marcia Clark, but they have only just arrived there, having spent the last year touring other galleries in the Northeast.

LEAD: NO. 16 Elm Street in Huntington Village is a familiar address to those who dine out frequently. First it was French, then seafood and now Italian: from Peche Mignon to Steve's Lighthouse to the present Villa Adriano.
LEAD: There is growing concern among American yachtsmen that the United States may be losing ground in its ability to defend the America's Cup.

LEAD: ASAD, THE SPHINX OF DAMASCUS: A Political Biography. By Moshe Ma'oz. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $19.95.) Moshe Ma'oz, a professor of modern Middle East history at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, has set out to write what he calls ''a political biography of an outstanding ruler of modern Syria,'' President Hafez al-Assad.
LEAD: BELLMAN AND TRUE Starring Bernard Hill (at center in photo), Kieran O'Brien, Richard Hope (right), Ken Bones (left). Directed by Richard Loncraine. 1987. Cannon. 121 minutes. $79.95. Rated R.
LEAD: IN its latest wrinkle, the jeans jacket has dropped its good ol' boy image and gone and got itself all duded up in what might be called a bright lights, big city blue denim motif.
LEAD: Poor Mrs. Tilley (''Model's Success Is in Her Hands,'' Nov. 27).

LEAD: In some ways Minneapolis at this moment may be the best place in which to ponder the essence of Los Angeles. No, it is not a matter of using sub-zero weather to instill a proper respect for palm trees and smog, but the fact that the Walker Art Center here, just two years after initiating a magnificent retrospective of the work of Los Angeles's pre-eminent architect, Frank Gehry, has now mounted an exhibition of the work of Franklin D.

LEAD: SNOWSTORMS IN A HOT CLIMATE. By Sarah Dunant. (Random House, $15.95.) First published in Great Britain, this psychological thriller travels well. While American readers may not find the settings - cramped, gritty New York City and the vast, sparkling California coast, among others - particularly exotic, they will find the writing refreshingly economical and astute.

LEAD: In the decade that he has been Mayor of Washington, Marion S. Barry Jr. has fought off reports of drug and alcohol abuse, always insisting that they were politically inspired. Last week, the Justice Department said it would investigate a visit the Mayor paid to an acquaintance suspected of selling drugs.
LEAD: The best performers were Dave Winfield, Jose Canseco and Frank Viola. Also: Patrick Ewing, Darryl Strawberry and Mario Lemieux. ALPHONSE MAZZINA Union City, N.J.

LEAD: IN London, one does not have tea. One does not merely drink tea. One takes tea, like one takes a holiday, or a calming constitutional, or a medicine that puts one's health to rights. English teatime is a social ritual, made fashionable in the 1840's, but it is a quiet and relaxing social ritual. As Michael Twomey, manager of the Palm Court of the Ritz Hotel in London, says, ''In the middle of the afternoon, when your batteries run down, it is a very nice thing to take tea.
LEAD: NICARAGUAN PEASANT POETRY FROM SOLENTINAME Translated by David Gullette. 211 pp. Albuquerque, N.M.: West End Press. Paper, $11.95.

LEAD: Anyone who thinks New York City co-op boards are fussy might consider the case at the Viewpointe, an adults-only condominium complex in Margate, Fla. The Viewpointe board has set a deadline of Jan. 10 for Jamie Swartz, 9 years old, to leave the apartment owned by her father and stepmother, who took the girl in several months before her mother died of cancer.

LEAD: Altitude may be a common metaphor for success, but not with opera singers. They are complaining with increasing stridency that international standards of pitch have broken disastrously free of their moorings and that the direction they are headed is up.
LEAD: MY INTENTION WAS TO become a great novelist, not a foreign correspondent, so naturally I never expected to end up in Westminster Abbey covering the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II.

LEAD: DEEDS, NOT WORDS, are what count, we are repeatedly reminded. And Shakespeare's Hamlet, with his sighing dismissal of ''Words, words, words,'' gave the word >words a cast of inaction if not meaninglessness.
LEAD: MY parents moved to Long Island in the spring of 1960. With little deliberation, they rented a house in Commack.
LEAD: What may have been the last issue of The Miami News rolled off the presses this morning, no last-minute deals having been made to keep the city's oldest daily newspaper alive.

LEAD: NINE HUNDRED Upper East Side residents, during a bitter community board hearing last June, spent hours speaking, cheering and booing plans to open a drop-in center for homeless people in their neighborhood.

LEAD: When Anthea Disney, who is credited with the successful redesign of Us magazine, took over as editor of Self magazine in July, she planned a redesign. ''Self will be 10 years old in March 1989, and every year our reader grows up,'' said Ms. Disney.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I was sorry to read that Orrin Pilkey opposes the plan of the Army Corps of Engineers to save the homes on Dune Road in Westhampton Beach, L.I. His singularly financial analysis of the situation ignores the human element involved. My family, along with many others, owns a home beyond the erosion. It is currently inaccessible because of the shoreline damage.

LEAD: When hundreds of residents were told they would have to leave their houses in the Logan area of the city, the structures already posed a hazard: the row houses listed at angry angles, sidewalks were crumbled and the ground seemed no more steady than the nerves of the residents. It was a situation, city officials said, that could only get worse.

LEAD: Brian Leetch's left foot, broken bone and all, is still swollen and painful. It hurts him to put on skates, hurts him to stand in them, hurts him when they are taken off. As a result, he is forced to tape his foot with care before a game and ice it afterward.
LEAD: MIND CHILDREN The Future of Robot and Human Intelligence. By Hans Moravec. Illustrated. 214 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $18.95.

LEAD: AS Congress considers the military spending bill that is near the top of its 1989 agenda, it will do so amid growing concern over the sharp rise in foreign takeovers of American military suppliers.

LEAD: You have been a good customer at the bank for 10 years, and now you want to apply for a mortgage. There are forms galore. Taking pen in hand you scribble answers to questions about your credit history, questions that the bank has asked many times before. A half-hour later the loan officer shakes your hand and says you will get an answer in three to four weeks.
LEAD: Celebrities bewitch us with fantasies of glamour, wealth and fame. Their scandals tittilate; their excesses stupify. Who's in and who's out for the new year?

By most thinking, for example, ''Parsifal'' must be greater art than ''Die Fledermaus'' because its themes of suffering and redemption sit more heavily on our consciousness. One must admit, moreover, that ''Die Fledermaus'' - which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Edward V. K. Jaycox and Victoria Holt Jaycox of Chevy Chase, Md., of the engagement of their daughter Tamara LaForge Jaycox to Lewis Maier Kessler, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Kessler of Pittsburgh.

LEAD: 'I'm hoping that people will look back and say that in that difficult period, he got the ship through the storm. Maybe the captain got thrown overboard, but the ship got through.' - Paul T. Gentile, District Attorney of the Bronx, who has been in office only 14 months and is now yielding the job to Robert T.

LEAD: CAIRO comes at you like an assailant, or a persistent vendor of dubious wares. It teems and hustles, bursts with energy, oozes decay, collapses under its own frustrations. But it will not be denied. On the banks of the Nile, the impressions tumble, willy-nilly: noise and dust and the strangled calls of street hawkers; awesome sunsets, chaos, traffic, polluted air; the click of croquet mallets on the pampered lawns of the Gezira Sporting

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 7 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. Q (Morrow, $19.95.) Four nuns become pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. 2 2 22 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy.

LEAD: Ronald Reagan, who knows something about scripts, is busily writing one of his own to guide future historians. They are likely to ignore it. His simplistic gloss does little justice to eight years full of contradiction and surprise.

LEAD: More things get started than get finished, and thus the notion of process carries with it a whiff of uncertainty. Ambition, dreams, vision - these are great human motivations. But, of course, between motivation and achievement a lot can happen.

LEAD: A DECADE ago China had a handful of bridge enthusiasts. Although the number is not known now, it is likely to be second only to the United States in terms of tournament players. A team event in Shanghai early this year attracted more than 700 teams and would have broken the world record for a single event if some players had not been excluded by lack of accommodation.

LEAD: Consumer spending is an important indicator of future economic activity. While many analysts predicted a lackluster holiday selling season, consumers emptied their pocketbooks in the last 48 hours before Christmas, pushing holiday sales 5 percent to 6 percent beyond last year's levels. Four experts assess the future economic impact of strong consumer demand.

LEAD: Although she said she would like to run again for Britain, Zola Budd, the world-class middle-distance runner, said she would never denounce apartheid despite pressure from opponents of the racial-separation laws of her native South Africa.

LEAD: OUT ON THE RIM, by Ross Thomas. (Mysterious Press, $4.95.) This ''nimble international thriller'' about a terrorism expert named Booth Stallings and his dealings with Filipino guerrillas plotting against the Aquino Government is an ideal book to read on a long flight, Marilyn Stasio said here last year.

LEAD: The White House and the Justice Department have begun drafting court documents seeking to overturn subpoenas issued to President Reagan and Vice President George Bush for their courtroom testimony in the Iran-contra conspiracy trial of Oliver L. North, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: Two new regulations intended to improve New York's environment will go into effect with the New Year.

LEAD: One of the most interesting judgments a player is called upon to make is whether inducing a weakness in the opponent's pawn position is worth the lost tempo that the probe and retreat require. The conflict is between structure and time.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Amiot Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Stephanie L'Abbe Amiot to Robert Stuart Hull, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd N. Hull of Greenwich. The couple plan a July wedding. Miss Amiot, a graduate of Denison University, received a master's degree in organizational psychology from Columbia University.

LEAD: Faye Deborah Levin, an associate at the Manhattan law firm of Taub & Fasciana, and Dr. Harvey Mark Levin, a dentist in Washington, plan to be married in June. Dr. and Mrs. Norman L. Levin of Brooklyn have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Gertrude Levin of the Bronx and the late Harry Levin.
LEAD: An article on Dec. 18 listing placement agencies for nannies gave an incorrect telephone number for Kare for Kids in Hackensack. The agency's number is (201) 666-9539.

LEAD: IF you are a graduate of a sizable college, you probably have been offered the chance to take a trip with academic overtones. Alumni tours are big business, often providing an opportunity to learn while you travel. But perhaps your fellow alumni aren't going where you want to go, or maybe their trip is focused on wildlife when you're more interested in archeology.
LEAD: Francis (Mickey) Featherstone, an admitted killer who turned informer, has won his freedom, largely in return for testifying against his former associates in a violent gang called the Westies.

LEAD: Garden City $405,000 4 Birch Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old center-hall colonial; fireplace, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $5,900. Hempstead $220,000 21 Clark Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 55-year-old colonial; fireplace in living room, den, 2-car garage; taxes $3,250.

LEAD: A story Dec. 11 [ ''Cutting Up Flipper,'' Long Island Journal ] serves as a source of great consternation to the students, faculty and administration of Bayport-Blue Point High School. The title blithely implies that a friend (Flipper) was brutalized by our students via dissection. The tone gives reason to suspect that people may have been running about in a confused state of nausea, looking for relief.

LEAD: These aren't the most revolutionary times, and Sonic Youth, who recently released their seventh album, the double disk ''Daydream Nation'' (Enigma/Blast First 7 754003-1; all three formats), are deeply and self-consciously aware of that fact. Like other artists who have come to the realization that modernist ideas of esthetic rebellion are old-fashioned and ineffective, they've developed their own set of postures.
LEAD: If Georgia's head football coach Vince Dooley wants to run for governor, James Blanchard of Michigan is willing to be there to coach him.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John E. Farrand of Watch Hill, R.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Laura G. S. Farrand to Charles Rene Cachera, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jean-Paul Cachera of Paris. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. S. Martin Kirsh of Lyndhurst, Ohio, of the engagement of their daughter, Marla Kirsh, to Dr. Brian David Gale, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael M. Gale of New Rochelle, N.Y. Ms. Kirsh is an associate at the New York office of the law firm of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue.
LEAD: ONLY weeks before time is scheduled to run out on Afghanistan's present agony, the first act of its next drama has not yet been written.

LEAD: AN 11 year-old's membership on the 78th precinct's bantam basketball team in Brooklyn was challenged in early November by an opposing team. The opposing team's coach did not want the 11-year-old in the game because she is a girl.

Imri Roth left his homeland in the 1880's and headed straight for Chicago. The Second City, Richard Roth explained, was preparing for a World's Fair. Only in 1897 did Imri - by then Emery - arrive in New York to establish, in 1902, Emery Roth &

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: Kirk Gibson. He inspired a wounded team to win the World Series over the heavily favored Oakland Athletics. JOSH HOWLEY Short Hills, N.J.

LEAD: Three people were arrested Friday evening at a Suffolk County hospital when a group of Jehovah's Witnesses sought to prevent a critically ill member of their group from receiving a blood transfusion, the police said.

LEAD: A year ago the Dynamic Dozen watched their salaries soar toward the stratosphere on 24-carat dollar signs. They were young players eligible for salary arbitration for the first time, and the results of their foray were dramatic. Their collective incomes nearly tripled, climbing from $3,586,000 to $9,544,000.

LEAD: Prime Ministers Rajiv Gandhi of India and Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan today ended three days of talks that South Asian leaders hope will mark the start of a new relationship between the two nations.
LEAD: By the time the Cincinnati Bengals' offense sputtered today, it had already scored 21 points. The defense made sure that was enough.
LEAD: TIME off for a Happy New Year. A Bit of Everything
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: BUILT for the venerable carriage manufacturer as it was entering the automobile business in New York in 1902, the Studebaker Building recently lost its elaborate cornice and with it, almost certainly, any possible landmark protection against demolition.

LEAD: Steffi Graf. Being in shape, staying healthy, playing at the top of your game, keeping mentally tough from the Australian Open in January to the French Open at the end of May is a season in most sports. But Graf still had Wimbledon, the United States Open and the Seoul Olympics to go. Graf's Grand Slam and Olympic gold medal is the best performance of 1988.

LEAD: EGYPT, in the course of its nearly six thousand years of civilization, has seen cultures come and go: between the earliest Pharaohs and President Mubarak, that ancient land has supported many rulers and quite a number of religions. For the lover of the ancient world, the Nile valley is full of treasures; for those whose favorite period is that of the Roman emperors, there are the admirable Faiyum portraits; some of the best Muslim art and architecture anywhere is to be found in Cairo; but, squeezed in between are the

LEAD: Joseph K. Miller, a lawyer and accountant active in Jewish concerns, died in the crash of Pan American World Airways Flight 103 Dec. 20 in Lockerbie, Scotland. He was 56 years old and lived in Woodmere, L.I.

LEAD: In the theater, as in life, people have been discovering that the fast track can be a treadmill. They are forced to confront what could be called the Yuppie Trauma: early success leading to young-life crisis. If you rise to the top of a profession before you are 30 - as stockbroker, movie producer, publisher, theater director - burnout may result when you are 30 something.
LEAD: FOR most homeowners, household maintenance and improvement are perpetual activities, as there always seems to be something that needs doing.

LEAD: WEARY of supporting Col. Mengistu Haile Meriam and his endless civil war, the Soviet Union is quietly encouraging Ethiopia to re-establish relations with its old ally, the United States. For a Government that prides itself on Marxist-Leninist purity, the rapprochement is bound to be difficult. So far, Ethiopia's gestures toward reconciliation have often come wrapped in socialist rhetoric, apparently intended to show that there is really no deviation from the revolutionary ideals that toppled Emperor Haile

LEAD: Q. The threads on the outside filler pipe for my oil tank are worn out, so when the cover is put on it does not form a watertight seal. When it rains, water seeps in, causing the oil burner to fail. The oil company wants to put in a new pipe, but this is expensive. Is there a less expensive way to fix this?

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Michael J. Gross of Armonk, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Stefanie Faye Gross to Stephen E. Shanck, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Shanck of Boca Raton, Fla. An April wedding is planned.
LEAD: For years, it was mostly a matter of amiability, portability and motivation. But these days, the job of the ''traveling salesman'' is undergoing some subtle but important changes.

LEAD: When 1988 began, a wandering journalist looked forward to new postmarks from South Korea in September while bracing himself not to daydream through the first two-thirds of the year. Fat chance. The usual suspects kept making news no matter what geographic or anticipatory state one was in.

LEAD: CONVENTIONAL wisdom and precedent suggest that American policy toward the Middle East should be in a state of suspended animation during a transition from one President to another. Instead, the last seven weeks have seen a startling amount of activity, illustrating the continuity between the Administrations of President Reagan and George

LEAD: ARCHITECTURE students on Long Island have completed dismantling and storing a three-story, five-room aluminum house. The house is being kept at the New York Institute of Technology in Central Islip until it can be reconstructed on the school's campus next spring.

LEAD: Historical objects sparingly placed in cool, modern settings - that is the dominant direction for 1989. Off-whites and muted shades are de rigueur. So are antique fabrics, or new ones made to look old. This season's lighting fixtures and surface materials range from somber, industrial-sleek to those as colorful as confetti.

LEAD: Here are seven achievements of the United Nations in 1988: Afghanistan. After seven years of peace talks led by a United Nations mediator, the Soviet Union agreed on April 15 to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan by Feb. 15. But the Soviet Union and the United States have continued arming their allies in the civil war, and no political solution is in sight.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: If the independent commission on military bases has its way, the closing of bases it has just recommended will be only the beginning of a long process to close or consolidate many more bases.

LEAD: A decade ago, Jan. 7, 1979, a group of moderate rebels in the Khmer Rouge, led by Heng Samrin and supported by Vietnamese troops, seized power in Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, from the extreme left Khmer Rouge led by Pol Pot and Khieu Samphan.
LEAD: Pervis Ellison scored 20 points to pace a balanced attack today as Louisville used its superior depth to beat Kentucky, 97-75.

LEAD: FAMILY: Family and Borghesia. Two Novellas. By Natalia Ginzburg. Translated by Beryl Stockman. (Seaver Books/Holt, $15.95.) At the conclusion of ''Family,'' a character on his deathbed reviews his life and can recall nothing but a kind of exalted trivia, a ''whole pile of random detailed impressions, that were hazy, but light as a feather.

LEAD: Shame on Leah D. Frank's review of ''Barnum'' [ Dec. 11 ] , applying Broadway standards to denigrate it. Considering the limited resources of Theater Three - small theater, local talent - the production was almost seamlessly delightful. My wife and I saw it and enjoyed it immensely. Some of the acting, singing and dancing and stage business was so professional as we've seen anywhere, and carried along the story line, not just ''a loose confederation of scenes.

LEAD: SET well back from the bustling junction of Waterloo Road and Hope Road near the center of Kingston is the grande dame of Jamaican architecture, Devon House. The sprawling mansion, which resembles a classic 19th-century American plantation house, is surrounded by manicured lawns. Gravel paths lead visitors past formal gardens and fountains watched over by smiling cast-iron cherubs.
LEAD: The headline spread across Page 1 of The Charlotte Observer yesterday read: ''Hornets Sellout a Blowout.''
LEAD: Three teen-agers were killed and another youth was critically injured today in a garage explosion at the home of a Brazilian Embassy employee, the police said.

LEAD: Martha B. Weyl of New York, a former librarian and bookbinder, was married yesterday to Edwin W. Kenworthy of Washington, a retired reporter for The New York Times. The ceremony took place at the Fifteenth Street Friends Meeting House in New York. The couple were attended by their children and grandchildren.

LEAD: I watched them cut the umbilical cord when each of my three children was born. But the telephone cord - now that's a different story.

LEAD: The Security Council today failed to agree on guidelines for a peacekeeping force to supervise elections in Namibia. The deadlock was seen as a setback to hopes for a smooth transition to independence in the territory, also known as South-West Africa.

LEAD: All that remains of the old apple orchard on Glenwood Road in Vernon Township stands around the sales office of the Pointe at Old Orchard Farm. Last fall the staff picked a few bushels and set them out for home shoppers to munch as they browsed.

LEAD: Last week's National Basketball Association player of the week and the league's seventh-leading scorer found a nice little break in the schedule. So Clyde Drexler, the Portland Trail Blazer guard, went back to New Orleans, the city where he was born, and on Friday married Gaynell Floyd, an attorney he met on a blind date last winter.
LEAD: The president of the Basketball Hall of Fame Tip-Off Classic says Villanova and Michigan will meet in the official opening game of the 1989 intercollegiate season.

After seven years of peace talks led by a United Nations mediator, the Soviet Union agreed on April 15 to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan by Feb. 15. But the Soviet Union and the United States have continued arming their allies in the civil war, and no political solution is in sight.

LEAD: WHEN Congress holds hearings on leveraged buyouts later this month, the nation's tax laws are going to come under scrutiny to see whether tax incentives are being given to the wrong people. To certain academic economists, the answer is a clear yes.
LEAD: Many startling and dramatic events took place in 1988, but followers of the Super Bowl stock market theory got no surprises. It came through with flying colors for the 22d year in a row.

LEAD: Like Hedrick Smith's knowing book from which it is derived, ''The Power Game'' is a shrewd observer's account of the movings and shakings of Washington's shakers and movers. Tonight's opening hour, on Channel 13 at 9 and Channel 49 at 8, deals with Congress, especially members who came in during the ''power earthquake'' of 1974, as anti-leadership, pro-reform insurgents.

LEAD: The Bund and the Bourse. Tokyo and Madrid. Rome and Oslo. They are nowhere near Wall Street. But they are where Americans should be buying many of their stocks, a growing number of analysts say.

LEAD: Santiago and Gloria Rodriguez have been married for eight years, but neither has ever met the other's parents, his in Mexico, hers in Guatemala. As immigrants living illegally in California, the couple dared not, until now, leave the United States for fear they might not ever be able to slip back across the border.
LEAD: A 23-year-old woman was charged with manslaughter after reportedly discarding her newborn infant with the trash sometime early last week, the Gloucester County Prosecutor said yesterday.

LEAD: In the midst of the worst shortage of consumer goods in recent memory, the Soviet Government announced today that foreigners would soon be prevented from taking such scarce locally produced items as caviar, coffee, television sets, children's clothing, refrigerators or washing machines out of the country.
LEAD: A public-radio ''business magazine'' program begins today on roughly 80 stations nationwide, the most widely distributed entry in a growing field.

LEAD: Thirteen Palestinians accused of leading the uprising in the occupied territories were deported to Lebanon today, and residents of the West Bank and Gaza Strip celebrated the 23d anniversary of the first attack against Israel by Yasir Arafat's Fatah guerrilla group.
LEAD: C. Shelby Coffey 3d became editor of The Los Angeles Times today, succeeding William F. Thomas, who retired after 17 years with the paper.
LEAD: Does advertising increase cigarette smoking? Representative Michael Synar, Democrat of Oklahoma, thinks so, and is pressing for legislation to end tobacco promotion.

LEAD: If the campaign works, Jimmy Johnson's next job might be in politics, working as a spin doctor for one of the candidates in the next Presidential campaign. The University of Miami football coach has apparently planted a seed of doubt about whether the winner of the Fiesta Bowl game on Monday in Tempe, Ariz., between unbeaten Notre Dame and West Virginia, should automatically be voted the No.

LEAD: Delmar Karlen, a professor emeritus of the New York University School of Law and a former director of its Institute of Judicial Administration, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Williamsburg, Va. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: The spirit of negotiation promulgated under Mikhail Gorbachev was everywhere in evidence as the Soviet Union's top hockey team, Central Red Army, spent three days on Long Island last week as part of their seven-game Super Series. Coach Viktor Tikhonov, who arrived irritable and weary after a daylong trip from Quebec that started in a breakfast squabble with the National Hockey League translator, Anna Udovicic, initially waved off reporters with a terse ''nyet.

LEAD: Patent battles now beginning could determine which organizations and even which nations control the rights to new high-temperature superconductors, materials that could revolutionize fields like computers and electricity generation.

LEAD: For Don Maloney, the week began and ended with broadsides, painful bookends to the most emotionally packed seven days of his life. The first changed his career; the second ruined much of the rest of his season. Maloney never saw either coming, and only in the last 24 hours have his vision and throat cleared enough for him to talk coherently about it all.

LEAD: Municipal leaders in San Diego are mobilizing to block what they view as a blow to the city's pride and pocketbook -the $2.5 billion takeover of their largest local corporation, the San Diego Gas and Electric Company.

LEAD: Last week, nearly five months after New York City police officers called to Tompkins Square Park clubbed and kicked scores of bystanders, 400 officers and 40 sergeants who had been there that night stood accused of a new offense: stonewalling investigators from the Civilian Complaint Review Board.

LEAD: No one picked the six correct numbers in Saturday's Lotto drawing, making the first jackpot of 1989 worth $26 million, state Lottery Division officials said today. A division spokesman, George Yamin, said if someone picks the correct six numbers in Wednesday's drawing, the winner - or winners -will receive the fourth-highest Lotto jackpot in state history.
LEAD: The Motor City is trying to mount an auto show that will help it burnish its faded image as the car capital of the world.

LEAD: When Shearson American Express Inc. acquired the Lehman Brothers investment firm four years ago, William C. Morris did not stay with the firm. Instead of working for the newly acquired organization, the investment banker became a private investor.
LEAD: An earthen dike broke early today, forcing the evacuation of an estimated 1,500 people for several hours and closure of a major interstate highway, the authorities said.
LEAD: Finance Minister Shimon Peres unveiled a stringent austerity plan today to rescue Israel's troubled economy.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Leigh Ann Wilcoxson, the daughter of Nancy Stade of Salisbury, Md., was married there yesterday to Harlan Adam Eagle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Eagle of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Cantor Alvin Donald officiated at the Sheraton Salisbury. Mrs. Eagle, a graduate of Salisbury State University, is an exercise specialist at the Dorchester General Hospital in Cambridge, Md.

LEAD: The national trade surplus with the United States in the first 11 months of this year decreased to $7.61 billion, down $890 million from a year ago, the Korea Foreign Trade Association reported Friday. Under American pressure, Korea has eased import curbs and taken other steps in efforts to reduce the trade excess.

LEAD: Jerry Rice had heard the sniping. He had listened to the comparisons of him and Anthony Carter, how he had produced a dazzling 23-touchdown season last year only to be shut out in the playoffs. Carter was the beauty in post-season play, Rice the beast.
LEAD: The Bears received good news today about Mike Tomczak, their starting quarterback. They learned that his shoulder injury was not as bad as expected, and they said he might play next Sunday.

LEAD: EVER since the Buffalo Bills emerged as a Super Bowl contender, pro football people wondered what the weather would be like here on Jan. 1 for a playoff game. Surely zero degrees. Maybe snow. But yesterday turned up sunny and warm. At least sunny and warm for Buffalo at this time of year: 33 degrees at the kickoff with hardly any wind.

LEAD: Overwhelmed by an increase in drug-related arrests, Connecticut prison officials are seeking to ease overcrowding by releasing scores of convicts early.

LEAD: * Vietnam, which is rolling back tight state control to revitalize its economy, said it would put some inefficient state enterprises into private hands next year to increase production and exports. Radio Hanoi said a National Assembly resolution on the economic plan for 1989 envisaged a 10 percent increase in industrial output, a 15 percent rise in the value of exports and a 6 percent rise in gross national product over 1988 levels.

Readers wishing copies of the corrected page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

LEAD: President Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras has apparently removed the last obstacle to a meeting of Central American presidents set for Jan. 15-16 in El Salvador.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: EVERY year at about this time, the people who live and work in the Valley of the Sun heard about these great parties going on from coast to coast.
LEAD: A California appeals court has upheld a jury verdict granting a large minority stake in the Computerland Corporation to a group of investors.
LEAD: The Cincinnati Bengals have already beaten the Buffalo Bills once this season. And the Bengals are 9-0 at home.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''I do not think an eye for an eye or a tooth for a tooth is ever valid. I can understand the anger. We feel the anger very deeply. The most important thing to do is to try to get the cooperation of all nations to track down these people so that they are brought to justice.'' - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, on the crash of Pan Am Flight 103.

LEAD: Once hailed by some as the most inspired politician of his generation and disparaged by others as ''Governor Moonbeam,'' Edmund G. Brown Jr. is attempting a comeback by running for the unlikely post of chairman of the state Democratic Party.

LEAD: A listing in the Company News column in Business Day on Friday about Tiffany & Company misstated when the company most recently sold shares to the public. Tiffany, which was taken private in a leveraged buyout in October 1984, made a public offering of shares in May 1987.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II today called on ''all men of good will'' to help build a world of peace and justice in 1989, and the Pope emphasized the need to defend the rights of members of minority groups.
LEAD: Can it be that the ''good Germans'' are at it again - claiming to know nothing about the participation of some of their countrymen in a power-maniac's plans for his own Final Solution?

LEAD: Wayne Johnson threw three touchdown passes and Rodney Hampton ran for 109 yards and scored three times tonight as Georgia gave Coach Vince Dooley a 34-27 Gator Bowl victory over Michigan State in his final game.

LEAD: Today is the legal holiday for New Year's Day. Below are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only; main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect.
LEAD: THERE is no one way to decoy ducks successfully, but knowledge of a few fundamentals will save you time and put more birds in your freezer.
LEAD: A couple were found dead last night in the master bedroom of their home in this affluent Westchester County village after a relative discovered a break-in at the residence, the police said.

LEAD: Five months after Iran embraced a cease-fire in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, the regime is struggling over how to rebuild its economy and recast its goal of ''war until victory'' to an ideology suited to peace.

LEAD: An interesting way for players of intermediate strength to sharpen their bidding skills is provided by a new monthly venture called ''Mike's Newsletter.'' It is written by Mike Lawrence, a former world champion with the highest credentials. Subscriptions, addressed to him at 131 Alvaredo Road, Berkeley,

LEAD: The author and illustrator Maurice Sendak is to be the opening-night speaker at the Hudson Park branch of the New York Public Library, 66 Leroy Street, on Jan. 12 at 6:30 P.M., when the library begins its fifth series of discussions titled Village Writers Meet Their Neighbors.

LEAD: In France's latest art controversy, a French court has ruled that the city of Strasbourg and its Museum of Decorative Arts defrauded a 73-year-old widow in the purchase of a 17th-century canvas, possibly done by Simon Vouet, the official court painter of Louis XIII.

LEAD: Daniel Curley, a novelist and short story writer, died Friday night of injuries suffered when he was struck by a car while vacationing in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 70 years old and lived in Urbana, Ill.
LEAD: Honoring another victim of the Pan Am crash, the Criminal Division of the Justice Department has decided to dedicate its law library to a colleague who was aboard Flight 103.

LEAD: An Armenian Communist Party newspaper has published what purports to be an anonymous ultimatum to the K.G.B., threatening to use American-made Stinger missiles in a campaign of ''mass terror'' if jailed Armenian nationalist leaders are not set free.

LEAD: Once the football teams from Notre Dame and West Virginia produce a result Monday afternoon, the 18th Fiesta Bowl will either demonstrate that polls and the bowl system can combine to produce a consensus national champion, or create another complex case of lobbying and haggling.

LEAD: The director and lyricist Martin Charnin is to teach a five-session workshop, ''From Page to Stage: Lyric Writing and Directing for the Musical Theater,'' at 7:30 P.M. on consecutive Thursdays, beginning next week, at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue. The fee is $85. Information: 996-1100.
LEAD: With the pressure of year-end exams, the Baruch College Coffee Klatchers did not have much time to think about giving, said Carol Robbins, director of Evening and Graduate Services.

LEAD: As the incoming Bush administration prepares to take its promised new look at Latin America's foreign debt crisis, the one well-tried method of reducing the region's payments - through conversion of debt into equity - is coming under fire in several countries.
LEAD: Hundreds of Tibetan students demonstrated in Lhasa, demanding that the Chinese authorities respect their culture and stop carrying weapons, Western witnesses said today.

LEAD: Vince Newsome of the Los Angeles Rams was Ed Block's kind of guy. Newsome has never whined or complained in the past two seasons, which were full of stress and strife for him. Now he is in a position to win the Ed Block Courage Award.

LEAD: Clement A. Smith, professor emeritus of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School and a past president of the American Pediatric Society, died Saturday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 87 years old. Dr. Smith conducted studies on the prevention of deaths of babies. He was a recipient of the Howland Award, the highest honor of the pediatric society, and a chair in pediatrics at the medical school was named for him.
LEAD: Bo Schembechler has mellowed so much that he is no longer impatient with silly questions. He even finds amusing ways to answer them.
LEAD: A 13-ship aircraft carrier battle group that left Norfolk, Va., on Friday for the Mediterranean was sent on a ''routine deployment,'' a Navy spokesman said today.

LEAD: Marilyn Horne was the hostess for Carnegie Hall's concert party this New Year's Eve, and singing was the main course served - the only course, in fact, aside from the fluent and elegant accompanying of Martin Katz. Neil Rosenshein, Barbara Daniels, Hakan Hagegard and Barbara Bonney - all fresh from the Metropolitan Opera's ''Fledermaus'' the night before - were joined by Samuel Ramey and Miss

LEAD: The New York Philharmonic closed its books on 1988 with a festive Pension Fund Benefit concert on New Year's Eve at Avery Fisher Hall. For the occasion, the orchestra was considerably enlarged and played under a canopy of colorful streamers, interlaced with microphone cables. The latter were used both for the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' broadcast, which piped the proceedings into living rooms across the country, and by CBS Records, which recorded the concert.

LEAD: Birthdays do not dictate the politics of American citizens. Nevertheless, when Congress and the President-elect Bush get around to attacking the Federal budget deficit, it's a safe bet they will be intimidated by all the usual assumptions about the elderly vote.

LEAD: It has been 20 years since the Kansas City Royals began their baseball academy to discover and develop prospective players. The academy passed out of existence long ago, but its purpose has not left the mind of its original director, Syd Thrift.

LEAD: Nicholas Calas, an art critic and poet who directed attention in his writings to young artists and new art movements, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

LEAD: Lynn Sara Glickman, a certified nurse-midwife at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York, and Eli Max Moore, an assistant district attorney in the Bronx, were married last evening at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue. Rabbi Irwin Feldman, an uncle of the bridegroom, and Rabbi Ephraim Buchwald performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Avnet Inc., the nation's largest semiconductor distributor, has elected Leon Machiz chairman and chief executive officer. He succeeds Anthony R. Hamilton, who died of cancer on Dec. 22.

LEAD: As the narrator says in tonight's two-hour documentary beginning at 8 o'clock on cable's Turner Network Television - TNT, of course - the movie ''Gone With the Wind'' was ''a huge thing, crammed with excesses'' and its realization required ''blind faith and great good luck.'' LEAD: Thirty years ago on New Year's Day, Cubans acclaimed Fidel Castro as the youthful liberator who felled the corrupt tyranny of Fulgencio Batista. Today the 62-year-old Mr. Castro himself resembles one of those crabbed caudillos in the novels of his Colombian friend, Gabriel Garcia Marquez.

LEAD: The ambulance was speeding toward St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan, carrying a 21-year-old college student who had been hit on the head as he stood in Times Square, the waning minutes of 1988 ticking away.
LEAD: Uranium emissions in 1961 at a federally owned processing plant were much greater than the Government has acknowldeged, a recently discovered memorandum shows.
LEAD: Harold W. Zancanata, a scientist who developed some of the first rockets for testing the atmosphere, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Florida Medical Center. He was 70 years old.
LEAD: The longest-lasting bank takeover finally came to an end Friday when the Irving Bank Corporation was legally merged into the Bank of New York Company.

LEAD: President Kim Il Sung of North Korea invited his South Korean counterpart, Roh Tae Woo, and six other political and religious leaders to a political conference, the official North Korean press agency reported today.

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that no revenge should be taken for the bombing that destroyed a Pan Am jumbo jet over Scotland with 259 people aboard.

LEAD: Gunshots fired on New Year's Eve struck police cars, knocked out electricity and left one man dead, and another man was killed by officers who said he had fired at an unmarked patrol car, the police said today.

LEAD: Closing 1988 on a hopeful note, L. William Seidman announced Friday: ''The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is pleased to announce that no F.D.I.C.-insured banks failed this holiday week anywhere in the United States.''

LEAD: Representative Robert H. Michel, the House Republican leader, said today that a tax increase would probably be part of a bipartisan budget compromise in 1989 despite President-elect George Bush's pledge to oppose higher taxes.

LEAD: Like resolutions, New Year's predictions tend to haunt those who make them. But some milestones can already be discerned in 1989 because of laws, rules or other government actions that will change the physical and social landscape in and around New York City.

LEAD: New York City's school decentralization law was born in the educational, political and racial crisis of 1968 that nearly tore the city apart. Issues of teacher accountability, union power and community control were dramatically contested in the streets. The resulting legislation was a rough political compromise, not a coherent educational vision.

LEAD: At least 51 people drowned and another 30 to 40 were believed to be missing when a boat carrying party-goers to watch a New Year's fireworks display along Copacabana Beach sank at the entrance to the bay of Rio de Janeiro a few minutes before midnight Saturday.

LEAD: Are all the latest costly savings and loan bailouts more costly to taxpayers and depositors than necessary? Federal regulators now face heavy criticism for a spate of year-end multibillion-dollar deals, in which private investors have agreed to take over bankrupt savings institutions.

LEAD: G. Keith Alexander first met his wife, Sharrell, at a crowded midtown Manhattan restaurant. He was making a telephone call; she was sitting at the bar. Their eyes met. They married nine weeks later.

LEAD: Rival Shiite Muslim militiamen today fought running street gun battles in southern Beirut for the second straight day, defying appeals from Shiite leaders to end months of violent confrontation.

LEAD: International 2-8 An Israeli austerity plan to rescue the troubled economy was unveiled by Finance Minister Shimon Peres. It includes major budget reductions and would call for the layoff of thousands of Government employees. Page 1

LEAD: The death of Steven Butler aboard Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland on Dec. 21 brought to six the number of Peace Corps volunteers who died in 1988. ''It has not been a good year,'' said a spokesman for the corps.

Canadians may find bargains in skis, furniture, computers and telephone handsets under the tariff cuts that took effect at midnight on Dec.

LEAD: The recent definitions of Palestinian attitudes will not ''solve'' the Middle Eastern crisis or bring a negotiation with Israel into early view. But all attempts in Israel and the United States to portray them as worthless or fraudulent have incurred total failure. Moreover, it is absurd to suggest, as many of Israel's friends have, that the American decision to talk to the Palestine Liberation Organization theatens Israel's very survival.
LEAD: A fire swept quickly through a house north of here today, killing eight children and the two adults who were baby-sitting for them, the authorities said.
