LEAD: In defiance of a recent trend toward decrepitude, the Islanders have been victorious twice in the space of a week, and Saturday's 6-4 domination of the Washington Capitals suggests that their transformation from chumps to challengers may finally have taken place.

LEAD: Customers who order an out-of-stock title from a bookstore would be well advised to settle down with another book while awaiting delivery -something on the order of ''War and Peace.'' While book publishing has modernized some production methods, the process of getting books from the warehouse remains mired in antiquity.
LEAD: This was how Jim Kelly remembered the way football should be played: you throw.

LEAD: Patrick J. Leahy, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, was reading a preliminary Federal report on the nation's forestry prospects for the next 50 years when he was struck by an ''inexplicable omission.''

LEAD: A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth, who the police later learned was a suspect in a fatal hit-and-run accident in June, was shot early yesterday morning by a police officer during a routine stop for a minor traffic violation, a police spokesman said.

LEAD: Except for a couple blocks of downtown, Camden looks like a war zone, with block after block of burned buildings, collapsing buildings, half-gutted buildings, boarded-up buildings and a staggering succession of lots covered with rubble.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Two hundred thirty housing units in 12 Connecticut communities used by off-base military personnel could be converted to homeless shelters under a 1987 Federal law.

LEAD: Horse Racing Cagey Exuberance Wins Handicap: Cagey Exuberance, the favorite in the field of eight and carrying high weight of 121 pounds, rallied through the stretch yesterday to score a two-length victory in the $87,150 Interborough Handicap at Aqueduct. The triumph in the race for fillies and mares 3 years old and up was the third of the day for Richard Migliore, Cagey's Exuberance's jockey.

LEAD: Publishers have already spent more than a million dollars on advances to authors writing about Manhattan's two most talked-about current courtroom dramas: the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg and the corruption trial that ended in the acquittal of Bess Myerson, a former Miss America and New York cultural commissioner.

LEAD: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, warning that current salaries for Federal judges threaten the quality of the judiciary, today urged President Reagan and Congress to accept the substantial pay increases proposed last month by a special commission.
LEAD: Five African students were tortured by the police in the eastern city of Nanjing, after a week of racial unrest in that city, an African diplomat today quoted the students as saying.
LEAD: After eight years as the epicenter of the AIDS epidemic, New York City still has no nursing homes for AIDS patients and only one modest residential center for them.

LEAD: As they peered into the new year from the relative safety of the one just past, credit market analysts seemed to have a remarkably clear view of what is likely to unfold over the next six months. What happens afterward is in considerable dispute.

LEAD: Hours after the High School for the Humanities has adjourned its regular daily sessions in Manhattan, a band of young Port Authority employees squeezes their young adult frames into the small desk chairs. Clad still in their dusty boots and green work uniforms, they join a larger contingent of union-sponsored apprentices for two hours of lectures, quizzes and the occasional catnap.
LEAD: IN a major advance in the study of obesity, researchers have discovered that abnormally low levels of a protein produced by fat cells may be linked to the propensity to gain weight.

LEAD: The recent tragic accounts of abused children have caused an outpouring of sympathy and contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Many donors have sent gifts in memory of Lisa Steinberg, the 6-year-old who was fatally beaten in Manhattan in 1987, and Jessica Cortez, 5, found dead with a broken neck in her apartment in the Bushwick section of

LEAD: A few shifts in the way you put yourself together - hair, makeup and jewelry - can make a significant change in your appearance. Herewith, some suggestions for achieving a 1989 look, at least from the neck up.
LEAD: Texaco Inc. and Saudi Arabia said they had closed their deal for a joint venture to refine and market petroleum in the United States.

LEAD: John O. Marsh Jr. is the longest-serving Secretary of the Army in modern times and one of the few senior officials in the Defense Department to have served through the entire Reagan Administration. He may also be the least known.
LEAD: * The American Advertising Federation has issued a call for nominations for its third annual Distinguished Advertising Educator Award. For information and nomination forms, call (202) 898-0089.
LEAD: AFTER a decade in the doldrums, grounded by budget cuts and the space shuttle accident, planetary exploration by the United States is primed for a big leap forward this year.

LEAD: BULGARIA last week stopped jamming radio programs broadcast from the West, a demonstration of openness. Hungary also moved in that direction with the announcement in November that an International Management Center had been opened in Budapest.

LEAD: William Haber, an economist who helped Jewish refugees after World War II as an adviser to the United States armed forces and for 25 years after that as president of the American Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training Federation, died Friday in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 89 years old. Dr. Haber, who was a professor emeritus of economics and former dean at the University of Michigan, died of pneumonia at his home, said Avi Feinglass, a spokesman for the federation.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''We are in danger of chemical weapons becoming just another weapon of choice. We seek to raise the political costs of their use, and we hope that even countries accused of using chemical weapons will join in affirming support for the 1925 Protocol.'' - Roger G. Harrison, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State.
LEAD: A jailhouse informer's recent disclosure that a prisoner can easily frame someone with bogus testimony has exploded into scandal for the nation's largest District Attorney's office.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The economy grew in December at the highest rate in five months, partly because of a surge in export orders, according to the monthly report of purchasing managers. Production, new orders and export orders all surged. [ Page D1. ] The Federal Home Loan Bank Board put on a stunning display of its ability and willingness to strike deals last week.
LEAD: WAS 1988 a good year for you?
LEAD: After less than a week's hiatus, lawmakers return to Albany today to start a legislative session that is expected to be dominated by the state's worsening financial plight.
LEAD: The Soviet Ambassador to the United States, Yuri V. Dubinin, has joined the saga of Vyacheslav Fetisov and his effort to play for the New Jersey Devils.
LEAD: The Agriculture Department has offered to reduce import restrictions on shipments of British swine, pork and pork products to the United States.
LEAD: Georgia has named Ray Goff, an assistant coach and former quarterback for the Bulldogs, to replace Vince Dooley as the football coach.
LEAD: Fighting between rival Shiite Muslim gunmen intensified today and spread from Beirut to southern Lebanon.

LEAD: LAST year's killing drought in the United States was caused by massive, naturally occurring climatic forces in the tropical Pacific Ocean and had little to do with global warming caused by the greenhouse effect, according to new evidence.

LEAD: A 24-hour strike by mechanics of Iberia Air Lines forced the cancellation of 55 flights today, an Iberia spokesman said. The cancellations mostly affected flights to and from Madrid and Barcelona on the domestic carrier Aviaco, the spokesman said.
LEAD: International A2-11

LEAD: Jim Bakker, the defrocked minister, and his wife, Tammy, were back on the air today with a new version of their religious talk show, two years to the day after a sex and money scandal forced him to shut down their popular PTL television program.
LEAD: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, emerged in 1988 as the interim captain of the American economy.
LEAD: Although the economy and the performance of the stock market rebounded nicely from the October 1987 crash, corporations found investors unwilling to buy many new stock issues last year.

LEAD: The Soviet Union once again demonstrated its superiority in team competition by winning the 28th Olympiad in Thessaloniki, Greece, on Nov. 27 with a 40 1/2-15 1/2 score in the 14-round Swiss-system event. This was the 16th time out of its 17 appearances that the Soviet Union has won the gold medal.

LEAD: An 88-year-old man who had been feuding with the other residents at a cramped retirement home was accused today of killing two of them and injuring four others while they slept, the authorities said.

LEAD: Yuli M. Daniel was buried and eulogized today in Moscow on a searing cold day, a day as cold as a prison camp. It was the sort of day, a man at the graveside observed, that Russia seems to reserve for the funerals of its bravest inmates.
LEAD: A sniper fired at a Southampton Town police officer who was responding to what turned out to be a bogus report of a traffic accident here early Sunday morning, the police said today.

LEAD: Troy Aikman converted 12 of 20 third-down situations as the U.C.L.A. Bruins set a National Collegiate Athletic Association record with its seventh consecutive bowl triumph, a 17-3 victory over the Arkansas Razorbacks in the Cotton Bowl.

LEAD: Michigan, home of the Big Three carmakers, will no longer invest state pension funds in two of the automobile companies because they have business ties to South Africa, state Treasurer Robert Bowman announced on Friday.

LEAD: Explaining Last Summer's Drought The 1988 drought was caused by cyclical changes in the tropical Pacific and had little to do with the greenhouse effect, new evidence indicates. With an improving understanding of the global climate system, scientists have linked cold waters off South America to storms and atmospheric disturbances that drove the jet stream northward, causing drought in North America.
LEAD: Cable television systems are offering more channels to more viewers, but the price for watching is also going up.
LEAD: Reiko Sekiguchi is the name she was given at birth, and that is how she is addressed at social gatherings and scholarly conferences, on research papers, even on letters from her husband.

LEAD: Q. Why do the altitudes of timberlines vary from one mountain range to another? A. The treeline or timberline, the line on mountains and in polar regions beyond which trees will not grow, is mostly determined by temperature, according to researchers at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.
LEAD: The French Government has decided to proceed with a $2 billion capital injection for Renault S.A., the state-owned auto maker.

LEAD: When Bruce Wasserstein and Joseph Perella bolted from First Boston early in 1988 to begin their own firm, Wall Street drubbed the investment house's stock. By the market's account the two merger and acquisition specialists were worth at least $127.5 million, the value lost that day in the stock.

LEAD: Twenty-seven people were arrested on trespassing charges Saturday at a brief demonstration to protest the restarting of the Pilgrim nuclear plant nearly three years after it was closed for management and maintenance problems.Those arrested were among more than 125 demonstrators, the authorities said.On Friday, the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission cleared the way for low-power testing of the 670-megawatt reactor.

LEAD: PREPARING for its third major marketing realignment since emerging from bankruptcy five years ago, Braniff Inc. has named McKinney & Silver, a veteran of airline advertising, as its agency of record.

LEAD: Nicholas F. Brady has a machine to read quotes from the markets, and he uses it. He has a facsimile machine hooked up in his Washington apartment. He calls in assistants and deputy assistants to explain Treasury business, and they say he is a rigorous interrogator. ''He scrutinizes you,'' one said.
LEAD: An Italian researcher will spend five months - the time required to fly to Mars - in a cave here this year.
LEAD: In a pioneering program that is being closely watched in Congress, the state of Washington this week began providing medical insurance to working people who cannot afford it.
LEAD: A listing in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Friday about the Consolidated Natural Gas Company misidentified a new board member. He is Steven A. Minter.

LEAD: Kim Thornton is the youngest of seven children. The others looked out for her. They had to; their parents were alcoholics. When Kim was 8, her mother and father got bad. Her father sold the house for cash and announced he was driving them to Arizona.

LEAD: Fueled by an increase in exports, the nation's economy grew in December at its highest rate in five months, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, which is scheduled to be released today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Fear hung over the stock market early last year as investors worried that the October 1987 crash would be followed by a 1930's-like depression and market decline. But the market turned in a remarkably strong performance, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 11.8 percent, ending the year at 2,168.57.
LEAD: Iraq has cut its oil exports by 90,000 barrels a day in accordance with its new OPEC production quota of 2.64 million barrels a day, the official Iraqi news agency said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Maybe, just maybe, the big pendulum of football fortunes is finally swinging toward the Big Ten in its long, frustrating Rose Bowl wars with the Pacific-10 Conference.

LEAD: Less than a month before the Reagan Administration folds its tent, the personnel staff is still recruiting. One newcomer of note is John F. Cogan, who joined the Office of Management and Budget in October as a consultant and then became an unofficial special assistant to the director, Joseph R. Wright Jr.

LEAD: With the fire gone out of ready-to-wear clothes and consumers staying close to home, hearth and VCR, designers are making lingerie to suit the elegant Park Avenue hostess or the working woman trying to unwind.

LEAD: Many stockbrokers will remember 1988 as a year they would like to forget. After the crash of October 1987, a steady stream of money from individual investors became only a trickle. Nearly every brokerage firm reported sharply lower profits, and many cut their staffs in an effort to compete in a tough new environment.

LEAD: Judy Kuhn, David Carroll, Philip Casnoff and other members of the original cast of ''Chess'' are to perform a concert version of the Broadway musical at Carnegie Hall on Monday at 7:30 P.M. The performance is a benefit for the Emergency Shelter Inc., which provides beds, job training and counseling for homeless teen-agers.
LEAD: The Utah Jazz guard Bobby Hansen will be placed on the injured-reserve list again after fracturing bones in his cheek at a New Year's Eve party.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In its first major overhaul since it was created in 1959, a standardized college admission test taken by about one million high school juniors and seniors annually will be redesigned to emphasize a wider range of mathematical knowledge and more abstract reading skills.
LEAD: Edward I. Koch, the Mayor of New York City, is not at all happy about the speech of the city's schoolchildren. Too often, he says, it is incorrect.
LEAD: The Larchmont police said yesterday that they still had no suspects and no motive in the fatal stabbing of a couple whose bodies were found in their home on Sunday evening.

LEAD: Heavy new security measures at European airports last week produced no major passenger snarls at check-in counters or delays in flights to the United States over a long New Year's weekend of light but growing trans-Atlantic air traffic.

LEAD: The proclamation came shortly after the Orange Bowl game ended tonight and, like much of what Jimmy Johnson says, it was not intended to win friends or soothe anyone's feelings. The Miami coach felt his team had a point to prove against Nebraska and did so emphatically. Now, he was ready to boast.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: TENNIS Chesnokov Upset by Volkov: Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union upset Andrei Chesnokov, the top-seeded player, 6-3, 6-1, in the first round of the $123,400 South Australian Open in Adelaide yesterday. Mark Kratzmann of Australia upset second-seeded Darren Cahill of Australia, 7-6, 6-4.(AP)

LEAD: As West European leaders skeptically weighed the Reagan Administration's accusation that Libya has a chemical weapons plant, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government said today that preliminary investigations had uncovered no proof that a West German company had helped build it.
LEAD: Sammie Smith rushed for 115 yards to lead an error-prone Florida State offense tonight as the Seminoles turned an early 13-0 lead into a 13-7 victory over Auburn in the Sugar Bowl.
LEAD: A 22-year-old Staten Island woman under treatment for depression jumped from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge early yesterday and survived a 230-foot plunge to the icy waters below.

LEAD: Three more Reagan Administration officials expect to receive subpoenas to appear as defense witnesses on behalf of Oliver L. North at his trial on conspiracy charges arising from the Iran-contra affair, an Administration spokesman said here today.
LEAD: American meat-exporting companies say that they have already found alternative markets for many products they normally sell to Europe but that the industry will not escape some harm.

LEAD: After years of inaction, Texas is trying to put together programs to address one of the nation's most wrenching public health problems: the tens of thousands of people living without running water or adequate sewage treatment along the border with Mexico.

LEAD: The Knicks' starting lineup will remain unchanged tonight when they play the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden. The ''subtle'' changes that Coach Rick Pitino promised after Friday night's embarrassing loss to the Charlotte Hornets, an expansion team, will involve execution on offense and defense and perhaps the substitution pattern.

LEAD: The six-story apartment building at 241 West 113th Street, just west of Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard in Harlem, is the kind of abandoned ruin that marks all of New York City's poor neighborhoods.

LEAD: The United States and Vietnam now share an important goal - preventing Pol Pot and his killer Khmer Rouge forces from regaining power in Cambodia. But common action requires that Hanoi fully honor its promise to withdraw all Vietnamese forces from Cambodia. And as those withdrawals continue, the U.S., Vietnam, the Soviet Union and China all need to work together with the aim of disarming Pol Pot's troops and inserting an international force to save the Cambodian people.
LEAD: In choosing among America's three stock arenas, investors would have fared most successfully last year if they had placed their bets on the American Stock Exchange.
LEAD: William Como, the editor in chief of Dance Magazine, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Gary Heidnik, who was convicted of murdering two of six women he abducted and kept shackled in the basement of his home in Philadelphia, took an overdose of anti-psychotic medicine he stockpiled in prison and was hospitalized in critical condition, his psychiatrist said today.

LEAD: Tonight at 9 on Channel 21 and at 10 on Channel 13, ''The American Experience'' on public television offers a documentary that was produced by Patchy Wheatley for the British Broadcasting Corporation. But ''Eudora Welty: One Writer's Beginnings'' is about a very American writer, a woman who has lived just about all of her nearly 80 years in the state-capital city of Jackson,

LEAD: Workers cleared wreckage Sunday at a harbor where at least 50 yachts were destroyed in an explosion that set off a chain-reaction fire. The explosion Saturday night was aboard a pleasure boat moored at the Watergate Yachting Center.
LEAD: Seventh Avenue Blues
LEAD: Did you remember, at the moment 1988 turned to 1989, to wish happy birthday to every racehorse in the Northern Hemisphere?

LEAD: Post-Christmas shoppers facing a sea of signs in store windows advertising huge discounts off ''our already reduced prices'' might find it hard to believe, but many retailers say discounts since Christmas have been equal to or slightly below those of the corresponding period last year.

LEAD: The parasite chiefly responsible for malaria has become increasingly resistant to chloroquine, a drug once regarded as a wonder cure for the disease. But a team of American scientists has discovered that chloroquine remains effective against the parasites if the drug is administered along with an antidepressant.

LEAD: Talk is cheap? It would be difficult to convince the San Francisco 49ers of that, a polished team now one victory short of Super Bowl XXIII after a punishing 34-9 playoff victory over the Minnesota Vikings in Candlestick Park on Sunday.

LEAD: Look out MTV, Dollar Dry Dock Bank has come out with its own in-house videos. LEAD: As the young Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan met for the first time Thursday, raising hopes for less bitter dealings between the two powers of the Indian subcontinent, a small motorcade drove up out of history with a cautionary message: Remember Kashmir.

LEAD: Scientists repeatedly descending to 11,000 feet in the deep-diving submarine Alvin, have discovered a number of communities of six-inch clams and other creatures fed by organic seeps along a 30-mile stretch of the Monterey Canyon, 50 miles off Monterey Bay, Calif.

LEAD: The United States will soon propose giving additional powers to the Secretary General of the United Nations to investigate allegations of the use of chemical weapons anywhere in the world, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: The buyout specialist Henry R. Kravis began last year by donating $10 million to build the Henry R. Kravis wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and followed with $10 million for the Mount Sinai Medical Center.

LEAD: Rebounding from the October 1987 stock market crash, the Dow Jones Industrial average climbed 11.8 percent last year to 2,168.57. Merger activity reached record levels and corporate profits soared. Articles on the outlook for the stock and bond markets, mergers and corporate profits begin on page D1, followed by full-year tables for the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq national market system.

LEAD: A little-noticed paragraph recognizing Chinese sovereignty over Tibet in a statement signed by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi on a recent trip to Beijing has aroused alarm and resentment among Tibetan exiles in India, a spokesman for the Dalai Lama said here today.
LEAD: Although Michael R. Milken will remember 1988 as a year in which he spent more time with his lawyers than he cared to, 1989 could be worse.

LEAD: Paul Brown, the Cincinnati Bengals' founder, general manager and vice president, said yesterday he would ask the league's competition committee, of which he is a member, to look into the question of fake injuries after the season.
LEAD: Although Lane Kirkland flatly denies it, there is growing speculation among labor leaders inside and outside the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s headquarters in Washington that he may soon step down.

LEAD: Business Week magazine has named Ray Hoffman to replace S. G. (Rudy) Ruderman as its lead radio announcer. Mr. Hoffman was Business Week's No. 2 announcer. Mr. Ruderman last year pleaded guilty to trading stocks based on his advance knowledge of Business Week stories.
LEAD: It was hard enough taking on all the Subway Alumni and the Freeway Alumni and the Windy City Alumni and the Sunbelt Alumni.

LEAD: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. has acquired a 14.3 percent stake in Satellite Music Network Inc., the Dallas-based company that pioneered the use of satellites to beam radio programming to AM stations nationwide. Last week, Satellite Music announced that Captial Cities had offered to buy the company for $5.40 a share, or a total purchase price of $48.38 million.
LEAD: RESOLVED: That this year we are finally going to get organized.
LEAD: An exhibition of modern art from the New York and Venice Guggenheim collections drew 121,000 visitors during its display at Prague's National Gallery.
LEAD: A 15-year-old boy who was lost in the Cleveland National Forest survived six days and bitter-cold nights by sleeping in hollow logs and eating snow and spiders, his mother said.
LEAD: AZT, the only drug approved for the treatment of AIDS, can on rare occasions damage the liver, a new report indicates.

LEAD: An American envoy told a Palestinian official in an informal meeting on Saturday that the United States would welcome any information the Palestine Liberation Organization might have about the Pan American bombing over Scotland, a White House spokesman said today.
LEAD: Mayor Thomas G. Dunn was sworn in today for the seventh time. It was also for the last time, he said.
LEAD: The Christian Science Monitor will introduce a revamped daily newspaper today, with fewer pages, color photography and less advertising, after months of internal turmoil over the project.

LEAD: Michael Adams, the Denver Nuggets' No. 2 scorer and most prolific 3-point shooter, was scheduled to undergo a bone scan to determine the nature of a painful injury to his right foot that will keep him out of tonight's game at San Antonio.

LEAD: A Federal licensing panel has approved New Hampshire's evacuation plans for the Seabrook nuclear power plant, dismissing objections that the region could not be cleared fast enough to protect thousands of people in an accident.
LEAD: Rodney Williams, Clemson's quarterback, does not always look pretty, but today in the Citrus Bowl against Oklahoma he showed why his record does.

LEAD: As ''Dump Barry'' signs went up on Capitol Hill, 3,000 of the faithful at a gospel revival in northeast Washington stretched out their hands to Marion S. Barry Jr., the besieged Mayor, in a prayer vigil being played out in the most loyal wards of this stunned and divided city.
LEAD: Before he assumed the chairmanship of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in July 1987, the question asked most frequently of M. Danny Wall was why he wanted the job.

LEAD: It's year-end bonus time on Wall Street, and by all accounts 1988 was a very, very good year to be a mergers and acquisitions specialist at firms like Morgan Stanley, First Boston and Goldman, Sachs.

LEAD: Cadwell Davis Partners handles the advertising for about half a dozen Johnson & Johnson products. J. & J. has long supported the Association of Retarded Citizens, which has 160,000 members and 1,300 chapters. So it was natural for Franchellie (Frankie) Cadwell and Herman A. Davis, the agency's president and chairman, to help the association create its first fully coordinated advertising campaign, including broadcast, outdoor and print ads.

LEAD: The Cleveland Quartet is to play Bartok's String Quartets Nos. 3 and 6 and the composer's ''Contrasts'' on Jan. 19 at 8 P.M. in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The concert is the second in a series of three devoted to Bartok's complete string quartets and other chamber works; the last one is scheduled for March 30.

LEAD: A company offering quick, cheap tests of blood cholesterol levels to shoppers says technology has outpaced state laws governing medical testing, but the state maintains the company's services do not have the proper licenses and has filed suit to enjoin the testing.

LEAD: James Chambers, a teacher and scholar of the French horn who was the principal hornist of the New York Philharmonic for 23 years, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Cranberry, N.J. He was 68 years old.
LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills.

LEAD: NEW research has produced strong evidence that an S-shaped bacterium causes the common stomach disorder gastritis. And scientists say there is increasing though inconclusive evidence that the microbe is linked to many stomach and duodenal ulcers.

LEAD: The Sovereign Military Hospitaller Order of St. John of Jerusalem, of Rhodes and of Malta has decided to mark its 900th anniversary this month by presenting its Grand Cross of Merit Special Class to President Reagan.
LEAD: The term ''computer virus'' spread into use like, well, a virus during 1988, but the outbreak came too late to make the latest editions of Merriam-Webster dictionaries.

LEAD: Gerry DiNardo, the offensive coordinator at the University of Colorado, confirmed yesterday that he had been interviewed for the head coaching job at Columbia. DiNardo, born and raised in New York, played at Notre Dame from 1972 to 1974.

LEAD: More than five years ago, when the World Bank decided to make the state-dominated economy here a model for free-market innovations in Africa, Ghana was in the grip of stagnation. Since then, Ghana has boasted Africa's highest consistent growth rate, an average of 6 percent a year since 1983.

LEAD: Syracuse was almost perfect today. A clever offensive display and a steady defensive effort resulted in an easy victory over Louisiana State, 23-10, in the Hall of Fame Bowl before an announced crowd of 51,112.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's pledge to cut 500,000 Soviet troops and 10,000 tanks could signal the beginning of a new era in East-West relations. If the Soviets are serious about economic reform - and I believe they are -these cuts may be just the first installment in a large-scale reallocation of resources from the military to the civilian sector.

LEAD: After ending 1987 in turbulence, the over-the-counter market bounced back with strong growth in 1988. Some of the largest gains were posted by companies that were sold or put into play as takeover candidates.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: From the day they gathered in South Bend, Ind., to begin their work in the August heat, the football players at the University of Notre Dame listened to the little man remind them of their shortcomings.

LEAD: There were television lights, radio microphones and nonstop requests for interviews. David Shaw stood smiling in the middle of it all last night. For once this season, the public spotlight warmed Shaw more than it burned.

LEAD: * Brian Anderson has been promoted to executive vice president and director of marketing at Marcoa DR Group, a direct-marketing company formed by the merger of BBDO Direct, the DR Group and Marcoa Direct.

LEAD: Despite China's steps in recent months to restore central planning in some areas of its economy, there are growing signs that the country remains committed to developing more of a market economy.
LEAD: With a stunning display of its ability and willingness to strike deals and spend money, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board put on a show last week the like of which is seldom seen in Washington.
LEAD: * Partners & Shevack has created a print campaign for the American Jewish World Service.
LEAD: This racially divided town held its first locally supervised election since the 1930's today, re-electing the Mayor and voting in her all-black council slate.

LEAD: The sounds the ushers hear at Carnegie Hall are not always music to their ears. There are perennial irritants, like the whisperers. And the persistent coughers. And the candy-wrapper soloists. There are the latecomers who demand to be seated in the middle of a symphony movement. And yes, there are even the sports fanatics who wear earphones to performances during the World

LEAD: Michael Deaver leaves the White House and promptly begins to lobby his former colleagues. Scandal jars the Pentagon. Congress fails to limit corrupting honorarium payments. Special-interest money pours into lawmakers' personal and campaign bank accounts. Americans are being insulted by a political culture that places private gain ahead of public trust.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: * Pacific Bell has retained Adland, San Francisco, to create advertising for the Asian-American market.

LEAD: Happy New Year, folks! But don't bother to read George Bush's lips. No matter what he said in the campaign, Federal taxes went up on Jan. 1 for a lot of Americans - most brutally for those who are elderly and reasonably well off financially.

LEAD: Loel Guinness, an heir of the banking branch of the Guinness family who was a Member of Parliament for 14 years and a socialite on two continents, died Saturday of heart disease at Methodist Hospital in Houston. He was 82 years old.
LEAD: RAIN at a monitoring station in central Pennsylvania registered the highest acid content of 131 sites in 46 states, according to a report by the Natural Resources Defense Council.
LEAD: Phoebe Hockstader Stein, an advocate of health-care causes, died of lung cancer Sunday at Montefiore Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: A ferry overloaded with New Year's travelers sank off the Caribbean coast after it ran out of fuel, drowning 67 people, the authorities reported today. Fourteen were missing and 46 people survived.
LEAD: They have made it more difficult to toss even one coin into the Trevi Fountain, let alone the Hollywood allotment of three.

LEAD: A British track official said yesterday that an inquiry into Zola Budd's eligibility for international competition would be reopened if the South African-born runner attempts to return to her adopted country.

LEAD: To Chinese readers, he is virtually a one-man literary movement, more a genre than an author, his 36 novels of chivalry and romance mesmerizing both Chinese peasants and foreign academics alike.

LEAD: WITH a lower dollar prompting stronger exports for many companies and years of restructurings in basic industries helping to cut costs, corporate profits in 1988 rose far more rapidly than expected when the year began.

LEAD: For some time, residents of the Bankhead Courts public housing project here suffered in silence from the brisk, open and frequently violent drug trade in their midst. Then last month an innocent letter carrier found himself in the middle of a drug deal gone bad, and the Postal Service cut off the mail to the 500 apartments.
LEAD: Is the revue dead? Not if Claudio Segovia and Hector Orezzoli, two Argentine producers who have brought new life to the genre, have anything to say about it.

LEAD: A recent report from the American Bar Association contains a noteworthy confession: Criminal justice can't control crime. The A.B.A.'s appeal for more acceptance of that uncomfortable point deserves wide attention.

LEAD: AN experiment in the Netherlands has called into question claims by many practitioners of ''alternative'' medicine that visible changes in the irises of patient's eyes can aid diagnosis of many different diseases.

LEAD: John Emmerling Inc. has added another member of the Time Inc. family to its client stable. Working Woman, a publication of the Working Woman/ McCall's Group (which is partly owned by Time), has retained the agency to create a trade campaign that will debut in mid-January. The magazine, which has a circulation rate base of 950,000, currently has no agency.
LEAD: Hong Kong By Jan Morris Illustrated. 359 pages. Random House. $19.95.
LEAD: The police today blamed overcrowding for the capsizing of a boat packed with revelers planning to watch a New Year's fireworks display off Copacabana Beach. At least 51 people died.

LEAD: It was the year of the big takeover. Even leaving out the still to be concluded RJR Nabisco buyout that saw one bidder raise the ante on another by several billion dollars, there was a record $266 billion in mergers, acquisitions and leveraged buyouts completed in 1988.

LEAD: PUBLISH-IT is a publishing program that, in the I.B.M.-compatible version I tried, seems to have everything anyone could want for producing professional-looking newsletters, brochures, advertisements, anything you would have gone to a printshop for, with a minimum of fuss.

LEAD: One of the world's oldest bridge clubs, the Studenterforeningen Bridge Club in Copenhagen, marked its 60th birthday recently with an international pairs event. The diagramed deal won a Swedish player the prize for best-played hand, and the Swedish expert Sven-Olov Flodqvist suggests it would probably have won a prize for the best-bid hand, too, if such a prize had existed.

LEAD: In an industry sometimes denigrated for its lack of boldness, J. Carter Bacot, chairman of the Bank of New York, stands out in 1988 as the banker who redefined the boundaries of what is acceptable.

LEAD: In studying for his master's degree in history at Harvard, Marv Levy learned George Santayana's dictum: ''Those who do not learn the lessons of history are doomed to the repetition of its mistakes.''
LEAD: A Brooklyn woman indicted in the death of her 5-year-old daughter last month pleaded not guilty at an arraignment yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

LEAD: REMEMBER when an acceptable substitute for a biscuit or cookie cutter was one end of an empty can of frozen orange juice? When the ingredient list made reference to a No. 2 can? When there was one size coffee can and it held a pound of coffee? It also held a loaf of bread, which is why so many recipes years ago called for a coffee can for bread baking.

LEAD: The Connecticut General Assembly will begin its 1989 session today, confronting not the opportunities of recent years but rather the limitations presented by a huge expected gap in the state budget.
LEAD: The Chicago Sun-Times said today that it had agreed to buy Pioneer Press Inc., a suburban newspaper chain, from the Field Corporation for an undisclosed amount.

LEAD: At precisely 1 P.M. on Wednesday, Vice President George Bush plans to enter the House of Representatives and, within 30 minutes, make a not very surprising announcement before a joint session of Congress.

LEAD: The off-season trade for Charles Oakley never paid better dividends for the Knicks than last night. The power forward, acquired from the Chicago Bulls for Bill Cartwright, did what he does best: rebound.

LEAD: The Holly Farms Corporation, a poultry producer, said today that it would fight a court ruling won by its hostile suitor, Tyson Foods Inc., that blocks its friendly merger with the Conagra Corporaion.

LEAD: A careful editor, amused by the vagaries of the English language, has for years found the word ''misled'' a momentary puzzle because in her head she read ''MY-zuld.'' Then it dawned on her that the word ''read'' itself poses a problem: its tense can be understood only from context. That is, although the spelling of misled might mislead her into a mispronunciation, she is not likely to be misled into the wrong tense.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, several of his aides and senior officials of the Defense Department and the Central Intelligence Agency have been subpoenaed as defense witnesses in the Iran-contra conspiracy trial of Oliver L. North, the agencies said today.

LEAD: ''CHATEAUNEUF DU MAHWAH,'' the label announced. Mahwah? New Jersey? The wine was flavored by ''hunks of choice native white oak from Newark,'' the label explained. Food aficionados were given a hot tip: the wine ''is best enjoyed with tofu and mashed potato sandwiches.''

LEAD: Archie R. Boe, a former president of Sears, Roebuck & Company and the Allstate Insurance Company, died of cancer Monday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 67 years old and lived in Chicago.

LEAD: Dr. Elisabeth Hoffmann Dietz, a retired professor of education at Brooklyn College, died of pnuemonia Monday at Emory University Hospital in Atlanta. She was 80 years old and lived in Sun City, Ariz.

LEAD: New state regulations intended to end overcrowding in emergency rooms in New York probably cannot be complied with, the heads of public and private New York City hospital agencies said yesterday.

LEAD: The British Petroleum Company, the nation's largest concern, today announced plans to sell off its mining operations to the RTZ Corporation and to buy back much of the major stake in the oil company held by the Kuwaiti Government.
LEAD: Serphin Maltese, the newly elected State Senator from Queens, sets a positive example for other New York politicians: he has resigned as chairman of the state's Conservative Party.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Monday about plans to address Israel's economic problems rendered a word incorrectly in a quotation from Finance Minister Shimon Peres. The quotation should have read, ''This is a directed and serious attempt to turn the economy toward growth, export, industry and economic independence''; he did not say ''dependence.

LEAD: Everything in pro football has come so fast and in such a flurry for Jerry Rice that, at first glance, he remains not only the game's consummate wide receiver, but also the happy, carefree youth he recalls being as he grew up in Crawford, Miss.
LEAD: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy was killed last night when he was caught in the middle of a shootout between two police officers and a gunman, the police said.

LEAD: An adoptee searches for her natural mother in Sybille Pearson's ''Phantasie,'' but that search is less for a new parent than it is for clues to the character's buried self. Without knowledge of the circumstances of her birth or of her parentage, the woman (Diane Salinger) has had to fantasize possibilities.

LEAD: Using biotechnology methods, a Maryland company has created an innovative corn plant that grows its own pesticide to combat the destructive corn borer.
LEAD: Francis J. Van Bortel, a former executive vice president of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, the advertising agency, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 67 years old.
LEAD: The cartoon cutouts on the manicured lawn here at first resemble the backdrop of a perverse miniature golf course: a gunslinger putting a bullet betwen Santa Claus's eyes.

LEAD: Toys ''R'' Us Inc., operators of the toy and children's clothing chains, yesterday announced the appointment of two vice chairmen and the retirement of its president, and reported an increase in Christmas season sales that disappointed some analysts.

LEAD: Supreme Court Justices do not usually deign to respond publicly to what people say about them. But a report in Jan. 2 issue of Newsweek that Justice Byron R. White ''has told friends'' that he was thinking of retiring soon was apparently too much for the normally taciturn 71-year-old Justice.
LEAD: A Presidential advisory panel has recommended that the Government organize a more aggressive national program to develop superconducting materials.

LEAD: Construction spending rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, reflecting an increase in work on homes and government projects that more than offset slower building of offices and shopping malls, the Commerce Department reported today.
LEAD: Amnesty International accused the Turkish authorities today of routinely torturing political detainees and said it had received reports of torture almost daily in the last two months.

LEAD: Roast squab with port wine sauce; grilled chicken breast with white bean, fennel and escarole salad; braised salmon on a bed of barley and white rice: hardly Spartan dishes, yet they are part of a program for people who want to eat healthful but elegant food when they dine out.

LEAD: The Stanley Works, the New Britain, Conn., manufacturer of home hardware products, has moved its $10 million to $12 million account from Della Femina, McNamee WCRS to Ammirati & Puris after a review that began in the fall.

LEAD: ''Banking Basics,'' tonight's opening hour of a three-part PBS series, ''Money in America: The Business of Banking,'' begins with an unusual credit. We are informed that the series was financed by the Wells Fargo bank ''in partial settlement of a class action proceeding involving overdrafts and returned checks.

LEAD: After suspending its troop withdrawal from Afghanistan two months ago, the Soviet Union now appears to be taking steps to carry out its original agreement to pull all its forces from the country by Feb. 15, Western diplomats said today. They said a major withdrawal seems to be planned as early as Jan.

LEAD: Seth M. Milliken, a lawyer who spent his career as a pro bono adviser to nonprofit groups, primarily working on housing for the poor, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78 years old. Mr. Milliken was on the board of the New York City Mission Society, where he founded a school tutorial program in East Harlem in 1964.
LEAD: Clues to the savage slaying of a couple here continued to elude detectives today as troubled residents walked by the stone-and-stucco house to see where the murders had occurred.

LEAD: Seeking to counter renewed criticism of her political views, Zola Budd said yesterday she did not support any ''political system that entrenches the superiority of one race over another'' or violates basic human rights. The former world cross-country champion issued one of her most explicit political statements in response to a controversy provoked by interviews she recently granted to British television networks.

LEAD: The leading association of obstetricians and gynecologists today opened a campaign to help women who are victims of physical abuse, a problem that C. Everett Koop, Surgeon General of the United States, said had become an ''overwhelming'' public health burden.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, whose Democratic Presidential campaign ended in defeat in November, announced today that he would not seek re-election as Governor of Massachusetts in 1990.

Before cooking, the fillets were soaked in water to remove the salt and reconstitute the flesh.

LEAD: After a delay of more than a two years, the Securities and Exchange Commission today awarded a $52 million contract to build its electronic data gathering, analysis and retrieval system, known as Edgar.
LEAD: President Reagan will undergo minor surgery Saturday to correct a condition in his left hand that makes it impossible for him to straighten his ring finger, the White House said today.

LEAD: The Koch administration announced yesterday that it would for the first time set aside Federal rent subsidies for homeless families as part of a plan to end the use of welfare hotels in New York City.

LEAD: ''My parents never really spoke about it,'' Janet Greenberg, whose parents are both survivors, said as she walked through Yad Vashem, the Israeli memorial to the six million Jewish civilians who died at the hands of the Nazis in World War II.

LEAD: The Department of Transportation said yesterday that it would comply with a court order awarding the coveted Seattle-to-Tokyo route to Continental Airlines. The department had previously argued that Continental was the least qualified of the three carriers seeking the route.
LEAD: Scientists have begun to combine two or more substances to create devices on computer chips that switch electronic signals hundreds of times faster than existing models.
LEAD: The way has been cleared to allow Soviet Jews formal representation in the World Jewish Congress, the executive director of the group said yesterday.

LEAD: After several weeks filled with hints and rumors of a staff shakeup, the Pittsburgh Steelers yesterday announced that four assistant coaches had been let go, the defensive coordinator had resigned and Coach Chuck Noll would stay with the Steelers until he retires. LEAD: The chances appeared to be growing yesterday that Claudell Washington would not return to the Yankees, which would leave them without a left-handed hitting outfielder.

LEAD: The Czar is baffled by his sister-in-law's taste in men. In an unusually down-to-earth moment from Roberto Pazzi's novel ''Searching for the Emperor,'' Czar Nicholas II wonders how Elizabeth could have chosen such an ''empty-headed and superficial'' lover. Her reason, which elevates imagination over sex appeal or love, points to the heart of the novel: ''Give me only a little of a man, a very little,'' she says.

LEAD: The Islanders stormed the Flyers with 18 shots in the first period tonight and took a 1-0 lead, but they let up after that, and the Flyers, with strong goaltending by Ron Hextall, took control and emerged with a 4-1 victory.

LEAD: The discovery of 900 skeletons at an ancient burial ground has led to a temporary halt in building an $80 million beachfront hotel on Maui island and to calls for changes in state laws that could slow Hawaii's construction frenzy.
LEAD: The judge in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg said yesterday that he would approve a prosecution request to order a psychiatric examination of Mr. Steinberg.

LEAD: Apollo Computer Inc., based in Chelmsford, Mass., said the Digital Equipment Corporation had licensed its network computing system and was evaluating it for use in future products. The system consists of software tools that allow the automatic distribution of parts of a single software application to multiple computers across a network.

LEAD: THERE is a generation of wine drinkers out there convinced that zinfandel is white. It's been good for the wine industry - and certainly for the zinfandel growers - and appears to have made a large number of consumers happy as well.

LEAD: CHANGING a meal's status requires more than a change of name, but not much more. Move, however, from the kitchen to the dining room and from everyday dishes to fine china, then add an appetizer and dessert, and a family meal becomes a festive dinner for guests.

LEAD: A new study challenges an earlier analysis compiled by Georgeson & Company that defended ''poison pills'' on the ground that companies adopting such takeover repellents outperform those that do not.

LEAD: Wells, Rich, Greene has resigned the Cosmopolitan account. The Hearst Magazines publication had put its account, worth less than $1 million annually, into a speculative review that the agency was not interested in participating in.
LEAD: ''We made a commitment to go to the moon. Can't we make a commitment that no person will drop out of school and that all people will be able to read?''

LEAD: In odd-numbered years, North America is entitled to send two teams to the world championships for the Bermuda Bowl. One of these is always from the United States, which has by far the biggest bridge population, and the other is from Canada, Bermuda or Mexico.

LEAD: Mollie Katzen was 10 years old in 1960 when she discovered that spaghetti did not come out of a can. She was well into her teens before she ate fresh broccoli, cauliflower or asparagus. Her first foray into cooking was a mud pie, made with real mud at age 2, and her first professional job, at 16, was flipping hamburgers at a department-store grill.

LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch and four other potential mayoral candidates filed yesterday to participate in the city's new public campaign-financing program. But City Council President Andrew J. Stein said he would not participate, contending the $28 million plan is too costly to taxpayers.
LEAD: MUFFS say as much about the times as they do about the temperature.
LEAD: A Jehovah's Witness who was given a blood transfusion against her will won an appeal today that set aside the court order that allowed the transfusion, her lawyer said.

LEAD: Boyd L. Jefferies, a crucial Government witness in several securities fraud cases, made his courtroom debut yesterday by accusing the GAF Corporation and one of its senior executives of asking him to manipulate the price of Union Carbide stock in the fall of 1986.

LEAD: When the Toyota Motor Corporation decided to call its 1989 luxury-car line Lexus, the Mead Corporaton went to court. The name, Mead said, infringed on Lexis, the registered trademark for computerized information services provided by Mead Data Central Inc.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Jim Shuck was named as Virginia Military Institute's head coach yesterday, saying the job with the Keydets would pose challenges similar to those he faced as Army's offensive coordinator. Shuck, 34, plans to use the wishbone offense, which has worked well for Army, as he takes over the job with a five-year, $52,000-a-year contract.

LEAD: Right-wing Israeli politicians said today that reported death threats by Yasir Arafat against other Palestinians showed that the Palestine Liberation Organization was still a ''terrorist organization.''

LEAD: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin asserted yesterday that the Koch administration had inflated the number of apartments it has renovated for homeless families by counting some renovations more than once.
LEAD: Dr. James Edwin Thompson, an educator and retired surgeon, died of heart failure Tuesday at his home in Siesta Key, Fla. He was 85 years old.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration is spending its final days militantly resisting the spread of chemical warfare. Whether part of a larger strategy or not, the shooting down of two Libyan fighter planes in the Mediterranean yesterday is likely to advance that high purpose.
LEAD: A 2-month-old infant on Staten Island being watched by a baby sitter was killed last night when a fire broke out in the baby's bedroom, the police said.

LEAD: IN the 50's, people bought suites of furniture for the bedroom. In the 60's, the brave slept on water beds, and in the 70's the avant-garde chose platform beds to make a minimal design statement. Today, although four-poster and brass beds are still popular, the beds of choice are reinterpretations of antiques or one-of-a-kind designs.

LEAD: A glittering crowd rolled out a welcome wagon laden with caviar tonight for President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, at a black-tie party that was held to mark the couple's impending return to California and to raise a million dollars for a new center to combat drug abuse.

LEAD: John J. Faal, a professor of economics and a former academic vice president at Suffolk County Community College, died of complications from acute leukemia yesterday at St. John's Hospital in Smithtown, L.I. He was 64 years old and lived in Commack, L.I.
LEAD: The Bush administration, three weeks before it takes office, has sent a signal of irresolution and hypocrisy in dealing with the Soviet Union.
LEAD: THE peripatetic nature of American society has spawned all sorts of strange creations, among them billboards, Winnebagos, Walkman radios and car telephones.
LEAD: Richard Siegel, a retired English teacher, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 70 years old.
LEAD: International A2-15

LEAD: Senate leaders, responding to public criticism of the recommendation to increase Congressional pay by 50 percent, agreed today to schedule a vote within the next month on whether to reject the pay increase.

LEAD: The much-honored ''Portraits'' campaign created by Ogilvy & Mather for the American Express Company is adding another leaf to its laurel wreath: Ms. magazine's first annual ''Making A Difference'' advertising award.

LEAD: The New York bureau chief and a producer for a French television station, working on a report about airport security, were arrested yesterday and charged with trying to check three packages containing fake bombs through Kennedy International Airport, the Port Authority police said.

LEAD: Executives of the Borden Company announced yesterday that they had put into effect a new type of takeover repellent that would result in the resignations of the company's top 25 managers if an acquirer took over the company at a price Borden's directors considered unfair.

LEAD: Nick Virgilio, a poet who specialized in haiku, died Tuesday at George Washington University Medical Center after a heart attack while taping an interview for the CBS television program ''Nightwatch.'' He was 60 years old and lived in Camden, N.J.
LEAD: American warplanes today shot down two Libyan fighters that displayed ''clear hostile intent'' in international waters off the Libyan coast, the Administration said.

LEAD: Frederick A. Klingenstein has resigned as co-chairman of Wertheim Schroder & Company, the Wall Street investment firm, to form his own company specializing in investing for individuals and families with substantial assets - about $10 million or more.

LEAD: Florence Ryder, chairman of the Times Journal Company, which publishes several weekly newspapers serving members of the armed forces worldwide and a number of suburban newspapers in the vicinity of Washington and San Diego, died in her sleep yesterday at her home in Washington. She was 88 years old.
LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed today to strengthen the deposit insurance system by giving it new powers to increase premiums on banks and to rein in high-risk lending.

LEAD: Secretary of Education Lauro F. Cavazos has said that he does not intend to reverse a decision denying money for a education program about the Holocaust, despite pleas from a group of Congressmen.

LEAD: Panama's ousted President, Eric Arturo Delvalle, has written to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega offering to negotiate an end to the nation's political crisis, according to a document obtained today.

LEAD: Investigators believe the cyanide poisoning of a teen-ager who ate tainted yogurt is an isolated incident, but they said yesterday that they were looking into a possibility that it might be linked to an unsolved product-tampering case two years ago.

LEAD: The legend has it that when Robert Fulton was about to launch this invention of his, a boat that would supposedly run on steam, he was told it would never go. When it did, he was told it would never stop. History informs us that it did that, too.
LEAD: Echoing concerns in neighboring states, Gov. Thomas H. Kean today disclosed growing shortfalls in the state's tax revenues and warned that New Jersey's next budget would be ''very tight.''

LEAD: Hoping to bring a European security conference to an end before President Reagan leaves office, the Administration announced today that it would support a meeting on human rights in Moscow in 1991.

LEAD: A memorial service for the pianist Raymond Lewenthal is to be held on Monday at 3 P.M. at Green Auditorium, 40 West 68th Street. Mr. Lewenthal died of a heart attack on Nov. 21 at the age of 62. The service is open to the public.

LEAD: When Effat Abbas Mohammed lost her life savings to Al Rayan, a huge Islamic investment fund, her story told much more than the sad failure of her ambition to make good and righteous money to help in raising four daughters. By now, hundreds of thousands of middle-class Egyptians may also have seen their modest wealth disappear in the hands of funds accused of dubious dealings.
LEAD: Charles M. Shapp, a retired New York City school superintendent, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Marbella, Spain, where he lived. He was 82 years old.
LEAD: T. Herbert Shriver 2d, a retired investment banker, died Wednesday at his home in Towson, Md., after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

LEAD: ''Starlight Express,'' the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical with lyrics by Richard Stilgoe, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Gershwin Theater. Directed by Trevor Nunn, the show will have run for 761 regular performances and 22 previews.

LEAD: Philip D. Tobin, a labor lawyer who was twice elected mayor of the village of Tuckahoe in Westchester County, died of pneumonia Tuesday night at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan after a long battle with cancer. He was 46 years old and lived in Tuckahoe.

LEAD: WHEN he was a graduate student, Clay E. Stobaugh enticed a dozen colleagues to pose for an ''Eligible Bachelors of the Harvard Business School'' calendar, a project that netted him several thousand dollars. As director of co-operative advertising at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles for the last two and a half years, he has routinely lured dozens of companies to join in one ad, a procedure that has gained the agency about $10 million in revenues.

LEAD: Beyond the battle to control the boxing future of Mike Tyson, a struggle that has pitted the heavyweight champion's manager, Bill Cayton, against Tyson and the promoter Don King, a small-scale skirmish is shaping up: one to influence public opinion.
LEAD: Concerned about the possibility of bombings, some travelers have begun to switch from United States airlines to foreign carriers for their flights to Europe.

LEAD: In ''Museum Memorializes Life in Tenements'' (Dec. 15, 1988), James Hirsch reported that the curators of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum had been unable to find anyone who had lived in its building at 97 Orchard Street in Manhattan. The article prompted this letter. To The Home Section:

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation took the wraps off its long-awaited plastic-body mini-van today, but the move was criticized by Chevrolet dealers who were angry at having to share the vehicle with Pontiac and Oldsmobile.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article headed ''Atlanta Journal'' on Tuesday about crime at the Bankhead Courts public housing project misidentified officers who kept watch over an all-night vigil by elected officials, ministers and students. They were police officers, not National Guardsmen.
LEAD: They were just a couple of guys from Texas, sitting around talking.

LEAD: A 34-year-old woman who obtained a protective court order after her former husband was accused of trying to murder her was shot to death on the front steps of her house here Tuesday night, the Suffolk County police said.
LEAD: The brokerage Security Pacific Hoare Govett announced today that it was getting out of the British and international bond markets and laying off 140 people.

LEAD: The Turner Broadcasting System said today that it would transmit the Cable News Network 24 hours a day to Latin America on the Pan American Satellite Corporation's international satellite. The agreement followed tests that began in November, TBS said. Turner's decision to use Pan American Satellite is a victory for the private company, based in Greenwich, Conn., and a defeat for Intelsat, the international consortium that operates most communications satellites.

LEAD: The battle for control of William Collins P.L.C., the Scottish publisher, took a new turn today as a friendly French bidder stepped aside and Collins said it would open talks with Rupert Murdoch's News International P.L.C.

LEAD: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Named Rick Lawes assistant public relations director. ST. LOUIS CARDINALS - Agreed to terms with Danny Cox, pitcher, on a one-year contract. BASKETBALL UTAH (NBA) - Waived Bart Kofoed, guard. COLLEGES CINCINNATI - Named Tim Murphy head football coach.

LEAD: The Chicago Rabbinical Council, a group of Orthodox Jewish leaders, has reluctantly agreed to the construction of a shopping center on a plot of land bordered on three sides by a Jewish cemetery, a member of the council says.

LEAD: ''YOU have traditional homes and Brave New World things, a fondness for Gropius and a Breueresque look,'' said Tom Martinson, referring to the conglomeration of styles in University Grove, a neighborhood of 102 homes built on the northwestern edge of St. Paul by University of Minnesota faculty members and administrators.

LEAD: James A. Baker 3d, the Secretary of State-designate, has offered the job of Deputy Secretary to Lawrence S. Eagleburger, colleagues of both men said today. Mr. Eagleburger is a career diplomat long associated with Henry A. Kissinger.

LEAD: The New York Mercantile Exchange is moving closer to the age of electronic trading, with its governors considering a plan to link their market with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange through a global computer network called Globex.

LEAD: A state judge has ordered the reinstatement of two student journalists at Dartmouth College, saying their suspensions were tainted by bias against the off-campus conservative weekly for which they worked.
LEAD: Aides to Vice President George Bush said today that the President-elect had asked that additional candidates be proposed for the post of Energy Secretary.
LEAD: ALTHOUGH the pure white sheet has been considered the height of fashion by decorators for several years, two lines of designer sheets currently in the works are anything but.
LEAD: * Progress Software Corp., Bedford, Mass., to Giardini/Russell Group, Watertown, Mass., with a $500,000 budget.
LEAD: The Knicks have had other superb comebacks this season, but tonight's bordered on miraculous.

LEAD: The injured Mike Tomczak and the now-healthy Jim McMahon alternated at quarterback today in the Bears' practice for the National Conference championship game Sunday against the San Francisco 49ers in Chicago. Coach Mike Ditka of the Bears said he would not decide until later in the week on which quarterback would start.
LEAD: A chart on Tuesday about key yields for fixed-income securities in 1988 mislabeled several yield curves. This is a corrected version.

March 1984 Braniff resumes service with 30 Boeing 727 jets serving 25 cities.

LEAD: Michael R. Milken, the head of the high-yield bond unit at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., will be removed from the firm and receive virtually none of his pay for last year as part of Drexel's settlement with the Government of charges of securities law violations, people familiar with the agreement said late yesterday.

LEAD: Partway through his State of the State address Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, the Cuomo who can charm with a word and a nod, heard some applause greet his call for expanding social programs despite budget rigors, and digressed from his text. He clapped his hands, grinned and said: ''I'm pleased to hear the applause.

LEAD: The Giants announced yesterday that Len Fontes has resigned as the defensive backfield coach. It was the team's first coaching change since the Giants finished the season with a 10-6 mark and failed to make the playoffs for the second straight season. Neither Bill Parcells, the Giants' head coach, nor Fontes could immediately be reached for comment.
LEAD: Lyman C. Thunfors, a retired business executive, died of cancer Monday at his home in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 85 years old.

LEAD: * Jennifer Clark has been promoted to senior vice president, management supervisor, at Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson.

LEAD: Israeli Debate on Arafat
LEAD: Stocks rallied strongly yesterday in a broad advance that market experts attributed to a stronger dollar and a late wave of program buying.

LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange has recently argued to the Securities and Exchange Commission that a new type of trading instrument proposed by the American Stock Exchange cannot legally be traded.
LEAD: * Ashland Coal Inc., Huntington, W. Va., named Kenneth G. Woodring senior vice president, operations, and Raymond Smallwood president of its Hobet Mining Inc.

LEAD: The World Bank is raising interest rates for relatively prosperous developing countries to 7.65 percent annually, the first such increase since the bank began lending at variable rates in 1982, officials said today.

LEAD: In a study with implications for the work performance of everyone from students and artists to hospital interns and pilots, a British researcher has found that loss of sleep sabotages creative faculties and the ability to deal with unfamiliar situations more rapidly than it impairs other mental abilities.
LEAD: Ruth Moore Garbe, a writer of books about science, died of cancer Monday at her brother's home in San Francisco. She was 80 years old lived in San Francisco.

LEAD: WITH much fanfare, several mail-order nurseries are introducing a new chrysanthemum in their 1989 catalogues, and all signs suggest that it is destined to become one of the most widely planted perennials in the United States in the next few years.

LEAD: The often-staid Connecticut General Assembly began its 1989 session today in tumult, with the bitterly contested ouster of the powerful two-term Speaker overshadowing Gov. William A. O'Neill's warnings of fiscal constraint.

LEAD: In a sweeping new move to tighten security at United States airports, the Government yesterday ordered that computer card systems be installed at the busiest terminals by early 1991 to keep people who might threaten airline safety from reaching restricted areas.

LEAD: Richard A. Gilleland, who has been in the hospital-products industry for 20 years, was named yesterday as chief executive of American Medical International Inc., one of the nation's largest hospital companies.

LEAD: Money was on the minds of the gov-ernors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut yesterday. They warned their constituencies separately of budget constraints necessitated by spending that is outpacing revenues.
LEAD: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday, with an article about the outlook for interest rates, provided incorrect labels for several yield curves. A corrected table appears today on page D15.
LEAD: Philippe Entremont, the French-born conductor and pianist, has announced his resignation as music director of the Denver Symphony, effective at the end of this season.
LEAD: Norman S. Matthews, the former president of Federated Department Stores Inc., has been named vice chairman and a director of the Best Products Company, the catalogue-showroom chain in Richmond.

LEAD: Libya said today that the downing of two Libyan jet fighters by United States Navy planes was a premeditated attack, and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said that his nation would ''meet challenge with challenge.''
LEAD: Ronald S. Lauder, former ambassador to Austria, traveled to Albany yesterday to announce that he was running for mayor of New York City.

LEAD: A prison parolee demanding an airplane to Libya held about 20 people hostage in a restaurant Tuesday, killing one of them. The police fatally shot the suspect but also killed a hostage by accident, the authorities said today.

LEAD: Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., an afiliate of the Swiss pharmaceutical concern F. Hoffmann-La Roche & Company, said it would build a $60 million plant in Freeport, Tex., to produce beta carotene, a nutritional supplement and food-coloring agent found naturally in carrots, broccoli, squash and other vegetables.
LEAD: Lech Walesa, interviewed by the Communist Party weekly Polityka for the first time since 1980, predicted that the authorities will have to reinstate his union one way or another.

LEAD: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week that ended yesterday, with the yield increases in C.D.'s concentrated in the six-month and one-year maturities.

LEAD: The PGA Tour, one of the favorite multimillion-dollar toys of corporate America and corporate Japan, will begin its 42-tournament season Thursday when Curtis Strange, the United States Open champion, and a healthy Greg Norman tee off first in the MONY Tournament of Champions here at the LaCosta Country

LEAD: Since conservative Republicans have long preached the gospel of ''fiscal responsibility,'' one might expect virtually all of them to oppose the hefty pay increase recently proposed for Federal lawmakers, judges and executives. Not so. Every year, their complaint goes, the financial sacrifice of public service grows greater.

A low-keyed, friendly observer of human foibles, Mr. Miller, who is appearing through Jan.
LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today it would launch Discovery on the next space shuttle flight on Feb. 23, five days later than originally scheduled.

LEAD: A motor launch carrying more than 140 people sank in the central Philippines and at least 16 people were killed, the coast guard said today. Twelve people were reported missing. The vessel, the Jem II, sank Tuesday off Romblon Island, about 150 miles southeast of Manila, a coast guard officer said.
LEAD: Fast Play, the Seattle Slew colt who had been considered a leading prospect for the Kentucky Derby May 6, is unlikely to run in any of the Triple Crown races, his trainer said yesterday.

LEAD: Federal prosecutors dropped all charges yesterday in a 1986 indictment charging a London lawyer, a retired Israeli general and nine other men with plotting to sell more than $2 billion in American-made weapons to Iran.

LEAD: In an aggressive step toward modernizing and expanding its fleet, Braniff Inc. said today that it would buy as many as 100 airplanes from Airbus Industrie in a deal valued at roughly $3.5 billion.
LEAD: 'Butterfly' by Prince
LEAD: Brian Lawton scored at 3 minutes 19 seconds of overtime tonight, giving the Hartford Whalers a 5-4 victory over the Buffalo Sabres.

LEAD: Tradition means a great deal on Capitol Hill. So does family. Representative John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, has honored both on the first day of every new Congress since he first came to Washington in 1955.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When River Phoenix learned he had just won the National Board of Review's award as best supporting actor of 1988 for his performance in ''Running on Empty,'' his first response was to ask what the society was.
LEAD: The Phoenix Suns broke a nine-season Boston Garden losing streak tonight with a 106-104 victory over the Celtics.

LEAD: The chief counsel for the committee that disciplines lawyers in Manhattan announced Tuesday that he would resign, amid news reports that he mishandled charges of drug use and other misconduct against Joel B. Steinberg.

LEAD: A week after being dismissed as the defensive coordinator for the Los Angeles Raiders, Charlie Sumner was quoted in yesterday's editions of The Los Angeles Times as saying that Coach Mike Shanahan had made him a ''fall guy.'' Shanahan, whose Raiders turned in a 7-9 record in his first year as head coach, dismissed Sumner and Willie Brown, another assistant, a few days after the Raiders were eliminated from playoff consideration.
LEAD: A daylong fly-fishing workshop sponsored by the Nutmeg, Mianus and Croton Watershed chapters of Trout Unlimited will be held at the Turn of River Middle School in Stamford, Conn., Jan. 14.

LEAD: African students at a Beijing language institute began boycotting classes today to protest what they feel is racism in China, and interracial clashes were reported in another city after two weeks of racial unrest.

LEAD: European nations are undertaking the world's most ambitious high-speed rail project, which will tie Europe closer together by allowing travelers to move across the Continent at speeds up to 186 miles an hour.

LEAD: If you need extra-long twin sheets, dust ruffles for higher than normal beds or linens for irregularly shaped beds, E. Braun is one shop that can make them. This specialty linen house, on New York's Upper East Side, even makes extra-narrow sheets for mattresses like those on boats or railway cars.

LEAD: Moving to counter criticism that the Civilian Complaint Review Board has not done all it could to expose police wrongdoing in Tompkins Square Park last August, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward has authorized the panel's investigators to selectively reinterrogate officers, this time under grants of immunity from departmental charges.

LEAD: Some of the challenges facing Mikhail S. Gorbachev as he pursues glasnost and perestroika in the Soviet Union also confront Mexico's new President, and drawing parallels between the two has become an intellectual parlor game among Mexicans of various ideological persuasions and foreign diplomats here.

LEAD: JUST as Congress and business leaders are growing alarmed over the mounting levels of debt associated with leveraged buyouts, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout specialist, seems to be looking at a Texas bank as a possible acquisition target. Could it be that leveraged buyouts are about to happen in the banking industry, one of the most financially sensitive businesses in the country?

LEAD: There have long been connections between what are generally considered the three leading intellectual games of the Western world: bridge, chess and backgammon. A century and a half ago Deschapelles had a good claim to be considered the world's best at chess and the world's best at whist, bridge's forerunner.
LEAD: The United States Customs Service today reclassified an increasingly popular category of imported utility vehicles and mini-vans, making them subject to a 22.5 percent tariff.

LEAD: As much as $2 million in coins owned by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago is missing from a suburban armored car company and the Federal Bureau of Investigation has entered the case, the authorities said today.

LEAD: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said today that his Government had found no evidence yet to substantiate American assertions that a West German company had helped Libya build a chemical weapons plant, though it took the charges ''very seriously.''

LEAD: Fidel Castro sought tonight to minimize differences between Cuba and the Soviet Union, but reaffirmed his refusal to adopt Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of economic liberalization to remedy his country's critical economic problems.

LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra investigation, Lawrence E. Walsh, held an unusual private meeting today amid indications that Government concerns about national security were posing a threat to Mr. Walsh's prosecution of Oliver L. North.

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher led several hundred mourners today at an emotional memorial service for the 270 people who were killed when Pan Am Flight 103 was blown apart by a bomb two weeks ago over the Scottish countryside.
