Although they were originally commissioned for his private collection, Mr. Munari began exhibiting these pieces in European galleries and museums, then hiring craftsmen in

LEAD: The image of the dinosaur is being refurbished. Long considered just dumb, oversized lizards, the creatures that dominated earth for 140 million years are getting a better press. Revisionist paleontologists now hold that dinosaurs were warmblooded, quite energetic, not necessarily unintelligent and, in at least one species, caring of their young.

LEAD: President-elect George Bush's strategy for dealing with the Federal budget has begun to take shape, and Richard G. Darman, who has been given unchallenged authority to draft Mr. Bush's budget policy, is trying to sell it to Congress.

LEAD: Testimony began today in an attempt by the Government to win more than $600 million in taxes from the estate of Samuel I. Newhouse, who built one of the country's largest newspaper chains before his death in 1979.

LEAD: ''PIPE smokers are funny people,'' said Vince Nastri, president of the Barclay-Rex Pipe Shop, started by his grandfather in 1910, in the Wall Street area. ''They break their pipes, and it's like they've broken their legs. They have to have them fixed right away.''

LEAD: Ken Miller said he did not leave Merrill Lynch almost one year ago to create a one-man boutique. That is why he called his fledgling deal shop the Lodestar Group, to suggest his role as guiding light. ''If you name a firm after yourself, it doesn't help in getting additional personnel,'' Mr. Miller said.

LEAD: President Reagan will deliver a farewell address over television from the Oval Office at 9 P.M. on Jan. 11, the White House said today. The speech will be given nine days before Vice President Bush succeeds Mr. Reagan as President.
LEAD: Paul Hecht's luck as an actor has certainly changed.

LEAD: TENNIS Sukova Advances: Top-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia advanced to the third round of the $150,000 Danone Australian hard-court championship in Brisbane yesterday with a 6-4, 6-2 victory over unseeded Alexia Dechaume of France. Fifth-seeded Hana Mandlikova, a native of Czechoslovakia who is an Australian citizen, continued her recent poor form when she served 18 double faults during her 6-4, 6-4 loss to unseeded Catherine Tanvier of France.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Contributions to the 77th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are running ahead of the last appeal, and donors seem to be particularly alarmed by the desperate plight of the homeless.
LEAD: Following are excerpts from Gov. William A. O'Neill's State of the State address to the Connecticut General Assembly:
LEAD: A new panel of experts hopes to find ways to streamline the bureaucracy of the Food and Drug Administration, its chairman said today.

LEAD: President-elect George Bush is receiving a lot of advice these days, some of it unsolicited. Still, he might welcome the thoughts of Donald T. Regan, President Reagan's ousted chief of staff, in the form of a chapter added to the paperback edition of his 1987 memoir ''For the Record.''

LEAD: ''L'AQUITAINE is a little-known region in the south of France, but it's a name I've always liked,'' Carlos Fernandez Llamas said. So L'Aquitaine was the name Mr. Llamas chose when he opened a furniture gallery and interior design company last month in a converted factory space at 17 Greene Street between Canal and Grand Streets in S
LEAD: Sean Miller had 22 points tonight as Pitt handed Syracuse its first loss of the season, 81-76, in the Big East Conference opener for both schools.

LEAD: The Anheuser-Busch Companies suspended production at its biggest brewery because an oil slick working its way down the Mississippi River has slightly altered the taste of the water used in making beer. Company officials have not detected anything that would indicate a health hazard, Andrew J. Steinhubl, senior vice president of brewing, said.

LEAD: The inspector general of the Department of the Interior said tonight that his auditors had found few records in the Virgin Islands concerning consulting work there by District of Columbia officials, including Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. But the inspector general, James Richards, said in an interview that some of the records that had been uncovered about the 1988 consulting project on personnel and pay matters, including hotel and travel expenses, ''would raise your eyebrows.
LEAD: Art Rush, a talent agent who represented such performers as Vladimir Horowitz, Orson Welles, Roy Rogers and Dale Evans, died of heart failure Sunday. He was 81 years old.
LEAD: Here in the desert of southeastern Washington State, home of the Hanford nuclear reservation, just about every piece of news lately has been bad.
LEAD: Lukas Foss, music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra since 1971, is to retire at the end of the 1989-90 season, orchestra officials announced yesterday.
LEAD: What do Robert R. Kiley and the average welfare mother have in common?

LEAD: Q. I own a two-family house that has baseboard hot-water heating. When the heat comes on the pipes knock, even though I have the system drained often. The banging is worse in the pipes going to the second floor. I was told that I would have to break walls open to correct this problem. Is there a simpler solution?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Brooklyn block where Norris Graham died is a bleak stretch of sidewalk that looks as if it is more for dying than living. Garbage and glass are everywhere, and someone has spray-painted ''Keep Out Killer Dog and Mother'' on a door.
LEAD: Premenstrual syndrome, now widely known, discussed, diagnosed and even used as a legal defense, is still a biomedical mystery whose cause and proper treatment have yet to be established.
LEAD: Scarves were wrapped tightly, flags flapped snappily and cars hacked hoarsely as a wind-whipped front of frigid air bore down on the New York metropolitan region yesterday.

LEAD: A fire in a turbine building at the Oconee Nuclear Station on Tuesday caused operators to shut down one of its three reactors, a utility spokeswoman said today. Workers were starting the plant's Unit 1 reactor, which had shut down automatically Monday, when an electrical breaker apparently caught fire, the station manager, Mike Tuckman, said.

LEAD: Calling drug abuse ''the single most ominous phenomenon of our times,'' Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today outlined a major new effort to combat drugs in New York despite the state's tremendous financial problems.

LEAD: The opening by the Rangers last night prompted a collective review that would have made the critical reception of ''Legs Diamond'' seem quaint, even mildly encouraging. New York, having stumbled ineptly through 20 minutes of hockey, was thunderously booed by the Garden crowd.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci has approved a special commission's recommendation to close dozens of military bases around the country, setting the stage for a final debate on Capitol Hill, Pentagon officials said today.

LEAD: Hunterdon Central Regional High School will be closed, at least for Thursday, because one janitor was confirmed to have and another is suspected of having Legionnaire's disease, a spokesman for the school said today.

LEAD: Two recent studies conducted by Japanese and European organizations show that the United States' share of the world's electronics production has dropped far more dramatically than previously estimated, a United States trade group said today.

LEAD: On Inauguration Eve, two environmental groups will sponsor a ball to raise public awareness of air pollution and its effects, specifically how the atmosphere traps pollutants under the sun's heat, like a greenhouse, in a way that is some think will raise the Earth's temperature. The ball will be held in a greenhouse.

LEAD: An article on Dec. 18 about a decline in civility during 1988 misstated an affiliation and title of Dr. James R. Walker. He is assistant professor of communication at Memphis State University, not a professor at the University of Tennessee.

LEAD: It was 3 o'clock in the morning and a man, finally fed up with a throbbing, long-neglected bunion, decided it was time to do something. He called a telephone number, and a registered nurse, after telling him how to relieve the pain, gave him the name of a specialist he could arrange to see later that day.

LEAD: The Governor's State of the State address has traditionally marked the start of a new political season. In years past, the event served as a sort of homecoming, with legislators who had not seen each other for months returning to slap backs and exchange stories in the manner of students coming back to school after a long summer recess.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A high-speed European rail network that would sharply cut travel times is in the works. [ Page A1. ] THE ECONOMY The F.D.I.C. wants new powers to increase premiums on banks and to rein in high-risk lending. [ A1. ] President-elect Bush's strategy for the Federal budget has begun to take shape.

LEAD: The attractive flier, offering the upscale magazine European Travel & Life at half price, says for openers that it ''invites you to begin a lifelong love affair with the most magnificent place on earth'' - meaning Europe. The advertisement for the three-year-old publication displays color photographs of a formal castle garden, a baroque ballroom, a prancing fashion model, some fine china, a contemplative writer, and an unidentified couple in Bavarian leather knickers, with a seal-point Siamese cat, captioned: ''The People.

LEAD: Lorillard Inc., the manufacturer of Kent, True and Newport cigarettes, has appointed Lucy M. Giordano its director of media. Ms. Giordano, 40 years old, started at the company 21 years ago as the secretary to Bill Sands, the retiring media director whom she is succeeding. Lorillard, a subsidiary of the Loews Corporation, does its media planning and buying in-house, and handles media placement for the Loews hotels and its Bulova watches.
LEAD: As the United States prepares for a conference in Paris on chemical weapons, a senior Administration official said today that Libya should tear down a vast chemical plant.

LEAD: A 14-year-old boy returning home from church services in Brooklyn was shot in the head and killed Tuesday night after he and his family were caught in crossfire between a policeman and a robbery suspect.
LEAD: An expert advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration will meet today to consider surprising new evidence that the use of oral contraceptives may increase the risk of breast cancer.
LEAD: The prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in lackluster, apathetic trading yesterday.

LEAD: British Petroleum Co., London, will pay Kuwait a profit of about $700 million for 790 million shares of B.P. On Tuesday, when the deal was announced, estimates of Kuwait's profits on the sale were lower.

LEAD: Officials grappling with New York's huge drug problem welcomed proposals today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in his State of the State Message to combat drug abuse. But some officials criticized the Governor's program as thin on specifics and new initiatives.
LEAD: The nation's only law requiring premarital testing for AIDS may not be a law much longer, mainly because the overwhelming majority of those tested have shown no signs of the AIDS virus.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Deep down, what do people really want in a car door? That is not a trivial question for the Budd Company, which is using an increasingly popular Japanese quality control system to find the answer and make better doors as a result.

LEAD: New regulations barring foreigners from taking scarce consumer goods out of the Soviet Union after Feb. 1 will not apply to Westerners who buy caviar, vodka and other items and pay for them with dollars and other convertible currencies in special stores, a customs official said today.

LEAD: The Energy Department estimated today that it could cost $53 billion to $92 billion to clean up radioactive and chemical pollution at plants used to manufacture nuclear bombs and at other military and civilian installations under the department's control.
LEAD: Lina Prokofiev, a singer and the wife of the Russian composer Sergei Prokofiev, died Tuesday in London. She was 91 years old and lived in London.

LEAD: In response to the rejection of its $785 million offer for the Pennwalt Corporation, Centaur Partners said that it would begin a hostile proxy fight to gain control of the Philadelphia-based chemical concern. Pennwalt rejected as inadequate a $100-a-share offer from Centaur.
LEAD: Needle in Hand, Art Center of the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue; 212-996-1100.

LEAD: The defense lawyer in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg said yesterday that his client ''probably would be found guilty'' in the death of Lisa Steinberg and that he would probably be sent to prison.
LEAD: New York horses and horsemen were rewarded with a virtual sweep of thoroughbred racing's championship prizes.

LEAD: FOR the last 14 years, trompe l'oeil facades by the muralist Richard Haas have been decorating urban landscapes from Los Angeles and Milwaukee to Fort Worth and Cincinnati. In New York, many remember the cast-iron facade he created at 114 Prince Street and his re-creation of the old Times Tower in Times

LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, is offering $1 billion in mortgage participation certificates through a real estate mortgage conduit, with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as lead manager.
LEAD: Daddy By Loup Durand Translated by J. Maxwell Brownjohn. 374 pages. Villard Books. $18.95.
LEAD: A forest planted by a Vietnam veteran in memory of Americans who died in the war was saved today when supporters raised enough money to stave off its sale by a bank.

LEAD: Gail Evans has 9,000 telephone numbers. She has dozens of earthquake survivors, 15 people who say they've had afterlife experiences, 4 who insist they've seen Big Foot. She has the phone number of Cher's mother and the number of Rocky Graziano's upstairs neighbor. She has business numbers, home numbers, country home numbers, car phone numbers, airplane numbers and beeper numbers.

LEAD: Orders to the nation's factories for manufactured goods increased by a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in November, a report some economists said reflected continued but slower economic growth.
LEAD: To The Home Section:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Utah Jazz yesterday waived the second-year guard Bart Kofoed, following an incident in which a teammate, Bobby Hansen, sustained a broken cheekbone during a scuffle at a New Year's Eve party. ''There are many versions of the story,'' said the Jazz general manager, Dave Checketts. ''The fact is, a punch was thrown, and I don't see that the situation could ever be patched up again.
LEAD: The Regina Company, the financially troubled maker of vacuum cleaners, yesterday reported a loss of $16.8 million for the period in which inaccuracies were cited in its earnings by accountants.
LEAD: Residents of a trailer park 10 miles northeast of here are at odds with state and Federal officials over the health risks of the cleanup of toxic waste at the nearby Rocky Mountain Arsenal.

LEAD: ''This announcement shall be deemed a sufficient declaration of the persons elected President and Vice President of the United States.'' - George Bush, President of the Senate, after the reading of the final vote of the Electoral College. [ A1:2. ]

LEAD: A consumer group said today that results from over-the-counter kits to test for the presence of the carcinogen radon in the home may be misleading or false because of poor quality control at laboratories that analyze the results.
LEAD: On their first day together at Alabama, the new head coach, Ray Perkins, told the freshman Cornelius Bennett, ''You're going to be the next Lawrence Taylor.''

LEAD: The Opera/Music Theater Institute of New Jersey, a training organization for young singers directed by the longtime Metropolitan Opera bass Jerome Hines, presented its first full opera production, ''The Magic Flute,'' Saturday and Monday at Newark Symphony Hall. On the evidence of the second performance, the institute has succeeded in what must be the first step of any such group's mission: identification of talents worth developing.

LEAD: Griffin Bacal has won the account for the Sharp Electronics Corporation of Mahwah, N.J., the American unit of the Sharp Corporation of Japan. The New Jersey operation, which makes consumer electronics and office automation products, has a budget for broadcast and print advertising of $12 million to $15 million.
LEAD: Following are excerpts from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's State of the State address, as recorded by The New York Times.

LEAD: Daley Thompson of Britain, the 1983 world decathlon champion and the 1980 and 1984 Olympic gold medalist in the event, says that Ben Johnson should be banned from international competition for life. Johnson was banned for two years after testing positive for steroid use following his victory in the 100-meter dash at the Seoul Olympics.
LEAD: It has become common sense in this metropolis of 11 million people not to enter an elevator within five minutes before or after 7 A.M., noon or 5 P.M.
LEAD: The New York City Council, after a committee meeting marked by shouts of anger and frustration, overwhelmingly approved a series of amendments to the city's new public campaign-financing law.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In its first financing of the new year, the Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, is offering $700 million in debentures due in 1994 through various securities dealers.

LEAD: Dick Thornburgh faces one daunting internal problem as Attorney General, the same one that has tested his predecessors in the Justice Department for 30 years. That is the character of the F.B.I.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission have tentatively settled an age discrimination suit filed by the commission in 1981 on behalf of 231 former salaried Chrysler employees.
LEAD: The Quaker Oats Company said today that it would sell its Ghirardelli chocolate business, based in San Leandro, Calif.

LEAD: Boyd L. Jefferies, the Government's main witness in a series of securities fraud cases, may have violated Federal election laws by concealing contributions made to members of Congress, lawyers involved in the stock manipulation case of the GAF Corporation said yesterday.

LEAD: A large group of Afghan cadets training at a Soviet police academy went on a rampage Tuesday in the Soviet Central Asian city of Tashkent, leaving an infant boy dead and several other people wounded, according to reports reaching Moscow tonight.

LEAD: THE Christmas tree, kept till the day after New Year's, is finally gone, the ornaments are back in their boxes, and my major present, new earrings, has been worn thrice already. Now I am settling in for the long, slow trek through winter, for the low sun and the short days and the air that drops like iron into the lungs.
LEAD: About three hours before game time Tuesday night, Seton Hall's team bus arrived at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Right then, the Pirates realized this wasn't an ordinary game.

LEAD: THESE days it seems even birds are deserving of historic houses. So believes Johanna Welty of Walnut Creek, Calif., who makes limited-edition bird cages in such styles as an Italian Regency dovecote and a Palladian aviary.

LEAD: A woman who had had nightmares about her mother's 1985 disappearance pried open a locked basement freezer and found the woman's battered body on Monday, the police said. The discovery led her father, a high school dean of students, to confess the slaying.

LEAD: Yasir Arafat should not be surprised that every word he utters, every statement made in his name is meticulously scrutinized. The world has so long associated the Palestine Liberation Organization he heads with terrorism that the credibility of his recent renunciation of this practice remains fragile at best.
LEAD: Newcomers In New Play
LEAD: Attorney General W. Cary Edwards announced today that he will quit his post in two weeks to contemplate whether to run for governor this year, a move that most politicians here consider likely.

LEAD: Samuel T. Carter 3d, a radio and television writer who retired to write on American history, died of cancer Dec. 28 at the Ponperaug Woods Health Center in Heritage Village, Southbury, Conn. He was 84 years old and lived in Heritage Village.
LEAD: By dropping the most serious charges against Oliver L. North, the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra case has left a host of questions that may never be answered.
LEAD: Last year, the Florida Legislature thought it had come up with a clever settlement to the endless war among the Miami area's three throughbred tracks over prime winter racing dates.
LEAD: The ESPN cable network yesterday won the television rights to 175 major league baseball games a year for four years, beginning in the 1990 season, in a $400 million deal.
LEAD: MAI Basic Four Inc. today disclosed new details of its relationship with the embattled investment banking firm Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

LEAD: The new judge, clad in a T-shirt and shorts, walked past a couple of lawyers at a local health club. Only a few years ago, he knew, both of his one-time bar brethren would have ignored him. ''Good evening, your Honor,'' said one, thinking he was leaving. In fact, the judge was only going to the Nautilus machine, and when he emerged a few minutes later he passed them again.

LEAD: Members of the special Congressional committees that investigated the Iran-contra affair in 1987 said today that they were not surprised by the independent prosecutor's decision to seek dismissal of the conspiracy and theft charges against Oliver L. North.

LEAD: Crude oil prices bounced back yesterday, reflecting reports of a possible squeeze in deliveries of North Sea oil in the London market and expectations that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and other producers might agree to further steps to reduce output.

LEAD: Storytelling, music and dance will be combined in ''Xanadu/The Millions,'' presented by Mark Taylor and Friends tonight through Sunday at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street. Suggested by the story of Marco Polo, the multi-media piece was choreographed by Mr. Taylor to a score for percussion and amplified cello, composed and played at each performance by Elise Tobin.

LEAD: President Reagan decided today to recommend that members of Congress, Federal judges and top members of the executive branch get a 50 percent pay increase, the White House and Congressional officials said this evening.

LEAD: ''Salt 40,'' a work about 40 years of conflict in Israel, by Kei Okada, is to be perfomred at Franklin Furnace, 112 Franklin Street, tonight at 8:30. Mr. Okada, a Japanese composer living in New York, has described the piece as an audiovisual madrigal. It is also to be performed tomorrow evening at 8:30.

LEAD: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration said today that no changes in the use of birth control pills or in warning labels on the pills are warranted despite new evidence suggesting that use of the pill may increase the risk of breast cancer.

LEAD: Ruggero Raimondi, the bass who was to sing in the ''Pavarotti Plus ... Plus!'' concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday at 8 P.M., has dropped out because of illness. Paul Plishka will take his place in the ensemble pieces requiring a bass. The performance is to be broadcast by the public television on ''Live from Lincoln Center'' and simulcast locally on WNCN radio (104.3 FM).

LEAD: Dr. Robert S. Coles, an internationally known ophthalmologist and educator, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Snow has fallen on the desert regions of Khur and Biyabanak in eastern Iran for the first time in 50 years, the official Iranian press agency reported today. Officials said four inches of snow had fallen in the last 24 hours, forcing schools to close.

LEAD: ''Andy, it's me/Haven't seen you for a while/I wish I had talked to you more when you were alive,'' begins the elegiac lyric for ''Hello It's Me,'' one of 14 new songs written by John Cale and Lou Reed for their new musical suite, ''Songs for 'Drella.''
LEAD: President-elect George Bush's attempt to complete his Cabinet remained stalled today with no clear choice for Energy Secretary, senior Bush aides said.

LEAD: Aug. 4, 1981 Maj. Oliver L. North of the Marine Corps is assigned to duty at the White House with the National Security Council. December 1981 President Reagan signs a ''finding'' authorizing a covert Central Intelligence Agency operation to support the Nicaraguan rebels, or contras. December 1982 The first Boland amendment becomes law barring use of Federal money to overthrow the Government of Nicaragua.

LEAD: Oliver North, the man at the heart of the Iran-contra affair, has cut the heart out of the criminal case against him. The special Federal prosecutor, after struggling to reconcile the needs of national security with the demands of a public trial, has decided that he must drop the major conspiracy and theft charges against the former National Security Council staff officer.

LEAD: The European Community said today that American walnuts and dried prunes, peaches, apricots and papayas would be subject to punitive tariffs if its trade dispute with the United States was not settled soon.

LEAD: About 45 African students who had been held against their will by the authorities in the eastern Chinese city of Nanjing for the last 10 days were released today. Most plan to leave China as soon as possible.

LEAD: Enron Gas Marketing Inc., a subsidiary of the Enron Corporation, signed a 15-year $150 million agreement to supply natural gas to a co-generation plant to be constructed in Uniondale, L.I., as part of the Nassau District Energy System, which supplies power on Long Island.

LEAD: Boyd L. Jefferies, an important Government witness in several securities fraud cases, testified yesterday that shortly before entering a plea-bargaining agreement in 1987 he destroyed many of his notes about his trading patterns and discussions with clients.

LEAD: The United States is seeking Soviet cooperation in pressing Libya to cease operations at a chemical plant that Washington says will be used to make chemical weapons, American officials said today.

LEAD: Mike Tyson was in another car accident yesterday, when his 1988 Lincoln was hit by another car trying to get around a stalled vehicle in Las Vegas, Nev. No one was injured in the accident, which police described as a minor fender-bender that slightly damaged the door of Tyson's car. Tyson, a passenger, was on way to his doctor to be fitted for a mouthpiece.
LEAD: Cream of the Plum

LEAD: Sammie Smith, the Florida State junior tailback whose 115 yards rushing made him the most valuable player in the 13-7 victory over Auburn in the Sugar Bowl, said yesterday that he would apply for the National Football League draft. Smith, whose freshman class will graduate this spring, was the Seminoles' leading rusher the last two seasons.

LEAD: The National Academy of Sciences urged President-elect George Bush today to place the threat of a significant increase in global temperatures high on his agenda because ''the future welfare of human society'' is at risk.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The West German central bank intervened against a surging dollar yesterday, indicating its increasing displeasure with the dollar's growing strength.

LEAD: Andrew Magee admits that he was intimidated by the big-name players while spending the last four years earning his spurs on the PGA Tour. He remembers the first time he played with Jack Nicklaus when he was a rookie.

LEAD: Curtis Mitchell is one of many artists living in a raw warehouse area in Brooklyn, not far from the Brooklyn Bridge. One of his three untitled works in the ''Emerging Sculptors'' show at the Sculpture Center was inspired by a visit to Manhattan's glitzy Trump Tower. With its rectangular trunk shape, its marble facing and a carpet placed over it as carefully as a shroud, the sculpture suggests a fancy portable altar.

LEAD: A 14-year-old boy has died of starvation and his parents and sister are under treatment for malnutrition in a case some people here link to the family's belief that God would take care of all their needs.

LEAD: * Allstate Insurance Co., Northbrook, Ill., a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Co., named as executive vice presidents Louis G. Lower 2d and David E. McPherson. In addition, it named Myron J. Resnick senior vice president and treasurer.
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission decided yesterday to review the decision of a Federal administrative law judge in the case against George C. Kern Jr., a prominent takeover lawyer.

LEAD: An article on Wednesday incompletely identified a West German company allegedly involved in illegal shipments of nuclear materials to third world countries. The company is Alfred Hempel KG GmbH & Company of Dusseldorf, not the F. W. Hempel Company Inc., also of Dusseldorf.

LEAD: Twenty years have passed since Joseph Kalichstein's New York debut, at which the Israeli-born pianist made a strong impression as a technician of heroic aspirations and a musician of serious intent. His subsequent capturing of the Leventritt Award further fueled that reputation and targeted him as one of his generation's most promising artists.
LEAD: A proposal by Finance Minister Shimon Peres to reduce the Israeli Government budget by $550 million was approved tonight by the Israeli Cabinet.

LEAD: ''The Eagle and the Bear,'' a 26-part weekly series on the cold war that begins at 8 tonight on the Arts & Entertainment cable network, is chronologically jumpy. The first episode starts, reasonably, with the end of World War II and of the United States-Soviet wartime alliance. In the second episode, we are in Korea a couple of years later.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation said yesterday that it would not conduct its regularly scheduled offering on Jan. 23 because it and its borrowers have only a limited need now to raise cash in the debt market for medium- and long-term financing.

LEAD: A Navy cockpit tape of the confrontation between American and Libyan jet fighters offers only flashes of video images, but provides in sound the drama of American aviators unexpectedly caught up in combat.

LEAD: Six New York City health inspectors and three restaurant consultants were convicted yesterday of extorting thousands of dollars from restaurant owners by threatening to cite them for violations or close them.

LEAD: ''36 Fillette'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 4. The film, which is in French with English subtitles, opens today at Lincoln Plaza 2, Broadway at 63d Street.

LEAD: Shops were open, workers went to their jobs and commerce and business seemed normal here today. But a day after an aerial confrontation in which two Libyan fighter planes were shot down, there was anxiety over what the Americans might do next.

LEAD: The director Steven Spielberg, a longtime lover of animated cartoons, is joining forces with Warner Brothers for a new television version of Warner's famous ''Merrie Melodies'' cartoons, to be called ''Tiny Tunes.''

LEAD: Andrew Stein, the New York City Council president, misleads the public about the true costs of his refusal to participate in the city's new public campaign financing system. He claims it will hold down the cost of an unpopular reform. In fact, it will trigger higher spending, while restoring the influence of wealthy donors.

LEAD: Larry Bird's recovery from surgery on his heels last Nov. 19 is ahead of schedule and he will probably return to the lineup before March 1, the Boston Celtics' team physician, Dr. Arnold Scheller, said yesterday. ''There's no buildup of scar tissue, but right now we've got to work on getting the strength back in his calf muscles,'' Scheller said.

LEAD: An obituary yesterday about a professor of economics and former academic vice president at Suffolk County Community College in New York misidentified him. The professor, who died on Wednesday, was John J. Saal, not Faal.

LEAD: Hattie Clark Rosenbaum, a longtime vice president at Columbia Artists Management and one of the first women to attain a leading role in the concert-management profession, died of a brain tumor Dec. 24 at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. She was 82 years old.

LEAD: Charles J. Buesing, a retired sales executive and longtime trustee of the American Cancer Society, died of emphysema Saturday at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Indian River Shores, Fla., where he lived. He was 79.

LEAD: As expected, the governors of the New York Mercantile Exchange voted late Wednesday night to join Globex, an electronic futures trading system developed by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Reuters Ltd. The system is designed to afford traders around the globe access to both markets after their normal trading hours.

LEAD: IF cities had official mottos, ''What's new?'' might well be the most fitting phrase for the five boroughs of New York. Change is so permanent a feature of city life that one almost expects yesterday's parking lot to be tomorrow's skyscraper and the nondescript coffee shop one visited last month to become the fashionable restaurant or trendy discotheque that opens next week.

LEAD: The Dallas Mavericks forward Roy Tarpley, who went to drug counselors for help Wednesday, was suspended indefinitely without pay yesterday in line with the National Basketball Association's anti-drug agreement. The 24-year-old Tarpley returned to the active roster Dec. 13 after missing 14 games with torn cartilage in his left knee.
LEAD: Ira D. London, Joel B. Steinberg's lawyer, tells the story himself. He goes into a fashionable Manhattan restaurant where he used to dine unknown but where he now gets a good table.

LEAD: Several Federal agencies have joined in a broad investigation of stock manipulation, using evidence that came to light as a result of the market crash of October 1987, officials reported yesterday.

LEAD: Freezing weather and gusty winds have prompted many homeless people to seek shelter in New York City's transportation terminals, prompting complaints from the police at Pennsylvania Station that they are being forced to work overtime to keep the homeless moving.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci approved a plan today to close dozens of military bases around the country, calling it a ''unique opportunity'' to save money that had been endorsed by military leaders.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury in Virginia is expected to announce on Friday the first indictment in a broad investigation of accusations of bribery and fraud involving Pentagon officials, the Justice Department said today.

LEAD: New Jersey's Mount Laurel housing plan is probably the most painless way to build low- and moderate-income housing in suburban America. Developed after 12 years of court battles, the state plan sets a quota of subsidized units for each suburb. But it doesn't cost the suburb a cent. The builder pays for it.

LEAD: Emperor Hirohito reigned over not one Japan, but three: a Japan consumed with militarism almost from the time he took over the Chrysanthemum Throne, a Japan that lay in ruins at the end of World War II and seemed destined for years of occupation and dependency, and finally a Japan that, from the shambles of defeat, achieved in peacetime global economic power.

LEAD: Among modern theater composers, Kurt Weill has proved to be the one with whom rock-era performers identify the most readily. The skewed bluesiness of his music, along with the cynicism of his collaborators' lyrics - not only those of Bertolt Brecht but also those of Alan Jay Lerner and Ogden Nash - lend the songs a perennial contemporaneity.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis inspired liberal followers and irked conservative critics with a suprisingly fiery State of the State Speech Thursday night. Mr. Dukakis lashed out at his opponents as ''gutless wonders'' and said ''baloney'' to those who accuse the state of overspending. Republican leaders and conservative Democrats said they found some of the Governor's remarks bitter and even tasteless.

LEAD: After 74 years and countless recriminations, Turkey plans to reopen the archival records on one of the more grisly episodes of this century: the mass deaths of Armenians at the hands of the Ottoman Turks during World War I. LEAD: The beginning of the new year is a perfect time to establish or review personal investment portfolios. Economic conditions should be an important part of any guide to what kind of investments to make. For instance, a weak or slowing economy favors bonds. Not everyone's financial needs are alike, and portfolios should vary - some are geared to increasing personal wealth and favor stock investments.

LEAD: ''Romance Romance,'' a four-character musical by Keith Herrmann, with book and lyrics by Barry Harman, will close after tomorrow's performance at the Helen Hayes Theater. The musical will have played 289 regular performances and 10 previews.

LEAD: More details of the Government's investigation of stock market manipulation were disclosed yesterday, as charges of regulatory violations were brought by the National Association of Securities Dealers.

LEAD: Should all Americans have health insurance? Yes; in the richest nation in the world, the question shouldn't be if, but how to finance decent universal coverage fairly and efficiently.

LEAD: Alfred S. Julien, a New York trial lawyer who was founder and senior partner in the law firm of Julien & Schlesinger, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 78 years old and also had homes in Manhattan and in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

LEAD: George M. L. La Branche, founder of La Branche & Company, a Manhattan stock trading concern, died of pneumonia Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: For days warlike sounds have issued from Washington about the need for a ''surgical strike'' to ''take out'' that troublesome chemical plant in Libya. This fast-food and medical jargon harks back to Vietnam days when it was used to describe what our air forces were up to, which was bombing with a ferocity somewhat less destructive than nuclear assault.

LEAD: Dr. John B. Newman, a retired professor of speech at Queens College and an expert in semantics, died of heart failure Monday at his home in Whitestone, Queens. He was 71 years old.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The hue and cry over the deplorable conditions of New York City's schools has produced, in record time, a new, if revolutionary, authority: the New York City School Construction Authority. Now provided with first-class leadership, it has the powers to press school projects to prompt completion. But a will and a way won't suffice if projects are not assigned and funds not allocated.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Though jazz has regularly used instrumental combinations that defy convention, the 1980's have seen a real increase in the popularity of oddly outfitted groups. The 29th Street Saxophone Quartet, which played at Visiones on Thursday night, made it clear why the practice has become so popular: without the interference of a rhythm section, its four saxophones are immensely sensual and capture an archtypical jazz sound.
LEAD: Dr. Thomas Holmes, a psychiatrist who helped create a stress scale of such events as marriage and work troubles, died Dec. 24 of a stroke. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: The Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister promised today that Soviet troops would be out of Afghanistan by Feb. 15, an Afghan guerrilla leader said after meeting with him.
LEAD: Arvia MacKaye Ege, a poet and a founder of the Rudolph Steiner Educational and Farming Association, died Wednesday at her home in Hillsdale, N.Y. She was 86 years old.

LEAD: The West German Government renewed its demands today that the United States supply evidence to support assertions that a German chemical company was involved in the contruction of a chemical plant in Libya. Bonn complained that it was being victimized by a ''media campaign'' in the United States.

LEAD: Now that Rupert Murdoch has won control of William Collins, Harper & Row will be able to integrate more closely its publishing and distribution in Britain and Canada, where the two companies have often gone their separate ways.

The N.C.A.A. warned that future infractions could result in the ''death penalty,'' which would shut down the program.

LEAD: The six senior Reagan Administration officials who decided to prohibit the use of certain classified evidence in the trial of Oliver L. North were advised in advance by the prosecutor that their action could cripple his case, Government sources familiar with the decision said today.

LEAD: The $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company moved nearer to completion yesterday after a few dozen of the world's largest banks agreed to lend in the vicinity of $10 billion for the deal.

LEAD: Sometime in the next three months most taxpayers will be sorting through their 1988 financial records to get the information they or their tax preparers need to file returns. A key to really getting finances under control is to do the job as soon as possible and as thoroughly as possible, by preparing an entire cash-flow statement that shows all expenditures as well as income and deductions.
LEAD: The dollar surged again yesterday, powered by an apparent change of stance by the West German central bank that left some currency traders wondering what was going on.

LEAD: In Unit C-73 on Rikers Island during the noon hour yesterday, one of the first questions the inmates asked Taylor Branch was: What prompted you, a white man, to write a book about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.?

LEAD: An article on Thursday about the opening of the Connecticut General Assembly misstated the vote to elect Richard J. Balducci as Speaker of the House. It was 94 to 57 for Mr. Balducci; he was supported by all 63 Republicans and 31 dissident members of the 88-member Democratic majority.

LEAD: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., under Federal investigation for a December visit to a man suspected of being a drug dealer, declined today to make public the results of 10 drug tests that he has said he took over the past five years.

LEAD: ITEM: In 1966, when the prototypical American man turned 50, he had enjoyed a 31 percent increase in income over 10 years. For his present-day counterpart, the increase has been only 10 percent.

The church was constructed in the late 16th century by Franciscan monks and although much of it has been rebuilt, the bells have a heavy, tired sound - as though they have been ringing for too many years.

LEAD: Best Boy Directed by Ira Wohl. 1979. Today Home Entertainment. 111 minutes. $59.95. Not rated.

LEAD: IT IS NOT OFTEN that a social historian gets to watch social history march past his own window. But that was Prof. Leon F. Litwack's rare opportunity when the Free Speech Movement erupted at the University of California campus in Berkeley in 1964. With what he calls a ''certain kind of exhilaration,'' the historian watched as his students succeeded where his older generation of social activists had failed.
LEAD: When Olympic National Park rangers reached the wild stretch of Pacific shore here a few days ago after hiking through the rain forest, they found a scene from their worst nightmares.

LEAD: SEVERAL years ago, a mini-phenomenon called bagel chips hit the stores. The idea originated with Jim Burns, Gary Ricker and Rene Reist, who were at that time owners of the Cheese Store in Bernardsville. Originally, the chips were a means of making use of bagels that would otherwise be thrown out.

LEAD: BUNDLE up and prune; lack of leaves reveals tree/shrub scaffolding, which makes it easier to do some judicious cutting; this is also a good time to prune overgrown conifers and hollies. Cut off the Christmas tree branches and place them over perennials to protect early growth in spring. Do not overfeed or overwater house plants now because most of them are in a resting or dormant period.

LEAD: Now you see it, now you don't. That could be said about the movement in many works by contemporary choreographers who send dancers hurtling through space. Images often flash by so rapidly that one may not be sure how to interpret them. Ambiguity may even be part of a dance's point. Yet, when employed skillfully, speed can convey its own message.

LEAD: I did enjoy Malcolm Bradbury's piece about Mrs. Thatcher's children, who are raking it in all over the new-look, designer Britain. For one thing, it's always nice to read about oneself. For another, Mr. Bradbury's assertions weren't too far off the mark.

LEAD: Four hundred and fifty years separate two conquerors who came to Miami in search of gold: Juan Ponce de Leon in the early 1500's and Don Johnson in the early 1980's. Ponce de Leon never struck gold. Don Johnson did, with his TV show ''Miami Vice.''

LEAD: In 1985 and 1986, record high water in the Great Lakes washed away and flooded streets. In 1988, a dry, hot summer was followed by a quick return to substantially lower levels that left harbors too shallow for ships to navigate. The extreme fluctuations in water levels have created a nearly continuous debate among engineers and planners over the success - or lack of it - of current methods to regulate the water's rise and fall.

LEAD: TODAY'S FIRST-GRADERS will be college freshmen when the 21st century begins a dozen years from now. Computers will be ubiquitous, creating and, at the same time, helping to meet a staggering challenge for students.

LEAD: ''IT'S my favorite project,'' said Adina Salmansohn-Affelt, who has been involved with many kinds of community endeavors through the years. Her most recent efforts, however, have led to the establishment of the Hudson School of Creative Arts. Opened last September in south Yonkers, the school's stated purpose is to teach music, art and dance to students who would not otherwise be able to afford lessons.

LEAD: AT the turn of the century, the creed of the founders of modern Israel was Labor Zionism. Steeped in European socialism and a belief in hard outdoor work, and determined to escape pogroms and shtetls, they sought not only a new country, but a new Jewish people.

LEAD: If everything went right for Townhouses on the Park, one-half block from Central Park West, all 77 of its two- and three-bedroom apartments with balconies and gardens would have sold for only $63,000 and $73,000. But just about everything went wrong for the community development corporation that started building the project eight years ago with Federal and city aid.
LEAD: THE E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company plant in Deepwater, N.J., knows how to make chemicals. But controlling the chemistry of rapidly reproducing deer has the company stumped.
