LEAD: TRYING to deal with the midlife crisis everyone says I am in, at my age, 47, I am baffled by my ordinariness. I felt by this time that there would be something more - I felt I was better, or at least different, than the rest.

LEAD: President Reagan was termed in ''good spirits'' after minor surgery today to correct a condition that had caused a curvature of the ring finger on his left hand. A White House spokesman said Mr. Reagan remained awake throughout the operation and chatted about horses with his doctors.

LEAD: As a public-school music educator for the last 23 years, I have had to deal with the issue of holiday music in a variety of school settings. The article ''Schools Strive for Seasonal Balance'' [ Dec. 18 ] was interesting but failed to point out one obvious solution to the dilemma. Simply make the issue a non-issue by remembering that the primary function of the music teacher is to teach music and to provide positive musical experiences to all students.

LEAD: FABLES FOR THE NUCLEAR AGE. By Alan Neidle. Illustrations by Jeff Leedy. (Paragon House, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $9.95.) Behemoths, butterflies and other creatures populate ''Fables for the Nuclear Age,'' canny political parables that take up where Aesop and Orwell left off. As animals scheme to shift the balance of power, they imitate Homo sapiens' diplomatic strategies more apt to escalate problems than to solve them.

LEAD: Last summer in Westhampton Beach, Sexton's was the same store it had been for 22 years. But no sooner did the season end in October than the department store began to change. By the time summer residents and vacationers start to return to the Long Island resort in April, Sexton's will be only one of 14 stores and professional offices operating out of the four connected buildings it once filled.

LEAD: SHOE buying for women is often a compromise between fashion and comfort. But now the U.S. Shoe Company, which came out with a specialized walking show for women in 1987, has a walking pump. The Easy Spirit Dress pump has features that promise a high comfort quotient. The shoes have a wide toe box, contoured heel support, a flexible sole, breathable fabric lining, and two layers of a shock foam.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE poet John Ciardi once looked at the false-fronted electronic dream factory of Southern California and wrote, ''The only possible mistake is in trying to perceive depth there.'' Anyone who thinks that Los Angeles is a shallow, post-literate wasteland might be surprised to learn that it ranks second to New York in book sales, according to a United States Department of Commerce survey.

LEAD: WHILE traversing a snowy trail on Hamburg Mountain here five years ago, Paul Kattermann of Frankford Township, an avid skier, caught up to the 12 participants in the first Ski-a-thon benefit for the American Cancer Society and its Sussex County chapter.

LEAD: Malcolm Bilson is to lead the On Original Instruments Chamber Orchestra in its debut performance, Jan. 25 at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The core group of string quartet, flute, oboe, horn and bassoon will be expanded to 19 members for the program of Haydn's Violin Concerto in C - with Stanley Ritchie as soloist - and Symphony No.
LEAD: THE EIGHT CORNERS OF THE WORLD By Gordon Weaver. 382 pp. Chelsea, Vt.: Chelsea Green Publishing Company. $19.95.

LEAD: Oliver L. North faces a long and in some ways more arduous legal battle on 12 remaining criminal counts against him now that national security concerns appear to have scuttled the two most serious charges, officials close to the case say.

LEAD: Skiing Schneider Posts Eighth Cup Victory: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, skiing through a driving rain, captured her eighth straight World Cup victory and fourth giant slalom of the season yesterday in Schwarzenberg, Austria. She had the best time in both heats for a winning total of 2 minutes 16.75 seconds.

LEAD: At St. Columba's Episcopal Church in Washington, Charlotte Weeks Morford, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Morford of Charlottesville, Va., was married yesterday to Lieut. Comdr. Steven Anthony Fillipow, U.S.N., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Fillipow of Long Beach, Calif. The Rev. William McDonald Tully performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Homeless residents of the capital and their advocates won a victory today when a judge ruled that the city must be prepared to open new shelters within three days in neighborhoods where existing shelters fill to capacity for two consecutive nights.
LEAD: THE COMPANY OF CRITICS Social Criticism and Political Commitment in the Twentieth Century. By Michael Walzer. 260 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

LEAD: The screams began sometime after dinner: a teen-ager and his father were having a quarrel that could be heard through the wall of a neighbor's apartment in a luxury building on East 87th Street in Manhattan. Suddenly the neighbor heard a banging. Apparently the father was bashing his son's head against the bathroom wall.

LEAD: IT will be another year before census takers fan out among the small towns and big cities, taking America's decennial head count. Among politicians in Iowa and other farm states, where tens of thousands of people have abandoned small towns and family farms over the past decade, the 1990 census is approaching with the tread of doom.

LEAD: AN unusual folk-singing revival will get under way in northern Westchester next Saturday evening when the folk singer Pete Seeger performs at the opening of the Walkabout Clearwater Coffee House at the Harvey School Hall in Katonah. Organizers of the monthly nonprofit coffee house say they hope the audience will sing in the chorus and help with the environmental-action programs of Walkabout Clearwater, a nonprofit environmental organization chartered by the Poughkeepsie-based Clearwater Inc.

LEAD: At the Harmonie Club in New York, Hilary Meg Ballon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ballon of New York, was married last evening to Orin Stuart Kramer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian S. Kramer of South Orange, N.J. Rabbi Ely Pilchik performed the ceremony.
LEAD: THE LYRE OF ORPHEUS By Robertson Davies. 472 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.
LEAD: THE PASSION ACCORDING TO G.H. By Clarice Lispector. Translated by Ronald W. Sousa. 174 pp. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $8.95.

LEAD: THE struggle over language in Canada has roots that go back to the 17th-century, when England and France first locked horns over the vast hinterland of North America. For the past 20 years, the legacy has been a bitter battle over the right of English and French minorities in various parts of the country to the full use of their languages.
LEAD: After the game, the Rangers spoke of togetherness, the Islanders of disintegration.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. James W. Wickenden of Belle Mead, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Wickenden to Lieut. James Arthur Crisfield, U.S.A.F., a son of James P. Crisfield of Youngstown, N.Y., and Lucile Stafford Proctor of Princeton, N.J., and Cotuit, Mass. The couple plan to marry in
LEAD: When President Reagan submits the final budget of his Presidency Monday, it will be the first in which both spending and revenue exceed $1 trillion.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''The heady days of pre-October 19 gave birth to this case. It is probably one of 1,000 tragedies from that day.'' Kalman Gallop, lawyer for Stanley Aslanian Jr., former Wall Street executive who agreed to plead guilty to stock fraud.
LEAD: Veneer is usually a thin layer of attractive woodthat is glued in the surface of thicker, less attractive wood to enhance its appearance.

LEAD: Q. Three years ago, we put siding on our house and had it stained, rather than painted. A couple of months ago, I noticed some gray spots on this siding, and they have now spread all over the outside. It seems to be some kind of mold, and scrubbing with Clorox got rid of it. This is harsh and seems difficult to do over the entire house.

LEAD: While a propensity for violence is a variable that many of us harbor in some degree, I cannot countenance the licensing of those who hunt with bows and arrows, ''Hunting of Deer Begins,'' (Dec. 18, 1988).

LEAD: In the closing days of World War II, as much of Japan lay in ruins, an 11-year-old boy was living and studying in Nikko, a quiet town in the mountains safe from the American B-29 Superfortresses that were bombing Tokyo nightly.

LEAD: The vision of a nonracial South Africa was raised just 77 years ago - on Jan. 8, 1912 - by the new African National Congress. Today blacks are still denied political and other rights; the A.N.C. is banned, its leaders imprisoned, dead or in exile. But its president, Oliver Tambo, is optimistic.

LEAD: A talented young dancer became a noble god on Friday night at the New York State Theater when Lindsay Fischer of the New York City Ballet gave his first performance in the title role of George Balanchine's ''Apollo.''

LEAD: Q. Three years ago, we put siding on our house and had it stained, rather than painted. A couple of months ago, I noticed some gray spots on this siding, and they have now spread all over the outside. It seems to be some kind of mold, and scrubbing with Clorox got rid of it. This is harsh and seems difficult to do over the entire house.

LEAD: The main article in the Business section on Dec. 25 discussed the possibility of renewed regulation on Wall Street, spurred by Drexel Burnham Lambert's decision to plead guilty to fraud. The article said critics of deregulation would probably paint the Drexel case as only the latest example of Wall Street's being out of control; it listed other disputed behavior, some illegal and some not.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Vanacore of North Caldwell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jill Roberta Vanacore to Richard Gerveys Reid, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Reid of Brooklyn Heights and Quogue, L.I. The couple plan a May 6 wedding.

LEAD: For a change of pace, we will not have to worry today which football teams are ''clean'' or ''not clean.'' Did the Chicago Bears give a sports car to that mastodon as a bonus for enrolling at Halas U.? Tsk, tsk.

LEAD: Richard M. Goldwater, a Manhattan lawyer and former New York State Assemblyman, died of complications of pneumonia Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: AFTER serving a year and a half, Thomas S. Holman has resigned his post as director of the Hudson River Museum, museum officials and Mr. Holman confirmed last week. The 35-five-year old Mr. Holman, the fifth director in this decade, signed a letter of resignation on Monday.
LEAD: W Or The Memory of Childhood. By Georges Perec. Translated by David Bellos. 164 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $16.95.
LEAD: AS the concert season struggles to awaken after its holiday nap, Stamford leads the way with Russian dances, jazz duets, a recital by an eminent pianist and an adventure in cabaret pops.
LEAD: Cyanide has been found in the home of a teen-ager who lapsed into a coma after eating yogurt tainted with the poisonous substance, a newspaper reported today.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in The Week in Review last Sunday listing successes of the United Nations in 1988 incorrectly described the participants in negotiations on the unification of Cyprus. The talks are between the leaders of the Greek and Turkish communities on the island.

LEAD: THERE'S something unnerving about having a four-foot stingray nuzzle against you while you're floating flat on your face, or offering a five-foot barracuda a bite of a bagel. You learn later that a barracuda doesn't particularly like bagels, though it might be tempted by lox. A stringray likes both, and will pester you for a handout.

LEAD: As Governor Mario M. Cuomo's Decade of the Child enters its second year, doctors, advocates for children and some government officials say that the quality of life for poor children in the state is deteriorating quickly and that Albany's efforts are not keeping pace with the problem.

LEAD: Do not underestimate the power of a beauty statement. When a number of women suddenly lop off their long hair, it may be more than just a collective whim. Short hair tends to be popular when women are battling societal restrictions. Right now, the feminine flourishes in fashion may be giving way to a more subdued, simplified look.

LEAD: Perhaps it is a measure of how East-West relations have changed. Vyacheslav Fetisov, a Red Army hockey player who would like to play for the New Jersey Devils, has made no perilous dash for freedom, but is behaving like any pro athlete seeking to be traded. While his team has been playing a series of exhibition matches against American teams - the last one is set for tomorrow in Buffalo - Fetisov has bantered with reporters, wheedled his coach, and even discussed the matter with the Soviet Ambassador to the United States.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Larholt of London of the engagement of their daughter Kay Marice Larholt to Neill Eric Silverman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Silverman of Livingston, N.J. Miss Larholt, a doctoral candidate in biostatistics at the Harvard University School of Public Health, graduated from Ben Gurion University in Beersheba, Israel.
LEAD: Any exciting young British actor is almost inevitably dubbed ''the new Olivier.'' But in the case of 27-year-old Kenneth Branagh, the comparison is unavoidable.

LEAD: When a personal computer fails at a large company, the worker usually places a frantic call to the technical support office. The technician comes to the desk and either fixes the problem or swaps the machine for a backup. The failure is annoying but rarely catastrophic. In most businesses, however, there is no in-house technical support, no backup machine or spare-parts inventory.

LEAD: IN the early 1960's, the executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. provoked an angry outcry from some labor leaders when it urged them to open their ranks to black workers. It was not until 1964, some 15 years after the armed forces began to integrate and a decade after the Supreme Court ordered desegregation of public schools, that the last labor federation affiliate removed the ''whites only'' clause in its constitution and bylaws.

LEAD: When the long-awaited withdrawal of Cuba's 50,000-man military force starts here Tuesday, verification promises to be limited to a friendly United Nations officer standing dockside with a clipboard.

LEAD: FROM THE REMINISCENCES OF PRIVATE IVANOV: And Other Stories. By Vsevolod Garshin. Translated by Peter Henry, Liv Tudge, Donald Rayfield and Philip Taylor. (Dufour Editions, Cloth, $27.50; Paper, $13.95.) For a few years in the mid-1880's, the eyes of the Russian literary world turned to Vsevolod Garshin.

LEAD: IN these bundle-up days, even city slickers who see trees only at Christmas have discovered the cozy woolen woodsman's coat. This colorful old American favorite is getting a lot of exposure, thanks largely to guess who? Right you are: it's that noted lumberjack (and occasional designer) Ralph Lauren.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kaloust of Gloucester, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Donna Louise Kaloust to Dr. Robert Christopher Hedgepath, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Hedgepath of Wilmington, Del. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: VELOCITY. By Kristin McCloy. (Random House, $16.95.) The night after her mother's funeral, Ellie, the heroine of Kristin McCloy's first novel, has a dream: she's riding in a car with her mother; neither is wearing her seat belt. They go faster and faster, until. . . . The very next night, Ellie meets Jesse, a long-haired, half-Cherokee biker who lives down the road.

LEAD: AS Westchester retailers tabulate the profits from a successful holiday season, they fear they are losing ground against a common enemy, the thieving employee. On Dec. 27 polygraph testing, one of the means retailers in the state have used to determine the honesty of employees, was banned under the Employee Polygraph Protection
LEAD: 'No Beer Here'

LEAD: I READ somewhere that yuppies are taking leave of one another these days with the word ''ciao.'' I have never been able to bring myself to say ''ciao.'' But I would like to. I roll it around in my mind. ''Ciao.'' Even better, ''Ciao, baby.''

LEAD: Peter Matthiessen's article on the Yellowstone fires was a thoughtful piece and goes further than anything else I've read to convince me that this disaster probably couldn't have been avoided, that change is part of the natural order of things and that life in all the beauty of Yellowstone will go on (''Our National Parks: The Case for Burning,'' Dec.
LEAD: Super Bowl prognosis: Bengals 24, Bears 10.
LEAD: China today sharply criticized what it described as fabrications in foreign news reports about recent racial incidents in several Chinese cities.
LEAD: Timothy Grimes, one of the victims of the Howard Beach racial violence, has been convicted of malicious wounding for shooting his brother in the face.

LEAD: STUDENTS and ducks shamble about the palm-lined campus of Florida International University on a bright Miami day, the former to classes and the latter to nearby ponds. Despite the sprinkling of people wearing chefs' uniforms, the ducks are unconcerned. Students at the F.I.U. School of Hospitality Management have little time to flambe anything with cherry sauce; they are too busy with classes in hospitality information systems, hospitality law and physical-plant management.

LEAD: IT IS a wreck, still elegant in parts, but definitely a wreck. Now the vacant, vandalized Woodycrest, a home for neglected children built in the Bronx in 1902 by the American Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless, seems on the road to repair, if not restoration.

LEAD: A man and a woman with homes in the New York metropolitan area have been arrested in Florida and charged as the organizers of a scheme in which more than 2,000 people across the country were cheated out of $21 million that they believed had been invested in precious metals, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.
LEAD: To Legislators I am angered that the County Board of Legislators is considering a bill that would ban smoking in public places and workplaces in the county.

LEAD: To the Editor: I recently returned from a bicycle trip through the Cotswolds and was interested to read Bruce Boucher's ''Stones of Wiltshire'' (Travel, Nov. 13) in which he describes the abbey at Malmesbury. I had spent part of an afternoon in this town while on the way to Bath.
LEAD: COUNTDOWN An Autobiography. By Frank Borman with Robert J. Serling. Illustrated. 448 pp. New York: Silver Arrow Books/ William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

LEAD: A security network that puts 39 buildings in radio contact with police dispatchers began operating on the Upper East Side of Manhattan on Thursday, and organizers hope the program will spread to other buildings in the area and to other parts of New York City.

LEAD: Danny Rivera, one of Puerto Rico's leading pop singers, declaimed ardent love songs Friday night at Carnegie Hall. He was performing a benefit concert for the literacy program of the National Puerto Rican Forum, an organization that works to improve employment opportunities for the economically disadvantaged.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''A producer's lifeblood is access to air time,'' said Av Westin, ''whether it is on a network station, on cable or on a cassette for which someone makes his own air time.''

LEAD: The petite woman is skiing swiftly down a slope somewhere in New England. Faster and faster she goes, when suddenly, to her horror, she is in midair and heading over a cliff. She cries for help; the words that tumble from her lips are spoken in a Boston accent. That really terrifies he and with that, Dr.

LEAD: The anti-African student riots of the last two weeks have opened a new window on China and the view isn't pretty: black students under attack . . . beaten by police . . . detained incommunicado . . . shocked on the genitals with cattle prods. The Chinese attitude toward blacks seems unapologetically racist.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Veron of White Plains of the engagement of their daughter Jane Elizabeth Veron to Andrew Todd Feldstein, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Murray Feldstein of Flagstaff, Ariz. The couple plan an August wedding.
LEAD: Westchester and Nassau Counties have agreed to team up to find alternatives to dumping sludge in the Atlantic Ocean, Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said this week.

LEAD: ITS TUITION compares with that of the best American universities. The people who run it are so determined that students get their money's worth that anyone absent without leave for more than 20 hours is automatically expelled. A four-year veteran of military life found it ''in some ways tougher than the Marine Corps.

LEAD: OVER the holidays I devised a great new party game, called ''Pass the Point and Shoot.'' The rules are simple. After spinning the camera on a table to see who goes first, you turn on its self timer and begin passing it around the table, to your left.

LEAD: THE CITY THAT NEVER WAS Two Hundred Years of Fantastic and Fascinating Plans That Might Have Changed the Face of New York City. By Rebecca Read Shanor. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: Viking. $35.

LEAD: China, Jordan and Qatar announced today that they will upgrade missions of the Palestine Liberation Organization in their capitals to embassies in recognition of the Palestinian parliament's declaration of an independent state.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: ALTHOUGH warehouse space tends to be tediously stable as a real estate investment in the metropolitan New York area, good fortune in 1988 was skewed sharply in favor of developers specializing in huge suburban warehouse complexes.

LEAD: TWO weeks before leaving office, the Reagan Administration was again tangling with the man America loves to hate - Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya. As they have done in the past, the Western European allies last week were sitting on the sidelines, wringing their hands and wondering whether the other shoe would drop.

LEAD: The return of Sean Burke in goal inspired the Devils to post their second consecutive victory, a 5-2 decision tonight over the Detroit Red Wings. It was the first time in almost a month that they won two in a row.
LEAD: Carlton Screen made two free throws with 11 seconds left to give undefeated Providence an 80-78 victory today over Connecticut in the Big East.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Tax Abatement for Condo

LEAD: THE SANDS OF TIME. By Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) Being Sidney Sheldon means never having to say you're writing. In his 10th book, ''The Sands of Time,'' Mr. Sheldon appears to have produced a literary version of painting by numbers. The story follows the fortunes of four nuns from an intensely austere Spanish convent as they wander through scenery that seems to have been imported from ''For Whom the Bell Tolls'' - in the company of some fugitive Basque nationalists.

LEAD: THE discovery of a Chinese restaurant with a style of its own is an auspicious way to welcome the New Year. Tiger Bowl, on the Post Road in Westport near the Fairfield line, boasts a chef and owner from Shanghai.

LEAD: Seventeen drug smugglers were hanged in Teheran and other Iranian cities during a nationwide anti-narcotics campaign in which 1,000 people were arrested and scores were killed in shootouts, official Iranian reports said today.

LEAD: The marriage of Suzanne Celia Kowalski, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon John Kowalski of Captiva Island, Fla., and Woodstock, Vt., to John Walker Kjorlien, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence John Kjorlien of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Osterville, Mass., took place yesterday at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.
LEAD: Alonzo Mourning scored 15 of his season-high 26 points in the decisive first half as Georgetown snapped Miami's five-game winning streak with a 112-79 victory today.
LEAD: Unions and clothing industry groups have filed a suit to block new Government regulations that would allow work at home in five industries, ending a 40-year ban.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The writer Andrei D. Sinyavsky likes to say that he resides in Paris but lives in Russia, a spiritual home built of literature, fellow emigres and surprisingly joyful memories of nearly six years in a Soviet prison camp.

LEAD: The new-year trade war between the United States and Europe got off to a halting start. The European Community, led by Jacques Delors of France, did impose its Jan. 1 ban on meat from animals treated with growth hormones. Washington, which says the ban is trade protectionism and not a health measure, did apply its 100 percent retaliatory tariff on $100 million worth of European food imports.

LEAD: My usual reaction to one of Barbara Klaus's articles is, ''Thank the household gods! I am not alone,'' and her piece on holiday cooking [ ''What It All Boils Down To,'' Long Island Sound, Dec. 4 ] evoked that consoling shock of recognition. I wonder if she is familiar with a further complication.

LEAD: To the Editor: Because I have tramped up and down the Abel Tasman National Park coastal track on New Zealand's South Island, I was delighted to see the article on that splendid part of the world (Travel, Nov. 20). But one small stone was left unturned.

LEAD: 'Mr. Sherwin called and asked me in summary and in substance: If they wanted to have Union Carbide close for a specific price for several days, could that be done? And I said, ''Yes.'' And Mr. Sherwin said, ''We'll make up any losses.'' . . . . In substance he said do you think you can close Union Carbide at 22 today, and I said, ''Sure, I think so.

LEAD: REMEMBER that crazy weekend in Vermont years ago when you first went skiing? You had a memorable time, even if you did crash into another skier and nearly fell off the lift. You were more daring in those days, but you didn't take up the sport. You're married now, have responsibilities, including a child or two, but you keep toying with the idea of getting the family on the slopes, schussing down trails together, relaxing in a lodge.

LEAD: What's it to be: gentility or barbarity? Television can give you either, as long as a demand is detected. On tonight's Masterpiece Theater presentation, ''A Wreath of Roses,'' we can find British actors bringing a familiar measure of good taste and, yes, exquisite manners to a violence-tinged tale of loneliness.
LEAD: It was payback time today for the Cleveland Cavaliers, who tied a National Basketball Association record by blocking 21 shots as they defeated the Knicks.

LEAD: DIFFERENCES in the interpretation of Suffolk County's policy of arrests in domestic violence have arisen since the recent murder of Elizabeth Croff by her estranged husband, William Croff, and his suicide.

LEAD: The engagement of Diane Marie Parsont to John Ehrman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Ehrman of East Sandwich, Mass., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Elinor S. Parsont of Port Chester, N.Y., and Robert E. Parsont of New Rochelle, N.Y. A March wedding is planned.
LEAD: The death of Emperor Hirohito may crystallize a national pride, self-confidence and search for Japanese values under way long before he took ill.

LEAD: THE EXTERIOR of a school can be deceptive. From the outside, two public schools, the Frederick J. Gaenslen School in Milwaukee, Wis., and the Mercer Junior-Senior High School in Trenton, N.J., look like any other new schools. They are both low-slung, modern brown brick structures. The American flag flies in front of the canopied entrances.

LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S call in September for an international conference to discourage the use of chemical weapons seemed like a straightforward idea. In December, a top State Department official said the conference would be ''an exercise in high rhetoric'' to revive a global taboo broken by the use of poison gas in the Iran

LEAD: Last week a Presidential panel released a report calling for a more vigorous national effort to develop superconducting materials. The report said the United States was falling behind Japan in commercializing this new technology. It recommended increased Government funding for research and establishing research consortia comprised of Government laboratories, industry and university researchers.

LEAD: In what appeared to be a display of something other than dazzling legal footwork, Ira D. London, the defense attorney in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg, said last week that his client would probably be found guilty and be sent to prison. Some legal experts called the remarks inappropriate and improper, and said they suspected that Mr.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Great Lakes have only recently been recognized for their potential to trigger fresh business development. After all, it was only 20 years ago that Lake Erie, which had been suffocating from a lack of oxygen, was declared ecologically dead. The problems with water quality in the Great Lakes are far from solved.

LEAD: To the Editor: Since insensitive tourists create a disproportionate amount of ill will for the traveling population, I am grateful for Arthur A. Witkin's advocacy of armchair travel (Letters, Nov. 20).

LEAD: Eastchester, N.Y. $335,000 104 North Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old colonial; fenced yard, paneled den, 1-car garage; taxes $4,651. New Rochelle, N.Y. $300,000 909 Webster Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 54-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, den, accessory apartment; taxes $3,600.
LEAD: Three people were killed Saturday in different drug-related incidents in New York City, the police said.
LEAD: ''HEY, lady, what number are you at?'' The young man tries to peek over my shoulder at the stack of numbered cards I'm holding. I tell him the number, he sighs noisily.

LEAD: A mile or two south of Pauillac, the famous wine town in the Bordeaux region of France, lies the renowned Chateau Pichon-Longueville, founded in the 17th century by Jacques de Pichon, Baron de Longueville and first President of the Bordeaux Parlement. The present, 19th-century neo-Gothic chateau, with its narrow black spires jutting up out of the vineyards, is along the

LEAD: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., Evelyn Morris Day, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney D. Day 3d of New York and Bryn Mawr, was married yesterday to David Paul Lasry, the son of Dr. and Mrs. James E. Lasry of La Jolla, Calif. The Very Rev. Arnold E. Mintz performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Elizabeth Ann Peterson and Michael Oliver Hill, both lawyers at the Department of Justice in Washington, were married yesterday at the Washington Cathedral. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by Canon Charles S. Martin.
LEAD: Adventure on a Shoestring is to conduct a walking tour of the Turtle Bay section of Manhattan at 3 P.M. today. The fee is $5; for meeting place, call 265-2663.

LEAD: To the Editor: If I wanted to boost tourism in Redneck City and was able to finagle a Travel section story on this hot spot, would you print the boast that my resort has no Jewish community? Would you run a promotion that implies ''Jew-Free Vacation!''? I hope not. And I would have hoped that you would not have done so on Dec.
LEAD: THE FIRST signs are in that it's going to be a particularly anxious season for high school seniors seeking admissions to the nation's most selective colleges.

LEAD: Somewhere between impressionism and post-Impressionism on the one hand and Fauvism and Cubism on the other, there is a niche that has no one name. What was done between 1888 and 1900 by the young Pierre Bonnard, the young Edouard Vuillard and their colleagues in the brotherhood known as the Nabis is difficult to identify in any existing major museum.
LEAD: PEOPLE going to the dentist may pay higher fees this year, because dentists are raising their fees to pay for protection against the AIDS virus.
LEAD: To the Editor: I would like to embellish on the ''Where to Eat'' section of ''What's Doing in London'' (Travel, Nov. 27).

LEAD: Among the problems that will be considered in coming weeks by the 101st Congress is how to pay the enormous costs of repairing and cleaning up the nation's crippled nuclear weapons production system. Last spring, the United States lost its remaining means of producing tritium and plutonium, essential ingredients of nuclear warheads, when the last reactors at the aging Savannah River Plant in South Carolina were shut down.
LEAD: There is a general practitioner in Florida who, while he may not realize it, is being watched from Connecticut. Those monitoring his performance do not like what they see.

LEAD: Rarely in any sport do two teams clash who have egos larger than the field boundaries on which they will play, who display confidence that oozes and overflows from owner down to equipment manager and who have the players to back any boast no matter how boisterous, no matter how brash.
LEAD: RAINBOW'S END Irish-Americans and the Dilemmas of Urban Machine Politics, 1840-1985. By Steven P. Erie. 345 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press.

LEAD: Marina Warner's article ''Lucian Freud: The Unblinking Eye'' (Dec. 4), full of compelling facts and rumors about Lucian Freud's personal life, is surely interesting, but what is important is to see and experience the intensity, depth and mastery of his work; there is no other painter like him. Only a self-portrait by Rembrandt or Van Gogh comes close to the profundity and honesty of Freud's ''Reflection.

LEAD: THE age-old debate continues. French or Chinese? Which is the world's premier cuisine? Residents of St. James don't have to choose; they have it all. Lotus East, an exceptional Chinese restaurant, recently opened approximately 500 crispy duck lengths from Mirabelle, one of Long Island's great French restaurants.

LEAD: WHEN Colorado proposed in 1987 to be the first state to mandate the use of high-oxygen gasoline to cut carbon-monoxide pollution, surveys showed that most of the affected motorists were angry or worried.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Select National Guard forces, including helicopter units and military police detachments, will be used increasingly this year in anti-drug activities. Defense Department officials hope one result will be to ease public pressure on the Air Force, Army and Navy to fight drugs.

LEAD: NO sooner had the new year begun when three of the state's 15 professional theaters got down to the business of opening their next plays - all on the same night. And within a month, three more productions will reinforce the new year's theater blitz in New Jersey.

LEAD: SITTING IN a movie theater a few years ago, Todd Gitlin had another of his frequent out-of-culture experiences. He was watching the movie ''The Big Chill,'' about a group of college friends who had abandoned their 1960's political and social commitment in favor of 1980's affluence and personal striving.
LEAD: Roy Marble's free throw with 11 seconds to play capped a 23-point performance, and Iowa beat North Carolina, 98-97, today.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Rachel Claire Heyman and Daniel Baruch Lidawer were married last evening at the Palmer House in Chicago by Rabbi Marc Berkson, an uncle of the bridegroom.

LEAD: After more than two years of planning, scientists have begun flights in specially equipped weather airplanes into the centers of fierce, unpredictable northeaster storms spawned in the Atlantic Ocean.

LEAD: After 20 years as head of the Italian track and field federation, Primo Nebiolo has decided to step down in the wake of a series of scandals. The 64-year-old industrialist, who also serves as president of the international track and field federation, has been criticized because of the scandals, which included the fixing of the men's long jump results at the 1987 world championships in Rome.
LEAD: Seton Hall never receives a warm welcome here. And tonight, the Pirates got another cold slap in the face.

LEAD: If you begin to peruse Tom Rosenbauer's ''Reading Trout Streams'' (Nick Lyons Books, $17.95) this winter, you'll spend less time flailing dead water when the fifth month's soft breezes are upon us.

LEAD: To the Editor: In the Nov. 20 Travel section there was a letter from Pilar Vico, director of public relations of the Spanish Tourist Office, regarding your article on the Dollar Abroad (Travel, Oct. 9).
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AN upheaval, bitter and factional, is reshaping the way apartments are bought and sold in Manhattan, forcing brokers to abandon traditional strategies in a marketplace lurching toward the future.

LEAD: LAST WEEK I RECEIVED a 'Grammatik III' word-processing program,'' writes Gertrude M. Webb of Waltham, Mass., ''and have been using it to analyze my own written work. I thought it might be fun to 'Grammatik-ize' a few paragraphs of your column. I'm passing the robot's comments along to you. Enjoy.''
LEAD: Seriousness has hit pop music big. Whether in the high-mindedness of Tracy Chapman or the industrial, mass-produced ditties of Tiffany, seriousness is the flavor of the day.

LEAD: In a soft market, smart money builds lavishly. That seems to be the lesson to be learned in Connecticut. While most of Fairfield County is enduring a residential sales slump, Greenwich is enjoying something of boomlet in mansion-building. Signaling the confidence builders have in the high end of the housing market, four large homes rising near one another there are all being built on a speculative basis.
LEAD: T. S. Eliot created a character who . . . pulled her stockings off With a frightful cry of ''Hauptbahnhof!''

LEAD: Q. Three years ago, we put siding on our house and had it stained, rather than painted. A couple of months ago, I noticed some gray spots on this siding, and they have now spread all over the outside. It seems to be some kind of mold, and scrubbing with Clorox got rid of it. This is harsh and seems difficult to do over the entire house.

LEAD: With his moviestar good looks, sultry New Orleans drawl and conviction that the jazz musician should be an entertainer as well as an instrumentalist, Harry Connick Jr. may have what it takes to inject the world of traditional jazz with a shot of Hollywood glamour.

LEAD: ''Mississippi Burning'' is now on trial. It's just 21 years and three months since the climax of the case that inspired the movie, when a group of white supremacists were put into the dock and charged with violating the civil rights of three young voter-registration workers. The means being murder, the violations were permanent.

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Bill Walsh is 8-4 in playoff games, 100-63 in his 10th season as the San Francisco 49ers' coach. He has won two Super Bowls, six National Conference West divisional titles and has coached the 49ers to their sixth consecutive playoff appearance.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James Giles Rittenberry of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Boughton Rittenberry to Walter M. Steppacher 4th, the son of Mr. Steppacher 3d and Margery D. Steppacher, both of Poughkeepsie. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: THE county's older residents have become a serious focus of interest for many of the area's cultural organizations. Theatrical and musical groups, as well as museums, are going beyond the standard discounted tickets for the elderly to seek new ways to attract them.

LEAD: THE surge in property values in the last few years has thrust hundreds of families into a position where Federal estate taxes are likely to be due at the time of death. Those taxes may turn out to be particularly steep if, in addition to a principal residence, there is a vacation home or investment property, such as a condominium, which may have skyrocketed in value, too.
LEAD: Quick Fiction

LEAD: IF you are visiting Mexico City and want to escape the bustle and noise for a day, there are several places not far from the capital that can be reached within two hours by car, for a picnic, a hike or a quiet day in the countryside.

LEAD: When auto racing finally discovered what other sports leagues already knew - that fans have an insatiable appetite for statistics - all sorts of performance barometers were created, from total laps led to fastest pit stops. But one statistic from each race is usually known only to the promoter and the Internal Revenue Service: total attendance.

LEAD: It is high time that the National Park Service's decision not to combat Yellowstone's lightning-caused fires was defended. The public's misguided furor over the natural calamity was fueled by election-year politics, local business interests and ignorance.

LEAD: The commercial opens with a shot of the actor Randy Quaid slouched in his rather messy apartment, holding a beer and a very large sandwich. He is complaining in a folksy way about a party he recently attended. ''They didn't even serve beer,'' he grouses. ''I oughta throw a real party - Texas style.
LEAD: Many of the judges who decide claims for Government disability and health insurance charge that they are being harassed by the Social Security Administration in an effort to reduce costs.
LEAD: Thaddeus Armie Eure, the nation's longest-serving state official, has ended a 52-year career as North Carolina's Secretary of State.

LEAD: I recently attended the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art, and, as in past visits, came away with an enjoyable and nourishing art experience. I am saddened to learn that the kind of exhibits and programs my family has come to expect may soon end.

LEAD: The video column on Dec. 25 incorrectly described the kind of machine on which tapes recorded in Super-VHS can be played. Such tapes cannot be played on standard VHS machines. However, tapes recorded in standard VHS can be played on Super-VHS machines.

LEAD: The San Francisco 49ers will see through the fog of Chicago, while no one at the game will see what is going on, and everyone will say how great it was to be there.

LEAD: AS the cold and flu season gets under way, Dr. Matthew L. Cartter, a medical epidemiologist with the preventable diseases division of the state's Department of Health Services, can expect to get busy sorting and analyzing reports of influenza in the state.

LEAD: WHEN the new high-temperature superconductors were discovered two years ago, they inspired visions of revolutionary products -trains that float above their tracks, supercomputers the size of grapefruits and perfectly efficient electric power lines.

LEAD: Around the display tables of university bookstores, ''the latest fashion from Paris'' does not refer to the length of skirts. It refers to a series of startling ideas and images out of the French mind. In paraphrase: That truth is castrating and humanism oppressive. That the ego is infinitely dissolvable.

LEAD: Pentagon lawyers, spending this weekend sorting through new disclosures in the investigation of military contracting, expect soon to announce steps against companies, consultants and Government officials involved in the case.
LEAD: Anthony Dilweg of Duke passed for three touchdowns to Michigan State's Andre Rison today as the East beat the West, 21-10, in the Hula Bowl.
LEAD: Big Stanley, the quickest 2-year-old sprinter in Florida last year, carried his speed a mile and an eighth today to win the $166,950 Tropical Park Derby by 1 3/4 lengths at Calder Race Course.
LEAD: Luke A. Baione, the former chairman of Crossland Savings Bank, the nation's 11th-largest savings institution, died of cancer Friday at his home in Staten Island. He was 67 years old.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz announced steps today to convince West Germany that a Libyan plant that the United States says is intended to produce chemical weapons was built with German help.

LEAD: IT was a curious thing to read some time ago that the Soviets have purposely been printing inaccurate maps of their motherland for years in order to bamboozle nosy foreigners. What amazed me most was the realization that I have never gotten a bum steer from an American road map.

LEAD: I'm a Christian and the Christmas described in ''Christmas Is Not My Holiday'' [ Westchester Opinion, Dec. 11 ] is not my holiday either. Like so many Christian and Jewish brethren, Christmas has been misinterpreted and mistreated for decades.

LEAD: Jill Caryn Norman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John C. Norman of Concord, Mass., was married there yesterday to Sami Hisham Fouad, the son of Dr. and Mrs. A. A. Fouad of Ames, Iowa. Naomi Cherny, a Justice of the Peace of Lexington, Mass., performed the ceremony at the Concord Academy Chapel.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Q. Three years ago, we put siding on our house and had it stained, rather than painted. A couple of months ago, I noticed some gray spots on this siding, and they have now spread all over the outside. It seems to be some kind of mold, and scrubbing with Clorox got rid of it. This is harsh and seems difficult to do over the entire house.

LEAD: FOR A BASKETBALL FAN, A VISIT TO the preseason training camp of any National Basketball Association team is instructive and perhaps a little deflating.

LEAD: Since the Giants are out of it, I really don't care. Anyway, I think the Cincinnati Bengals and the Chicago Bears will meet in the Super Bowl. It will be a great matchup between the Boomer and Jim (Taco Bell) McMahon. ADAM KRAMER Madison, Conn.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In his first major speech as the National Collegiate Athletic Association's executive director last January, Dick Schultz told a convention audience that intercollegiate athletics, in attaining unprecedented popularity and riches, had lost a measure of its integrity.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies on Dec. 25 about abortions performed solely because of the sex of the fetus attributed remarks by Dr. Michael A. Roth to Dr. Lawrence D. Platt. Dr. Platt does not perform abortions. It was Dr. Roth who said that doctors who decline to perform abortions for sex selection but perform abortions for other reasons ''are selectively picking out who they want to do them on and who not,'' and added, ''I haven't turned anybody down.

LEAD: ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' Andrew Lloyd Webber's $8 million megamusical, has been a consistent sellout since its opening last January, taking in more than $28 million at the box office. But it is not expected to reimburse its investors fully until the end of April - more than 15 months into its run.
LEAD: Some economists dream of writing textbooks, others of having equations named for them. Li Yining is more ambitious: He dreams of changing China.
LEAD: ''One of these days this will be a great city, if nothing happens to it.'' - Henry Adams, 1877.
LEAD: BONNIE PRINCE CHARLIE A Biography. By Carolly Erickson. Illustrated. 331 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.
LEAD: Libyan officials took journalists to this town today and drove them past a disputed chemical plant, but then refused to allow a visit to the grounds of the complex.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: He's certainly had his share of problems since leading the Atlantic Coast Conference in rushing with 1,250 yards as a freshman in 1986, but now Derrick Fenner says he's going to turn pro. After losing his scholarship to Gardner-Webb College because of academic deficiencies, Fenner, a transfer student who has not played in two years, said he had decided to waive his last years of collegiate eligibility and apply for the April draft.

LEAD: It is not surprising that United Airlines was the only major carrier to support deregulation when debates heated up in the late 1970's. The free-for-all competition created by deregulation, United figured, would enable it to consolidate its position as the undisputed king of the skies.

LEAD: WHEN I FIRST began teaching, I was invited to a workshop for new faculty. Like most people who teach at universities, I had spent a long time learning what to teach, but none learning how to teach it. Somehow, my university seemed to hope, a weekend spent with experienced members of its faculty would make up for that.
LEAD: ON most Tuesday evenings, children do their homework or settle down in front of television sets. But not at the Maguire home in New Canaan.

LEAD: I AM not suited to capitulation. It is not in my stubborn nature, nor was it in my lexicon until the question of sneakers arose. Up to that point sneakers (grimy, disreputable, gargantuan) were a way of life for my grandsons, and they could have them, I decided.

LEAD: Catherine Mary Gallaher, the daughter of Frank Dixon Gallaher of New York and the late Catherine Antoinette Gallaher, was married yesterday to William Anthony Mulligan, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank Bernard Mulligan of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Robert J. Verigni performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel at St.

LEAD: Ninety-four Haitians were rescued Friday after their 30-foot wooden sailboat ran onto rocks off the Florida Keys. Most of the Haitians have been detained until a judge decides whether they should be deported, the authorities said.

LEAD: ON THIS BRIGHT NOVEMBER morning the mood is anything but gloomy in Sikoroni, Mali, a mud-hut village of the vast West African savanna. The summer rains were generous for the first time in years, and today 10-foot sorghum stalks are bowed by heavy heads of grain. True to protocol, the chief of this village of 400 has called in the elders to exchange ceremonial words with arriving visitors.

LEAD: AT the turn of the century, summertime crowds of New Yorkers came by train to vacation in the seaside village of Stony Creek and the nearby Thimble Islands. The New Yorkers who now come to Stony Creek hope to buy part of it. Although the state's real estate market as a whole has cooled, Stony Creek, on Long Island

LEAD: A dangerous, virtually unquestioned assumption has taken hold of American management - that the best way to be competitive is to cut people, wages and salaries. This assumption has led to the trade deficits that are bankrupting America, and it is making our nation dependent on foreign powers for all manner of capital, products and - increasingly - technology.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on the Business Forum page last week by K. Graham Walker, president of the Dexter Corporation, dropped a phrase from a sentence about the company's goals. It should have read: ''My goals for Dexter are very clear - to renew the growth of earnings on a sustainable basis to equal at least two times the growth of real gross national product plus two percentage points.

LEAD: Now that Ronnie and Nancy are about to pack their Vuittons and ride off into the sunset - hey! they're headed in the opposite direction, away from the Sturm und Drang of Long Island's infamous Shoreham, that is - the parting shot is that it's now O.K. to license and open all nuclear stops.

LEAD: Investors began the new year preoccupied with the possibility of more corporate takeovers. And by the second trading day they had zeroed in on insurance stocks. LEAD: ''In a way, they're pretty touching. They all talked so much. Like they'd seen this movie and wanted to be in it.'' That's Sam, the 16-year-old son of Jake and Catherine, explaining his parents to the audience in Susan Miller's new play, ''For Dear Life,'' which opens Tuesday at the Public Theater.
LEAD: A statistical study determined last off season that for the previous four seasons Don Mattingly easily was the best player in the universe.

LEAD: The temptation is to tell the story like a morality play. Marcel Breuer's gray-granite Whitney Museum of Art, for two decades a Modernist fixture on Madison Avenue, is challenged by the upstarts of post-Modernism in the form of a design for a massive addition by Michael Graves. The addition would not so much expand the Breuer building as overwhelm it by merging it into a post-Modern collage.

LEAD: AS president of the New Jersey chapter of the National Association of the Lower Half and one of the founders of the organization, I want to express our organization's concern and annoyance over the criticism and harassments directed toward Dan Quayle for his scholastic record.
LEAD: Ben A. Frank has the air of a man under siege.
LEAD: Moses Malone scored 12 of his 26 points in the fourth quarter tonight, leading the Atlanta Hawks to a 103-93 victory over the Nets.
LEAD: A Namibian opposition leader has asserted that South Africa is creating a rebel Namibian group similar to groups aided in the past by South Africa in Mozambique and in Angola.
LEAD: OPERA IN DENVILLE
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Hannah Fryshdorf, the assistant executive director of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research in Manhattan, died of cancer Friday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 68 years old and lived in the Bronx.

LEAD: ExecutiveS of the Mentor Graphics Corporation, whose revenues far exceed those of their next-biggest rival, like to describe their competition in the computer-aided engineering industry as ''vanquished.'' But now, the forces that turned Mentor into the industry's No. 1 company may be working against it.

LEAD: The first public financing of political campaigns in New York State went into effect in New York City last week. It provides for the partial financing of primary and general-election races for municipal offices, similar to the national financing of Presidential candidates.

LEAD: A NEW EUROPE In 1992 twelve European nations will lift all restrictions on their citizens' ability to live and work in each others' countries. ''There will really be a united European nation,'' said Henry Gordan, moderator of a forum called ''Is World Federalism Inevitable?'' scheduled from 3 to 5:30 P.M.

LEAD: JUST over a year ago, the demise of social dance was reported in the newspaper. Apparently, in the age of health clubs and videocassette recorders, neither the physically fit nor the couch potato seemed inclined to cha-cha into the night. But it is now clear that this particular obituary notice was greatly exaggerated.

LEAD: NEARLY everybody seems to be getting into the act of making it easier for future generations of students to afford the rapidly rising college costs, which have more than doubled in the last decade.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: I'm responding to the article ''Mount Sinai Vote Due On High School Plan'' [ Oct. 30 ] .
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: SWEATY PALMS. Rapid pulse. Muscle spasms. All symptoms of families anticipating those tuition and expense bills that will start arriving the moment their child starts his college career. But parents needn't resign themselves to elevated blood pressure or a four-year liquidity crisis; all they need do is learn - before their child applies to college - what financing is available at each one, and how it is parceled out.

LEAD: The story of Wanda A., the battered woman who is now beginning a new life with her 7-year-old daughter in Harlem, has inspired many contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. An account of her struggle was published by The Times early last month.

LEAD: PARENTS HAVE LONG appreciated the Picasso-like brilliance of their own children's first finger-painting. But never before have they paid so much attention to the amateur-quality strokes of the child next door.

LEAD: Ever since birth control pills were first marketed in the United States in 1960, many doctors and women have found themselves torn between enthusiasm for the liberating contraceptive and fears about possible dangers from long-term use.

LEAD: There may be many composers who made a major mark in other fields than music, though the only ones who occur to me are Charles Ives (insurance), Paul Bowles (fiction) and Arnold Schoenberg (painting). Turn the coin the other way, however, and the situation changes: famous people from every sector of the nonmusical world seem impelled to dabble in composition.

LEAD: IN my newly independent circumstances, the salary from my full-time job barely covers my expenses - expenses being all those boring necessities like food, shelter, car maintenance and panty hose. So to make a little extra cash for the holidays, I pounded the pavement one day in November asking local shopkeepers if they needed Christmas help on Saturdays through the season.
LEAD: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica has asked that the summit meeting of Central American Presidents scheduled for Jan. 15 to 16 be postponed.

LEAD: Kate Bonanno, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bonanno of Demarest and Mantoloking, N.J., was married yesterday to Ian P. Turner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Turner of Brisbane, Australia. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: IT ONLY HURTS WHEN I LAUGH. By Stan Freberg. (Times Books, $19.95.) America's self-styled ''gray-flanneled kamikaze pilot,'' Stan Freberg wields the stiletto of satire against the smug and self-satisfied in popular culture and advertising. Mr. Freberg was the mad prophet of the airwaves, performing on radio, television and records his hilarious sendups of everything from ''Dragnet'' to the overcommercialization of Christmas.

LEAD: MY HIGH SCHOOL classmates completed four years of college last June, a date at which I too had completed four years of study. Their graduation was greeted by presents, parties and diplomas. Mine never occurred. What studies and studies and never graduates? The answer can be found in one word: autodidact.

LEAD: WHERE ONCE decisions about college life were made by administrators and faculty, the 60's changed all that. Today student representatives sit on panels and committees alongside faculty and officials. Where once students were seen and heard only in the classroom context, the 60's empowered them. Now their counsel is institutionalized, in an effort to avoid potential conflicts.
LEAD: PERHAPS more than a whimper, but there certainly wasn't much of a bang when the main thrust of the Government's case against Oliver L. North collapsed last week.
LEAD: SCIENCE AND THE UNBORN Choosing Human Futures. By Clifford Grobstein. Illustrated. 207 pp. New York: Basic Books. $18.95.

LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday called a Federal program that evicts innocent tenants from buildings seized in drug raids ''nuts'' and proposed that New York City oversee such buildings so occupants not charged with crimes can stay.

LEAD: IN A LETHAL version of Show and Tell, pupils are increasingly bringing guns to elementary school and accidentally maiming or killing classmates. While school districts nationwide grasp for solutions, officials in Dade County, Florida, unanimously approved the nation's first comprehensive ''gun awareness'' program.

LEAD: AS the Eiffel Tower Management Company prepared to mark the centenary of its Paris attraction this year, it envisioned a display so dazzling that the entire world would notice it. Space art, it was called. One proposal under study last summer was for a ring of light made of 100 silvery plastic spheres, each six feet in diameter, connected by tubing into a circle 15 miles in diameter.

LEAD: A system to match fingerprints in a few hours is to be introduced this year, New Jersey officials said this week. The $12.2 million Automated Fingerprint Identification System can compare prints from a crime scene with the 1.9 million in the state's file at the rate of 9,000 a minute, officials said.

LEAD: As is usually the case, many people ushered in the new year resolving to put their affairs in order. One good place to begin, experts say, is to work out a system to deal with accidents, serious illness or other emergencies.

LEAD: Cablevision has been running recent TV commercials portraying ''the man on the street'' in an interview situation. A woman claims she is not a sports fan, so why should she be expected to pay an increased rate if MSG (the Madison Square Garden network) was incorporated into the basic service? Furthermore, why should someone who is not a Ranger or Knick fan have to pay for someone else's pleasure?

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William J. O'Connor of Convent Station, N.J., and Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Mary O'Connor to Michael V. McKay, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. McKay of Hempstead, L.I. The couple plan to marry in April.

LEAD: The silent run was accelerating at the First RepublicBank Corporation's offices in Texas - silent because retail customers were not lining up on the streets. This run was being fueled by large institutions, including other banks, racing to electronically withdraw uninsured deposits. Alarm bells went off around Washington, as the nation's top bank regulators met in an emergency session.

LEAD: IT'S becoming more and more expensive to get rid of something nobody wants: garbage. Many garbage haulers say they are considering raising their prices 20 percent or more this year, as towns charge more at disposal centers to cover their own costs and as recycling requirements make handling garbage more complicated and expensive.
LEAD: YES, Gigi, they really are going to build a shopping mall and movie theaters on 161st Street in the South Bronx.
LEAD: In his loafers, cable-knit sweater and chinos, Marv Levy looks like a middle-aged poet.

LEAD: For many of the Great Lakes region's downtowns, which have been hurt by the move to the suburbs as well as by a persistent industrial image, waterfront redevelopment is considered risky at best - especially since private developers have generally preferred more populated cities and warmer climates.

LEAD: IF it's orange, it must be Wednesday. Like soldiers they line both sides of the street as far as the eye can see. Each week the bright-orange trash cans of Smithtown's recycling program stand neatly at curbside.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William T. Hocart of Essex Fells, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jody Ann Hocart to Gregory Michael James, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John James of Glen Rock, N.J., and Fairfield, Conn. A spring wedding is planned.

LEAD: Troops used tear gas and fired shots in the air to break up a group of women protesting the compulsory draft of young men in poor neighborhoods, witnesses said. Reynaldo Blanco, head of the independent El Salvador Human Rights Commission, said 20 people were detained at the demonstration Friday outside the barracks of the 1st Infantry Brigade.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH the rising number of AIDS cases on Long Island has prompted concern among businesses, its impact in the workplace is hard to gauge because of the continuing stigma attached to AIDS and the reluctance of most affected employees to admit that they have the dreaded virus.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Weingarten of New York and New Milford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Joy Weingarten, to Scott Ryan Singer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Singer of Huntingdon Valley, Pa.
LEAD: From a farm on Long Island to Notre Dame to the Red Sox to baseball immortality in Cooperstown, N.Y.

LEAD: THE Kasbah des Oudaia in Rabat stands as it has for centuries, aloof atop the cliffs overlooking the Atlantic and the Bou Regreg River, keeping watch over the mouth of the river, the inland plain and the little boats ferrying people to Sale, Rabat's gleaming white sister city on the right bank of the river.

LEAD: THE death of Lisa Steinberg and the trial of her adoptive father led to an increase in reports of child abuse on Long Island during 1988, although authorities think that the incidence of abuse has probably not risen.
LEAD: On this last day of the era called Showa, or Enlightened Peace, this nation cried, prayed, skied, shopped and had its hair done.

LEAD: The 101st Congress will likely challenge the Bush administration to spend less overseas to defend our allies and more to defend our own economic future. The alternative is to witness a continued erosion not only in commercial competitiveness but in our military-industrial base as well.

LEAD: Weill Recital Hall is regularly visited by ensembles from universities across the country; that is one of the traditional ways for faculties to declare themselves to the larger musical community. Not many of them, though, are assisted in their programs by one of New York's best-known chamber groups.
LEAD: Troops backed by combat helicopters stormed a military garrison today held by Muslim gunmen and ended a three-day standoff in which at least 17 people were reportedly killed.
LEAD: The highly decorative and accessorized bathing suits shown on these pages are mostly for making a splash. Suits strictly for swimming, however, are still primarily maillots.

LEAD: TAKEOVER specialists searching for companies with undervalued assets are increasingly noticing a type of publicly owned companynot typically thought of as takeover play: closed-end stock funds. Indeed, as corporate acquisitions remove more equity from the stock market, investment professionals believe that acquirers will become increasingly interested in closed-end funds, especially those whose shares sell at sharp discounts to their net asset value.

LEAD: Elizabeth Duncan Koontz, the first black president of the National Education Association and director of the Women's Bureau in President Nixon's Department of Labor, died Friday after a heart attack at her home in Salisbury, N.C. She was 69 years old.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis, who spent much of 1988 in an unsuccessful bid to cut short his third term as Governor of Massachusetts by becoming President, announced last week that he will not seek a fourth term. Mr. Dukakis noted that he will have served for 12 years when his current term ends in 1990, and said that it would then be time to ''pass the mantle of leadership to new hands.

LEAD: PEDESTRIANS strolling through the West Rock Tunnel of the Merritt Parkway in New Haven on the day of its dedication, the stones of Bulkeley Bridge in Hartford being set by hand, and even a worker loitering by a portable latrine as construction of the Hartford Armory went on all around him - such sights as these tracing the history of Connecticut's public buildings, highways and bridges are displayed in a new exhibit at the Connecticut Museum of History.

Peters of Massapequa, L.I. The Rev. Cristobal Figuero performed the ceremony.

LEAD: President Reagan will submit a final budget Monday that largely suits George Bush's priorities but still leaves the President-elect opportunity to put his own stamp on the Government.

LEAD: ACCORDING to the theater calendar, the beginning of the year corresponds to the middle of the season. By January, one can be certain that theater schedules will have changed since the first announcements of September. Some shows have been postponed or canceled; others have been switched to different time slots.

LEAD: A smokestack economy, polluted lake water and icy winters are tough negative images to fight. But after suffering years of national derision, civic leaders in such Great Lakes cities as Cleveland, Buffalo and Detroit are turning to idled industrial waterfronts to bring back residents and attract new visitors.

LEAD: Jim Valvano, the North Carolina State basketball coach and athletic director, said he was never interviewed for a book scheduled for publication next month that, according to a published report, accuses him of running a corrupt basketball program on its jacket.

LEAD: Infertility is not exactly a funny subject, but the cast now making a film that tackles this problem is striving for laughs as well as tears.

LEAD: In this city where Mayor Daley remains as revered as George Halas, where politics inspires as much devotion as the Bears, the pro football politicians had it all figured out. They knew why Mike Tomczak, despite a damaged left shoulder, and not Jim McMahon would be the Bears' starting quarterback today in the National Conference championship game.

LEAD: In a room just down the hall from the State Secretary of Transportation's office and a few floors down from the headquarters for Boston's subway, Paul Tucker spends most of his days writing a book about Claude Monet's paintings of the 1890's.

LEAD: IMELDA: Steel Butterfly of the Philippines. By Katherine Ellison. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) Katherine Ellison is part of the Pulitzer Prize-winning San Jose Mercury News team that in 1985 traced the money of Ferdinand E. Marcos, then President of the Philippines, around the globe. In ''Imelda,'' she is on the track of bigger game - the soul of the country as well as of her subject, Imelda Marcos, the President's wife, his political equal and - but for the explosion of long-simmering revulsion with their staggering corruption - his potential successor.

LEAD: ''We will do everything in our power to prevent German nationals, citizens of the Federal Republic of Germany and German companies from cooperating in a foreign country in the production of chemical weapons.'' - Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. [ 1:6. ]

LEAD: Walter Cronkite had always been more comfortable delivering the news than making it. But something was gnawing at him, and when the opportunity arose one evening not long after George Bush was elected President, Mr. Cronkite made a speech in defense of liberal values that surprised people more than he could have imagined.

There are crime, drugs, overcrowded prisons and stagnant areas of dire poverty - all largely products of the state's big cities, a realm far removed from the Connecticut of Currier & Ives.

LEAD: Blue Point $125,000 19 Smith Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, partial basement, porch; taxes $2,100. Bayport $160,000 930 Division Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 1-year-old ranch; basement, decks, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000.

LEAD: Joseph Saleh called the Broadway basement where he is creating Manhattan's newest downtown moviehouse ''a miracle.'' Here was cheap space - less than $20 a square foot - where zoning permits a cinema. It even seemed to have been built with the multiplex in mind: big at 20,000 square feet - ''like a football field'' - and tall with 26-foot ceilings.

LEAD: Maria Jose Britto Pereira Lanari, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roberto Lanari of Rio de Janeiro, was married there yesterday to John FitzGerald Foy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. W. Foy of Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Adilson performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Brejal Chapel.
LEAD: I HAVE MOSTLY BLAND recollections of the professors in my seven years of higher education. Two I recall vividly, because -though it was not their intention - they terrified me.

LEAD: Casts seem to be shifting more rapidly in the later years of the James Levine regime at the Metropolitan Opera than they did earlier on, and the four newcomers to Wednesday's cast of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro'' served to underscore that instability.

LEAD: ''I'VE ALWAYS BEEN INFLUENCED by landscape,'' says Kenneth Frazelle, a 33-year-old composer who lives in Winston-Salem, N.C. And though such a sentiment borders on a romantic cliche, it would appear that for Frazelle, the hills are alive with the sound of music. His impromptu, crayon-and-pencil representations of the musical ideas he derives from the outdoors initiate his compositions.
LEAD: The scholastic legacy of the 60's, its scholars and multimedia courses.

LEAD: FAMILY OF SPIES Inside the John Walker Spy Ring. By Pete Earley. 385 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95.

LEAD: To the Editor: The Argentina Tourist Information Office listed in your article on Argentina (Travel, Oct. 2) is a travel agency, not a government office. The official Argentina Tourist Office in the United States is the Argentina National Tourist Office, 12 West 56th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019; 212-603-0443.

LEAD: Jean K. Dexheimer, an associate at the law firm of Davis Hoxie Faithfull & Hapgood in New York, and Paul M. Dudek, an associate at the New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, plan to marry in April.

LEAD: What ''Mississippi Burning'' intends is clear from a scene disturbingly like one in ''A World Apart,'' a film set against the black struggle with apartheid in South Africa. In the closing scenes of ''A World Apart,'' the camera's eye comes in on a crowd of blacks assembled to bury one of their own murdered by the South African security police - and settles on two whites in that assembly.

LEAD: Ask a fan where to find the greatest array of sports figures assembled in one place this month and the guess would probably be the Super Bowl. The guess would be wrong. No star or stars will shine brighter than the collection of sluggers who will sign autographs at Tropworld Casino and Entertainment Resort in Atlantic
LEAD: In an effort to reach the sophisticated buyer who is hard to impress with lists of extras, the Nissan Motor Company is relying on an unusual advertising campaign for one of its newest lines.

LEAD: A group of second graders at Public School 221 in Little Neck, Queens, raised $360 for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. They did it by selling toys, games and books to other classes in the school.

LEAD: In the basement of the Capitol an investigation of Representative Jim Wright grinds toward its conclusion. Around him, allies advise a cautious, let-George-do-it-first approach in discussing the budget deficit with the new President. But anyone expecting a weakened or wary Speaker finds that Mr. Wright is not easily derailed.

LEAD: Ever since Ivan Lendl left to play several tournaments in Australia a few weeks ago, he has had his secretary, Diane Nagy, send him daily messages about the doings of the Hartford Whalers of the National Hockey League.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: There is nothing quite like Mazowsze. The Polish folk ensemble began its American tour - the fourth since its founding in 1948 - with a typically rich and heartwarming performance on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

LEAD: PENCHINA, SELKOWITZ INC., a tiny New York agency known for its work for Burroughs computers, was acquired on Friday by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, the $2.5 billion advertising giant. Executives of the agency will receive an undisclosed amount of cash and stock in D.M.B.&B., and a percentage of their agency's profits.
LEAD: The Bush administration's first real foreign policy test is likely to come in the Mideast.

LEAD: Backer Spielvogel Bates has cemented its dominant position in Europe's ''Nordic region'' with its agreement to acquire four agencies in Norway and Sweden from Scan Partner, a marketing communications company based in Oslo.

LEAD: With her brown hair in a ponytail and heart-shaped earrings in her ears, 19-year-old Vivian Hernandez Caballero of the Cuban women's antiaircraft battery is already preparing for a long-awaited reunion this week with her boyfriend in Havana.
LEAD: In the end, it was hitting, tackling and running that won for the Bengals today and sent them on their way to Super Bowl XXIII.
LEAD: Rival Shiite Muslim militiamen fought their fiercest battles in a year of confrontation in southern Lebanon today, and the police said 28 people were killed and 51 wounded.

LEAD: The explosive issue of ''who is a Jew'' has been removed from the immediate political agenda in Jerusalem, but in the United States the debate continues to alter the relations of Jews with Israel and each other fundamentally, many American Jews say.

LEAD: The Chicago Sun-Times's agreement to acquire a second major suburban newspaper chain is a sign that the daily is on a firmer financial footing than it appeared to be a few months ago, despite a continuing decline in circulation, industry analysts say.
LEAD: These organizations can provide information about outdoor workshops, outings and lectures.
LEAD: A 16-month-old boy has become the newest resident of a Brooklyn block, but his reception by most of his neighbors has been as frigid as the recent weather. The child has AIDS.

LEAD: ''Tradition on Ice'' might be one of the most stirring hockey videos ever made. It's a 60-minute, 62-year retrospective that includes rare and dramatic early footage of Ranger action, interviews with Ranger stars from Murray Murdoch to Phil Esposito, and an almost nonstop narrative gush by David Perry.

LEAD: The best came last on Friday evening at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace, where the Mary Anthony Dance Theater Foundation presented work by Bertram Ross and Nai-Ni Chen. Nothing in the program quite measured up to Mr. Ross's ''Raymond,'' the bittersweet portrait of Isadora Duncan's addlepated brother, which closed the program.
LEAD: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Detroit today ordered 30 parishes in this city to close in the coming months and gave 25 others a year to improve their status or suffer the same fate.

LEAD: The unlikely is commonplace in television movies and dramas. Even the Hallmark Hall of Fame recently offered Anthony Hopkins as a Frenchman who is arrested by the Nazis during World War II, gives away his possessions to save his life, and then returns after the war to be a servant in his own chateau, completely unrecognized by anyone in the village.
LEAD: * Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston, a publishing company, named Robert Baker to the newly created post of chief operating officer and executive vice president.

LEAD: In Manhattan, new emporiums where the public can play pool and billiards are opening faster than the city's massage parlors closed.
