LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association opened its 83d convention today with the executive director reaffirming the healthy condition of intercollegiate athletics and urging members to create more executive-level opportunities for women and members of ethnic minorities.

LEAD: Skiing Schneider Wins Again: Vreni Schneider continued her string of successes yesterday, winning a World Cup women's slalom in Mellau, Austria, for her third triumph in three days and her ninth of the season. Tamara McKinney of Squaw Valley, Calif., who led after the first heat, straddled a gate in the second run and was disqualified.

LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch's budget proposal for the next fiscal year, which is expected to call for service cuts and tax increases, will include $60 million in additional spending on child-abuse programs and education.

LEAD: Treasury financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. On Wednesday, the Treasury will auction $7 billion of seven-year notes, followed on Thursday by the regular monthly sale of one-year bills.

LEAD: FORTUNATELY for the Bengals and the stern muse of the dance, Ickey Woods, the rookie with the wacky hoofs, saved his best choreography for the playing field yesterday afternoon in the American Conference championship game.

LEAD: Leslie Lowenbraun, an associate at the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, and Jeffrey H. Weitzman, an associate at the New York law firm of Rogers & Wells, were married in New York yesterday at the Union League Club by Rabbi Donald R. Gerber.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''Tajemstvi'' (''The Secret''), the next-to-last of Bedrich Smetana's eight operas, was composed under the strain of deteriorating health, financial troubles and progressive deafness. ''I'm afraid my music is not cheerful enough,'' he wrote to his librettist in 1877, ''but when I see only poverty and misery ahead of me all enthusiasm for my work goes.
LEAD: A doctor who had gone to work on her day off Saturday was found yesterday beaten to death in her office at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, the police said.

LEAD: In preparation for 1992, when European trade barriers will be eliminated, the Douwe Egberts/Sara Lee Corporation, a European subsidiary of the American consumer-products giant, has consolidated its advertising, currently at 30 local agencies, in B.B.D.O. Europe, HDM and Saatchi & Saatchi. A B.B.D.O.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: After the game, Randy Wood sat ruminatively in a locker-room corner tonight and held an ice pack to his left knee as all around him his teammates used words like ''disaster'' and ''awful'' to describe themselves and their losing ways.

LEAD: SPORTS like skiing, hiking, snowshoeing, climbing and snowmobiling can turn cold and snow into a bounty of winter fun. But you have to know when to be cautious. Park trails and mountainsides are a lure for day trips and weekend excursions. The risks are small if you go well prepared. If you dress properly, take along the right food and recognize the signs of hypothermia and frostbite, you have little to fear and much to gain.
LEAD: Halrose benefited from a scorching early pace to beat Jabotinsky by a long neck and win the $57,950 Spectacular Bid Stakes today before a record opening-day crowd of 26,517 at Gulfstream Park.

LEAD: Though they cheered for the proposed Federal equal rights amendment, more than 1,100 women representing 61 organizations focused more on trade deficits, job training, child care and other economic issues at a national conference this weekend.
LEAD: The owner of this town's only theater said today that she would not show the film ''Mississippi Burning,'' a fictionalized account of the deaths here 25 years ago of three civil rights workers.
LEAD: Only one parent, Luis Santiago, was waiting in the bitter cold outside the Prince George Hotel in Manhattan the other afternoon when the first yellow school bus rumbled down East 28th Street.

LEAD: Partners & Shevack is focusing on consumers' inability to distinguish between brands of memo pads in its first campaign for a new client, Ampad. In trade ads for the paper-pad manufacturer based in Dayton, Ohio, the agency eschews serious discussions of rips and runs in favor of whimsy.

LEAD: ''In the Heat of the Night'' has emerged as one of the few hits of the new television season, and its success can be attributed at least in part to the active role taken by the series' star, Carroll O'Connor.

LEAD: A front-page picture caption in some copies yesterday, based on information from The Associated Press, misidentified the men with Emperor Akihito of Japan. From the right were Akihito; Crown Prince Hiro; Akihito's brother, Prince Hitachi, and a cousin, Prince Tomohito.

LEAD: An investor group led by Paul S. Levy, one of two contenders to buy Allegheny International Inc., is well on its way to acquiring control of another company operating in bankruptcy, McLean Industries. Although the two companies do not seem to realize it, their destinies could be intertwined.

LEAD: A survey of members of the college class of 1992 shows that more are smoking, that they may be losing interest in business careers and that they overwhelmingly favor mandatory testing for AIDS and drugs.
LEAD: A foreign investor has shaken things up at the Rangaire Corporation in Cleburne, Tex.

LEAD: An American and a Canadian have been ordered out of China because they were working for a United States-based dissident organization, the official New China News Agency said today. Huang Wencheng, an American citizen, and Huang Han, Canadian, were accused of carrying out ''illegal activities'' for the New York-based Chinese Alliance for Democracy since they arrived in China as tourists, it said.
LEAD: That symbol of the Northern suburbs, the commuter rail line, has come to South Florida. But getting the track and the trains was easy. Now comes the hard part: getting people to ride it.

LEAD: Bob Kerrey's Vietnam War buddies attended his inauguration as Governor of Nebraska in 1983 and they watched last Tuesday as Mr. Kerrey, a Democrat, was sworn as the junior Senator from Nebraska.

LEAD: At first, it was a quick death for the Chicago Bears. They blinked, and swoosh, there went Jerry Rice blazing past them into the end zone. Then it became a slow death for the Bears. LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that the Reagan Administration did not try to thwart Lawrence E. Walsh, the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra case, from pursuing any avenue of inquiry in the matter.
LEAD: BILLED as the oldest affair of its kind in the world, the 79th New York National Boat Show at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan opens Saturday and continues through Jan. 22.

LEAD: Kitty Carlisle Hart, the chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts, will read selections from her autobiography, ''Kitty,'' as well as from Moss Hart's autobiography, ''Act One,'' and other works, on Jan. 19 at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 50th Street. The reading will take place from 12:30 to 1:30 P.M.; admission is free.

LEAD: Authorities in the Armenian capital of Yerevan have arrested a dozen more Armenian protest leaders in the latest crackdown on nationalist dissent in the republic, a Yerevan resident said tonight.

LEAD: After steadily improving a nearly bankrupt system of trains and buses through most of the 1980's, N.J. Transit is losing riders, revenue and some of its hard-earned reputation in what some commuters say is a rerun of the bad old days.

LEAD: One cold afternoon last week, the Swedish baritone Hakan Hagegard emptied the living room of the West Side apartment where he is staying and hauled in two enormous packing trunks. The trunks contained pieces of a scale model of the Hakan Hagegard Music Center, a rehearsal space, recording studio and artists' retreat the singer hopes to build in Brunskog, Sweden - a project for which Mr.

LEAD: Even before taking office on Feb. 2, Carlos Andres Perez, the President-elect of Venezuela, has begun trying to forge a more unified Latin American approach to the region's foreign debt problem.

LEAD: BACK in 1981, when Priscilla Clarkson was a new faculty member at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst and the ink was still wet on her Ph.D. diploma, she was fascinated with studying exercise and its relationship to muscle strength and fatigue.

LEAD: An insider-trading investigation involving the acquisition of Triangle Industries by Pechiney S.A., the French aluminum company, grew last week when investigators linked a friend of President Francois Mitterrand, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., and several stockbrokers in France and Luxembourg to the affair.

LEAD: Iraq and other Arab nations said today that a call for a comprehensive ban on chemical weapons should be linked to a similar stand on nuclear weapons in light of Israel's reported possession of nuclear arms.

LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Consumer Credit Nov. Tuesday Wholesale Trade Nov. Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Producer Prices Dec.

LEAD: In a move certain to increase the competition in the fastest-growing portion of the computer industry, the Digital Equipment Corporation will introduce tomorrow a range of aggressively priced work stations and personal computers.

LEAD: THE Federal judge presiding at the GAF Corporation stock-manipulation trial, Mary Johnson Lowe, is expected to decide this week whether to declare a mistrial because of charges of prosecutorial misconduct.

LEAD: ''The Unbearable Lightness of Being,'' the film version of the novel by Milan Kundera, was voted the best film of 1988 yesterday by the National Society of Film Critics, a 39-member group that includes critics from New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and other cities. Philip Kaufman was voted best director for his work on that film.
LEAD: It begins officially Monday - the collision of political wills, national priorities, parochial interests and slippery arithmetic otherwise known as the budget process.

LEAD: IT is a back alley of Wall Street that normally gets little attention from the press or prosecutors, involving small companies and stocks that shoot into the stratosphere, only to fall back to the ground. But although the companies are small, the losses for investors can be very large. Sometimes, the losers are also the owners of family businesses that have been acquired by high-flying companies.

LEAD: More than a dozen private school and passenger bus companies in Brooklyn are under investigation for offering bribes to an undercover inspector to overlook possible safety violations, law-enforcement officials say.

LEAD: President-elect George Bush's economic policy makers are preparing proposals to encourage American businesses to concentrate more on productivity and growth and less on quick profits, Mr. Bush's advisers in the Treasury Department report.
LEAD: The Soviet Union announced today that it would start to destroy its stocks of chemical weapons.
LEAD: An Israeli-appointed Palestinian official in the West Bank was stabbed by masked youths early this morning in the second such attack in two days.
LEAD: Cam Neeley of the Bruins flying through the air after he tripped over Robert Picard of the Nordiques last night in the first period in Quebec. Boston won, 4-2. (AP)

LEAD: IN the warmth of the 49ers' locker room, Guy McIntyre, their offensive right guard, was smiling as he pulled his white ''62'' jersey over his shoulder pads.''Not against the Bears,'' he was saying to two teammates. ''Not in the frigid cold.''

LEAD: Pacific Resources Inc., an oil refiner and marketer, has agreed to merge with a subsidiary of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, the largest public company in Australia, the two companies announced yesterday.
LEAD: After a five-way review, the 120 Greater Pittsburgh Buick Dealers group tapped David Deutsch Associates as its agency.

LEAD: Fujio Mitarai, who helped to make Canon cameras and business machines leading sellers in the United States, is going back to the parent company in Japan after 23 years -an unusually long stay here for a Japanese executive.
LEAD: An obituary headline in some editions on Friday about one of the first women to become a leader in concert management misidentified her. She was Hattie Clark Rosenbaum.

LEAD: The Osipov Balalaika Orchestra, returning to the United States for the first time in 12 years, will present a benefit for Armenian earthquake relief at Carnegie Hall on Jan. 25 at 8 P.M. The Osipov, directed by Nikolai Kalinin, will be joined by the dancers and singers of the Babkina Folk Ensemble and two Bolshoi Opera soloists, Galina Borisova and Vladimir Malchenko.

LEAD: There have been times in recent months when Harry De Soi wasn't sure if waste handlers would accept the toxic heavy metals left over from his electroplating business in Franklinville, N.J. Mr. De Soi had visions of being fined by the Government and being labeled a polluter, as have so many other people in his business.
LEAD: A political storm was gathering today over reports that Finance Minister Shimon Peres's austerity budget is less austere than it first appeared.

LEAD: Jean Willes, an actress who appeared in films like ''Elmer Gantry'' and television series like ''Perry Mason'' and ''Bonanza'' in her 30-year career, died of liver failure Tuesday. She was 65 years old.

LEAD: On the elm-lined streets of Washington's Fourth Ward, where residents live in neat brick houses and dutifully tend their azaleas, many people now hurry indoors and dare not stroll the way they used to.

LEAD: Nathan G. Finkelstein, the chairman of the board of Glemby International, which operates more than 1,600 beauty salons around the world, died of lung cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen in early trading today, while share prices set a record on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in the first day of trading after Emperor Hirohito's death early Saturday.

LEAD: After teams lose important football games, their players are often stunned or angry or sullen or tight-lipped. After the San Francisco 49ers soundly defeated the Bears, 28-3, today to advance to the Super Bowl, most of the Bears were calm and contained.
LEAD: This was not the first time Tim McGee and Derrick Burroughs had met. Just the most significant.

LEAD: Hundreds of children in Louisiana's foster care program have been neglected by the system intended to protect them, the American Civil Liberties Union contends in a report to be issued this week.

LEAD: A report in the Sports World Specials column of SportsMonday on Jan. 2 about the Ed Block Courage Award misstated the reason Tom Baldwin of the New York Jets was nominated for the award. He was nominated because of his fight against alcoholism.

LEAD: Cyanide was found in the home of a teen-ager who lapsed into a coma after eating yogurt tainted with the poison, a newspaper reported this weekend.
LEAD: DID you know that you can experience one of winter sport's ultimate fantasies, taking a turn down the Olympic bobsled course at Lake Placid, N.Y.?

LEAD: The nation awoke to a new imperial epoch on Sunday, the Heisei era of Achieving Peace. But along with the celebrations came stark black-and-white images of Japanese soldiers invading Manchuria, assassinating prime ministers, bombing Pearl Harbor and hoisting the Rising Sun flag next to Nazi swastikas.

LEAD: The Export-Import Bank, a Government agency making below-market-value loans to buyers of American exports, has decided to suspend new lending operations as a result of the Reagan Administration's budget squeeze, bank officials said.

LEAD: QUESTION: Once again this past season, the two Canadian major league teams, Montreal and Toronto, failed to have a pitcher win 20 games. Have the Expos or Blue Jays ever had a 20-game winner?

LEAD: At least 37 people were killed and about 75 others were injured Sunday when a British domestic airliner crashed near a major highway in central England while trying to make an emergency landing, the police said.

LEAD: * Swiss economic growth in 1989 and a more restrictive monetary policy could combine to push interest rates higher, the Swiss National Bank said. In its latest quarterly report, the bank reiterated its projection that real gross domestic product growth would be 2 percent this year, with inflation between 2 percent and 3 percent.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The hottest product at this year's Consumer Electronics Show is one of the oldest - the television set. So strong has the demand been for television sets around the world that there is now a growing shortage.

LEAD: Tony Bennett, as much as any other pop singer of his generation, symbolizes continuity in a city where it often seems nothing was meant to last. His mixture of streetwise toughness, starry-eyed romanticism and punchy sincerity also gives musical expression to a time-honored image of New York as a place where you have only to scratch someone's hardened surface to discover an unexpected reservoir of integrity, loyalty and decency.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In an American Conference championship game devoid of newfangled offensive gimmicks, the Bengals chugged along on the old-fashioned running of Ickey Woods today to beat the Buffalo Bills and advance to Super Bowl XXIII.
LEAD: So far, the only predictable thing about the Big East has been its unpredictability.

LEAD: Last spring, Brenda Vaughan, a 29-year-old Washington woman, pleaded guilty to forging about $700 worth of checks. It was her first offense and one that would normally have brought probation. But because Ms. Vaughan was pregnant and tests showed she had used cocaine, the judge sent her to jail until the date the baby was due, saying he wanted to protect her fetus from drug abuse.

LEAD: IT is virtually impossible to be around booksellers or publishers very long without realizing that they generally respect each other, taking considerable pride in their roles as disseminators of the written word.

LEAD: Channel 9 is showing a rerun tonight. But it's the kind of program that cannot be repeated too often.

LEAD: Job security replaced wage increases in the 1980's as the top contract goal of many American labor unions. But with the decade almost over, the unions have had precious little success in winning employment guarantees.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY President-elect Bush's economic team is preparing proposals to encourage businesses to concentrate more on productivity and growth and less on quick profits, Treasury officials say. The new administration hopes to confront problems like the decline of savings rates, the relative erosion of America's standard of living and lackluster investment in long-term growth.

LEAD: The Palisades Interstate Park Commission governs one of the region's loveliest roads. It runs along the base of the Palisades from just north of the George Washington Bridge to Alpine, N.J., offering intimate Hudson River views and access to marinas and picnic grounds. The road, however, is barely two lanes wide and full of curves, and despite repeated requests from bicycling groups, the commission considers it unsafe for simultaneous use by autos and bikes.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Clippers lost another road game last night. They were thrashed by the Knicks, 134-100, at Madison Square Garden in a game that served as a morale builder for Johnny Newman and Gerald Wilkins, who had been in shooting slumps. The 34-point margin was the largest this season for the Knicks, who brought their record to 21-11.

LEAD: Nearly four months after a spontaneous popular uprising against 26 years of eccentric military autocracy was crushed by the armed forces, the people of Burma have settled into a sullen and angry watchfulness made worse by economic hardship and continued repression. Promised elections seem ever more remote.

LEAD: On a day when chipping into the cup from off the greens became commonplace, Steve Jones used a chip shot to help him win the MONY Tournament of Champions by three strokes over David Frost and Jay Haas.

LEAD: President Reagan's final budget completes a transforming chapter in American fiscal history. With eight years of deficits that will have tripled the national debt, this President, who wants a constitutional amendment to forbid all deficits, has made huge deficits acceptable. Thanks to him, balancing the books in future years will be harder than ever.
LEAD: Many Congressional protests against plans to close military bases so far seem to have been perfunctory objections lodged for the sake of appearances before constituents.

LEAD: THOMAS EISNER had barely reached school age when he was smitten by a ''disease'' he calls biophilia - love of living things, especially the more than billion billion creatures with six or eight legs that crawl, swim and flit through nearly every conceivable habitat on earth.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in moderately active trading yesterday, as dealers spent the session reacting to the dollar's twists and turns on the foreign exchange markets.

LEAD: Cranston Williams, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association for 21 years before his retirement in 1960, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at his home in Lynchburg, Va. He was 93 years old.
LEAD: It's that time of year - gray skies, gray moods, and you feel a head cold coming on. There are positive steps you can take to brighten your wardrobe and your mood.
LEAD: New York City school officials yesterday urged Mayor Edward I. Koch to provide $15 billion to rebuild and modernize New York's dilapidated school system by the end of the century.

LEAD: The Justice Department, which has taken few antitrust actions during the Reagan Administration, said yesterday that it would seek to block two proposed joint ventures between the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and ABB Asea Brown Boveri, a Swiss industrial equipment manufacturer, unless the deals are modified to eliminate features that the department says are anti-competitive.

LEAD: A spokesman for the Sudanese rebels said today that Libyan forces supporting the Khartoum Government had used chemical weapons against them in the Sudan in the last six months. American officials said they had been investigating the charges.

LEAD: Instead of appealing a Delaware Chancery Court ruling on its efforts to avoid being acquired by Tyson Foods Inc., the board of the Holly Farms Corporation will put the chicken-producing company up for auction for the shareholders' benefit.

LEAD: Thousands of contemporary Soviet artists are to be offered the chance to sell their works at art galleries around the United States as a result of a joint venture agreement signed yesterday between the Soviet Ministry of Culture, the Union of Soviet Artists and a New York art dealer who will act as wholesaler of the works.
LEAD: * Ad Hoc Marketing Resources, New York, has agreed to create a campaign for New York City to decrease the number of non-emergency calls made to the city's 911 emergency telephone services.

LEAD: Administration officials said today that an Iraqi civil engineer who operates several companies in Switzerland and elsewhere in Europe played a central role in the construction of the Libyan chemical plant.

LEAD: No sooner did Emperor Hirohito fall gravely ill than Japan starting projecting the economic cost of an imperial mourning and succession period. LEAD: William E. Powers, the victim of an accident that left him blind, who become a Justice of the Rhode Island Supreme Court and the state's Attorney General, died Saturday at the Wayland Health Center in Providence. He was 81 years old.

LEAD: In the largest sale under a Government program of tax breaks that is intended to increase ownership of broadcast properties by members of minority groups, The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its cable television system for $420 million in cash.

The league also fined each club $5,000, O'Relly $1,000 and Korn $500 for their fight in the runway under the stands at the end of Boston's 6-2 victory.

LEAD: Besides the 100 or so members of the sprawling Bush clan taking over the Jefferson Hotel near the White House for the inaugural festivities, 28 Bushes will be camping out at the White House. LEAD: ''Parting the Waters'' (Simon & Schuster), Taylor Branch's detailed account of the rise of the American civil-rights movement, yesterday won the National Book Critics Circle award for general nonfiction.

LEAD: Governor Mario M. Cuomo said today that the state would probably have to borrow ''somewhere in the range of a couple of hundred million dollars'' to close its budget gap for the current fiscal year.

LEAD: Kenny Wilson scored 20 points tonight to lead Villanova to a 75-73 victory over No. 4 Syracuse. It was the Orangemen's second Big East Conference loss in a week.

LEAD: An obituary on Friday about Dr. Robert S. Coles, a New York City ophthalmologist, included erroneous dates given by Lenox Hill Hospital for some events in his career. LEAD: THE very notion of cooking risotto in a microwave oven may seem as close to culinary blasphemy as one can get. Risotto cooked this way is not cooked more quickly than the traditional stove-top version, but the quality is excellent and the cook is liberated from the endless standing and stirring.

LEAD: Electrical transformers, which reduce high voltages on power lines to levels useful in homes and businesses, are inefficient devices. Their metal cores must be magnetized and demagnetized dozens of times each second, which wastes electricity. But amorphous metals, in which the atoms are arrayed radomly rather than in tight rows, are much more efficient as transformer cores because they are more easily magnetized and demagnetized.

LEAD: A wage and price freeze reduced inflation last year to 51.7 percent, down two-thirds from the 1987 rate, Mexico's central bank said on Monday. The Bank of Mexico noted that consumer prices rose by 159.2 percent in 1987. Last Feb. 29, the Government froze the peso's exchange rate against the dollar.

LEAD: ''Smoking: Everything You and Your Family Need to Know,'' on Home Box Office tonight at 10:30, marks the 25th anniversary of the Surgeon General's report linking cigarette smoking and lung cancer. Nothing good has been discovered about smoking in the interim.

LEAD: Tarlow Advertising, which received a portion of Revlon Inc.'s Almay account several weeks ago, said yesterday that it had picked up the rest from its former agency, Korey, Kay & Partners. LEAD: The proposal by Gov. Thomas H. LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN has delivered his farewell address and his final budget. His one great regret, he said, was ''the deficit.'' LEAD: The United States has strongly protested the severe beating and threatened killing of an American sailor by Panama's Defense Forces, Pentagon officials said today. The Panamanian Government has acknowledged that the incident occurred, but made no apology.
LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation yesterday named Edward M. Browne to lead its commercial space venture.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation has made only two major strategic acquisitions in recent history, and both have proved troublesome. Its $2.5 billion purchase of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation in 1984 led to an embarrassing public dispute with the E.D.S. founder, H. Ross Perot. Now G.M. is embroiled in a potentially costly wrangle over its 1986 purchase of the Hughes Aircraft Company.
LEAD: The space agency, scarred by the explosion of the Challenger in which a teacher was killed, announced today that it will no longer carry civilians on the space shuttle.

LEAD: Five months after South Africa and Angola agreed to jointly patrol Namibia's border, a 300-mile gap remains under the control of Angolan rebels supplied by South Africa, an Angolan Army officer asserted here today.
LEAD: Alain Chevalier resigned today as chairman of LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the apparent loser in a bitter board-room power struggle with Bernard Arnault, the largest shareholder.

LEAD: There were 18 seconds remaining in tonight's game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The Nets trailed the Boston Celtics by a point. And Roy Hinson, New Jersey's forward, had the ball exactly where he wanted it: 12 feet from the basket in the lane.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved the Delta Government Options Corporation yesterday as the first registered clearing organization for over-the-counter options on Treasury securities.

LEAD: The Saturn Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said it would hire 1,000 people and spend $1 billion on capital equipment this year to prepare for the introduction of its cars by the fall of 1990, as planned. The company now employs 500 people at its complex in Spring Hill, Tenn., where buildings are still being completed.

LEAD: Schneider Sings Weill Helen Schneider, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street (244-3005). Over the last five years, Helen Schneider has grown into a cabaret performer of exceptional breadth and theatrical command. In her new show, devoted to the songs of Kurt Weill, Ms. Schneider dives fearlessly into the tempestuous emotional world of the songs, rather than taking the ironic distance that an older generation of Weill interpreters used to adopt.

LEAD: The developer Harry Macklowe, who illegally tore down four buildings in Manhattan in 1985, has started building a hotel on the site two years before he was supposed to because the New York City Council - apparently unknowingly - removed a ban on the construction.

LEAD: Highest-paid city workers hired through the Mayor's Talent Bank, a job-referral program operated out of the basement of City Hall, according to a list taken home in a shopping bag by Nydia Padilla-Barham, the program's former director. List covers period between 1981 and July, 1985. Salary is as reported in that list.

LEAD: The Treasury Department has taken under advisement a Customs Service decision to classify imported sport-utility vehicles like the Suzuki Samurai and most small vans as trucks, subjecting them to duties 10 times higher than those for cars, a spokesman for the agency said Thursday night.
LEAD: The Houston Independent School District opened gymnasium doors Thursday night to schoolchildren who had no other place to sleep, and eight children 5 to 18 years of age spent the night.

LEAD: As expected, Bernard Arnault, the 39-year-old French financier, was elected chairman today of the world's largest luxury- goods group, LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, and a new executive committee was formed that for the first time includes no representative of the Moet-Hennessy faction.

LEAD: An article on Dec. 23 about Representative Manuel Lujan Jr., who has been selected as Interior Secretary, discussed his background, his record in Congress and the response to his selection. In describing Mr. Lujan's family, the article noted that he is a Roman Catholic.

The designer, who completed the fitting on several evening dresses Thursday, is not sure which she will select. In addition to the long dresses, he made a number of daytime outfits in silk and in wool.

LEAD: Andrew McBurney Jackson Jr., a retired vice admiral of the Navy who also served as vice chairman of the United States delegation to the United Nations, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday at a nursing home in Edgewater, Md. He was 81 years old and lived in Annapolis.

LEAD: New York City, while sharply disputing the state's assertion that large amounts of garbage fly off the barges that travel to the city landfill on Staten Island, will begin placing covers over the barges next Tuesday.
LEAD: Interest rates continued to plunge yesterday, largely because of coordinated actions by the Federal Reserve and other central banks to reduce the dollar's value.
LEAD: Budget worries have left 21 employees of the Justice Department's press and legislative affairs offices looking for work this week.

LEAD: ''Jewels,'' a three-act plotless work that George Balanchine created in 1967, has always had a special place in the New York City Ballet's repertory, and on Thursday night it was presented as part of a special occasion.

LEAD: St. John's will seek its third consecutive victory in the Big East Conference today when it is host to Syracuse, ranked fourth in the latest Associated Press poll, at 2 P.M. at Madison Square Garden.

LEAD: The highest-paying jobs allocated through Mayor Edward I. Koch's Talent Bank - an office set up in part to promote the hiring of black and Hispanic applicants - went overwhelmingly to whites, a review of city records shows.

LEAD: There were indications yesterday that Ray Tellier, the head coach at the University of Rochester, would be appointed the next football coach at Columbia University. But Al Paul, the Columbia athletic director, and Tellier refused to confirm that a choice had been made.

LEAD: William Michelson, a former president of the United Storeworkers Union, died of a heart attack Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Sid Fernandez, the left-handed pitcher, filed for salary arbitration yesterday.

LEAD: The manager of a single-room-occupancy hotel in midtown Manhattan was arrested yesterday after a building inspector found evidence that the hotel was being renovated without a permit.

LEAD: A computer virus struck personal computers in Britain today, wiping out program files and causing problems for businesses, a computer expert said.

LEAD: Royal Little, the shrewd Rhode Island entrepreneur who is widely regarded as the inventor of the modern conglomerate, the highly diversified breed of corporation that became the rage on Wall Street in the late 1960's, died Thursday night at his home in Nassau in the Bahamas. He was 92 years old and also had a house in Narragansett, R

LEAD: The game of the season comes up today in Canton, N.Y., where Harvard plays St. Lawrence. Both teams are expected to be undefeated after games last night against lesser opponents, and a midseason clash such as this one between two major unbeaten teams is rare.

LEAD: An obituary by The Associated Press on Thursday and its headline, about Gen. Maj. Raden Haji Harsoyo of Indonesia, incorrectly described a peacekeeping unit in which he was an officer. He was deputy commander of an Indonesian contingent in Vietnam created under the Paris peace accords of 1973; the operation was not affiliated with the United Nations.

LEAD: An international group of scientists is planning to use satellite photography and other sophisticated computer-imaging techniques to aid searchers still looking for the remains of 28 passengers in the widely scattered wreckage of a Pan Am Boeing 747 in Scotland.

LEAD: James E. Hurtubise, a race-car driver who once held the average qualifying speed record for the Indianapolis 500, died Jan. 6 after suffering a heart attack near his home in Port Arthur, Tex. He was 56 years old.

LEAD: The General Electric Company and the General Electric Company P.L.C., Britain's largest manufacturing concern, yesterday announced an agreement to create joint ventures in consumer products, medical equipment and electrical distribution equipment. The companies, which are not related, will also cooperate in the gas turbine business.

LEAD: Dave Winfield's latest feud with George Steinbrenner has begun to produce a modicum of trade interest around baseball, but the Yankee outfielder yesterday repeated his pronouncement of the past: No trade.

LEAD: Advanced Micro Devices, a semiconductor manufacturer, said today that it lost $34.1 million in the fourth quarter of 1988. Sales in the quarter were $248.1 million, down 5.5 percent from $262.5 in the fourth quarter of 1987.

LEAD: ''On the Sacred in Art: Receptacles of Spirit,'' an exhibition of work by six artists, will be on view at the Rotunda Gallery in the Brooklyn War Memorial, Cadman Plaza West and Orange Street, through Feb. 11. Many of the works, from a variety of traditions, are used in specific religious rituals.

LEAD: When Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Comptroller announced a plan this week to save the state hundreds of millions of dollars in pension costs, the announcement raised questions about whether the state's pension fund could be manipulated to yield savings.

LEAD: An American Jewish delegation has ended a visit to India, saying it is hopeful that the time is right to upgrade relations between India and Israel and end Indian discrimination against Israelis.

LEAD: Prosecutors in Norman, Okla., have charged Jerry Parks, a starting cornerback for Oklahoma, with shooting with intent to injure after a teammate was wounded during an argument in an athletes' dormitory early yesterday morning.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a front-page article last Saturday about the Pentagon procurement case described Stuart Berlin, a defendant in the case, incorrectly in some copies. He continues to work for the Defense Department.

LEAD: Dan Quayle's first trip out of the country as Vice President is likely to be to Caracas, Venezuela, for the inauguration of Carlos Andres Perez as president on Feb. 2, an aide to President-elect George Bush said Thursday.

LEAD: The New York City Board of Estimate, in a pre-dawn vote yesterday, approved zoning changes to allow construction of a twin-tower condominium, hotel and shopping complex on First Avenue at 60th Street, overshadowing the Queensboro Bridge.
LEAD: A man sprayed the inside of a McDonald's restaurant with gunfire last night in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, fatally wounding an 18-year-old woman, the police said.

LEAD: Mexican oil prices rose an average of more than $2 a barrel in December in the wake of the new OPEC quota agreement, Pemex, the Government oil monopoly, said. The price of light Isthmus crude in the Americas was $13.93 a barrel in December, up from $11.62 in November, Petroleos Mexicanos said late Thursday.

LEAD: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed on Monday. Below are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed.

LEAD: Soviet press agencies and television cast doubt tonight on reports that six survivors were found Wednesday under the rubble of an apartment building that collapsed in the Armenian earthquake 35 days earlier. But the news organizations did not retract the reports.

LEAD: Bruce Kimball, the former Olympic diver, may be allowed to change his guilty plea in a drunken-driving manslaughter case to safeguard insurance money for victims and their families, his attorney said yesterday.

LEAD: Turkish newspapers are increasingly free-wheeling and unafraid to challenge Prime Minister Turgut Ozal. Old taboos are being broken, or at least tested for the first time in years: there is public debate on whether to legalize a Communist party, to give more latitude to Islamic fundamentalists, to abolish the death penalty and to expand cultural rights for the country's large Kurdish minority.

LEAD: A Rockland County jury began hearing evidence today in the murder trial of 18-year-old Alonzo Williams, who shot his mother five times after, he said, she had sexually abused him since he was 6 years old.
LEAD: The sale of the General Cinema Corporation's soft-drink bottler to Pepsico Inc. is on again, but at a higher price of $1.75 billion, the two companies said yesterday.
LEAD: Michael M. Katzoff, a retired principal at the High School of Fashion Industries, died of heart failure Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old.
LEAD: Israeli forces in recent weeks have been using a new type of bullet against Palestinian protesters in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, Palestinians and Israelis say.

LEAD: The Labor Department today broadened its regulation of toxic and hazardous substances in the workplace, putting new limits on such substances as grain dust and gasoline fumes while strengthening existing limits on others.

LEAD: The Pro Musicis Foundation, which presents young musicians in concert and requires that they also perform in prisons, hospitals and shelters, is celebrating its 20th annivesary with a series of five free concerts at Florence Gould Hall. The first was offered by Sharon Robinson, the cellist, on Thursday evening.

LEAD: After every duplicate event, almost every partnership tends to be embroiled in post-mortem arguments: ''Why did you bid this?'' Or ''Why did you play that?'' The maximum dispute potential comes from mixed-pair events, since more than a third of the participants are combinations of husbands and wives who drive home together and can bicker, if they choose, far into the night.

LEAD: Considering all the flap about his family's recent Colorado ski vacation, Vice President-elect Dan Quayle may regret he ever took the trip. Yet he did nothing wrong in asking the Republican National Committee to pick up a portion of the cost.

LEAD: TENNIS Shriver Upset: In the $350,000 New South Wales Open Championships in Sydney, Australia, yesterday Top-seeded Martina Navratilova beat Patty Fendick, 6-1, 6-1, and Pam Shriver, seeded second, was beaten by 16th-seeded Terry Phelps, 6-3, 6-3. In men's action, Aaron Krickstein, seeded third, beat Carl Uwe Steeb of West Germany, 2-6, 6-3, 6-3.(AP)

LEAD: Scott Verplank just didn't feel comfortable on the PGA Tour. For the first year or two, he struggled on the circuit. That was ''just a feeling'' he said, even though he was the rookie in 1986 who everybody thought would be the next big star.

LEAD: It's late, 1 or 2 o'clock in the morning, and the man of the house taps the woman of the house on the shoulder. She stirs in bed. ''Huh?'' she says foggily. ''Sweetheart,'' he says in typically dulcet tones for that hour, ''can you do me a favor?''
LEAD: John Thompson of Georgetown intends to walk out of tonight's basketball game to protest a new N.C.A.A. rule on scholarships. Page 45.

LEAD: Like sports records, New Year's resolutions often seem made to be broken. Perhaps it is because they tend to be made in haste or because the carrying-through must start just when post-holiday letdown comes face to face with January.
LEAD: After deliberating 16 hours over three days, a Federal jury today convicted two top officials of the Ohio teamsters' union of racketeering and embezzlement.

LEAD: Chris Cochrane, who played at A-Mica (324 East Ninth Street) on Sunday, performed two different types of music. Mr. Cochrane, a guitarist and co-leader of the group No Safety, sang several songs that referred to regular songwriting conventions. And he played industrial, metallic soundscapes that fit into the Lower East

LEAD: Art Farmer on fluegelhorn, Clifford Jordan on tenor saxophone, the singer Chris Connor and many other musicians will perform at J's All-Star Jazz Reunion at 6 and 9 P.M. tomorrow. J's is on the second floor at 2581 Broadway, above 98th Street; admission is $15, with a two-drink minimum. Information: 666-3600.

LEAD: John Thompson, the Georgetown University basketball coach, said today he would leave the bench at the start of Saturday night's Big East game with Boston College as a protest against a new scholarship regulation approved this week by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. He called the regulation ''discriminatory.

LEAD: One week before he leaves office, President Reagan declared that he will never ''leave the battle'' to reshape Federal policy on abortion and welfare reform, two issues that have emerged as political litmus tests for conservatives in the Reagan years.

LEAD: West Germany said today that its intelligence services had warned of possible participation by German companies in a suspect Libyan chemical plant almost a month before President Reagan told Chancellor Helmut Kohl of similar concern.
LEAD: Bishop G. P. Mellick Belshaw of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey has sent $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
LEAD: Stock prices gained slightly yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average inched up to yet another post-crash high.

LEAD: Felix Kruglikov, who immigrated to this country from the Soviet Union in 1979 and became assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic in 1984, led a stirring account of Prokofiev's chilling, historically important Symphony No. 6 on Friday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall. The concert was part of a subscription series that will continue tonight at 8 and Tuesday at 7:30 P

LEAD: Pots of gardenias, geraniums, African violets and ficus sit serenely near the window. But look again. When the heat is on, insects multiply indoors. These minute nuisances often live their lives undetected until leaves turn yellow or drop, or the plant fails to thrive. An arsenal of chemical weapons is not necessary to get the insects under control.

LEAD: President Reagan has suggested in a television interview that some civil rights leaders exaggerate the degree of racism in America to keep their cause alive and to maintain their own prominence.

LEAD: Gordon Wright, a noted horseman and riding instructor who helped establish the United States Equestrian Team after World War II, died Jan. 5 at a nursing home in Tryon, N.C. He was 85 years old and had lived at Wright Way Farm outside nearby Landrum, S.C.

LEAD: Citing social and political tensions in impoverished Latin America, the United States and other major industrial nations are trying to induce their commercial banks to lend the countries much more and to absorb some losses on loans they have already made, American officials and officials of other leading governments said.
LEAD: John Hauk, an inventor in Oakland, Calif., won patent approval for Lactote, a device to help working mothers store breast milk while they are on the job.
LEAD: At first, Troy Canty enjoyed the attention that engulfed him after he and three other teen-agers had been shot by Bernhard H. Goetz in an IRT subway car, Mr. Canty's lawyer said yesterday.

LEAD: A long practice session was nearing its close in the gymnasium of Elizabeth High School, and Ben Candelino had seen enough. For two hours, Candelino, the basketball coach at Elizabeth, had watched the most gifted player in New Jersey jog up and down the court, lumber through drills and allow smaller players to score and rebound inside without fear.
LEAD: After three decades of welcoming Hispanic immigrants with open arms, officials here said today that Miami could not cope with the latest wave of Nicaraguans and had no jobs or housing for them.

LEAD: A decade after predicting that measles was on the verge of eradication, Federal health officials have proposed two new steps to try to wipe out the persistent disease.

LEAD: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday suspended its involvement in a lawsuit charging The New York Times with publishing racially discriminatory housing advertisements.

LEAD: Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell today dismissed the main criminal charges against Oliver L. North in the Iran-contra case, saying he was ''totally powerless'' to try the two charges without classified documents the Reagan Administration had ordered withheld.
LEAD: Libya today returned the body of a United States Air Force officer who was killed in the bombing raid on Tripoli in 1986.

LEAD: An article yesterday about the arrest of a Spanish Basque separatist leader in France referred incorrectly in some copies to the period in which a conservative Parliament and Cabinet shared power with President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist. It was March 1986 to May 1988.

LEAD: As I watched ''Mississippi Burning,'' a new film about civil rights unrest in the South in 1964, I found myself remembering. I recalled the lost moral universe relegated to the background of the film.
LEAD: The dollar surged again yesterday, overcoming a round of coordinated central bank intervention led by the Federal Reserve with repeated dollar selling.
LEAD: Moisturizers soothe dry skin and protect it from low temperatures and high winds. With winter here in earnest, the question is: which products work best?
LEAD: Peter Nichols, for 30 years the Rome correspondent of The Times of London, died Wednesday of a brain hemorrhage in Bracciano, Italy, where he lived. He was 60 years old.

LEAD: William Chaison, a dancer and choreographer and associate professor of physical education at Kean College in Union, N.J., died last Friday at Doctor's Hospital in New York City. He was 44 years old.
LEAD: John Eugene Unterecker, a poet, biographer and educator, died after heart surgery Monday at Straub Hospital in Honolulu. He was 66 years old and lived in Hawaii.
LEAD: Nationwide retail sales ended 1988 with a whimper.
LEAD: In a report signaling that inflationary pressures are still growing, the Labor Department said yesterday that producer prices rose by four-tenths of 1 percent in December.

LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation received a patent this week for a computer-controlled system that anticipates the likelihood of a car to roll over and tries to prevent it.

LEAD: In a trade of minor leaguers, the Mets have traded Rich Rodriguez, a pitcher, to the San Diego Padres for Brad Pounders, a first baseman. Pounders, 25 years old, hit .279 in 110 games for Class AAA Las Vegas of the Pacific Coast League last season. He had 14 home runs and drove in 74 runs. LEAD: An investment group led by the Continental Casualty Company, a unit of the CNA Financial Corporation, has sold its entire 5.8 percent stake in Liberty All-Star Equity Fund. The sale by the Continental group is a blow to certain of the mutual fund's shareholders, who are planning a shareholder vote to convert Liberty All-Star Equity Fund from a closed-end fund, with a fixed number of shares, to an open-end fund.

LEAD: A 16-year-old student at a Roman Catholic diocesan high school in Manhattan was arrested yesterday after he brought an unloaded .38-caliber revolver to school and hid it in his locker, the police said. They said five cartridges were found in his pockets. The student, Anthony Reyes, of 220 East 102d Street in Manhattan, brought the revolver to Immaculata High School, at 317 East 33d Street, yesterday morning the police said.

LEAD: The Honda Motor Company this week received the first of what appears to be a series of patents for its system of four-wheel steering in automobiles. The company introduced its first four-wheel steering system last year, as an option in the Prelude, and the new patent sheds considerable light on how it works.

LEAD: The library of the American Cultural Center here is dedicated to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. At the conclusion of the African-American Institute's conference this weekend, a memorial ceremony was held at the center to honor Dr. King.

LEAD: Carlos and Bermaida Fajardo, who struggled for years to get to the United States from Cuba - he arrived in 1984, she in 1986 - find themselves outside the land of opportunity again. Mr. and Mrs. Fajardo, who live in Miami, wanted their two children to have a white Christmas, so they drove north to see snow - all the way to Niagara Falls.

LEAD: 'A lot of money got put into people's pockets and they've rat-holed it somewhere. Some of it is in artwork, fancy homes, fancy airplanes and Rolls-Royces. Some of it went to Rolex watches, lizard shoes, hunting parties and yachts.' - H. Joe Selby, former chief regulator for the Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas, discussing abuses in some savings and loan associations in Texas.
LEAD: A BURNS BIRTHDAY Did you know that Robert Burns, the great Scottish poet, was born in January - Jan. 25, 1759, to be exact?

LEAD: Want a photograph of Alf, the lovable TV space alien, presiding at your company's board of directors meeting? Or how about the Eiffel Tower in the middle of the Manhattan skyline? Such doctored photographs have always been possible, of course, through tedious cut-and-paste operations. But the advent of still video photography, in which images can be stored in digital form in computers and manipulated on the screen, enables users to arrange tricks - or, more typically, to improve existing photos - at the touch of a button.

LEAD: The engagement of Heidi Helm Wasch to Robert Owen Leversee, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack H. Leversee of Bellevue, Wash., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William K. Wasch of Middletown, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: To hear Igor Moiseyev tell it, Americans still insist inexplicably on seeing the same rosy-cheeked Russian maidens they remember from his theatricalized folk dances of more than 30 years ago. But times are not the same since the Moiseyev Dance Company from Moscow made its wildly acclaimed United States debut in 1958.

LEAD: Randy Barnes, a 1988 Olympic silver medalist, overcame the loss of sleep following an early morning confrontation with an Arkansas gunman and recorded the second-best American indoor shot-put today.

LEAD: An expatriate American freind of mine who has devoted five years to voracious London theatergoing is thinking of moving home to New York. I asked him what he would miss most about the theater in London and wasn't surprised when he failed to answer ''musicals on roller skates.'' But I was wrong to assume that he would rhapsodize about ''the classics'' or the Royal Shakespeare Company or the National Theater.

LEAD: Rick Barnes, the first-year coach at Providence, took his first loss of the season the same way he did the news the Friars were ranked No. 20 last Monday, in stride.

LEAD: AS soon as the ground thaws enough in the spring, construction is to begin to transform a blighted block of Monticello Avenue here into modern apartments and shops. The $2.9-million project will be the first investment of casino funds in urban redevelopment in northern New Jersey.

LEAD: To many Mississippians, the first public screenings of ''Mississippi Burning'' here Friday revived painful memories of the state's violent past and raised concern that the movie would negate the progressive image the state has been trying to project nationally.

LEAD: AS more companies go into the business of growing herbs hydroponically, various fresh herbs are now available all year. A few sprigs of fresh thyme, rosemary or tarragon can be found in many produce markets, sealed in plastic. In winter they usually cost $1.25 to $2 a package.
LEAD: WHAT is wrong with today's children? They just don't seem to be reading anything and, what is worse, they don't seem to have any desire to.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Glenn W. Christian of Independence, Ohio, have made known the engagement of Mr. Christian's daughter Kathleen Estelle Christian to Charles Francis Morgan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: The article regarding Long Island radio [ ''Radio Redux: Frequencies Are in Demand,'' Dec. 25 ] was interesting but made a common mistake, namely, that Long Island radio is one market. It is not. It is two. Nassau and western Suffolk is one and Long Island's East End is the other. While Arbitron does not measure them separately, Birch Research does.

LEAD: The engagement of Rosemarie Patricia Connors to Vincent Gerard McCallion, a son of Rosetta McCallion of New York and the late Vincent McCallion, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Connors of Brooklyn. Miss Connors, a graduate of Fordham University, is the director of research in Mayor Edward I.

LEAD: REAL-ESTATE taxes have increased dramatically in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and the extent of the rise not only has become a political issue but also is likely to be contentious through the local elections this year.

LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl came under strong attack from the political opposition and the press today over his Government's disclosure that it had known since October of potential West German involvment in the construction of a suspect Libyan chemical factory.

LEAD: She won two gold medals at the 1988 Olympics and now Jackie Joyner-Kersee has her sights set on a world record. She will try to break the indoor mark for the 55-meter hurdles at the Panasonic Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden Feb. 3. . . . James (The Heat) Kinchen and Chris Tiozzo of France will fight a 10-round super-middleweight bout in Paris March 10 under the aegis of the Houston Boxing Association.

LEAD: Six canoes slipped through the dark bayou waters under a full moon. But where was the moonlight? Not over our left shoulders, where it should have been, beaming into the narrow stream that wandered through a patch of Louisiana wetlands. That early autumn night all celestial rays were blocked by thick clouds just blown in from the Gulf of Mexico.

LEAD: The shooting of one Oklahoma football player by another was an accident after a series of arguments ''about stupid stuff,'' according to a third Sooner player who said he witnessed the incident early Friday morning. Rod Fisher, a halfback, told The Daily Oklahoman that he was present when Jerry Parks, a freshman, shot Zarek Peters, a third-year lineman, during a scuffle in Peters's dorm room.

LEAD: Ruth Ann Brophy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles George Brophy of Southport, Conn., was married at the Southport Congregational Church yesterday to Frederick Chorlton Mitchell 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Jr. of Newark, Del. The Rev. Loring Sabine Ensign performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Soundance, a repertory company that features dances in a variety of styles, was enterprising enough to present works by five choreographers on Thursday night at the Dia Dance Foundation. But its laudable intentions did not produce equally laudable results.

LEAD: To the Editor: I would like to warn Times readers about the amounts paid to a traveler who buys trip cancellation insurance. The round-trip fare to Milan, for example, varies from as little as $400 to a high of about $660. T.W.A. advertises round trip to Rome, which is farther, at $546. These are restricted fares and are nonrefundable, noncancelable.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Bingham of New York and Argyle, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Ann Bingham to Jeffrey R. Perry, a son of Beverly Perry of New York and the late Jay H. Perry. The couple plan to marry in April.

LEAD: ALAN GREENSPAN, CHAIRMAN OF THE FEDERAL Reserve Board, comes quickly across the office from his big, mahogany-brown desk, and greets his visitor with a nod and a gentle handshake. A friend of his says that Greenspan looks like Woody Allen, and there is a resemblance. But the thick, horn-rimmed glasses are gone; Greenspan has switched to thinner frames.

LEAD: Donald J. Atwood Jr., vice chairman of the General Motors Corporation, is expected to be named to the No. 2 post at the Pentagon, officials involved in the transition to a new administration said today.

LEAD: In 1770, eight years after she became Empress of Russia, Catherine the Great established the workshops that would lavishly and permanently furnish the imperial palaces. Catherine's move gave birth to the Russian furniture industry - and the Russian style. Antoine Cheneviere, a Swiss-born London antiques dealer specializing in Russian furniture, has written RUSSIAN FURNITURE: The Golden Age 1780-1840 (Vendome Press, $65), the first major book outside of the Soviet Union on the style as it evolved over a 60-year period.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''My mail tells me a lot of fat, white-haired, wrinkled ladies are tickled pink.'' - Barbara Bush. [ 1:1. ]

LEAD: All over India, where Hindu wives traditionally burned on their husbands' funeral pyres, brides in recent years have been dying in their husband's homes in fires that were called ''accidents'' until women's organizations began to demand an official accounting.

LEAD: This year my Christmas spirit did not make it well into the New Year. It exploded into thousands of angry fragments on Christmas morning, when I read the article, ''Taxes Will Rise by Average of 9 Percent for Homeowners.'' To tell someone, whose tax burden is already approaching five figures, that his liability will be upped another big notch so as to pay $150-per-night hotel bills for the ''underprivileged'' is enough to create total outrage.
LEAD: We were at somebody's 40th birthday party the other night, mourning the 60's. My friend said he missed the time when people took a stand if they thought something was unjust.
LEAD: A tax break for Brown University professors that dates to the days of King George III is being phased out but still gives 32 faculty members a discount on their property taxes, officials say.

LEAD: Ever since Walter Huston introduced ''September Song'' in the 1938 Broadway musical ''Knickerbocker Holiday,'' Kurt Weill and Maxwell Anderson's solemn meditation on aging has marked an unofficial rite of passage for pre-rock male singers seeking certification as pop interpreters. Of course, this great song in which an older person reflects on the follies of youth and the shortness of life should not be restricted to men.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Peter Goldis spent most of mid-December in Holland, breaking into the Amsterdam computer of a major international financial services firm. Earlier in the fall, he did the same thing at corporations in Detroit, Chicago and Los Angeles. This month, he has an assignment in Phoenix.

LEAD: With President Alan Garcia seemingly overwhelmed by the challenges posed by wild inflation and mounting terrorism, Peru has been shaken over the last two weeks by intense rumors of an imminent military coup.
LEAD: Unmarried Shareholders?
LEAD: A high-ranking Vietnamese official arrived here tonight for talks apparently aimed at settling the conflict in Cambodia.

LEAD: In the late 1960's a small group of American and West Indian blacks, caught up in the move to regain their lost African heritage, established Holy Trinity Ethiopian Orthodox Church in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx.
LEAD: ROMAN ART

LEAD: Marie Colvin's article ''The Ambiguous Yasir Arafat'' (Dec. 18), is accompanied by a large picture of Mr. Arafat addressing the Palestine National Council in Algiers. It was at this conference that he renounced terrorism. In the picture, Mr. Arafat is wearing army fatigues and has a large gun in a holster at his right side.
LEAD: A front-page contents listing on Dec. 18 for an article about Rio de Janeiro characterized the city incorrectly. The capital of Brazil is Brasilia.

LEAD: Angel Antonio Sanchez-Cabanas turns away from the glare of Madrid's midday sun and leans his frame against a wall, the better to show off his garb. He wears a snug-fitting toreador-style jacket, a black ribbon tie - the sort of thing that Zorro might have fancied - and a Mexican belt with a hand-tooled silver buckle.

LEAD: Q. We have been caring for our teak furniture by rubbing it periodically with an oil sold specifically for this type of unvarnished furniture. However, the wood seems to have darkened over the years. The other day I repaired the top of one piece, and I first cleaned off the surface with acetone. I was amazed to see how clean and light the finish looked after cleaning it with this solvent.

LEAD: A year ago he was on his way to leading his Univerity of Kansas team to the national championship and being voted the college player of the year. Yesterday, Danny Manning, the No. 1 draft pick in the National Basketball Association last summer, underwent reconstructive knee surgery in Inglewood, Calif., and will be in rehabilitation for up to a year.

LEAD: Twelve-year-old Robert Camp takes private saxophone lessons at New York City's Collegiate School, where he is a seventh grader. He says he likes the kind of music - jazz, rock, pop - that can be played on the alto sax he is renting.
LEAD: Varian D. Schmokel won her court case but died before she ever knew it.
LEAD: NATO and the Warsaw Pact announced an agreement clearing the way for conventional-arms talks and a human rights declaration. Page 4.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-15

LEAD: A Superior Court justice in Maine has ruled that game warderns' searches of boaters along the Saco River last summer were unconstitutional. Game wardens conducting the searches cited rowdy and potentially dangerous behavior by some boaters. But Justice Donald Alexander said there was ''no significant connection'' between the behavior the wardens sought to stop and the charges that were subsequently filed.
LEAD: With a laugh, Barbara Bush acknowledges that she now views herself as a role model for many American women.

LEAD: In a bitter dispute over the creation of a program to train emergency-room doctors at Bellevue Hospital, the hospital's community board has called for the resignation of its longtime chief of medicine, Dr. Saul J. Farber.

LEAD: RICOCHET. By Ovid Demaris. (Scribners, $17.95.) Frank Conti is not your average bank loan officer. True, he does have an M.B.A., an upscale wife and a nice house in the suburbs, but he also has a very heavy enemy in Tony Allio, leader of the Atlantic City mob, who has hated him since they were in high school together in south Philadelphia.

LEAD: This family fraud made the Medicaid mills of the 1970's look like small potatoes. Sheldon Weinberg and his sons, Jay and Ronald, were sentenced to prison last week for stealing $16 million over seven years; essentially, they billed Medicaid for twice as much service as they actually provided to poor patients at the Brooklyn clinics they owned.

LEAD: It's a sunny, sweater-weather winter afternoon, and as Jerry Lee Lewis's ''High School Confidential'' blasts from an eight-foot-high tower of speakers, the actor Dennis Quaid, playing the wild and legendary rocker, bounces up the steps of a Memphis elementary school to grab Winona Ryder, who portrays Lewis's 13-year-old bride, Myra, in the film ''Great Balls of Fire!
LEAD: The baby boom generation embraced the marine industry last year as never before. Industry officials say the union produced record sales and a period unmatched in boating history.

LEAD: Holli Georgia Gunther, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Gunther of Arlington, Vt., and Alan Harry Roth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Roth of Patchogue, L.I., were married last night at the Parker House in Boston. Justice of the Peace Vivian T. Burns of Woburn, Mass., performed the ceremony.

LEAD: As the bright, full early evening moon cast its glow on the Judean Desert, turning the Dead Sea beyond an unexpected pink, my reverie was broken by the sound of my stepson munching on his cucumber sandwich. A loud ''shhhhh'' punctuated the still air.

LEAD: THE question came directly and clearly, in that way of asking questions that only children possess. It came at breakfast in between orange juice and oatmeal. I should have expected it and kept a more careful watch. ''What is terrorism?'' my 6-year-old daughter asked.
LEAD: A FRIEND of mine says that she can see ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'' as many times as it is produced, regardless of the quality of the production. She never tires of it.

LEAD: AFTER hearing that a handful of other police departments in the country had found teddy bears valuable assistants on the beat, the Dade County Police in metropolitan Miami decided to recruit their own.

LEAD: After years of dancing around the edge of sensationalism, television leaped enthusiastically into the pit last year with the kind of journalism many newspapers have practiced for a hundred years or more. The half-dozen or so new shows and the old ones that remade themselves on a sex-and-mayhem model proved so successful that they have spawned a multibillion-dollar industry: reality-based television.

LEAD: The Ashton-Tate Corporation has finally completed dBASE IV version 1.0, the latest revision of the most popular data base program for personal computers. It offers a number of improvements over dBASE III-Plus and adds features that will make it attractive to the two million dBASE users. And beginners will find it less intimidating than previous versions.
LEAD: When that ol' devil auditor comes to mark against your name, He marks not if you won or lost but how much you banked from fame.

LEAD: Mark Calcavecchia would prefer playing golf in wide-open spaces. It better suits his game, with those gigantic drives. He won the Honda Classic two years ago with an 8-iron shot from way out in left field to reach a green after a wild drive.
LEAD: Of course they can play strictly by the rules, just as soon as they decide that education is more important than athletics, even for athletes. BERNARD LIEBMAN Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.
LEAD: A resounding yes!

LEAD: Adventure travel is not for watchers but for doers. For some travelers, simply leaving the tour bus behind and striking out on an independent itinerary is adventure enough. For others, the destination is the adventure - China before it had Western-style tourist facilities certainly qualified, but fewer travelers would categorize it that way today.

LEAD: AT 6 O'CLOCK ON A FRIDAY night, Dr. Robert F. Ward waits for his last patient of the day. She rushes into his office at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, in Manhattan, and croaks a greeting. The patient is a singer who goes on stage in two hours - and she has laryngitis. Dr. Ward asks her to stick out her tongue; he grasps it with a piece of cotton gauze.
LEAD: THE lazy days of summer are gone. The Mets have left Shea and the Great Pumpkin is memory. The earth is cold. Boy, am I glad.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. George B. Emmons 3d of South Salem, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Harley Emmons to Ames Borden Colt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard B. Colt Jr. of Little Compton, R.I. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: THE CONSTRUCTION OF HOMOSEXUALITY By David F. Greenberg. 635 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $29.95.

LEAD: What Irish actor can boast a longer and more impressive bio than Ray McAnally? None, surely. He's appeared in over 250 theater productions, 150 television dramas and a score of movies. Back home on Dublin stages, he's played Macbeth and Arthur Miller's Willy Loman and heroes and non-heroes galore.
LEAD: MICHAEL PALMER'S debut as music director of the New Haven Symphony, delayed since Nov. 15 because of a musicians' strike, will be Jan. 24 in Woolsey Hall.
LEAD: Coach Al Arbour did a slow burn tonight behind the Islander bench in the first period, the one that wound up costing his team the game.
LEAD: THERE is something about a ghost railroad stati, , ananding forlorn vigil in a lonely town, that grabs many city dwellers.

LEAD: LOCAL independent pay-telephone companies have reached out and touched upon a new multimillion-dollar industry, creating big changes in phone booths, while leaving many customers calling for help.

LEAD: ONLY in Massachusetts and Texas are automobile insurance rates set by state government. In Massachusetts, the public control was meant to reduce differences in premiums between cities and suburbs, but the result has been a continuing wrangle over rates between the state and insurance companies.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Eugenie Compton French of Hamden, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Compton Pille, to William Theodore Georges, the son of Theodore William Georges of Colts Neck, N.J., and the late Rhoda Brounstein Georges. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: FOR corporations, sports-sponsorship programs are effective and prestigious sales tools. For fund raisers, they are a fine source of financial benefit. For sports-marketing companies, which bring the parties together, they have become a big industry.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Gaynell L. Hawkins and Walter E. Hawkins Jr., both of Shreveport, La., of the engagement of their daughter Heather Covell Hawkins to John Bruce Duncan, a son of J. Bruce Duncan of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Leila H. Duncan. The couple plan to marry in April.
LEAD: EARTH AND FIRE By Horst Bienek. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 257 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

LEAD: WHEN the wind is blowing over 20 knots, Wayne DeVingo, a hair stylist at Guy Sasson in Stamford, stops cutting hair and starts windsurfing. It has been arranged with the shop that when the wind is up, Mr. DeVingo can get out.

LEAD: As long as academically unprepared students are accepted at colleges, college will be a business - a big business! So let's stop pretending and get rid of the myth about halls of learning.

LEAD: I can empathize with the anguish and frustration experienced by William and Joan Squadron. My husband waited eight anxiety-ridden months for a desperately needed heart transplant, which he was lucky enough to receive last August. He, like Joan, was running out of time, and we will be eternally grateful to an anonymous family in Cleveland, who offered John the gift of life in the midst of their grief.

LEAD: WHEN the Rev. Julio Colon, a pastor at Hartford's Christian Pentecostal Church, took a second job as a state prison chaplain, his increased income cost him his Federal subsidy on his apartment and his rent soared from $476 to $966. Such increases are applied to hasten the turnover of apartments to needier families.
LEAD: AT REAGAN'S SIDE By Helene von Damm. Illustrated. 341 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

LEAD: The police counterinsurgency teams that have ruthlessly hunted down guerrillas from the South-West Africa People's Organization are being retrained for a more mundane role in anticipation of Namibia's independence.

LEAD: IN Italy, La Sila is a lovely mountain in Calabria. On Long Island, it's an Italian restaurant on a quiet street in Inwood. A taste of La Sila's food is an instant lesson in Italian geography. Robust red sauces all point to a restaurant whose heart and soul are near that mountain in the south of Italy.
LEAD: Daniel Barenboim, the artistic and music director of the new Opera de la Bastille, was dismissed on Friday in a dispute over duties and salary.

LEAD: IF there are two overworked words in the English language at the moment, they must be ''kinder'' and ''gentler.'' Since President-elect George Bush chose them to convey his vision of the country and the future, they have filled newspaper columns and airwaves, have been sprinkled in countless conversations, have jumped out of advertisements and commercials and have been used in almost every context, with a grand disregard for accuracy.

LEAD: A broadened policy of bilingual education in New York's public schools to meet the anticipated needs of a growing population of students with limited skills in English has been announced by the state's Commissioner of Education, Thomas Sobol.

LEAD: When President Reagan signed the authorization for reparations payments to 60,000 Japanese-Americans last Aug. 10, he said that ''no payment can make up for those lost years'' when the Government held them in internment camps during World War II. Next year's budget provides virtually that - no payment.
LEAD: With Europe's fastest economic growth rate and foreign investment that has tripled in five years, Spain is turning into the continent's Sun Belt.

LEAD: A Brooklyn youth was arrested yesterday and charged in the inadvertent shooting death of an 18-year-old Brooklyn College student in a McDonald's restaurant in the Flatbush section, the police said. They said the gunman had been aiming at another person.

LEAD: The Bolshoi Ballet is to tour the United States in the summer of 1990 under an agreement by Classical Artists International and the James Nederlander Organization. The itinerary will be announced later.

LEAD: The days before christmas were made lively to some and hideous to others by the emergence - thanks primarily to the investigations of a provincial examining magistrate with a flair for publicity - of a truly French scandal. It ran the gamut of society from the former keeper of a dubious bar in Toulon to one of the most flamboyant trial lawyers of the day.

LEAD: In this drab industrial city on the Gulf Coast, the main supermarkets are owned by the Mexican oil workers union. So is the only funeral home and so are some of the auto repair shops and gasoline stations.
LEAD: Crime in general, and street crime in Madrid and other big cities in particular, has begun to alarm residents and Government officials concerned about the country's image.

LEAD: The Dec. 18 article ''Link Between AIDS and Drug Abuse Is Studied in State'' is insensitive and misleading. It contains racist, classist and sexist overtones, and muddies important points about AIDS transmission and prevention.

LEAD: EVEN in the aftermath of his death, the world is not sure which Emperor Hirohito to remember: the warrior on a white horse or the kindly old marine biologist who saw his nation transformed into an economic superpower.

LEAD: Since the beginning of the year the dollar has been surprisingly strong. To bring down its value, central banks in Europe and Japan sold dollars on Wednesday and Friday. But despite a high level of intervention into the currency markets, the dollar continued its rise, closing out the week in Europe at 126.65 yen and 1.8275 West German marks to the dollar.

LEAD: THIS has not been one of Westchester's glittering art seasons and, viewed from the halfway point, it offers little promise of improvement. Apart from the Neuberger's artists' books show (closing today), most of the action for county residents has been at nearby museums in the Bronx, specifically at the Lehman College Art Gallery, whose 1960's exhibition has just closed, and at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, where the massive roundup of Hispanic artists remains through Jan.

LEAD: Researchers at the University of Chicago say a new social survey of low-income inner-city residents here offers evidence of a strong correlation between unemployment among men and the growing number of children who are being reared by single mothers.

LEAD: Many experts in reproductive health and psychology challenge the contention of Dr. C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States, that scientific data on the health effects of abortion are inconclusive.

LEAD: As a new President comes into office, it is commonplace to express hope for the future. But even a cynic would have to acknowledge an extraordinary combination of events, at the end of the Reagan Administration, that offer the world more hope for peace and freedom than at any time in decades. It is crucial that we understand how we reached this point.
LEAD: Months after concern over the spread of the AIDS virus caused a shortage of rubber gloves, a New Britain-based medical supplier is stuck with millions of them.
