LEAD: On Friday night, the San Francisco 49ers' special teams got together for a Gutbuster Dinner. The entertainment for the 25 players and their wives and dates was a video of the special-teams season, the good parts and the funny. Lynn Stiles, the special-teams coach, picked up the check.

LEAD: ''It's no accident that the critics agree,'' says an ad on behalf of ''The Accidental Tourist,'' going on to tout the fact that the film was voted 1988's best by the New York Film Critics' Circle. Even in the world of movie promotions, where exaggeration is a way of life, this amounts to a monumental whopper.

LEAD: EXPRESSIONISM AT YALE The Yale Art Gallery has gleaned ''Expressionist Prints: From Nolde to Kokoschka'' from its substantial collection of German and Austrian graphics by artists working in Dresden, Munich, Berlin and Vienna from the turn of the century to the 30's.

LEAD: IT looks as though Danbury and Stamford are racing to see which city can open the most restaurants in the shortest space of time. Every time diners turn around, a new restaurant has emerged. For quality at moderate prices, however, the edge at this moment would go to Danbury.

LEAD: When Leela Raja was growing up in an affluent suburb of Philadelphia, her classmates thought of her Indian face and clothes not as exotic or interesting, but only as different - and that put a distance between her and them.

LEAD: SCOTTSDALE PAVILIONS, a 600,000-square-foot shopping center, is scheduled to open in March on the Salt River Indian Reservation just outside this city of 126,000 residents. It will be the country's largest private commercial development on Indian land.

LEAD: Helene von Damm's description of how Ronald Reagan formed his Cabinet read like a Doonesbury comic strip (''Out of the Kitchen, Into the Cabinet,'' Nov. 27). LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S Reach program, which gives welfare recipients training and helps them find jobs, was developed along with similar national welfare reform. But in the end, New Jersey got ahead of the Federal Government and helped guide the national effort.

LEAD: The dollar kept bouncing up despite coordinated efforts by central banks to wrestle it down. The gains were especially strong against the West German mark. The dollar has risen more than 3 percent against the mark this year. On Friday, the dollar reached three-month highs, trading above 1.84 marks in Europe before falling when the central banks began selling dollars in their fourth intervention of the week.

LEAD: For the consumer who has everything, a new toy will soon be beckoning. It is the electronic still video camera, a device that looks like a bulky 35-millimeter camera but captures images on electronic sensors instead of film. The images are then stored on built-in magnetic disks that can be played back with a machine connected to a TV.

LEAD: THIS is the time of year when co-op boards of directors and condominium owners associations send out their annual budgets. For many, the statements will carry the message of assessments and higher monthly charges, provoking another round in the long and abrasive debates among New York's resident owners that turn on the question, '
LEAD: Members of the committee that disciplines lawyers in Manhattan have charged that the court that supervises it improperly forced the committee's top two staff lawyers to resign.

LEAD: STANDARDIZED college admissions tests have often been criticized as inaccurate and biased against women and members of minority groups. But many critics of the tests admit that they are fighting a losing battle.

LEAD: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission will decide whether to allow the construction of what could be the last apartment house on upper Madison Avenue. As the public hearing on Jan. 24 approaches, its developer is stressing one point: Not one brownstone will be harmed.

LEAD: On Thursday, the 93d annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of New York will be presided over by its 43d chairman. The new year brought Burton P. Resnick to the helm of the city's largest realty trade group. He succeeds Jerry I. Speyer and will serve a three-year term. The biggest problem facing the board, he said, is the ''perception of the real estate industry in the eyes of the city.

LEAD: When Daniel Sullivan, a veteran director of New York and California theatrical productions, moved to the Pacific Northwest nearly 10 years ago he was asked at a party about his private passions. ''Do you ski?'' the guest queried Mr. Sullivan. ''No.'' ''Do you like to climb mountains?'' ''No.'' ''Do you own a boat?

LEAD: ON the impact of James Joyce, a writer once commented: ''He made it impossible to be unaware of word choices.'' Another said, ''I don't think there's a writer alive who's escaped his influence.''

LEAD: If the nuns at Our Savior elementary school in the Bronx could see Sheelah Ryan now: being toasted with champagne on the deck of the yacht Trump Princess, talking about the hundred marriage proposals she has turned down, counting her millions.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A SOVIET ODYSSEY. By Suzanne Rosenberg. (Oxford University, $19.95.) As a child in the Ukraine, Suzanne Rosenberg would be awakened by the gunfire of the Russian civil war. But she spent her formative teens in Montreal, where she was taken by her mother at the urging of their Canadian relatives.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Perhaps no hotel in the world has as remarkable a past or as controversial a future as the Plaza. Since the architect Henry J. Hardenbergh completed the French Renaissance-style structure in 1907, it has been the spot where gray-haired dowagers demurely sip tea in the Palm Court and giggling debutantes twirl through the Grand Ballroom until dawn.
LEAD: Ray Morehart, a reserve infielder on the 1927 New York Yankees, died at home Friday. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: A listing of Caribbean housekeeping accommodations on Dec. 11 included an erroneous report from the Cayman Islands Tourist Board about the status of the Driftwood Village apartments on Grand Cayman Island after Hurricane Gilbert. The resort remained open despite storm damage.
LEAD: VACATIONS, I've found, serve two purposes. They let us shed the woes and cares we've been carrying with us for months. They give us a chance to point ourselves in a new direction.

LEAD: ONE spring morning last year, Bob Walters decided to commute between Pleasantville and Yonkers by canoe instead of by car. For the environmental leader, the choice of a route less traveled - the Saw Mill River - and his successful navigation of it, ''made all the difference,'' as the poet Robert Frost once observed about such decisions.
LEAD: Cynics might suggest that John Thompson chose the perfect time and place for his protest.

LEAD: Re: ''To the Reagans: Happy Trails'' [ Letters, Jan. 8 ] . Those who read the papers and watch TV know that evacuation around a nuclear power plant in the event of emergency is required only for those within a 10-mile limit of the plant. Physicists are confident only two miles is necessary because of the improved safety of our U.S.

LEAD: William Squadron's story of his wife's agonizing wait for a suitable heart-lung organ transplant surely emphasizes the critical need for donors (''Two Lives on Hold,'' Dec. 18). One can only hope that thousands will respond by making the decision to become donors. In signing up with a human-parts bank, it is also helpful for the donor to inform his physician and lawyer, as well as next-of-kin.

LEAD: IN mid-August, in the small Outback town of Coober Pedy, South Australia, thieves broke into the home of an opal buyer and removed a safe containing about $750,000 in stones and cash. The local police began their investigation assuming that the valuables were still in the safe, that the safe was still in or around Coober

LEAD: The descent of winter on the garden and the produce market colors everything green, brown and ivory. People shopping wear looks of resignation. They may fill their baskets with bright red tomatoes or strawberries, knowing that lively color disguises something that tastes more like styrofoam than food.

LEAD: Pop musicians and their advisers slave to make themselves clear. They agonize over lyrics, try dozens of takes on solos, mix and remix arrangements, scrutinize album packages, fiddle with advertisements and re-edit videos according to private combinations of game plan and instinct. At some point in the project, they'll try to think like a casual listener, a radio program director or a longtime fan, all in attempts to guarantee that their initial inspiration comes through just the way they planned it.
LEAD: My friend McCutcheon was wallowing in richness, breathing in the aroma of new leather. ''One thing you got to say,'' he said, ''this thing is luxurious.''

LEAD: Until recently, electronic still photography manufacturers had been chasing after the business and professional sector because of its specialized needs and ample budgets. Now they are turning their attention to the average consumer.

LEAD: Julia Welles Pierson, a daughter of Mrs. John Jay Pierson of St. Paul and Gulf Stream, Fla., and the late Mr. Pierson, was married yesterday to Michael Edward Mombello, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gary Mombello of Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. Richard Lampert and the Rev. Thomas Mitchell, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St.

LEAD: Jill Greenwald and Jonathan Roy Liebman, a son of Muriel Liebman of Hartsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Theodore Liebman, plan to marry in May, the the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. James H. Greenwald of Olympia Fields, Ill., have announced.
LEAD: Gentrification, a New England woman complains, is not exactly the word for what's happening to her town. Cute is more like it.
LEAD: ''Dr. Greenspan is administering the medicine the economy needs. The unintended side effect is that the dollar gets too strong.'' Neal M. Soss, chief economist, First Boston Corporation.

LEAD: When Bill Cosby gave $20 million to Spelman College in Atlanta, the largest individual donation ever made to a black college, he made it clear that he intended the money not just as a gift but as a challenge to other black Americans to support black colleges.

LEAD: Fashion can catch us up in the excitement of the moment, lending a surge of energy to contemporary artworks. But fashion can be cruel, too, and nowhere is it crueler than in the consignment of once-honorable, once-popular composers to oblivion.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE basketball court has long been a sanctuary for David Rivers. Whether it is a shiny wooden floor in a famous arena, or bent rims on a glass-strewn playground, all he needs is a basketball to control the action.

LEAD: There are lots of things that tiny A&W Brands Inc. just cannot do. It cannot hype its sales and brand awareness by getting McDonald's or Burger King to serve its root beer; a contract with the A&W restaurant chain prohibits the soft drink maker from selling to any other fountain operation.
LEAD: A New 60-foot bridge in Middletown represents a step back in time, both in technology and price, but transportation planners hope that it also offers a glimpse of the future.
LEAD: It was a first-half laugher at Madison Square Garden last night.

LEAD: Carle Place $242,000 4 Midtown Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement, eat-in kitchen, dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,400. Hauppauge $190,000 22 Saturn Boulevard 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; dining room, den, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $3,800.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. David H. Fairburn of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Lisa Farnsworth Fairburn to Todd Rhoads Clark,the son of Mr. and Mrs. C. William Clark Jr. of Harvard, Mass. The couple plan to marry in June.

LEAD: THE ousted director of the Playland Amusement Park in Rye, indicted for having used park employees to assist in Republican Party mailings, has responded by accusing the District Attorney, Carl A. Vergari, of conduct ''virtually identical'' to that attributed to the director.

LEAD: Millions of Americans will soon be knocking on their accountants' doors, an annual rite as the tax-filing deadline nears. Besides seeking the obligatory help in cutting their tax bills, many clients will ask the accountants to go one step further and provide broad financial assistance and investment advice.
LEAD: The Koch administration has offered a plan to force many residents of middle-income subsidized housing into smaller apartments, and many of the residents are bitterly opposed to the program.

LEAD: Q. We have been caring for our teak furniture by rubbing it periodically with an oil sold specifically for this type of unvarnished furniture. However, the wood seems to have darkened over the years. The other day I repaired the top of one piece, and I first cleaned off the surface with acetone. I was amazed to see how clean and light the finish looked after cleaning it with this solvent.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WITNESS A WORD with its meaning being stretched.
LEAD: Dr. John L. Norris, a former chairman of Alcoholics Anonymous, died of complications from pneumonia Friday in New London Hospital in New Hampshire. He was 85 years old and lived in New London.

LEAD: To the Editor: In her ''Abroad but Aground'' (Practical Traveler, Nov. 6) Betsy Wade defines the flight delay problem well but does not point out that the most common example is not the long international flight but rather the everyday short-haul domestic flight.
LEAD: FROM Baroque to burlesque, from gospel to Gershwin, from song to symphony, the Connecticut music scene has definitely returned to its pre-holiday level of activity.

LEAD: Despite the serious issues considered at the just-concluded National Collegiate Athletic Association convention and the recent controversy involving Jim Valvano and North Carolina State, I think the status of collegiate basketball has never been better. The quality of coaching, the new rules that have dramatically improved the style and flow of the game, the incredible individual talent and the dozens of teams that can realistically set their sights on the national championship all combine to enhance the already grand expectations for the 1990's.

LEAD: Tony Granato, a towel draped around his stiffening neck, stood in the Ranger locker room and ran a hand softly across his face, assessing the afternoon's damage. There was a nasty gash under his right eye and a red welt covering his forehead, and his ears had the look of cauliflower.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Usually, it's George Steinbrenner who is the scrutinizer. He scrutinizes his manager, he scrutinizes his pitching coach, he scrutinizes his players, he scrutinizes his general manager, not to mention everyone else who works for him. Now, however, the Yankees' owner has become the scrutinized.

LEAD: Schubert and Schumann have been getting a workout by some of the biggest pianistic guns in the contemporary arsenal. The most ambitious undertaking is a two-disk excursion into the last three Schubert sonatas, the three Klavierstueck and the C minor Allegretto played by Maurizio Pollini (Deutsche Grammophon 419 229-2).

LEAD: ON the ''Tonight'' show one night last month, the comedian Larry Miller was describing a Thanksgiving family dinner that ''starts out great, with the kids in polo shirts chasing puppy dogs through piles of leaves,'' until animosities surface.

LEAD: In many ways Zimbabwe is the success story of black Africa. Food production is booming. The country's foreign debt is low. Visitors arriving here from elsewhere in Africa, or from abroad, remark on the prosperity in this capital city.
LEAD: When a Protestant minister in Maine became overwhelmed by personal problems, he sought help not from a psychiatrist but from a rabbi.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Ellen R. Dickman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin L. Dickman of New York, was married in New York last evening to Steven Koch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Koch, also of New York. Rabbi Jacqueline Koch Ellenson, a cousin of the bridegroom, and Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg officiated at the Rainbow Room.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The pianist Richard Goode will play works by Beethoven, Schubert, Chopin and Debussy at Alice Tully Hall today at 3 P.M. Tickets are $17.50. Information: 874-6770.
LEAD: CITY FOR SALE Ed Koch and the Betrayal of New York. By Jack Newfield and Wayne Barrett. Illustrated. 466 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.

LEAD: Music becomes a little self-conscious when called upon to describe itself, whether in Mozart's ''Impresario'' and the whole tribe of parody operas about how funny opera supposedly is or in the family of rhapsodies and apostrophes to which the odes to St. Cecilia by Purcell and Handel belong. The two most substantial of those composers' Cecilian offerings - Purcell's ''Hail, Bright Cecilia'' of 1692, with words by Nicholas Brady, and Handel's 1739 ode to verses by Dryden - were sung by Musica Sacra under Richard Westenburg, with an orchestra of period instruments, at Alice Tully Hall

LEAD: The article ''Shoreham Impasse: Suggested Solutions'' (Jan. 1, 1989) failed to include comments from people representing the views of a majority of Long Island's scientists, engineers and physicians. Having participated with many of my colleagues in the analysis of numerous Shoreham issues, I believe that the following conclusions represent the prevailing professional opinion of this group.
LEAD: THE NOTEBOOK By Agota Kristof. Translated by Alan Sheridan. 183 pp. New York: Grove Press. $15.95.

LEAD: AS I watch the plumbing in my 35-year-old house get rusty and I realize I'm getting the same way, I wonder what the future holds for me. At 50-plus (where did the time go?), when I squander my energies on a cleaning spree or on preparing fancy meals for 10, I find myself footsore, short-winded, exhausted.

LEAD: When Senator Edward M. Kennedy posed with his nephew, John F. Kennedy Jr., at the podium at last summer's Democratic National Convention in Atlanta, a photographer from USA Today snapped a picture of the scene at 9:07 P.M. Twenty-one minutes later, editors in the newspaper's home office in Roslyn, Va., had the resulting photo in hand and were preparing color separations from it for the front page of the next day's edition, which had a 10 P.M.
LEAD: EDWARD R. MURROW An American Original. By Joseph E. Persico. Illustrated. 562 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Publishing Company. $24.95.

LEAD: As law enforcement officers go, the New York City Police have never had a reputation for being particularly conformist. And Nick Starkey, the shaggy, mustachioed protagonist of ''The January Man,'' an offbeat political melodrama that opened Friday, is hardly your average Gotham police officer. Not by a long shot.
LEAD: Just past the stuffed bird displays and behind the Aztec statues, a new exhibition on South American tribes will open this Friday at the American Museum of Natural History.

LEAD: The newly appointed Federal ''drug czar'' sits at his desk, putting the finishing touches on a new strategy to stop traffic in addictive substances that can threaten health and life itself. Satisfied with his work, he leans back and lights up a cigarette.

LEAD: Kate James Horning and Mark Spencer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Spencer of Annapolis, Md., plan to marry in June, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Horning of Fairfield, Conn., have announced.

LEAD: DESPITE attempts to introduce modern, refined bread, the Portuguese by and large prefer the old-fashioned country kind, loaves that are big and rough and the color of earth, with crisp crust and a moist interior.

LEAD: AMERICANS will watch on their television sets this week the grand ceremony of inauguration, when those chosen by politics are invested as the leaders of Government. As he takes the oath of office Friday as the 41st President, George Herbert Walker Bush will be surrounded on the steps of the Capitol by the members of the 101st Congress.

LEAD: WHEN studying catalogues from nurseries and seed houses, don't get lost in colorful pictures; look for unusual and challenging introductions to make this year a particularly rewarding one in horicultural expertise. Keep bird feeders stocked with fresh supplies of their favorite seeds; provide water daily, if an outdoor heater is available so the water does not freeze.
LEAD: THE classical prescription for winning was to more or less slowly outmaneuver the opponent by trenchant positional play and, when all was in readiness, to strike with the decisive combination.

LEAD: To the Editor: The Dec. 18 Q & A included a California couple's request for sources of information on freighter travel. Besides the two publications suggested, freighter information of a different nature is available from the Freighter Travel Club of America (Post Office Box 12693, Salem, Ore. 97302).

LEAD: Dorothy M. Desrochers, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Desrochers of Baltimore, and Bradford L. McLane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. McLane of New Canaan, Conn., plan to marry in April.

LEAD: I RECENTLY watched Frank Capra's ''It's a Wonderful Life'' for the eighth time. As always, I was emotionally uplifted by the story, which paints good and evil in broad strokes, letting the former prevail. But I was also saddened, for the movie highlighted a major failing of too many of my contemporaries - their need to measure success in terms of material wealth.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, the Theater View column on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today appears with a sentence omitted. The sentence should have read, ''An old poster behind a refreshment stand at the Royal Shakespeare's present London base reawakened my memory of Mr. Hall's restoration of another Broadway failure, Edward Albee's 'All Over,' with Peggy Ashcroft and Angela Lansbury, at the Aldwych Theater in 1972.

LEAD: WHILE one might wonder just what it is about ''Fathers and Sons'' that has drawn one playwright after another - all of different nationalities - to dramatizing Ivan Turgenev's 1862 Russian novel, it is clear that George F. Walker's version is the popular play of the regional theater season.
LEAD: THE CLINICAL DIARY OF SANDOR FERENCZI Edited by Judith Dupont. Translated by Michael Balint and Nicola Zardy Jackson. 227 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $29.95.
LEAD: The Maine Public Utilities Commission has refused to allow the state's largest utility to buy electrical power from Canada, a plan that would have required laying a 140-mile power line.

LEAD: A June wedding is planned by Paige Alison Gilbert and Daniel Jon Goldfarb, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Gilbert of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Goldfarb is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin F. Goldfarb of Bryn Mawr, Pa.
LEAD: LOST IN TRANSLATION A Life in a New Language By Eva Hoffman. 280 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

LEAD: CONNECTICUT ski resorts are collectively off to one of their best starts ever, largely because of an early-season dearth of natural snow in Vermont, a colder-than-normal December, relatively cheaper lift tickets and continuing expansion.
LEAD: HAMPTON IN MONTCLAIR Lionel Hampton, a giant of jazz who has performed with virtually all the other jazz greats, will appear with his orchestra Saturday night in Montclair.
LEAD: THE voice coming from my answering machine was brusque, the message explicit.

LEAD: FROM the hundreds of soldiers who marched along the Champs Elysees in August 1944, one more has stepped forward to identify himself on the 1945 stamp that honored the United States Army. The soldier is Alfred G. Gilbert, who has retired from the dressmaking industry in New York City and lives in Bala Cynwyd, Pa.
LEAD: More than 300 pounds of a powerful plastic explosive stolen from a mine were seized in a raid by Federal agents posing as buyers for the material, the authorities said today.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Eileen C. Weiler of New York and Sun Valley, Idaho, of the engagement of her daughter, Pamela Brooke Weiler, to Douglas Keane Grayson, the son of Dr. Isabel T. Whitehill-Grayson and Dr. Bernard N. Grayson of Brooklyn. Miss Weiler, the daughter also of the late Henry Weiler, and her fiance plan to marry in

LEAD: SCARFS are making a strong fashion statement this year, so an exhibition opening Tuesday at the Hermes boutique at 11 East 57th Street is a timely one. Called ''A Scarf Is Born,'' the show will include demonstrations of scarf-making as well as a display of 100 framed scarfs chosen from the 900 designs in the company archives in

LEAD: President Reagan, saying ''Saturdays will never seem the same,'' delivered his final weekly radio talk to the nation today, thanking the American people for the chance to lead them in pursuit of ''the American saga.''

LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S Insurance Commissioner, Kenneth D. Merin, once suggested that the chief reason for the state's high automobile insurance rates was that it had more people and cars per square mile than any other state, ''and they keep bumping into each other.''

LEAD: The way Arnold Palmer sees it, if professional golf is to continue to prosper and expand there will have to be an end to the tugs-o'-war among rival national tours, including the separate United States, European and Japanese circuits. What is needed, he says, is the creation of one super all-world tour.

LEAD: Donald A. Schwartz, the president of the Medallic Art Company, was fidgeting. With just days left before Inauguration Day, everything in his production room was at a virtual standstill while workers were taking inventory.

LEAD: NOT since Dwight D. Eisenhower has an incoming President had more foreign policy experience than George Bush. As chief United States representative at the United Nations, as American liaison officer in Beijing, as Director of Central Intelligence and finally as Vice President, he has served a long, varied and testing apprenticeship.

LEAD: Henry Ford didn't believe in giving his customers much of a choice. When he launched his famous Model A in the l920's, he thought that painting the cars in different colors was wasteful. ''They can have any color they want,'' he declared, ''as long as it's black.''

LEAD: Has any new President ever been dealt a stronger hand in foreign affairs than George Bush? Consider the opportunities for progress, some of which senior officials in the new administration say they are already looking into.

LEAD: ''Apollo,'' which George Balanchine choreographed in 1928 to Stravinsky's ballet score ''Apollon Musagete,'' refers to Greek mythology but has also acquired a mythical aura of its own. A virtually all-new cast in a seminal Balanchine work, then, is a major event at the New York City Ballet.

LEAD: The Dec. 18 article ''Nannies Are Striving to Upgrade Status'' was informative, underscoring the importance of having qualified caregivers in the home. However, the article overlooked a resource that addresses the child-care needs of the family and is affordable and legal.

LEAD: Katmandu, capital of a kingdom closed to all but a few official foreigners until 1951, has done a lot of catching up, particularly in the last decade. While much of the country remains medievally rural, steeped in social traditions, religious customs and even superstitions established by centuries of practice, the outside world has made inroads all over Nepal, especially in the capital.

LEAD: Lacquering, an ancient craft combining exotic imagery, exquisite detailing and satiny finishes, has transformed a stunning variety of ordinary and esoteric objects over many centuries. LEAD: NATO and Warsaw Pact negotiators in Vienna announced an agreement today that cleared the way for the start of new negotiations on reducing conventional armed forces in Europe and for a major East-West document on human rights and economic cooperation.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Conlin of Ann Arbor, Mich., Harbor Springs, Mich., and Red Hook, V.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Anne Conlin to Daniel Hirsch Rivkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. LEAD: Marie Colvin tells us that Yasir Arafat has ''launched a campaign to convince the world - and Washington in particular - that there is now a new, moderate, realistic P.L.O.''

LEAD: The two ubiquitous artists of the late 1980's are Joseph Beuys and Andy Warhol. Beuys was featured in last year's inaugural exhibition of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles and given prime place in the 1987 Documenta, whose theme was social and political art. Warhol had a museum and gallery show in New York City last fall.

LEAD: Alabama's state prisons are back in state hands, more than 16 years after a Federal judge cited them for ''barbarous'' and ''shocking'' treatment of inmates and 13 years after he took control of the entire system.

LEAD: THE typical restoration story reads like a honeymoon, with a rosy aura of press releases, civic awards and back-patting. But the story of the Children's Aid Society's old Rhinelander Industrial School at 350 East 88th Street is more like a tale of child abuse.

LEAD: MOST CENTURIES, IN ORDER TO compensate for the accumulated irregularities of measured time, the calendar skips a leap year Feb. 29. There are watches complex enough to adjust for this. However, at the turn of every fourth century (the year 2000 is one), the one leap year day must be reinstated, compensating for a slightly out-of-whack compensation.

LEAD: Stefanie Pam Block, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Jay Block of Miami, was married there last evening to Evan Jared Reed, a son of Heidi A. Hyman of Danbury, Conn., and Boca Raton, Fla., and Ary Reed of Bethel, Conn. Rabbi Herbert M. Baumgard performed the ceremony at the Kings Bay Country Club.

LEAD: The N.C.A.A., like OPEC, is a cartel, and any economist will confirm that cartel members gain a competitive advantage by cheating on their fellow members. Since no big-time coach willingly yields or fails to pursue an edge, cheating naturally inheres in big-time college sport. It is one more way our major universities teach their students the futility of fairness and the wisdom of greed.

LEAD: When the founder of the Communist New People's Army, Bernabe Buscayno, began talking about shifting to a peaceful political struggle a couple of years ago, he set off a furious debate within the top echelons of the party that still has not been resolved.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Diana Beth Pietraszewski, a daughter of Mrs. Frank P. Pietraszewski of Simsbury, Conn., and the late Mr. Pietraszewski, was married yesterday to Edward Frederick Wagner Jr., the son of Mr. Wagner of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Columbus, Ohio, and the late Margaret Wagner.

LEAD: After five and a half years as the very visible United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani announced last week that he was leaving the job, touching off speculation that he would run for Mayor of New York.
LEAD: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, visiting Kabul, pledged continued ''all-around assistance'' to Afghanistan's beleaguered Government, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

LEAD: Marjorie Ann Curran, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Curran of Ashland, Mass., was married yesterday in Framingham, Mass., to Dr. Thomas Ptak, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Ptak of Fitchburg, Mass. The Rev. William H. McLaughlin performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: Boyd L. Jefferies puffed nervously on a Benson & Hedges cigarette while pacing the hallway of a Federal courthouse early last week. LEAD: The Thin Blue Line Featuring the principals in the case and, in re-enactments, Adam Goldfine, Derek Horton, Ron Thornhill, Marianne Leone, Amanda Caprio and Michael Nicoll. Directed by Errol Morris. 1988. HBO Video. 101 minutes. $89.99. Not rated.

LEAD: Navratilova Eliminates Mandlikova: Martina Navratilova advanced yesterday to the final of the New South Wales Open in Sydney, Australia. Navratilova, a three-time winner of the tournament, scored her 25th victory in 32 matches against Hana Mandlikova, winning, 6-3, 6-2. Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden also moved into today's final with a 5-7, 6-3, 7-6 victory over Terry Phelps of Larchmont, N.Y.(AP)
LEAD: FREEZING winter weather brings with it the threat of frozen plumbing. To minimize the risk, most household water pipes are deliberately situated away from unheated areas.
LEAD: Whenever Seton Hall faced a problem tonight, someone solved it.

LEAD: Medgar Evers College, a two-year community college in central Brooklyn with a long history of administrative problems, should be turned into a four-year institution to give it greater stability and status, an independent consulting firm has recommended.
LEAD: Pro golfers can make as much money as corporate sponsors are willing to put up in prizes. That has been the theme of the PGA Tour under Commissioner Deane Beman: money, money, money.
LEAD: Doctors at the Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh have stopped performing multiple-organ abdominal transplants until they can find a better way of keeping the body from rejecting the organs.

LEAD: IRELAND has its rains and winds; it also has some of their most effective antidotes. Irish civilization at its best puts sufficient warmth inside the home to counter the deepest chills or damp. The heat of a good peat fire penetrates; steaming tea and fresh wholemeal scones brace one against the elements.

LEAD: WHEN references are made to the courage of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. we may think of his willingness to challenge the system of segregation or his denunciation of our Government's involvement in the Vietnam War or his determination to continue his nonviolent protests despite persistent death threats, or all of these.

LEAD: ANYONE who has ever raised a boy knows that gym class is a metaphor for life. Here in the sports arena of junior athletics, the boys are separated from the men, wimps are weeded out from winners and coach is a deity second only to the Highest Power. I should know. I'm a sports mother, dedicated to the care and feeding of the next lean, mean money machines: two young athletes in the making.

LEAD: The police arrested 685 abortion opponents yesterday demonstrating outside Manhattan abortion clinics for the second consecutive day. Many of the protesters had stopped traffic, blocked sidewalks and, in once case, chained themselves together, the police said.

LEAD: A VACATION is - or should be - a time of relaxation, a time to put aside the daily routine and avoid petty annoyances. In short, a time to escape from stress. But vacation travel is fraught with situations that bring on stress: getting stuck in traffic on the way to the airport, waiting in line to check in, sitting on the runway wondering when the plane will take off, arriving at a hotel only to be told you have no reservation.

Guilmant's name and some of his work are known to organists - he was a notable teacher, of Nadia Boulanger among others -but his music rarely turns up in recitals.

LEAD: In her article, Marie Colvin writes, ''After 1967, when the Arabs lost the last inch of Palestine. . . .'' Our modern definition of Palestine is derived from the British Mandate on Palestine, which defines an area including Jordan and Israel as ''Palestine.'' Although it may hardly satisfy the Arabs on the West Bank, who want an independent state, the fact remains that there is an Arab Palestine - it is called Jordan.

LEAD: FOR a quarter of a century Vail has been one of America's big-league ski resorts. Now Vail is twice the area it was a year ago. That's not just a figure of speech. Vail this season has opened the China Bowl Expansion, a shorthand reference to the opening of four bowls (large, deep expanses of terrain mostly free of trees) on the back of the mountain - China, Teacup, Siberia and Mongolia - all made accessible by two new lifts.
LEAD: Since late last fall, I have been sliding certain brochures and letters into a manila folder which bears the legend ''faraway places.''

LEAD: The article on the increase in county taxes for 1989 [ ''Taxes Will Rise by Average of 9 Percent for Homeowners,'' Dec. 25 ] quoted the official explanation - rising corrections and homeless requirements. The first increase by $13.4 million, the second by $13.1 million. But the total budget rose from $847 million in 1988 to $930 million for 1989, a jump of $83 million.

LEAD: An article about a municipal building getting a face lift appeared in The New York Times on the same day that Melvin Konner's Body and Mind article ''Mortality'' did (Dec. 4). I doubt whether anyone would object to the ravages of time, weather and pollution being effaced from the building; one would rejoice, rather, that the landmark was being restored to its former splendor.

LEAD: A Bethel man on Wednesday was convicted of cruelty to animals for letting his cows starve to death and will spend nine days in prison, a court spokeswoman said Thursday. The man, David Townsend, 46 years old, who is now a truck driver, had farmed for 20 years before the discovery of dead and dying cows drove him out of business.

LEAD: ''IT'S amazing,'' said the hard-driving coach of the Bengals' receivers, Bruce Coslet, ''what a player will do for $5.''
LEAD: A subsidiary of the ABD Securities Corporation has become a specialist on the New York Stock Exchange - a rarity for a foreign-owned firm.

LEAD: The Roundabout Theater Company will announce today the appointment of Todd Haimes as its producing director, effective at the end of the 1989-90 season. Mr. Haimes, who is 32 years old, has been the company's managing director since 1983.

LEAD: As 1988 drew to a close, Turkey's Prime Minister Turgut Ozal received an unusual, and unwelcome, package in the mail: Five men from the western city of Denizli had sent him the belts to their trousers.

LEAD: A United States subsidiary of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. will end operations as a primary dealer of United States Treasury securities, the bank announced Friday, a little more than three months after the unit had gained approval to be a dealer from the Federal Reserve Board.

LEAD: NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: Regular collections. No street cleanings. Schools: Closed.

LEAD: THREE months later, the reminders are still being transmitted from Jerry Rice's left ankle. Rice's season goes on, longer than any of his three previous years with the San Francisco 49ers. His contribution has met the personal standards that his record-setting 1987 season established.

LEAD: When New York City's elementary and junior high schools were given greater autonomy 19 years ago, parents were supposed to gain direct control over their children's schooling through the local school boards that took over much of the central administration's responsibility.

LEAD: Introducing a new dimension to the cola wars, the Coca-Cola Company has been distributing 20 million 3-D glasses to retailers all over the country, including Walgreen, CVS and other chains in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

LEAD: Policemen used riot sticks, dogs and water cannon today to crush a rally commemorating the death 20 years ago of a student who set himself afire to protest the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.

LEAD: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, meeting on Tuesday to consider the nomination of James A. Baker 3d as Secretary of State, is preparing an examination dominated by questions on changes under way in the Soviet Union, according to a committee briefing paper.

LEAD: Two players who have won five national titles between them, Warren Rosner and Ron Gerard of White Plains, captured the Superflighted Pairs title at the Tri-State Regional Championships in Port Chester, N.Y., Saturday.

LEAD: Looking beyond the cold winter days toward June are Good Housekeeping and Sesame Street Magazine's ''Parents Guide.'' Together, they are preparing a special section called ''Kids of Summer,'' a 48-page section scheduled to appear in both magazines in June. The YMCA plans to distribute some 250,000 reprints of the issue to its 1,200 branches across the nation.

LEAD: Robert Lekachman, a teacher of economics whose maverick views often set him apart from mainstream economists, died of cancer of the liver Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old.

LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission has given the developer Donald J. Trump permission to buy more shares of Caesars World Inc. stock.

LEAD: In a city teeming with vibrant cultural institutions, the Hispanic Society of America has chosen to go its own anachronistic way. A magnificent cache of Spanish art and literature far from the busy museum-gallery scene of mid-Manhattan, it draws only 10,000 visitors a year, and its administration likes it that way.
LEAD: Philip J. Cram will be carrying the flag of Texaco Inc. in Canada after the oil company sells its 78 percent interest in Texaco Canada Inc.

LEAD: Paperback publishers rely heavily on freelancers to write the copy for the covers of paperback books. ''Some are aspiring writers, some moonlight while they work as editorial assistants in publishing houses, but some do it full time,'' said Natalee Rosenstein, the Berkley Publishing Group's executive copy chief, who herself started as a freelance copy writer.

LEAD: For the last six weeks, 15 prison inmates have assembled daily in a classroom here to consider the harm they have caused others, including the strangers they have assaulted, robbed or raped and the family members they have abused, stigmatized or left abandoned.

Born and reared in New York . . . Graduated from New York University with highest honors .

LEAD: Naomi Sue Freeman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Freeman of Millburn, N.J., and Morris Klein, the son of Mae Klein of Pittsburgh and the late Abraham Klein, were married yesterday at the Small Jewish Museum in Washington by Rabbi Max Ticktin.
LEAD: For many tribal members, being a Pamunkey Indian these days is as much a state of mind as anything.
LEAD: For the Rangers, silliness seemed the order of the day.

LEAD: In the two weeks since West German companies were accused of helping to outfit a suspect chemical plant in Libya, West German officials have gone from a petulant defensiveness to the surprising admission that they knew all about it long before the Americans told them of their concerns.

LEAD: The New York City Ballet is offering a cascade of debuts this season. On Saturday afternoon, Damian Woetzel, one of the company's most promising young male dancers, was seen for the first time in George Balanchine's ''Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux'' at the New York State Theater.

LEAD: Almost three-quarters of the victims of violent crimes who survived to tell about it say they made some effort to protect themselves, and most believe their resistance was worthwhile, a Federal survey shows.

LEAD: Additional charges will be brought against the top officers of a defunct New Jersey investment partnership who were indicted last summer on charges of engaging in a racketeering conspiracy, lawyers in the case said yesterday.
LEAD: Seven people were killed and eight others were injured here early today when a fire swept through a boarding house on the bluffs overlooking the Hudson River.

LEAD: A Colorado start-up company backed by a Japanese electronics giant will introduce on Monday a line of computers it says is fully compatible with a popular work station sold by Sun Microsystems Inc., the leader in the engineering work station business.

LEAD: Cardinal Hayes High School of the Bronx upset Lincoln of Brooklyn yesterday, 77-75, in the second game of the Martin Luther King Classic at St. Francis College in Brooklyn. Lincoln's defeat was its first of the season by a New York City school.

LEAD: The 1989 Surgeon General's report calls it ''phenomenal,'' and it surely is. Nearly half of all living adults who ever smoked have quit. In doing so they have kicked a habit responsible for more than one out of every six American deaths. Surgeon General C. Everett Koop warns, however, that progress has to continue and accelerate or the health impact of smoking will remain into the 21st century.

LEAD: Perestroika has rippled through Finland, the Western nation with the longest and most extensive trading relationship with the Soviet Union, causing almost as much turmoil and uncertainty in board rooms and government offices as the restructuring has brought on the other side of the border.

LEAD: Credit market conditions could well stabilize or perhaps even improve a bit more during the next few weeks, buttressed by strong technical factors and interest rates that hover close to or above 9 percent across the maturity spectrum.
LEAD: Maybe Pitt should stick with top 10 opponents. Just ask the Oklahoma coach, Billy Tubbs.

LEAD: President-elect George Bush's economic policy appointees are ideological agnostics who call themselves results-oriented, and they are. But Mr. Bush has yet to present them with a detailed map for reaching his goal of budget reduction and continued prosperity.

LEAD: In Milltown, N.J., in 1940, Edward W. Bradley was chosen by his eighth-grade teacher to deliver Special Delivery letters around town for the local postmaster. The only requirements were to get a bicycle and to report to the Post Office every morning at 6:30 sharp. Mr. Bradley recalled delivering hundreds of letters, receiving about 8 cents for each of them.

LEAD: Although Sarah Rothenberg's piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday night was a conscious effort to blend new music with old, attention and curiosity turned naturally to the former. Bruce Adolphe's ''. . . And Time Future Contained in Time Past . . .'' is a piece made whole by its scrupulous and intelligent economy.

LEAD: As they continue exposing Stalin's repressions and trying to correct the many distortions of official history, historians and journalists here have begun to sketch a clearer picture of a complex figure whose role in setting up Soviet power was blotted out for 60 years: Leon Trotsky.

LEAD: With the Christmas rush over, Alfred Chappy Morris of Manhattan sent his annual contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, saying, ''I know it is never too late to help those in need.'' He donated $250.

LEAD: ''Guys like to fight - it's like petting but it's hard and very fast,'' observes John O'Keefe in ''Shimmer,'' a rivetingly kinetic solo performance piece in which he remembers his troubled adolescence in Iowa in the mid-1950's.

LEAD: Fishing report, Friday, Jan. 13: The Vice President caught a 13-pound bonefish, using 8-pound line with spin-casting gear.

LEAD: 'Phantom' Mini-Series For years, Arthur Kopit wanted to write a musical based on the Gaston Leroux novel ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' The playwright had even collaborated on an adaptation with Maury Yeston, a composer with whom he had created the Broadway musical ''Nine.''

LEAD: The cover conference at Berkley Books was under way for only a few minutes when someone raised the question: Should the cover on the paperback edition of the suspense novel ''Smoke and Mirrors'' actually depict a mirror?
LEAD: Scientists at Johns Hopkins University, using electrodes connected to a monkey's brain, say they have produced a computer image of the brain as it thinks.

LEAD: Sylvia Meagher, a writer and retired senior liaison officer of the World Health Organization at the United Nations, died of complications from the flu Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Each week about a dozen teen-age girls, some with babies in their arms, come to La Mariposa Health Station here to pick up $7 each, a dollar a day for not becoming pregnant again.

LEAD: When experts gathered here recently for a widely publicized conference on AIDS in Latin America, they used words and notions about people's sex lives that must have startled the more conservative corners of the continent.

LEAD: As a storm of insider trading allegations, some of them touching French Finance Ministry officials, continued to grow in intensity, President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Michel Rocard moved last week to try to contain the damage to their Government.

LEAD: Casinos are delivering payoffs in three recent buddy movies. In ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels,'' Michael Caine and Steve Martin compete for the fortune of a reputed soap heiress, Glenne Headly, at a Riviera roulette table. In ''Things Change,'' Joe Mantegna, a Mafia underling, takes Don Ameche on an outing to Atlantic City, where the old fellow is allowed to make a seeming killing before the mob boss decides to really kill him.

LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market. The regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, normally held on Mondays, will take place tomorrow. The Treasury cash market is closed today for the observance of Martin Luther King Day.

LEAD: An American Airlines jet bound for Dallas with 91 people aboard returned to Baltimore-Washington International Airport shortly after takeoff today when an engine caught fire. An airline spokeswoman said a part on the left engine of the McDonnell-Douglas MD80, Flight 201, apparently came loose and a compressor stalled, prompting the pilot to shut the engine.

LEAD: City Council members, civic leaders and lawyers who represent poor New Yorkers yesterday challenged the Koch administration's assertion that there had been public disclosure and debate over a change in city law that benefited the developer Harry Macklowe.

LEAD: Dispute Over Building Ban City Council members challenged Mayor Koch's account of public disclosure of a change in a law that benefited a developer. Page B1. 7 Die in Yonkers Fire In the city's worst fire in years, seven people were killed and eight injured when flames swept through a boarding house.

LEAD: Cesar Pelli & Associates, a Connecticut architectural firm, is to receive the 1989 Architectural Firm Award from the American Institute of Architects in May at its National Convention in St. Louis, the institute has announced. The award is given annually to a firm that ''has consistently produced distinguished architecture for at least 10 years.
LEAD: A civil rights advocate, who arranged a sting operation to prove local police harass blacks, said today that an officer beat him and pushed his head through a window in a routine traffic stop.

LEAD: President Reagan is expected this week to lift some prohibitions on American oil companies doing business in Libya to prevent theirlosing their assets in the country, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: The man who compiled these statistics doesn't put much faith in his own figures. But for the record, attendance at college football games declined a bit last season, providing further evidence that the proliferation of televised games may be keeping some fans at home on fall Saturdays.
LEAD: One of the most ambitious postwar plans for opera on an international level has exploded with the ouster of Daniel Barenboim as artistic director of the new Bastille Opera of Paris.

LEAD: The Classical Quartet, which generally plays music from the Mozart-Haydn era suggested by its name, is branching out somewhat this season. Saturday evening at St. Michael's Church (Amsterdam Avenue and 99th Street), the group investigated Baroque territory already familiar to most period-instrument players - including, no doubt, this foursome, since all are active with other early-music ensembles.
LEAD: Micheline Keating, a novelist and reporter, died Friday in a nursing home in Tucson, Ariz. She was believed to be about 85 years old.

LEAD: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has acquired the Connecticut Consulting Group, a 10-year-old marketing planning and promotion services company in Wilton, Conn. Terms were not disclosed. D.M.B.& B. said it planned to merge the firm into Ted Colangelo Associates, its Greenwich, Conn.-based subsidiary specializing in marketing and corporate communications, including sales promotion, package design and direct marketing.

LEAD: FIVE months after Hollywood returned to work at the end of a paralyzing strike against producers by the Writers Guild of America, the three networks are assessing the costs and the consequences of the strike - particularly its impact on viewer habits and on revenue.

LEAD: Composers of the world seem to have found each other in the last generation, and their elaborate efforts to homogenize once-distant cultures, to find meeting grounds for once-irreconcilable music styles, are ending up in programs like Aki Takahashi's piano recital at the Asia Society late Saturday afternoon.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: At the time of the breakup of the Bell System, few would have picked Cincinnati Bell Inc. to emerge as a star performer. But it has done just that.

LEAD: The Boston Company's profits for the first three quarters of 1988 were overstated by $30 million, more than twice as high as preliminary estimates, officials with the investment firm said. Shearson Lehman Hutton

LEAD: SHORTLY after arriving in Miami this week, each of the 90,000 visitors expected for Super Bowl XXIII at Joe Robbie Stadium next Sunday will receive an original piece of artwork: the medium is crayon, the artists nearly 100,000 students in the Dade County elementary school system.
LEAD: There have been fantasy camps where those who dream of playing major league baseball can rub elbows with real former major leaguers.

LEAD: TWO years ago, a skier riding sideways on a single, wide snub-nosed ski was a rare sight. Most conventional skiers dismissed it as a fad. Today, between 200,000 and 250,000 people are climbing onto snowboards and swiveling downhill, according to the North American Snowboard Association, the sport's governing body.
LEAD: The Reagan Administration is likely to allow five American oil companies to resume doing business in Libya, U.S. officials said. Page A7.
LEAD: President Reagan said in a television interview broadcast today that he does not believe the United States will be ''completely civilized'' until it stops abortion.

LEAD: After 34 years out of power, a stint of minority status unbroken since cars had fins, Republicans in the House of Representatives have had it. In the face of a muscular Democratic majority of 259-to-174, signs of a new Republican scrappiness abound.

LEAD: A sculpture depicting a contemporary creche of a homeless family huddled on a steam grate is the centerpiece of a legal battle over whether the creator or the patron of a commissioned work of art owns the copyright for it, and thus sometimes lucrative licensing and reproduction rights.
LEAD: The Soviet Union reduced its trade with Cuba by 12 percent in the first quarter of 1988, according to documents of the Cuban National Bank made available here.

LEAD: A crowd of 15,000 chanting, cheering protesters marched through Managua today to dramatize their grievances against the Nicaraguan Government in the broadest collection of opposition groups since the Sandinista Front took power in 1979.
LEAD: * Goya Foods Inc. to Angotti, Thomas, Hedge, with a budget in the $3 million to $5 million range.

LEAD: Just a decade ago, media companies especially wanted to own network-affiliated television stations. The seemingly inevitable increases in advertiser spending, predictable cash flows and loyal audiences made owning a network affiliate a sure-fire investment.

LEAD: ''Trotsky is no longer the evil spirit of Russian history. He's simply a political leader who held rather unacceptable views in many ways.'' - Adam B. Ulam, professor of government at Harvard, on emerging new views of Leon Trotsky. [ A3:4. ]

LEAD: THE cottontail rabbit is the most sought-after small-game animal in this country.

LEAD: Banks and Government offices will be closed Monday to observe Martin Luther King Day. The stock markets will be open, and there will be foreign exchange trading.

LEAD: Like their counterparts in California, New Jersey drivers are fed up with soaring auto insurance bills and won't let state officials rest until they've done something about it. LEAD: James A. Davidson, the founder and board chairman of the Hampton Jitney, a bus service between eastern Long Island and Manhattan, died of complications from AIDS yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 48 years old and had homes in Water Mill, L.I., and Cocoanut Grove, Fla.

LEAD: Commercial banks proved to be willing lenders for the $24.88 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

LEAD: Senator Christopher J. Dodd has a suggestion for colleagues who say they oppose the 50 percent pay increase recommended by a Federal commission: Give it back.

LEAD: Thanks to the Art Institute of Chicago, and above all to its director, James N. LEAD: The results of two ballots on Proposition 42, an amendment to the N.C.A.A. bylaw popularly known as Proposition 48. Proposition 42 would tighten academic requirements for an athletic scholarship. The first vote was Jan. 10, with the proposition being defeated by 159-151. On a second vote, on Jan. 11, the proposition was passed, 163-154.

The company also announced selected price cuts for expensive products, effectively rolling back part of the unusual price rises it made in September.

LEAD: Iran's Prime Minister met today with Italian leaders and with Pope John Paul II, receiving pledges of aid to rebuild the Iranian economy but also hearing calls for human rights improvements and for swift prisoner-of-war exchanges.
LEAD: Beginning with its 1989-90 editions, the Nynex Yellow Pages will be reorganized to include a previously unpublished listing: gay and lesbian services.

LEAD: An article on Friday about foreign reaction to Emperor Hirohito's death misidentified a South Korean official who visited the Japanese Embassy in Seoul to sign a book of condolences.

LEAD: The police used force to clear the streets last night as blacks burned automobiles and threw bottles in the Overtown section for the second night and violence spread to another black neighborhood.

LEAD: Poland's Communist Party approved a complex plan early today that if accepted would lead to the legalization of the outlawed Solidarity labor union. But it contained conditions that senior Solidarity advisers have said make it virtually impossible to accept.
LEAD: Bobby Martin scored 17 points and Jason Matthews added 16 to lead Pitt to a 73-64 Big East victory over Boston College tonight.

LEAD: George Bush ascends to the Oval Office this Friday having made a broad set of domestic policy promises: to clean up the environment, fight drug abuse, improve education and make day care more affordable for the poor.

LEAD: Walter Payton, who rushed for more yards in his career than any other professional football player, was named the winner of the Dapper Dan Club's fifth annual Farewell to Sport Award yesterday. The honor goes to a retiring athlete who exemplifies competitive excellence and service to the community.

LEAD: THE dinner began with woodcock breasts in brandy sauce and ended, 44 dishes later, with chocolate truffles. ''If anybody's still hungry after this, you can go get a pizza,'' said Mark Avondoglio, one of the hosts, to the 110 guests, many of them hunters and fishermen.

LEAD: A famous clown named Max Luck is in Florida rehearsing a role in an avant-garde tragicomedy (very much like ''Waiting for Godot''), and his insecurity in the play sends him into a swirl of memories about his early days in vaudeville. For many years, he and his partner, Maxie (later his first wife), had been struggling troupers.

LEAD: Smith Barney Inc., the big securities firm owned by the Primerica Corporation, will announce today that it plans to re-enter the risk arbitrage business on Feb. 1, Frank Zarb, the company's chairman and chief executive, said yesterday.

LEAD: The mother of Samantha Smith, a Maine schoolgirl who visited the Soviet Union on a peace mission at the invitation of the Soviet head of state, has settled a $50 million lawsuit she filed after the girl and her father died in a plane crash, a lawyer said today.

LEAD: The statue of Dr. David Livingstone gazes out across the falls, a roaring curtain of water more than a mile wide that is truly one of the world's wonders. He was, as a signboard explains, ''the first European to see the falls, which he named in honor of Queen Victoria.''

LEAD: Faced with an indication that he has planned to resign as coach of the San Francisco 49ers after Super Bowl XXIII Sunday, Bill Walsh repeated today that he would not make that decision until after the game.

LEAD: DOCTORS at most family-planning groups and student health clinics surveyed said they did not plan to change guidelines for prescribing contraceptive pills in the wake of three new studies linking the pills with increased risks of breast cancer.

LEAD: The start of the Rockwell International Corporation's trial on charges of overbilling the Air Force on a navigation-satellite contract was delayed today after the company and Federal prosecutors apparently made progress in negotiating an out-of-court settlement.

LEAD: Columbia University will establish a graduate fellowship program next fall in American and international studies with students from the United States, the Soviet Union and four other countries, school officials say.

LEAD: The State Department has disclosed that United States and Soviet officials have started talks on the repayment of bonds issued by the czarist Government of Russia but repudiated after the Soviet revolution of 1917.
LEAD: The Justice Department's ethics office said yesterday that if Edwin Meese 3d were still Attorney General he should be subjected to Presidential discipline.
LEAD: EVERYONE in the Miller household admits that living the past eight months under one roof has taken some adjusting.

LEAD: It would not be fair to say that Larry Roberts was being pushed around a season ago. He was in his second season as a defensive end with the San Francisco 49ers, primarily responsible for an outside rush in passing situations, when injuries suddenly necessitated a new role and created extenuating circumstances.

LEAD: Symphony Saintpaulia and its associated choirs, the Voices Saintpaulia, made their Carnegie Hall debuts Monday night in a tribute to the Rev. LEAD: The Department of Transportation, after reviewing the financial and managerial fitness of Donald J. Trump to run an airline, gave its initial approval today for the New York real estate developer to buy the air shuttle operations of Eastern Airlines.

LEAD: The Association of Tennis Professionals unveiled its inaugural tour yesterday, a 77-event schedule for 1990 that includes new tournaments in China and the Soviet Union while omitting several major American events that had been fixtures of the tour operated by the Men's Tennis Council.

LEAD: A gynecologist who faces charges from the State Medical Board that he performed unnecessary surgery on women has offered to surrender his certificate to practice medicine, his lawyer, Earl Moore, said Tuesday. Dr. James C. Burt asserted that the genital surgery would enhance sexual responsiveness.

LEAD: United Parcel Service announced the acquisition of seven transport companies, which it said would strengthen its operations in Europe and the Pacific. The acquisitions, whose terms were not disclosed, will also facilitate the company's expansion into the Middle East and Africa, it said.

LEAD: The Mood is Generally Optimistic

LEAD: A man who said he was the rapist who has attacked seven women in the subway called the police yesterday and arranged to surrender, but then failed to show up, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said.

LEAD: Aldo DeDominicis, who founded the first television station in New England, died Tuesday at Hartford Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Cheshire, Mr. DeDominicis and a partner, Patrick Goode, financed and built what is now WTNH-TV in New Haven in 1948. Earlier in the 40's, Mr. DeDominicis was a co-founder of WNHC-AM in New Haven and bought stations in New Britain that he renamed WRCH-AM and FM.

LEAD: As might have been expected, when a bumbling bank robber dropped the $2,900 he had just stolen from Redlands Federal Savings on Tuesday, passersby quickly gathered to grab what was blowing in the wind. What they caught they returned to the bank. All but $20 was turned in, said Sgt. Dan Castellini.

LEAD: The duo of Kenny Barron on piano and Red Mitchell on bass will perform tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Music begins at 9:30 P.M.; there is a $5 cover and an $8 minimum.

LEAD: Motorola Inc. filed a lawsuit Wednesday charging that Hitachi Ltd. had infringed on several of its patents and was engaging in unfair competition in the sale of microprocessors. In the lawsuit filed in United

LEAD: They have talked enough about the blitz to make them blue and plenty more about who will shuffle last and who will slip first, who has the edge and who has the heart in Super Bowl XXIII. They have played the game 100 times in practices and several times more in their sleep.

LEAD: In great blues and country performances, there's usually a moment where the music drops to a hush and the singer quietly confesses stark, primal terrors. Cowboy Junkies, a Canadian band that sold out the Bottom Line on Tuesday, want to extend that moment through its entire repertory.

LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices closed narrowly mixed yesterday as the fixed-income securities markets were again dominated by the gyrations in the dollar. Dealers said that moves by several European countries to raise domestic interest rates were ignored by the bond market, as were several economic reports that would usually be considered positive for the market.

LEAD: The exhibition ''The Age of William III and Mary II; Power; Politics and Patronage, 1688-1702'' continues through Jan. 28 at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street. For the first time on display outside the archives of the House of Lords, is the Declaration of Rights, which effectively established parliamentary rule in Britain and is considered the most important document in English history after Magna Carta.

LEAD: Micro D Inc., a distributor of microcomputer hardware, software and books, said today that it had agreed in principle to be acquired by Ingram Industries for $14.75 a share in cash. Ingram, a privately held company based in Nashville, already owns about 59 percent of Micro D, of Santa Ana, Calif.
LEAD: Friday WOOLF'S WOMEN
LEAD: Steve Jones's attempt to win a third consecutive PGA Tour event got off to a fair start today in the first round of the Phoenix Open as he shot three-under-par 68.

LEAD: Not everyone is celebrating in Washington today. Hundreds of frustrated out-of-towners are spending their first hours in town in the cavernous Convention Center, standing in long lines and sitting in abject resignation in the Error Resolution Area.

LEAD: Thirteen letters written by Aleksandr Pushkin were handed over to a Soviet official at a ceremony in a Geneva hotel Wednesday night. The letters once belonged to a member of the Czar's family and later to Sergei Diaghilev.

LEAD: Ramesh Krishnan of India defeated Mats Wilander, 6-3, 6-2, 7-6, in the second round of the Australian Open today, leaving the top-ranked player in the world contemplating a complete break from the sport.
LEAD: Intimacy By Susan Chace 161 pages. Random House. $14.95.

LEAD: With the Beach Boys at the Lincoln Memorial, a mariachi band at the Kennedy Center, rhythm-and-blues at the Washington Convention Center and country music everywhere, the entertainment for the inaugural festivities adds up to the capital's most populist cultural event since the heyday of Jimmy Carter.

LEAD: Bob Satterfield, a Notre Dame player, collapsed at a nightclub and died yesterday, a few hours after returning with his teammates from a White House visit, school officials said. A preliminary autopsy indicated that Satterfield, 22 years old, suffered a seizure followed by cardiac arrest, said the Notre Dame sports-information director, John Heisler.
LEAD: Of the 50 formal inaugural ceremonies that have installed American Presidents from George Washington to Ronald Reagan, only a handful remain memorable.

LEAD: A letter signed with the names of four members of the Bingham publishing family of Louisville, Ky., has been sent to book reviewers with documents to try to support what it calls misstatements in ''Passion and Prejudice'' by Sallie Bingham. The book is to be published by Alfred A. Knopf on Feb. 3.

LEAD: SKIING Walliser Wins Again: Maria Walliser of Switzerland won her second World Cup race of the season, defeating Carole Merle of France yesterday in a women's downhill in Tignes, France. Walliser was timed in 1 minute 19.16 seconds. Merle, who moved to second place in the overall standing, was clocked in 1:19.57.

LEAD: ''Field of Honor'' was shown as part of the 1988 New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 18. The film, in French with English subtitles, opens today at the Carnegie Screening Room, Seventh Avenue at 57th Street.

LEAD: A Federal district judge issued a restraining order tonight that bars the Government from destroying computer files containing interoffice messages sent by Reagan Administration officials on the White House computer.

LEAD: Presidents' inaugural addresses from George Washington onward have dwelled on similar themes. Turn them upside-down, shake them out, and one can excerpt and assemble the parts into a single all-purpose speech, like the following. (The authors are footnoted below.)
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Everett Quinton is sitting in the front row of the Charles Ludlam Theater thinking about the last two years.

LEAD: Jerry Rice, the San Francisco 49ers' dangerous pass receiver, did limited work today in a 90-minute practice session at the University of Miami field. Coach Bill Walsh said he expected Rice to take part in practice Friday and continued to give him a 75 percent chance to play against the Cincinnati Bengals on Sunday in Super Bowl XXI

LEAD: After lengthy discussions about what to buy each other for their first wedding anniversary, Leslie J. Lane and Alan H. Vorchheimer of Manhattan decided to celebrate the occasion with a gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

LEAD: There is a new hot line here that has nothing to do with impending confrontations with the Soviet Union. If you are calling 1-800-333-6988 it relates to the Washington metropolitan area's drug wars.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: President-elect George Bush, suggesting he would take a cautious approach in the first weeks of his administration, said today that he would not rush to reach an arms control agreement with the Soviet Union.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Aggressive efforts to improve nutrition, including intravenous feeding and other medical intervention when necessary, could greatly improve the quality of life and possibly extend the lives of AIDS patients, a study group said today.
LEAD: A first grader was suspended Wednesday for carrying a knife into the same Bronx elementary school where a 5-year-old student was found with a loaded pistol last week.

LEAD: A consortium formed to make a multibillion-dollar takeover bid for the General Electric Company, Britain's largest manufacturing enterprise, said today that it was shelving its attempt.

LEAD: One-shtick restaurants, like one-shtick comedians, can be amusing for a while, but their routines soon wear thin. That was my impression after repeated visits to Trattoria dell'Arte, a restaurant designed by Milton Glaser with an anatomical theme that is about as subtle as Pee-wee Herman.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Diversity in Hiring From remarks Jan. 6 by Prof. Alan Freeman of the State University of New York at Buffalo at the convention of the American Association of Law Schools in New Orleans. Professor Freeman spoke on behalf of 300 colleagues who had signed a petition calling for the appointment of an independent commission to promote ''diversity in hiring'' in law schools.

LEAD: * An anti-crack radio campaign, featuring the 1950's hit song ''Yakety Yak,'' with new lyrics recorded by the original group, the Coasters, has been produced by Mark & Jeff's Jingle Company, San Francisco, and financed by Foote, Cone & Belding/ San Francisco, for the Partnership for a Drug Free America.

LEAD: Already the spotlight is turning away. In a few more hours, President Reagan will snap off a parting salute and be gone. Come noon, it will be George Bush's day, city and Government. But there will be time to think about all that. For the moment, Ronald Reagan is still President and he remains, to the end, both amazing and comfortable; it's a fit time to contemplate why.
LEAD: A maintenance worker at a Brooklyn day-care center was arrested Wednesday and charged with the rape of an 11-year-old girl, the police said.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Caribe Diner's Journal (March 14, 1986), 117 Perry Street (255-9191) - A jungle of palms thrives at Caribe, an informal Greenwich Village restaurant with flamingo-pink walls and wicker furniture.

LEAD: Don King castigated Bill Cayton for a second day yesterday as he gave his deposition in the suit that Mike Tyson has brought against Cayton, his manager, to void their contract, which runs until February 1992. During six hours of questioning by Thomas Puccio, Cayton's attorney, King accused Cayton of ''double-dipping'' on foreign sales for Tyson's championship fights against Larry Holmes, Tony Tubbs and Michael Spinks.

LEAD: The Knicks were in trouble early tonight with Patrick Ewing in foul trouble and on the bench in the first quarter. The Knick center tried to bring his team back, scoring 34 of his 38 points in the final three quarters, but it was not enough.

LEAD: Scientists said yesterday that they had found that two genes, when inherited together, heightened the risk of developing multiple sclerosis, a severe and mysterious disease of the central nervous system.

LEAD: An article on Wednesday about next season's plans at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center misidentified the composer of a work it has commissioned. The work, a String Sextet that is to have its premiere, is by Charles Wuorinen, not Milton Babbitt.
LEAD: Defense lawyers said yesterday that it was a jealous and deceitful Hedda Nussbaum who murdered Lisa Steinberg, not Joel B. Steinberg, who is accused of beating the 6-year-old child to death.
LEAD: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimously today to recommend confirmation by the full Senate of James A. Baker 3d as the Bush Administration's Secretary of State.

LEAD: As part of the fourth season of the New York Voices readers series of public readings by writers who live in or write about New York, Meg Wolitzer, whoe most recent novel is ''This Is Your Life,'' is to read from her works this afternoon at 12:15 at 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza. Thulani Daivs, a poet and staff writer for The Village voice who wrote the libretto for the opera ''X, the Life and times of malcolm X'' and Mark Richard, a writer and photographer, are to read next Friday at the smae time and place.
LEAD: One of the scarcest commodities in Zimbabwe these days is a spunky newspaper that has been attracting national attention with tales of wrongdoing in high places.

LEAD: Shamrock Holdings Inc. said today that it would raise its offer for the Polaroid Corporation by $3, to $45 a share, and begin a proxy fight for control of the company's board. The revised offer is worth $3.1 billion.
LEAD: Following are excerpts from the Communist Party resolution calling for talks leading to legalization of new trade unions, as translated by the official P.A.P. press agency:
LEAD: Prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in December, contained by a sharp drop for gasoline. For 1988 prices rose 4.4 percent, the same as in 1987.
LEAD: The Interior Department, in the last hours of the Reagan Administration, took two actions tonight to benefit the oil industry.
LEAD: Ante Markovic, a member of the collective presidency of Croatia who is regarded as a supporter of economic change, was chosen as Yugoslavia's Prime Minister today.

LEAD: Borman's Inc. said it would contest a lawsuit by shareholders who say they sold their stock at artificially low prices at a time company officials were holding secret acquisition talks with the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.
LEAD: The first time Sam Wyche met Ickey Woods, the Bengals' coach couldn't help noticing the rookie was wearing a ponytail.

LEAD: Every time a politician runs for President the real message is the same: Just put me into that Oval Office and I will show you that I can get things done and that I can make changes. Count on me.

LEAD: President-elect Bush has installed a White House staff of seasoned, but relatively unknown senior aides. Its mission is to stay that way. While the aides will have the same lofty-sounding ranks as their predecessors, they have been told in no uncertain terms that the important word in a title like assistant to the President, is assistant, not
LEAD: New productions of operas by Mozart and Bellini and a world premiere by Laurie Anderson are to be part of the 13th Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., May 26 to June 11.

LEAD: The high price of success was spelled out yesterday when more than 100 baseball players and their teams exchanged salary arbitration numbers and Dwight Gooden joined Orel Hershiser, Roger Clemens and Kirby Puckett in asking for salaries of more than $2 million.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Clippers dismissed Coach Gene Shue yesterday and named Don Casey, an assistant who was a former coach at Temple, as interim coach.
