LEAD: In a move that will reduce competition in domestic air travel in Canada to only two significant carriers, the PWA Corporation announced today that it planned to acquire all outstanding shares in Wardair Inc. of Toronto.
LEAD: President Reagan's power is dwindling fast, but he can still do a few favors for friends.

LEAD: Poland's leaders today published the long-awaited text of the Communist Party resolution calling for talks leading to legalization of new unions, including Solidarity, which was banned more than six years ago.

LEAD: The classic guitar, with its gentle voice and its ability to play contrapuntal music, is usually regarded as a solitary instrument - the province of the soloist. But throughout the instrument's modern history, guitarists have teamed up as duets, trios and even, if more rarely, quartets, in order to take on music that makes demands greater than two hands and six strings can negotiate.
LEAD: Housing construction fell by 2.2 percent in December, ending a year in which residential building activity dropped to its lowest level in six years, the Government reported today.

LEAD: ''Romance Romance,'' a musical with book, lyrics and direction by Barry Harman and music by Keith Herrmann, closed Sunday after the matinee at the Helen Hayes Theater. The production ran for 297 regular performances and 10 previews.

LEAD: Is Lillian Lux, the Brooklyn-born star of Yiddish stage, bringing to her native heath new wine in old bottles or old wine in new bottles? The question, which arises in connection with her presentation of a musical, ''Oy, Is This a Rebbitzin!,'' by the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, may not have an answer.

LEAD: President Reagan, whose obsession to gain the release of American hostages in Lebanon prompted the failed arms-for-hostages initiative with Iran, is saddened that he will leave office with nine Americans still captive.

LEAD: Bob Froese does not complain or despair. He plays only occasionally, but keeps his mouth closed. The Rangers, from management to minor leaguers, admire his unfailing stoicism. What they appreciate even more, though, is that when he does play, he gives them no reason to complain.

LEAD: Murray Chris-Craft Inc. will close next Friday, ending a 50-year presence as a manufacturer of pleasure boats. Chris-Craft's debt-ridden parent company, Murray Industries of Bradenton, Fla., made the announcement Wednesday to the 70 workers at the Holland Township plant, which employed about 600 workers as recently as 1983.

LEAD: The Evergreen Media Corporation, an Irving, Tex., radio station operator, said today that it had paid $55 million for the Los Angeles classical music station KFAC. Louise Haifetz paid $33.5 million in 1986 for the FM station, along with its AM sister station, which was sold separately last summer for $8.7 million.
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday reported that short interest on the Big Board rose 2.4 percent in the four-week period ended last Friday.

LEAD: Government prosecutors brought additional charges yesterday against the top officers of a disbanded New Jersey investment partnership and one other person who had been indicted last summer on charges of engaging in a racketeering conspiracy.
LEAD: The biggest conspiracy of silence in recent Japanese medical history started sometime in late 1987, in a secret meeting at the University of Tokyo.

LEAD: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the nation's largest cellular telephone operator, and Affiliated Publications Inc., owner of The Boston Globe and specialty magazines, yesterday announced plans for separate but related financial transactions that change the structures of both companies.

LEAD: John D. Hickerson, a former Ambassador and chairman of the group that established NATO, died of cancer Wednesday in Maryland at Bethesda Retirement and Nursing Center. He was 91 years old and lived in Washington.

LEAD: Almost every balletgoer knows that George Balanchine loved to choreograph for women. But it should not be forgotten that he also created interesting parts for men. LEAD: Republicans in tuxedos and long dresses are roaming everywhere about Washington this week. So much so that at a ''Cabaret Night'' for the conservative wing of the party, Oliver L. North, no longer a marine, outshone other partygoers by wearing his medals on his dinner jacket.

LEAD: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, who opposes abortion, said today that if the Supreme Court returned control of abortion to the states, ''we'll have 50 problems instead of one.''

LEAD: Gage & Tollner, the 110-year-old landmark Brooklyn restaurant operated by the Dewey family since 1919, was sold late last year to a partnership headed by Peter Aschkenasy, a Manhattan restaurateur who has vowed to keep its 19th-century character, including its faded tin ceiling, burnished wood walls and period chandeliers.

LEAD: For the first time since World War II, Albania is the host of a meeting of Deputy Foreign Ministers from the six Balkan countries, Bulgaria, Romania, Yugoslavia, Turkey, Greece and Albania. The three-day conference in Albania is seen a strong indication that the country is emerging from a long self-imposed isolation.

LEAD: Jay Burson scored 26 points and No. 16 Ohio State ran away from No. 7 Iowa tonight, defeating the Hawkeyes, 102-91, in a Big Ten Conference game.

LEAD: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. went before a Federal grand jury today, asserting as he entered the closed hearing that he had done no wrong and was not the target of the jury's investigation into allegations of drug dealing and misuse of government funds.
LEAD: The Federal Government yesterday approved the first federally sanctioned attempt to transplant foreign genes into humans.

LEAD: The New York Times and the union representing its 72 machinists reached a tentative agreement yesterday on a six-year extension of a labor contract that expired nearly two years ago. The accord averted a strike that had been set for 12:01 A.M. today.

LEAD: The General Electric Capital Corporation, a financial subsidiary of the General Electric Company, announced yesterday that Michael A. Carpenter, an executive vice president, had been named president and chief executive of its Kidder, Peabody Group.
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Saturday about Advanced Micro Devices Inc. misstated its earnings in the fourth quarter of 1987. The company earned $262.5 million.
LEAD: Timothy Grimes's life had been deeply troubled even before he was a victim of violence two years ago in Howard Beach, Queens. Since then his problems have worsened.

LEAD: The Devils' goaltending was so poor tonight that Coach Jim Schoenfeld covered his eyes in their 5-4 loss to the Quebec Nordiques.

LEAD: The Merchant Navy Officers Pension Fund said it planned to sell from time to time its 6.9 percent stake in First Union Real Estate Equity and Mortgage Investments, a real estate investment trust in Cleveland. The Merchant Navy fund, which provides pensions for retired officers of the British Merchant Navy, controls 1.24 million First Union shares.
LEAD: Irving (Ash) Resnick, a gambling figure credited with bringing high rollers to the Las Vegas Strip, died Wednesday after a long bout with cancer. He was 72 years old.
LEAD: The condition of Salvador Dali worsened today after he developed pneumonia and an inflamed lung, the Spanish radio reported the artist's doctor as saying.

LEAD: ''Noise! Noise! You call that music?'' a father trying to read a newspaper says to his son, who is bopping to music blasting in the living room. The dialogue is in Russian, with English subtitles. A can of Pepsi is on top of a shortwave radio.

LEAD: Dennis Oppenheim's two SoHo exhibitions, one at the John Gibson Gallery, the other at the newly opened Willoughby Sharp Gallery, mark something of a comeback for an artist who has kept a low profile in New York for the last five years. Mr. Oppenheim emerged in the late 1960's as a combination earth artist and body artist who came to specialize in indoor and outdoor installation works.

LEAD: Dr. Michael B. Shimkin, a researcher who helped establish the link between smoking and lung cancer, died of a stroke Monday at the Medical Center of the University of California at San Diego. He was 76 years old and lived in LaJolla.

LEAD: Ten members of San Jose State's team who demanded the dismissal of Coach Bill Berry were replaced by eight walk-ons for the game last night at Fullerton State. Four replacements, who joined the four remaining members of the team, are football players, including the tailback Johnny Johnson. Only one walk-on, 6-foot-9-inch Craig McPherson, a transfer from Santa Clara, has college experience.

LEAD: Annette Krebs, a former director of the adult literacy project of the Massachusetts Council for Public Schools, died of Alzheimer's disease Tuesday at her home in Newton, Mass. She was 72 years old.

LEAD: From September to January he's a flattop kind of guy. Tom Rathman could not explain why his hair, which grows out when the football season ends, becomes a flattop again each year when it's time to return to work. ''It's just something I do,'' he said. Rathman is 6 feet 1 inch and 232 pounds, and his appearance reflects a role that is functional and basic.
LEAD: In a conjugal dustup in a television interview, President-elect George Bush and his wife, Barbara, have exchanged gibes about her weight and his dancing.

LEAD: Dr. Edgar P. Mannix Jr., a thoracic surgeon and former director of surgery at the St. Francis Hospital Heart Center in Roslyn, L.I., died Jan. 9 at his home in Escondido, Calif. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: China and the Getty Conservation Institute today announced a joint effort to preserve two of China's largest and most significant cultural sites, where statues and paintings dating from the fourth century are decaying from harsh weather, pollution and damage by earthquakes.

LEAD: Even though it posted an earnings decline of 15 percent, the Digital Equipment Corporation fared well on Wall Street yesterday because those second-quarter results were 25 to 30 cents a share better than analysts had expected.
LEAD: * Sharyn Williamson has been promoted to executive vice president/planning and operations at Eisner & Associates, Baltimore.

LEAD: A bruising round of central bank intervention and an increase in interest rates in Europe stopped the dollar rally yesterday, but some traders said they still expected the dollar to move higher.

LEAD: To meet its expanding needs, the New York City water-supply system will likely have to begin to take up to 300 million gallons of water a day from the Hudson River, a state report says. The report also says that Long Island will probably need to be connected to the city's system soon to prevent depletion of its ground-water acquifers.
LEAD: The stock market continued its peak-and-valley pattern yesterday, managing to eke out another post-crash high on the Dow Jones industrial average.
LEAD: * American Capital Management and Research, Houston, a provider of financial services, to EBW Advertising, with a $2 million budget.

LEAD: The lawyer representing William Lozano, the city police officer whose fatal shooting of a black motorcyclist on Monday set off three days of racial violence here, said today that the officer acted in self-defense when the 500-pound vehicle came roaring toward him.

LEAD: ''Memoirs of Prison'' was shown as part of the 1984 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 10, 1984. The film, in Portuguese with English subtitles, opens today at the Public, 425 Lafayette Street.

LEAD: Lawyers for shareholders and creditors of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire Tuesday dismissed a $2 billion offer for the company by Northeast Utilities as too low. LEAD: A fugitive convicted in 1968 of plotting to murder two civil rights leaders, Roy Wilkins and Whitney M. Young Jr., has made overtures to return to New York, the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.

LEAD: A White House report made available today lauded Federal efforts to combat homelessness, but concluded that state, local and private groups bear most of the responsibility for addressing the problem.

LEAD: The Rambo-style assault by Mexican troops last week against the home of Joaquin Hernandez Galicia, boss of the powerful oil workers' union, can be seen as evidence that Mexico remains, behind its democratic facade, a virtual presidential dicatorship. Legal niceties lost out in the raid and in Mr. Hernandez's swift imprisonment on charges of amassing a private arsenal.

LEAD: The state police said yesterday that they were looking for two men who posed as police officers to pull a driver off the New England Thruway on New Year's Day and for the ''good Samaritan'' who may have saved her from harm.
LEAD: Dr. Carlos Carrillo, a psychiatrist and physician, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: George Bush's lavish Inaugural festivities carry a lavish price tag. By the time the five-day extravaganza ends, a record $30 million will have been spent - about eight times the tab for Jimmy Carter's 1977 Inauguration.

LEAD: The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company is offering $125 million in 10 percent first mortgage bonds due in 2019 at a price of 99.35, to yield 10.7 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

LEAD: Americans begin the Bush administration in a buoyant mood, optimistic about the country and the new President and especially satisfied with their own lives, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

LEAD: Several more banks reported record quarterly earnings yesterday as they benefited from interest payments from Brazil that had been overdue since the beginning of 1987. Even excluding that unusual item, however, banks continued to show progress in controlling expenses and in generating additional fee income.

LEAD: WHEN the world pauses for the Super Bowl on Sunday, there may be no giddy spectacle of players writhing on the ground, trying to remember which knee to clutch, the way the Seattle Seahawks did three weeks ago, trying to evoke a free timeout.

LEAD: Senator Alphonse M. D'Amato will ask the Justice Department to name Otto G. Obermaier, a top defense lawyer in New York, to be the next United States Attorney in Manhattan, a spokeswoman for the Senator confirmed last night.

Mr. Janis was a shrewd businessman, having made a fortune selling shirts (this, following a stint dancing the hesitation waltz and the one-step on the Gus Sun Time vaudeville circuit).

LEAD: The world of advertising, as scores of novels and movies have insisted over the years, is populated with sensitive artists prostituting their creative talents in order to live well. For those who make it big in the business, the cliche has it, success and self-flagellation often go hand in hand.

LEAD: Retail prices rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in December, the Labor Department reported yesterday.

LEAD: In a speech that could serve as a mayoral campaign theme, United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani declared yesterday that the Federal, state and local governments have not done enough to combat drug abuse and addiction. But he conceded that the problem could not be solved, only reduced.

LEAD: The Lessons column on the Education page on Dec. 7, about Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos, described Richard M. Nixon's 1968 campaign remarks about the Vietnam War incorrectly. Mr. Nixon pledged to end the war if elected President.

LEAD: Ferdinand E. Marcos's health took a turn for the worse yesterday, his doctors said, while a court in New York was holding a hearing on whether the former Philippine President is too ill to stand trial.

LEAD: Don't fax me, I'll fax you: Under a bill proposed in the Connecticut General Assembly, that would be the official message here to businesses, direct marketers and others who send unsolicited advertisements - ''junk fax'' - over the telephone wires.

LEAD: In the latest example of New York City's inability to track troubled families, a Bronx woman whose 10-month-old boy suffocated last week was supposed to be contacted by city caseworkers once a month but had not been visited since last April.

LEAD: The 24-year-old man who opened fire on children in a schoolyard here Tuesday was a troubled loner full of hate who could not keep a job and had alcohol and drug problems, according to the portrait that is emerging from investigators and family members.

LEAD: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union announced today that Soviet troops leaving Eastern Europe under a previously announced reduction would take their battlefield nuclear weapons with them.

LEAD: If President Bush follows his plan to use the phrase ''thousand points of light'' in his address to those attending the inaugural balls Friday night, 40,000 points will shine.
LEAD: Heart disease patients who smoke are three times more likely to have chest pains and restricted blood flow to their hearts than those who do not, researchers say in a new study.
LEAD: Nana Vasconcelos and his Brazilian-funk band Bush Dancers are to perform tonight at midnight at B#2, 157 Hudson Street (966-5881). Tickets are $15; doors open at 10 P.M..

LEAD: A couple of long shows are on tap this weekend. Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, ''Great Performances'' begins the four-part ''Melba,'' a weekly mini-series that tells more than you probably care to know about the legendary soprano from Australia. And Sunday at 9 P.M., NBC is offering the first half of a four-hour television movie adapted from the David Morrell thriller ''Brotherhood of the Rose.

LEAD: A Palestinian in the occupied Gaza Strip was killed by soldiers today and dozens of others were wounded during widespread violent protests against the army's harsh new measures to quell the Palestinian uprising.

LEAD: If Ronald Reagan represents the apotheosis of cowboy values, symbolizing the enduring American myths of self-help, self-sufficiency and self-confidence, George Bush embodies the patrician ideal of responsibility begotten by privilege: an equally American tradition reaching back through the many Presidents more at home in mansions than log cabins, from Washington of Mount Vernon to Jefferson of Monticello to Roosevelt of Hyde Park.
LEAD: The Japanese Government today made public a budget for 1989 that will, for the first time, make it the world's largest donor and lender of foreign aid.

LEAD: Children at a New York State psychiatric center near Buffalo operated a ''sex club'' in which younger patients were intimidated into performing sex acts, an investigation by a state watchdog agency has found. Several staff members at the center also engaged in sex with children, the agency said.

LEAD: Consumer prices in the metropolitan New York area rose one-tenth of 1 percent in December, finishing the year with an inflation rate that was markedly lower than that in 1987, the Labor Department's regional Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

LEAD: A year after announcing that it was leaving the agency business, Trout & Ries is leaving New York City as well. Jack Trout and Al Ries are packing up some of their remaining employees and establishing their marketing-strategy consulting operation in Greenwich, Conn. With their books and articles, the partners had established themselves as doyens of positioning when they lost the United Jersey Banks account in late 1987, an event that hastened their move out of advertising.

LEAD: Roman Catholic bishops from nine southern African nations appealed today to governments and guerrillas in the region to make peace. LEAD: Officials of Chicago's commodities exchanges acknowledged today that Federal investigators were looking into trading activities to determine whether investors had been defrauded.
LEAD: A senior member of the South African Cabinet was sworn in as Acting President today, 34 hours after President P. W. Botha suffered a mild stroke.

LEAD: The finest songs of Richard Maltby Jr. and David Shire, the collaborative team best known for the 1977 cabaret revue ''Starting Here, Starting Now'' and the 1983 Broadway show ''Baby,'' communicate something rarely found in theater music nowadays: a rich sweeping sense of lives being lived and people changing over time.

LEAD: A study of the American nuclear power industry found it had one of the worst performance records in the industrialized world, and management weaknesses are probably at fault, a group of nuclear engineering experts said this week. The best nuclear plants in the United States are as good as any in the world, they said.
LEAD: Tom Russell is to lead his country band tomorrow at 11 P.M. at Delta 88, 332 Eighth Avenue, at 26th Street (924-3499). There is a $5 cover and a $5 minimum.

LEAD: On Friday, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. ends his tenure as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and as the only person to have served in President Reagan's Cabinet for the full eight years.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation and the General Motors Corporation expanded low-interest incentives by offering financing as low as 4.9 percent on some of their small cars and light trucks. LEAD: More than 11,000 air traffic controllers lost their jobs in their ill-fated strike of 1981. Jack Solerwitz, the lawyer who represented many of them, arguably lost even more.

LEAD: President Reagan announced today that he was modifying trade restrictions against Libya to allow American oil companies to resume operations there and avoid a Libyan takeover of their assets.

LEAD: Another frightening opponent, another Islander victory. The modest two-game string of success is enough, said Pat LaFontaine, to make the Islanders believe they can make a habit of winning once again.

LEAD: Three Federal enforcement agencies announced a 36-count indictment on Wednesday, charging 10 individuals with criminal conspiracy and securities fraud in the trading of Protecto Industries. Protecto is a so-called penny stock - one that is thinly traded and for which little information is available.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 454 money market mutual funds increased by $2.2 billion, to $284.59 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 137 institutional funds increased by $998.2 million, to $73.93 billion. The assets of the 226 general-purpose funds were down by $2.9 million, to $90.17 billion.

LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that he had not meant to suggest last week that city officials and City Council members had publicly discussed a change in a city law that benefited the developer Harry Macklowe.

LEAD: Four nervous but assured conductors, all Americans under 35 years of age, took their turns on the podium at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night. Each led the American Symphony Orchestra in bits of Beethoven's ''Egmont'' overture as well as Tchaikovsky's ''Pathetique'' and Mozart's ''Jupiter'' symphonies; each accompanied an aria by Leonard Bernstein and rehearsed a difficult stretch of Aaron Copland's Orchestral Variations.
LEAD: An obituary article and headline yesterday about a former executive vice president of the Atlantic Refining Company misidentified him. He was Harry G. Schad, not Shad.

LEAD: Blind Idiot God, B.A.L.L., Reverb Mofos and Rude Buddha at CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street (982-4052). Rough, brute-force rock -pounding drums, distorted guitars, disheveled vocals - takes the stage tomorrow at CBGB. Blind Idiot God, at 11:30 P.M., plays bruising instrumentals that embrace dub reggae, hard-rock and Stravinsky; B.A.L.L., at 12:30 A.M., plays grinding, lumbering, sometimes off-handedly funny songs; the Reverb Mofos, at about 1:30 A.M., bash away like a latter-day Steppenwolf.

MONTREAL (NL) - Agreed to terms with Pascual Perez, pitcher, on a one-year contract and with Kevin Gross, pitcher, on a two-year contract.

LEAD: J.B. Fuqua, the man who built Fuqua Industries, has stepped down as chief executive, and the post has been given to Lawrence P. Klamon, Fuqua's president and chief operating officer, the company announced yesterday.
LEAD: Uzi Baram resigned as Secretary General of the Labor Party today, formalizing a split in the party's ranks that may create new leaders for Labor in the months ahead.

LEAD: Burmese Government troops backed by mortars captured a major rebel camp near the Thai-Burmese frontier, sending 600 civilians of the Karen ethnic group fleeing to Thailand, Thai officials said today.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority is offering $143.6 million in sales tax revenue bonds, with a maximum yield of about 7.437 percent for an issue due in 2010, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

LEAD: The emphasis was on long, continuous strands of motion on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater, where the Womanworks festival presented Risa Jaroslow and Dancers and the Monica Levy Performance Group. There was also some fine dancing by the two companies. But there the similarities ended.

LEAD: Although the number of black and Hispanic workers in New York City government has increased, whites continue to hold a disproportionate share of the highest-paying jobs, a study by the Community Service Society has found.
LEAD: * Big B Inc., Birmingham, Ala., a drugstore chain, said it would acquire Reed Drug Co., a unit of Peoples Drug Stores Inc., Alexandria, Va., for about $50 million.

LEAD: Gary Moss, who was dismissed as the Sam Houston State coach after the National Collegiate Athletic Association issued sanctions against him, has filed a lawsuit against school officials and others, including Dick Schultz, the N.C.A.A. executive director. In the suit filed Wednesday in Huntsville, Tex., Moss said his constitutional rights were violated because a hearing on his dismissal was not held.

LEAD: The violinist Gidon Kremer and an ensemble of string soloists will play a concert of chamber music at Carnegie Hall at 8 o'clock tonight. The program includes the American premiere of Sofia Guaidulina's ''Rejoice'' for violin and cello, Schubert's Five Minuets and Six Trios, Alfred Schnittke's String Trio, and a group of Johann Strauss waltzes, arranged by Alexander Weinmann.
LEAD: The First Lady, dressed in what has already become known as ''Barbara Blue,'' swept through a gilded railroad station tonight for her first inaugural ball.

LEAD: In the recent election campaign, a number of responsible voices claimed that foreign investment in the United States was both big and bad. LEAD: STEWS are the most inviting and practical of winter food. They can be made in one pot, cooked a day or more in advance and are economical, since cheaper cuts of meat are used. They are also warming and filling on a cold day. Here are some hints for making perfect stews: Use cheaper cuts of meat. They will have less fat and more flavor.

A 16-year-old boy was hospitalized in serious condition with a head injury.

LEAD: On Jan. 12, The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced the nominations for this year's Grammy Awards, to be presented on Feb. 22 at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. In the three decades since Domenico Modugno's ''Nel Blu Dipinto Di Blu (Volare)'' was voted both record and song of the year and Henry Mancini's ''Music From Peter Gunn'' was chosen best album, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences has grown from a small group of musicians and executives centered in Los Angeles and New York into a 6,000-member organization with chapters in seven cities.

LEAD: South Africa's President, P. W. Botha, who suffered a mild stroke on Wednesday, will probably be discharged from the hospital early next week but will then require a six-week period of recuperation, Health Minister Willem A. van Niekerk said today.

LEAD: An article on drug-testing technology in The Week in Review on Nov. 20 included an erroneous reference to ibuprofen, a drug used in some over-the-counter pain remedies. LEAD: An energetic George Bush completed his first full day as President today with a flourish of symbolic gestures and conciliatory statements, including a renewed plea for the assistance of other countries in winning the release of American hostages in Lebanon.

LEAD: Pleased with the results of its just-completed five-year plan aimed at restoring optimum spawning runs of Atlantic salmon in its rivers, the province of Quebec expects few changes in its sport-fishing regulations for the species in 1989.

LEAD: The stock ''corner'' flourished in the age when it was every man for himself, and when insider trading was accepted as a normal practice. Corners grew rarer and less profitable in the 1920's, and were supposed to have disappeared entirely until a series of transactions made it appear that a corner is now in the works.

LEAD: Football Gary Leads South in Senior Bowl: Cleveland Gary of the University of Miami was voted the outstanding player in the Senior Bowl after he rushed for 97 yards to spark the South in a 13-12 victory over the North yesterday in Mobile, Ala. Gary caught 5 passes for 42 yards, including a 10-yard catch on a fourth-and-2 at the North 41 to keep the game-winning drive going on the opening play of the fourth quarter.(AP)

LEAD: Winter in Montreal can be as old-fashioned as a horse-drawn sleigh on Le Mont-Royal, the 500-acre park at the city's center, or as futuristic as the Olympic Stadium, built for the 1976 Summer Games and crowned a year ago with a 556-foot tower to hold up its retractable, seasonal roof. It's this blend of the Old World and New France that makes Montreal intriguing.

LEAD: When commentators insisted that election year 1988 was one of ''peace and prosperity,'' some New Yorkers could only gape and snarl in disbelief. LEAD: I object to the implication that the collection at the Museum of the American Indian melted away in vast numbers during my tenure as director (''The Indian Museum's Last Stand,'' by William Grimes, Nov. 27). George Gustav Heye freely disposed of objects by exchange and sale; indeed, three major museums were largely created from the Heye collection by this practice.
LEAD: Witnesses to the fatal shooting that led to widespread racial violence here have given an account sharply at odds with that given by the lawyer for the police officer who fired the shot.
LEAD: On the 16th anniversary of the Supreme Court's landmark decision legalizing abortion, polls show that Americans remain sharply divided about their stands on abortion.

LEAD: A story ''Museums Seek to Halt Thefts,'' Jan. 1 addressed a problem that I as a creative artist was confronted with in June: the theft of a piece of my artwork from a prestigious gallery on Long Island.
LEAD: This is another in a series of columns answering questions about New York's changing streetscapes.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: AMERICANS depend on newspapers and television for an image of their President. But their impression of George Bush depends substantially on whether they remember what they read and heard about him before he was elected President or since.

LEAD: HENCE By Brad Leithauser. 320 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

LEAD: Three score years ago, Larry L. King sprouted from the jackrabbit plains of West Texas, a barren space where the air stinks of crude oil somebody else owns, the dust burns in your nostrils like needles and the sky seems boundless principally because there are no trees. LEAD: Since the first week of December some short-term interest rates have moved up so sharply that they now exceed the rates on long-term securities. In the past, such an occurrence, known on Wall Street as an ''inverted yield curve,'' has often been followed by a recession and falling stock and bond markets.

LEAD: On the banks of the West Lake, an enchanted region of islands and temples shrouded by mist and magic in this city 100 miles southwest of Shanghai, a love story has been unfolding before the cameras. It is a Chinese love story, in which the leading actress is both chased and - after a fleeting temptation - chaste.

LEAD: ALL 14 school districts in the Towns of Huntington and Smithtown and 5 of 11 in the Town of Islip are suing their respective towns, accusing the towns of violating the Suffolk County Tax Act by failing to forward tax-receipt money to them promptly.
LEAD: CRISES by definition never break at opportune times.

LEAD: Five newcomers have joined the cast of the Met's ''Fledermaus'' since it opened in late December. But the principal reasons to see this production - Hakan Hagegard's fine singing as Eisenstein and Sid Caesar's comic turns as Frosch, the jailer -have been there from the start.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: James Michener is a novelist whose biography reads like the invention of a novelist. Itr begins with Mr. Michener, an adopted child, growing up poor in Doylestown, Pa., continues with his obtaining, by dint of hard work and a scholarship to Swarthmore College, a good education and jobs as a school teacher and then an editor.

LEAD: PETER W. RODINO Jr. returned from World War II with a battlefield commission and a desire to enter politics. Focusing on issues that were important to returning veterans, like housing, and supported by a growing Italian-American population in the 10th Congressional District, he unseated Fred A. Hartley, a Republican, in 1948 and began a 40-year career in Congress.

LEAD: WITH the Persian Gulf war stilled, the Arab world is looking to the new Administration to focus on an older and far more persistent priority - a settlement of the Palestinian dispute with Israel.

LEAD: Dr. Basil Harris, former director of health services at Metropolitan Hospital Center in Manhattan, died of lung cancer yesterday in Rutland Memorial Hospital in Rutland, Vt. He was 70 years old and lived in Manchester Center, Vt.
LEAD: To the Editor:

Suite 3178 came with a wet bar in the foyer, sumptuous Biedermeier furniture, a marble bath with gold fixtures, a panoramic view. I parted the drapes and gazed at hills aglitter with pinpoints of light that limned the contours of
LEAD: A SEASON INSIDE One Year in College Basketball. By John Feinstein. 464 pp. New York: Villard Books. $18.95.

LEAD: Heavily armed guards restored order early today to the District of Columbia prison complex after a night of disturbances by inmates left one prisoner dead, another injured and two buildings badly damaged by fire.

LEAD: Three long pieces in short sections made up the concert of Lawrence Axelrod's compositions Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. The young composer has at least one enviable ability: It is not easy, in a time when convention no longer provides formal structures, to write persuasive and coherent half-hour spans.

Risko, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Risko of Portsmouth, R.I., were married yesterday at the Beverly Hills (Calif.) Hotel. The Rev. Robert H. Stucky, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony. E. J. Dionne Jr.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Schmitt Jr. of Seaford, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Karen Schmitt, to Kenneth Arnold Buenker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Buenker, also of Seaford. A May wedding is planned.
LEAD: SUCH is its allure that on a recent wintry day, when the melting detritus of a snowstorm was keeping most New Yorkers off the streets, Gramercy Park was zinging with activity.

LEAD: Randy Cross, 49ers' center, vs. Tim Krumrie, Bengals' nose tackle: Krumrie stays low, and he moves so quickly and so well laterally that he can take away the cutback by a running back. Bill Walsh, the 49ers' coach, said it would take two men to block him. ''Krumrie is the foundation of our defense,'' said Dick LeBeau, the Bengals' defensive coordinator.
LEAD: MANY of my best friends are gone. I knew them well, admired their strengths and enjoyed their jokes, and in no time they were dead.

LEAD: Q. I have cabinets of ash wood in my kitchen. Food and dirt stains have accumulated around the handles and knobs on the cabinet doors. Is it possible to clean off this dirt without also removing or damaging the finish, or must the cabinets be revarnished?

LEAD: Meldrick Taylor beat John Meekins to retain his International Boxing Federation junior welterweight title today when Referee Steve Smoger, acting on the advice of the ringside physician, stopped the bout after the seventh round of a scheduled 12-rounder.

LEAD: The embrace that is also a stranglehold, the caress that becomes a blow: Images of this sort have emerged with surprising ferocity in new choreography. These obsessive love-hate motifs are often criticized when they surface in the ballet world, but they are accepted and admired when explored in modern dance.

LEAD: A CONVERSION of a group of buildings that once were part of a textile mill is bringing a year-round residential population to an island near the mouth of the Saco River.

LEAD: HOW could the New York City Council have changed a municipal law without knowing that it had done so? LEAD: Michelle Gail Kaplan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Kaplan of Marlboro, N.J., and Dr. Michael Douglas Sicklick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sicklick of Hackensack, N.J. were married last evening in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi David Feldman performed the ceremony at the Short Hills.

LEAD: IN the freezing predawn darkness of Mardi gras in the Belgian town of Binche, a drummer and two costumed men dance along a lamp-lighted alley to round up fellow celebrants for the day's procession. The Binchois call this precarnival dawn ''the best moment.''

LEAD: IF you are a biking enthusiast you are probably already thinking about taking some extended trips come warmer weather. Even though spring is still three months away, it is not too soon to start planning, especially if you intend to use a bicycle while vacationing abroad.

LEAD: In a stifling hall in the heart of the Amazon, a group of American legislators sat listening to the people of the rain forest -Indians and rubber tappers, who appealed for help from abroad to save their jungle habitat.
LEAD: Two years ago, Annie Goolabia, a 59-year-old mother of six, could not read this sentence. Today she could probably write it herself.

LEAD: The world of the ancient Nazca civilization of South America comes alive in a killer whale rendered in a whiplash of clay and in boldly painted images on bottles and jars, depicting whiskered cougars, fierce-eyed condors and hummingbirds soaring.

LEAD: To understand the food of the Carolina Low Country, you have to know first a little geography and then a little history. The Low Country is that narrow stretch of South Carolina coastline that runs from Pawleys Island in the north, southwest into Georgia, and inland 80 miles or so to the Fall Line, as Carolinians call the dramatic divide where the Sand Hills rise abruptly from the coastal plain.
LEAD: In a case more reminiscent of Pirandello than of Freud, scholars of psychoanalysis are in a furor over an article by an eminent historian.

LEAD: SEIGE coins are representative of tumultuous eras and such is the case with the shekel of the First Revolt (A.D. 66-70) This shekel is one of only three examples of ancient silver Jewish coinage. The other two being a miniscule coin from earliest times and the shekel of the Second Revolt (A.D. 132-135).

LEAD: Americans now spend more than $1 out of every $10 on health care. How we put this money to the most cost-effective use is one of the most important questions facing individuals and political leaders today.
LEAD: OLE! Argentina has come to Long Island. Nassau-Suffolk's first Argentinian restaurant is La Estancia in Elmont. This authentic, convivial South American storefront is muy bueno.

LEAD: The problem of child abuse and neglect is unfortunately ''more common and complex'' than the public realizes. While solving the problem will undoubtedly require complex and creative approaches, there is one currently recognized remedy that is fairly simple, that of educating people in the art of parenting.

LEAD: Tom Savage scored 23 of his season-high 33 points in the second half, when Rutgers shot 80 percent from the field, and the Scarlet Knights defeated Duquesne by 102-87 today in an Atlantic 10 Conference game.

LEAD: Two days before Israel opened schools in the occupied West Bank last fall, Ibrahim Bali was buying new shoes for his young daughters at the downtown Hebron store of his friend, Khayed Salah, when both men were startled by the sound of gunfire.
LEAD: CATHERINE THE GREAT Life and Legend. By John T. Alexander. Illustrated. 418 pp. New York: Oxford University Press.
LEAD: One week after walking away to protest a new rule on freshman eligibility, John Thompson, the basketball coach at Georgetown, returned to the bench in triumph this afternoon.

LEAD: Driven by fierce competition, magazine publishers are finding innovative ways to compete for advertisers. Consider a computerized process known as selective binding, which at least a handful of publishers are using to create custom editions for small clusters of subscribers who share similar characteristics.

LEAD: MUTTONTOWN's 3,900 acres have long been among the most exclusive on the North Shore, with its large open spaces preserved through the years by private individuals and municipal actions of the village. However, a rapid increase in development in recent years has generated concern within the village.

LEAD: WHAT was formerly the Quarterdeck in Stamford has evolved into a new restaurant called Crispin's. In a freestanding house on Long Ridge Road, it is about one-quarter mile north of Lord & Taylor's on the right hand side of the road.

LEAD: Sharon Monahan's article ''Army Acts to Save Eroded Gilgo Beach in Babylon'' [ Dec. 25 ] might well have been written by the Public Relations Department of the Army Corps of Engineers. It ignores the wealth of geological and oceanic knowledge regarding our barrier island.
LEAD: THE COMPANY WE KEEP An Ethics of Fiction. By Wayne C. Booth. 557 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $29.95.

LEAD: Last year was a tough one for the so-called ''market timers'' - money managers who frequently move back and forth from stocks to cash, depending upon their reading of economic or technical indicators. Their approach, which some academics have questioned, is designed to take advantage of rallies while missing market downturns.
LEAD: Paul Townsend, editor of Long Island Business News (Jan. 1, ''Shoreham Impasse: Suggested Solutions'') said Shoreham should open, and called it ''nonpolluting as compared to fossil fuels''!
LEAD: Take a newcomer to the kind of program the New York City Ballet presented on Friday night and you will see preconceptions about classical ballet break into shards.

LEAD: The Roman Catholic Bishop of East Timor, saying claims that human rights abuses had ended were ''lying propaganda,'' has accused the Indonesian Government of continuing to practice torture in the region.

LEAD: WHEN Hilton International announced a decade ago that it intended to build the financial district's first new hotel in over a century, many people in the hospitality industry smiled knowingly. Hotels in Manhattan were equated with midtown and that's the way it would remain, ran the conventional wisdom.

LEAD: Colonial women in the Gloucester area depended on Isabel Babson, a midwife, to help deliver their babies. Three hundred years later, parents and children can rely on a library devoted entirely to family topics that was inspired by the midwife's work.

LEAD: Terry Creach and Stephen Koester both create dances for themselves and commission works from guest choreographers. What the resultant pieces have in common is their all-male casts. Mr. Creach and Mr. Koester wish to explore all the possibilities of male dancing.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm M. Donahue of Westwood, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Louise Donahue to Andrew Hamilton Richards, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben F. Richards of Far Hills, N.J. The couple plan to marry in June.

LEAD: CONGRESS did away with quotas based on national origin when it overhauled the immigration law in 1965. And in 1980 it abolished the presumption that anyone fleeing Communism was a refugee. But experience in the last few months shows that it is much easier to write an evenhanded law than to carry it out in the face of political pressures reflecting special concern for particular groups of emigres.

LEAD: With the presence of ''German Art in the Late 80's'' here, the other shoe of the ''Binationale,'' an unusual German-American exhibition exchange, has dropped. LEAD: One thing the Cuomo administration had never been known for is its frivolity. Indeed, one of the favored pastimes on the second floor of the State Capitol, where the top officials work, is to see who can stay even later than Gov. Mario M. Cuomo himself, a famed workaholic.

LEAD: The New York Landmarks Conservancy has donated $5,000 from its Sacred Sites and Properties Fund to help restore the front of the Fifteenth Street Monthly Meeting building, a two-story Greek Revival structure more commonly called the Friends Meeting House, on the west side of Stuyvesant Square. The funds will help defray the cost - estimated at $45,000 - of restoring the wood on the entrance doors and their portico.

LEAD: Earlier in the century, publishers sought the lowest common denominator in editorial content, attempting to appeal to the widest spectrum of Americans and advertisers. Look, Life and Reader's Digest were born.

LEAD: TUCKED away in corners of New York City, a new form of potentially troublesome low-income housing is being created in vacant city-owned buildings as part of the response to the problem of finding permanent apartments for the homeless.

LEAD: FOR the last quarter-century, the Old Town Hall, a designated national landmark in downtown Stamford, has stood virtually empty and very much out of place, a Beaux Arts anachronism in the midst of what has become a business district of modern corporate towers. Now there are plans afoot to turn the hall into a museum of borrowed glories and local exhibits.

LEAD: The fin is back. Call it a bit of madness or simply a return to 1950's kitsch, but this angular, wing-like shape is cropping up as a design element in everything from vases to chairs. Some 30 years ago, the fin became a symbol of modern efficiency and power. Most notable was its appearance on cars like the 1957 Cadillac shown here.

LEAD: WITH its central location, rich commercial history and seemingly unsurpassed access to major transportation, downtown Hempstead offers perhaps the greatest potential for redevelopment of any business district on Long Island.

LEAD: Nearly all eyes will be on Joe Montana and Boomer Esiason, Ickey Woods and Roger Craig, Jerry Rice and Eddie Brown, the prime players in Super Bowl XXIII. They are the favorites to win the most valuable player award of the game.

LEAD: I'd like to rebut Edwin Ritchie's letter of Jan. 8 in which he calls for a ban on bow hunting. Mr. Ritchie's request carries no supporting logic. Instead I see a bitter diatribe of personal emotions laced together with his own opinions of what constitutes psychiatric behavior.

Martin Luther King Jr. being assassinated is followed by a commercial for an underarm deodorant.

LEAD: Three former chiefs of the Federal Aviation Administration and other experts are calling for more autonomy for the agency and a new push for technological solutions to a host of problems facing aviation.

LEAD: BUDAPEST 1900 A Historical Portrait of a City and Its Culture. By John Lukacs. Illustrated. 255 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson.

LEAD: U.S. Representatives who left office in 1988 who were in office on or before Jan. 8, 1980. Legally, they may keep leftover campaign funds for their personal use. In some cases, it is not known how the money will be spent. Robert E. Badham (R-Calif.) Retired.

LEAD: EVERY TIME SHE SEES ME SALTING THE spaghetti water, my daughter sucks in her breath with a slight, righteous whistle. She eats the spaghetti (and the lightly salted sauce), but with a shrug of self-sacrifice, contemplating what this dietary indiscretion will do, sooner or later, to her blood pressure.
LEAD: It was a moment of high drama that severely tested the Burmese military Government's lurching, awkward efforts to open up a bit to the world.
LEAD: FROM a work in progress, ''Tales of Tinseltown'' has devolved into a musical in regress.

LEAD: IT has been called a hedge against the extinction of life on earth and a step toward colonization of the moon and Mars: Biosphere II, an enclosed, airtight, 2.25-acre ecosystem in which plants, animals and humans could survive indefinitely in harmony.

LEAD: An article in the Education Life section on Jan. 8, headed ''The Financial-Aid Numbers Game,'' depicted the use of 401(k) plan contributions erroneously as a method to reduce income reported on aid forms. For the forms, such retirement funds are considered untaxed income. Money paid into rollover pensions may be excluded from consideration.

LEAD: MARRIAGES are not made in heaven any more, they are made on the cutting-room floor. This may not be news to those who have attended avant-garde wedding ceremonies in recent years, but there may be many like me who have not undergone this latest shock to the battered modern psyche. My cautionary tale may serve to limit the trauma to the innocent among us.

LEAD: Nine-tenths of the way through this century, reverberations from one of its earliest eras still hold powerful sway over our collective imagination. That era, depicted in ''Black and Blue'' (which opens Thursday at the Minskoff Theater), saw an explosion of black American culture, one that radically changed the nature of American and world entertainment.
LEAD: HOW COME,'' A LADY asks her husband in a James Stevenson cartoon in The New Yorker, ''you're never on anybody's >short list?''

LEAD: BREATHES there anyone who doesn't get a kick out of saving money, who doesn't love a bargain, who wouldn't take advantage of a discount that requires no coupon, no stamp and no effort? Probably not - depending. . . .

LEAD: WITH Larry Shue's ''Nerd,'' a standard situation comedy on their main stage, and a pair of Christopher Durang's howlingly funny offbeat comic one-acts on its second stage, Port Jefferson's Theater Three is offering something for everyone.

LEAD: At two White House meetings on the sale of American arms to Iran, in December 1985 and May 1986, George Bush supported Robert C. McFarlane's advice to Ronald Reagan that the operation should not proceed, according to a published interview with Mr. McFarlane.

LEAD: SAFE PASSAGE. By Ellyn Bache. (Crown, $16.95.) Ellyn Bache's first novel begins with a mother's premonition of disaster: ''At four-thirty on Sunday morning Mag came up from sleep with her heart thumping and sweat pouring from her.'' Mag Singer's premonition rapidly proves true as she and her husband, Patrick, learn from an early-morning newscast that the Beirut airport, where one of their seven sons is stationed as a marine, has been destroyed by Lebanese terrorists.

LEAD: It is almost 24 years since the publication of an eccentric, brilliant, and eerily prescient advertisement for the Plaza Hotel. The ad had no picture of the Plaza or of anything inside it; it was simply a parable, and it was called ''The Day New York Almost Vanished.''
LEAD: One-stop shopping for money management? That's the idea behind an investment product increasingly being marketed by the big brokerage firms - the so-called wrap account.

LEAD: Cemeteries are, perhaps paradoxically, living catalogues of history, and when it comes to name-dropping there are few that can match Woodlawn Cemetery's roster of illustrious interments. From the first burial there in 1865, Woodlawn's 400 splendidly landscaped acres have grown increasingly crowded; today there are almost 300,000 occupants.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ...And See Who Salutes IVIA question of the year: What can East Hamptonites put on a flagpole? The query began last year in the village when Morgan Rank put more than a flag on his flagpole. An ''American primitive art'' dealer, Mr. Rank decided to add some ''American primitive art'' to the landscape.

LEAD: New powers for banks were granted by the Federal Reserve, which approved giving them limited authority to underwrite corporate bonds. The action is the most significant yet in breaking the barriers that the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933 put between banking and the securities business. Bankers have long complained that the law restrictsed them as securities firms encroached on the banks' traditional businesses.

LEAD: National youth service, sidetracked for eight years by the Reagan Administration's resistance, suddenly is on the fast track. The new Bush Administration is readying YES to America, a youth service foundation. The Democratic Leadership Council, meanwhile, offers a plan to make service a prerequisite for Federal education aid.
LEAD: Israeli troops shot and killed a 14-year-old youth and another Palestinian today in scattered demonstrations throughout the occupied West Bank.
LEAD: S. Dianne Moritz's article ''Going Home Again: But Where Is 'Home'?'' [ Opinion, Jan. 1 ] brought to mind Commack as I knew it in 1953 to 1959; lovely suburban community with one general store.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Axel Litchfield of Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Litchfield's daughter, Amelia Richardson Hamill, to Timothy Balch Hopkins, a son of Elizabeth Balch Hopkins of Westport, Conn., and the late Dwight Douglas Hopkins of Buffalo. LEAD: AS OUR 9-YEAR-OLD son stretched to turn off the television during the halftime show of the football game, my wife stopped him. ''That's the only part Daddy likes,'' she said. We all laughed at the role turnabout in our household: My wife, an otherwise appealing woman, loves to watch football on television, and I do not.

LEAD: To the Editor: I noted with interest Stanley Carr's answer to the question on how those using frequent-flier credits to fly overseas can find on their own the kind of inexpensive hotels and tours offered in package deals (Q & A, Nov. 27).

LEAD: A WORD ON TREES A free talk about ''Historic Trees of Westchester'' will be given at 2 P.M. today by Ted Kozlowski, the county forester with the Department of Parks, at Washington's Headquarters Museum in North White Plains. Mr. Kozlowski is in charge of the Westchester County Big Tree Register, on which some 40 of the largest trees of a particular species are listed.

I remember going to my first singles dance and wine-tasting party in 1974 with a male friend also divorced but already into the scene.

LEAD: The visibility of the homeless has risen dramatically over the past three years, with a majority of Americans now saying they see the homeless problem at first hand and not just through the news media, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

LEAD: Back in 1820, Orlando Montague, a blacksmith, complained to his wife, Hannah, that he did not have a clean white shirt in the evening when he came home from work. Mrs. Montague solved the problem by cutting collars off her husband's shirts, providing a clean one for him to wear whenever he wanted.

LEAD: Greek education is in turmoil. Many private schools and universities have come to a near standstill as staff, students and even parents have taken to the streets this week in a dispute over funding, educational change and politics.
LEAD: Merlin Olsen isn't saying, but he knows what the first play of Super Bowl XXIII will be. In fact, he probably knows what the first half-dozen plays run by the Bengals and the 49ers will be.
LEAD: I am in general agreement with Karon Cooney's many criticisms of teachers.

LEAD: The fund that pays all Government reimbursement for hospital care of Medicare patients is projected to become insolvent in the next decade or so, but the proposed remedies hold little political appeal.

LEAD: A Soviet newspaper panicked the nation's liberals last March with an article signed by Nina A. Andreyeva, a 50-year-old Leningrad chemistry teacher, complaining that liberals were using glasnost to sow ideological confusion and blacken Soviet history. Three weeks later, Pravda denounced the letter as an anti-perestroika manifesto; nonetheless, she said she has received many letters supporting her views.
LEAD: Nearly 200 House members have stockpiled $39.2 million in campaign funds that they could use as retirement cushions because of a provision of the Federal election law, a new study reports.

LEAD: Two men waiting to throw dynamite at a plane carrying Mario Vargas Llosa, the author and politician, shot four people on Thursday after their attack was foiled, a newspaper said today.

LEAD: AT a small sign posted on a fence halfway between Miami and Miami Beach we turned off MacArthur Causeway and drove to the water's edge where a private ferry was waiting. The ferry was called the Eagle. (Two others are available at all times, the Flamingo, and the Pelican.) A security guard in full regalia stopped us and requested identification.

LEAD: A 12-year-old girl who was talking with a group of friends less than a block from her home was shot and killed Friday evening when she inadvertently walked into a drug-related dispute on a sidewalk in Brooklyn, the police said.

LEAD: On Thursday it was disclosed that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had posed as commodities traders as part of a two-year investigation of the commodity futures markets. Typical of the violations they reportedly discovered was ''bucket trading'' - where brokers and traders arrange deals in secret to purchase commodities for clients at prices that are too high.

LEAD: Investigators say they have yet to find a suspect, motive or murder weapon in the stabbing deaths of an Indian-American couple here, and Indian-Americans in the region are becoming increasingly worried that the slayings may have been ethnically motivated.

LEAD: Q. I have cabinets of ash wood in my kitchen. Food and dirt stains have accumulated around the handles and knobs on the cabinet doors. Is it possible to clean off this dirt without also removing or damaging the finish, or must the cabinets be revarnished?

LEAD: At the Battell Chapel at Yale University in New Haven, Victoria Anne Chave, the daughter of Mrs. Charles T. Chave of Madison, Conn., and the late Mr. Chave, was married yesterday to Peter Wickham Clement, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold T. Clement of Buffalo. The Rev. John G. Macort Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: To the Editor: You mentioned (Travel, Nov. 27), ''Christmas is still a bit more secular and lighthearted for the English . . .'' Having spent several Christmases in England, it is fair to say the English Christmas today is one of religious services, family reunions and general merrymaking and carol singing.

LEAD: Marilyn Silverman and Paul Feiner, a Westchester County Legislator, plan to marry next month. The future bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Silverman of Brooklyn, who have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Alan Feiner of Scarsdale, N.Y. Ms. Silverman is a freelance book editor.

LEAD: AS RECENTLY as the 1970's, when the American divorce rate began to soar, divorce was thought to be a brief crisis that soon resolved itself. Young children might have difficulty falling asleep and older children might have trouble at school. Men and women might become depressed or frenetic, throwing themselves into sexual affairs or immersing themselves in work.
LEAD: George and Barbara Bush had a few thousand folks over this morning to show off their new house.

LEAD: The three choreographers presented by Dance Chance on Saturday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater of Dance Theater Workshop have different styles, histories and choreographic interests. But the new and recent works on the second program of a two-part series were recognizably of 1980's post-modernist dance, with its emphasis on sheer energy and physicality.

LEAD: If it wasn't beyond the call of duty, it certainly exceeded his job description. Mark Hardy, who is not even a stylish defenseman, tonight performed a good imitation of a gifted left wing. The odd change in role consequently preserved a familiar theme for the Rangers.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Thank you for the Christmas present - Bill Bryson's article on John Cleese (''Cleese Up Close,'' Dec. 25).

LEAD: A SERIES of recent court decisions has substantially increased the state's responsibility to care for the homeless, straining a small supply of shelter beds and magnifying the difficulty of finding permanent low-cost housing.

LEAD: One minute Dale Ellis would pop a shot from the wing or put up a 3-pointer. Then he would drive the lane or crash the boards for a rebound. Just when the Clippers thought they had the 6-foot-7-inch Seattle SuperSonic guard covered, he would pass the ball inside.

LEAD: LATIN AMERICANS routinely shrug when new United States administrations pledge special interest in their region. The record shows that other parts of the world invariably gain precedence. But this time may be different. Latin America's multifaceted crisis is so acute that its main problems - debt, drugs and democracy - may be difficult to ignore.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: At the Old West Church in Boston, Suzanne Patnode, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Patnode of South Natick, Mass., was married yesterday to Thomas Edward Dean, the son of Mrs. George A. Dean Jr. of Port Washington, L.I., and the late Mr. Dean. The Rev. Charles McCracken performed the Methodist ceremony.

LEAD: The Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz introduced itself to Durham on Jan. 14with a high-voltage handshake at the Page Auditorium of Duke University: a concert by some of jazz's most noted musicians and appearances by Steve Allen; his wife, Jayne Meadows, and Clint Eastwood, who directed the movie ''Bird.

LEAD: THINGS that are genuine tend to last, to hold up over the years. Fads come and go, styles change. But stylishness, if one really has it, and more importantly, a quiet gracefulness, tend to be constants, as impervious to whim as a skillful sailor is to slight variations in the wind.

LEAD: On a dusty plain above the harbor hundreds of men and women sit at rickety stands, shielded from the sun by battered sheets of metal. Spread in front of them are their wares: shoes and Coca-Cola, eggs, tomatoes, steel wool, whisky, vitamin B tablets . . .

LEAD: Arunas Zebriunas, chairman of the Filmmakers Union of Lithuania, is one of the leaders of Sajudis, the Lithuanian Movement for Perestroika, a grass-roots nationalist movement. Now 58, he joined the Soviet Communist Party three years ago

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Dr. Marvin Klein, a pediatric neurologist, died of cancer yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 52 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

LEAD: AIDS has come to Long Island. It's been here since nearly the beginning, of course, but much like the early turn of autumn leaves, few took notice. Indeed, the first Long Islanders who developed the disease had the good taste to be diagnosed in the pernicious anonymity of the Big City, only to return home for the family support most never received.
LEAD: IS it possible that the days of kissy-kissy are over? That instant intimacy, like transcendental meditation, break dancing and all the other fads that spew from the tube, has run its course?

LEAD: The right of family members to remain in their rent-stabilized apartments in New York City after the tenant named on the lease has died or moved out was upheld last week by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

LEAD: IT is a little like watching someone try to slip the pin back into a live grenade. Slowly and with a caution learned the hard way, Moscow has begun a new campaign to pacify the ethnic tensions in Armenia and Azerbaijan. If the exercise is successful, it will bode better for the orderly resolution of ethnic discontents in other republics with restive non-Russian majorities.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

LEAD: The game was one-dimensional, the goaltenders were besieged and the scoring came at breakneck speed. So far as Coach Al Arbour was concerned, the game was a monstrosity, but he couldn't control the hint of a smile as he made that observation.
LEAD: The Soviet budget deficit could reach $162 billion by 1990, according to figures published today in a Soviet newspaper.

LEAD: CIVILIZATION OF THE ANCIENT MEDITERRANEAN: Greece and Rome. Edited by Michael Grant and Rachel Kitzinger. (Scribners, $225.) That price is not a typographical error. What you get here is 1,980 double-column pages in three volumes containing 97 chapters by 88 authorities on everything from farming and cooking to taxes, warfare and divinities in Greece and Rome.

LEAD: THE best road to the best beach in Puerto Rico - and one of the best in the world - isn't the main one. The car rental agency in San Juan may tell you that Route 3 east from San Juan is the best way to reach Luquillo Beach - and they'd be half-right. Route 3 is two-lane highway, and if a bit more beat-up than the average Interstate, it's fast and direct.
LEAD: WINTER, a time of stark grays and cold whites, can also bring on the blues. And overcoming the low spirits is a struggle that many find requires a well-planned strategy.

LEAD: Think of New York's concert life and one thinks first of the big, glamorous events: first nights at the Metropolitan Opera, famous recitalists and singers at Lincoln Center, glittering visiting orchestras at Carnegie Hall.

LEAD: A poet and assistant professor from Shanghai, he agreed to speak candidly only if his name was not used. He joined the party in 1985, when he was asked to apply during his third year in college. He said cynicism and disillusionment are widespread among younger party members, particularly among intellectuals.

LEAD: Railroad locomotives have killed 61 moose in Alaska so far this winter, as against 329 from November to April a year ago. The Alaska Railroad keeps moose kill figures in that five-month period because it is then that deep snow drives the moose from their summer range in the mountains down toward firm footing on or near the cleared railroad tracks.

LEAD: LONDON is the very mecca of clubland. It contains clubs for every conceivable purpose, but one of the most universal is the consumption of food. The dining club has long been a congenial place to gather with like-minded friends, and London offers two types, the traditional members' club, where food is only one of the home-away-from-home facilities, and the private dining club, sometimes sniffily called the checkbook club, but an option for Americans who are in

LEAD: Movies are too easy to make. When you come down to it, all it takes is money, which buys access to writers, directors and actors. It buys long shooting schedules, location trips, special effects and stretch limos. It also buys technicians who are so talented that they can make even a frivolous orangutan look like a serious orangutan, if not a movie maker of substance.

LEAD: One of the great truisms of the Super Bowl is that the games have been artistic failures 22 straight times, a series of high-platform belly-whoppers rated 7.5 by the judges in the stands and the press box.

LEAD: Just as Angola brought the breakdown of detente in the mid-1970's, it is an early beneficiary of the ''new climate'' in East-West relations. But it is also a prime example of how much more is involved than decisions in Moscow and Washington. The superpowers may command, but they are caught in local tides that run their course.
LEAD: WINTER CARNIVAL

LEAD: THE CARPATHIANS. By Janet Frame. (Braziller, $17.50.) Janet Frame's 11th novel, her first in nine years, is an unconventional fantasy. Told for the most part from the viewpoint of a wealthy, compulsive globe-trotter, a middle-aged New Yorker named Mattina Brecon, it describes her two-month stay in the fictional New Zealand town of Puamahara.
LEAD: VANISHING ACT Starring Mike Farrell (in photo), Elliott Gould, Fred Gwynne, Margot Kidder (in photo). Directed by David Greene. 1986. Vidmark Entertainment. 93 minutes. $89.95. Rated PG.

LEAD: I applaud the informative article on the legislative battle for tenants' rights to keep pets (Jan.l). As a single musician with two cats, I can testify to the emotional necessity of the companionship they provide.
LEAD: A United Nations official left for the Persian Gulf today to hold new talks with Iran and Iraq as a report circulated that Iraq may be easing its stand.
LEAD: Absolutely not.

LEAD: When it comes to casting leading roles in opera - and particularly in ''bread-and-butter'' works that are or used to be at the center of the repertory - people in the opera world repeatedly stress the sometimes insane conditions under which this complex and exotic art operates today, singers' vagaries being only one aspect, and not even the most difficult.

LEAD: Did you hear that? Promises, promises from Bill Walsh and Sam Wyche, the Super Bowl XXIII coaches, pals offering predictions. Both guarantee that this will be one of the most exciting Super Bowls ever, a close, high-scoring affair full of twists.

LEAD: For the last 40 years, the Louisville Orchestra has been giving American composers a specific reason to write symphonic music. A decision in 1948 to commission works, and subsequent support by the Rockefeller Foundation, set in place a program that has put a little optimism in composers' hearts and some money in their pockets.

LEAD: President Bush's Inaugural Address contained no specific battle plan, no detailed agenda for the next Hundred Days. But it offered something at least as important: a conciliatory and practical strategy for governing.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The purse for the 1989 Buick Open will be $1 million, up from $700,000 last year. The 25-year-old tournament becomes the 15th on the PGA Tour with a purse of at least $1 million.

LEAD: ROBERT C. (BUD) MCFARLANE SOMETIMES has trouble with the truth, even when he is telling it. Take the time in 1982 when he was deputy national security adviser, and an intelligence leak reached The New York Times. McFarlane proposed that National Security Council staff members in the know be given lie-detector tests to find the leak, and he volunteered to go first.

LEAD: After 14 years, ''The Papers of William Livingston'' a major publishing project that was edited by Carl E. Prince, was completed last month when its fifth and final volume was issued by the Rutgers University Press.

LEAD: Staging a comeback - even a modest one - often suggests vindication and moral triumph. There is a sense of an earlier injustice being righted, of wrongly withheld recognition bestowed at last, and true deserts finally enjoyed.

LEAD: After 12 years as a minor league umpire, Pam Postema, is getting a second chance to become the first woman to work behind a major league plate. As it did last year, the National League has invited her to umpire during spring training.

LEAD: Keith Jarrett, James Levine, Steve Reich and Wynton Marsalis will take part in the Lincoln Center Off Stage series of snacks and discussion beginning in March. Each program begins with a wine-and-cheese reception at 5:30 P.M. and is followed by a talk and a question-answer session with the guest.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Going strictly by the book, more citizens become lawbreakers on Super Bowl Sunday than any day of the year. Unless, that is, they spend the day in Nevada.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AS the sun rises along a deep and smooth bend in the Huangpu River, where the boats known as sampans tie up at the mouth of the Suzhou Creek, the river bank already shows signs of bustle. On the main street, Doric columns, Gothic windows and plaster friezes adorn the grand buildings towering above the rest of the city's low, flat-roofed houses and hint at the past presence of European brokers in the opium trade.

LEAD: Associated Black Charities, a federation of 59 human service agencies in New York City, has named three winners of its annual Black History Maker awards for ''extraordinary achievement.'' The 1989 awards went to Franklin Thomas, president of the Ford Foundation, Rachel Robinson, chairwoman of the Jackie Robinson Foundation, and Arthur Mitchell, president of the Dance Theatre of Harlem.
LEAD: FRIDAY Baseball

LEAD: WHERE does a satellite get the electricity it needs as it orbits the earth? The Soviet space program uses small nuclear reactors aboard some of its most important space vehicles, while American spacecraft tend to generate electricity from the sun.

LEAD: If there is a word to describe the United States Navy's operations now winding down in the Persian Gulf, it has to be ''improvise.'' Captains and crews had to adapt high-tech ships to what military people call a low-intensity conflict.

LEAD: The Stamford Urban Redevelopment Commission has chosen the Lincoln Property Company of Dallas to build an $87 million mixed-use downtown project as one of the major pieces of Stamford's urban renewal plan. Stamford Court, as the project is called, will have 365 rental apartments, 35 town houses, medical office space, a 1,020-car garage and a recreation center that will include movie houses and restaurants.

LEAD: Two years ago, when a one-man judicial commission appointed by President P. W. Botha of South Africa castigated a prominent commercial banker, Christopher J. W. Ball, for his anti-apartheid activities, his business colleagues said the action was a politically manipulated bid to destroy his career.
LEAD: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin'-race! Aboon them a' ye tak your place. Painch, tripe or thairm: Weel are ye wordy o' a grace As lang's my arm.

LEAD: THIRTEEN months have passed since New York State first allowed cameras a front-row seat at criminal trials. So far at least, the only clear casualties of the experiment, a test of the effect of television on the judicial process, are courtroom artists who have been automated out of their jobs.

LEAD: Granddaughter of a wealthy landlord and daughter of a doctor who died when she was 5 years old, Li Shuxian, now 53, spent her youth in poverty. She welcomed the revolution and joined the party in 1954, only to be expelled three years later in an ''anti-rightist'' campaign and then, finally, reinstated automatically along with other purge victims in 1979.

LEAD: The trade figures for November showed a sharp and unexpected widening of the trade deficit to $12.5 billion, from $10.3 billion in October. The cause of the increase was a surge in imports and a decrease in exports. The question for the analysts is whether the growth in the deficit is an aberration or a trend.

LEAD: At least 17 people were reported injured and 42 were arrested today as several hundred people broke through police barricades in an attempt to attack seven avowed racists parading in downtown Atlanta.

LEAD: Q. I have cabinets of ash wood in my kitchen. Food and dirt stains have accumulated around the handles and knobs on the cabinet doors. Is it possible to clean off this dirt without also removing or damaging the finish, or must the cabinets be revarnished?
LEAD: PUBLIC school pupils in Cleveland can get more than a diploma when they graduate. Each can collect up to $4,800 toward a college education.

LEAD: ON THE AFTERNOON OF MAY 18, 1988, COMMENCEMENT Day at Columbia University, more than 25,000 people - including 7,000 degree candidates and their families - sat outdoors beneath a driving rain, wondering what would happen to the graduation exercises.
LEAD: After Rudolph W. Giuliani brought a few prosecutions that made waves around the world, critics and admirers both said he was the only prosecutor in the country with a foreign policy.

LEAD: Government prosecutors investigating possible fraud on the nation's two largest commodities exchanges are using documents from disciplinary proceedings conducted by the exchanges against traders to help build the criminal inquiry, people involved in the case said today.

LEAD: Acoustically there is no space in New York more ideal for the delectation of acoustic jazz than St. Clement's Church (423 West 46th Street). Last season, when Lyn Austin's Music Theater group presented ''Prison-Made Tuxedos,'' an ambitious music-theater piece featuring the great alto saxophonist Frank Morgan, a muddled concept was redeemed by thrilling music perfectly projected.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 8 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 2 5 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $4.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and-roll performers in tinselly southern California.

LEAD: Three years after Donald R. Manes first attempted suicide and threw the Queens Democratic organization into turmoil and investigations that overturned its leadership, a new leader is presiding over a tranquil Queens Democratic Party that is trying to reassert itself politically.

LEAD: Theodore Bundy, linked by the authorities to about three dozen killings, confessed to at least nine additional murders today, while his lawyers maneuvered to block his execution scheduled for Tuesday, officials from two Western states said.
LEAD: Jayson Williams scored 22 points, including 7 in a key second-half rally, to lead St. John's to a 74-66 victory over Boston College tonight in a Big East Conference game.

LEAD: Randy Barnes may quickly outgrow the indoor shot-put. Barnes's final attempt nearly hit the barrier at the back of the shot-put sector on the floor of the Sports Arena Friday night at the Sunskist Invitational.
LEAD: Idaho State Penitentiary inmates are talking about a possible disturbance.

LEAD: The marriage of Annella Marie Tuolumne White, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Brooke White of New York, was married there yesterday to Roy Christopher Dignes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lyder Dignes of Mountain Lakes, N.J. The ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. Susan C. Harriss.

LEAD: The founder of the Museum of the American Indian, George Heye, started the collection literally by taking the shirt off the back of a Native American. I say, give every object in the museum back to its rightful owners, the Native Americans themselves. Let them decide what they want to share and what they need for the spiritual nourishment of their nations.

LEAD: Twenty-eight years after his first two-bit bet at the race track, the double life of lies and deception caught up with an insurance executive whose gambling debts had climbed into the hundreds of thousands of dollars. The business he had built went bankrupt. His marriage ended in bitter divorce. Often, he considered killing himself.

LEAD: Magazine publishers seem undaunted by the fact that only two out of 10 new magazines survive beyond their fourth year. Indeed, in 1987, 477 new consumer magazines appeared on the newsstands, a 28 percent increase over new launches in 1986.

LEAD: THE BLOB Starring Shawnee Smith (in photo), Donovan Leitch, Kevin Dillon, Jeffrey DeMunn, Candy Clark, Del Close. Directed by Chuck Russell. 1988. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Entertainment. 95 minutes. $89.95. Closed captioned. Rated R.
