LEAD: GEORGE BUGLIARELLO, the president of Polytechnic University in downtown Brooklyn, seems happy now to tell the story of being offered his job in 1973 and turning it down at first, not because of the school's faculty, finances or academic standing, but because of the urban blight surrounding its campus.

LEAD: MY father-in-law died recently at the age of 96, and of all the memories I have of him, his telling of one small happening in his early years, which he kept in his memory for all of his life, has stayed with me for all of mine. Perhaps that is because in the telling he revealed some part of himself that was not apparent, that told me something about the little boy who later became the ''Pater Familias'' whom I so loved and admired.

LEAD: Because of the stiff competition among traditional print magazines, some publishers are delivering magazines on video cassettes. Of the handful of magazines now on video in this country, most are about sports.

LEAD: At the Judson Memorial Church in New York, Nana Graves Hilliard Smith, the daughter of Dr. Gilbert Graves Smith of Raleigh, N.C., and the late Sherry Griffing Hatch, was married yesterday to James Bennett Milliken, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Milliken of Fremont, Neb. The Rev. Howard Moody, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Spending a few days in Biarritz, we'd been loafing at the Hotel du Palais, sampling the bustling open-air fish restaurants under the cliff, poking around the shops down at St. Jean-de-Luz and, one night, enjoying a great dinner at the old and still-grand Cafe de Paris.

LEAD: A British Airways Boeing 757 carrying 82 people made an emergency landing at Heathrow Airport today after one of its two engines developed problems in flight, the airline said. The airline first reported that the left engine had been shut off, but later it said the engine had just been slowed down after developing problems.
LEAD: On-Time Tally For Amtrak Is Still Eroding

LEAD: POOR Agfa. When we think of films in this country, we think first of Kodak, then of Fuji, and finally, maybe, of Agfa. Few of us remember that Agfa was a pioneer of color films, back before World War II.
LEAD: A homeless man chased down and shot a policeman to death Friday, then mortally wounded another before being killed by other officers in a noontime gun battle on the street.
LEAD: THE CLUSTERING OF AMERICA By Michael J. Weiss. Illustrated. 416 pp. New York: Tilden Press/Harper & Row. $22.50.

LEAD: Remember the advertisement for Popeil's Veg-O-Matic? It diced, it sliced, it shredded, it chopped. That marketing spirit is at work for makeup today. It isn't enough for makeup to provide color; now, it has to deliver treatment benefits as well.

LEAD: Christine Diane Henderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Thomas Henderson of Wellesley, Mass., was married there yesterday to Stephen Holbrook Beach 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Beach Jr. of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Vincent Warner performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

LEAD: Peter Brook, the magician who makes theater in unlikely places, is transforming his epic ''Mahabharata'' into a six-hour film for television, and a theatrical movie of about half that length. Filming has just been completed in a formerly abandoned studio at Joinville, outside Paris.

LEAD: THE Palestine Liberation Organization has recently been talking a more moderate line, and that has thrust its older leaders into the spotlight and brought new prominence to some younger voices. Radical P.L.O. groups have gone along with the avowals of moderation but have warned that if the peace process does not produce results, they will return to harsher tactics.

LEAD: HEAVENLY MUSIC For some musical tastes, the only thing better than one harp is two harps. This truism is something that Eva Jaslar and Margery Fitts figured out in 1981, when they formed the New York Harp Duo.
LEAD: A CRACKDOWN on polluters netted the state more than $1 million in fines last year, more than twice as much as in 1987, Environmental Protection Department officials said.
LEAD: The Board of Regents has declined to approve mandating professional degrees for directors of small libraries.

LEAD: Huang Gang, a Chinese literary critic, writer and party member in his late 60's, is a member of a party wing that holds that Communism's basic principles are being forgotten. He acknowledged that past crises, particularly the cultural revolution, challenged the party's integrity. But, he argued, those ''mistakes'' have been recognized.

LEAD: IT has been a long time since Western Europe was so reassured by the transition from one American President to another. In the hand-over from Ronald Reagan to George Bush, there is something almost European in the respect for continuity.
LEAD: Norma Varden, whose acting career in films, television and on the state included such roles as Jack Benny's mother and the housekeeper in ''The Sound of Music,'' has died at age 90.

LEAD: Five years after the breakup of the Bell system changed its world forever, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company finally seems willing to do what it takes to thrive in a fiercely competitive marketplace.
LEAD: THE influences on the playwrights in this year's Winterfest series of the Yale Repertory Theater are eclectic, to say the least, and range from Euripides to Pat Boone.

LEAD: IT doesn't take much more than a cursory glance to realize that Vallauris, a town in the Maritime Alps of France, is a pottery center of consequence. Avenue Georges-Clemenceau, the main street, is lined with shops spilling their wares out onto the sidewalk. Individual artisans and artists have studios and shops on the avenue and on adjoining side streets.

LEAD: IN New York's capital, as in the nation's, taxes are out; revenues are in. To prove it, the budget that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed last week calls for $800 million in new revenues, but no increase in the state's primary taxes on corporate and personal income and on sales.
LEAD: Mark Calcavecchia, a husky, free-swinging long hitter,shot 6-under par over the stretch from No. 13 through 17 today to take a three-stroke lead in the $700,000 Phoenix Open.

LEAD: Kathleen Anne Kelly and Richard Jeffrey Broomer were married last evening at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Joseph Kelly, in Scarsdale, N.Y. Mr. Broomer is a son of Fay Broomer of Ossining, N.Y., and the late Cyril J. Broomer. Msgr. Edward M. Connors, who presided at the marriage of the bride's parents 27 years ago, and Rabbi Abraham J.

LEAD: ''Failing in Teaching'' by Karon Cooney is one of the saddest statements I've ever read about education, although my first reaction to it was why such a negative, unforgiving article would be printed at all.

LEAD: What a grand operatic plan it was. As artistic director of the new Bastille Opera of Paris, Daniel Barenboim, the Israeli conductor and pianist, assembled an international team of conductors, singers, directors and designers for three seasons to begin in 1990. A $350 million theater for the opera is scheduled to open with a concert on July 14.

LEAD: Steinbrenner and Winfield possess two totally incompatible personalities. Their never-ending squabbles have left the Yankee organization in ruins and the national media laughing. Soon, the integrity of every Yankee fan will be threatened. Peace can only be achieved if: 1) the Yankees win the World Series; 2) Winfield resigns; 3) Steinbrenner resigns; 4) both Winfield and Steinbrenner resign, or 5) Donald Trump takes over the Yankees and dumps
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: The whole Schoenberger family - 17 people in all - spent the year-end holidays in Israel and had a wonderful time, but before they left they remembered The New York Times Neediest Cases.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Bumsted of Vero Beach, Fla., and Lake Placid, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Cleaver Bumsted, to Dennis Patrick O'Hearn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Charles O'Hearn Jr. of Fripp Island, S.C. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: No subject has held the attention of more types of photographers during the last 25 years than the self-portrait. A list of those artists who have looked at themselves seriously - not just glancingly -would include such disparate stylists as Andy Warhol, Lee Friedlander, Anselm Kiefer, Eleanor Antin, Lucas Samaras, William Wegman, John Coplans, Judy Dater, Robert Mapplethorpe, Arnulf Rainer, Cindy Sherman, Chuck Close, Duane Michals, Adrian Piper, Bruce Charlesworth, Christian Boltanski and Ann Noggle.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Gambling on the future of the commercial real estate market in central New Jersey, two developers in the area will start construction in Bridgewater next month on two three-story office buildings with 325,000 square feet of rental space. Named the Grande Commons at Bridgewater, the $60 million project on a 24-acre site on Route 22 near the junction of Route 28 is a joint venture of the Bellemead Development Corporation of Roseland and Claremont Properties of

LEAD: For one half tonight, the Nets looked better than ever. They were outplaying the team with the best record in the National Basketball Association. They were functioning as a poised, cohesive unit. And if they had been able to upset the Cleveland Cavaliers, it could have done wonders for New Jersey's confidence.
LEAD: SOMEONE described a boat as ''a hole in the water into which you throw money.'' A small farm is like that.

LEAD: PINNED to downtown denim and uptown designs, cloisonne French military insignia sold by a sidewalk vendor are a hot costume jewelry item in Manhattan. The colorful pins have become especially popular since appearing in fashion magazines, said the vendor, James Kusnir, who sells them for $20 to $50 in SoHo and on Columbus
LEAD: If Martin and Steinbrenner can fall apart (and then make up) so many times, why not Winfield and Steinbrenner?
LEAD: WAR AND PEACE IN THE NUCLEAR AGE By John Newhouse. Illustrated. 486 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John Watson Scully of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Crowell Scully, to Todd Hodges Doolan, the son of Mrs. James A. Gobes of West Hartford, Conn., and Dwight M. Doolan of New York. The couple plan to marry in September.

LEAD: CAPT. JAMES M. MOONEY of the State Police, has headed the Statewide Narcotics Task Force, a cooperative effort between state and local police officers, for the last five of its 11 years. In that time he has seen some dramatic changes in drug use in Connecticut.
LEAD: IN their push to erect new towers, developers today are feeling pressure to work around pieces of history. Projects are rising over, behind and around relics of the past.

LEAD: WHAT becomes of a legend lost? Bygone film stars slip into obscurity, obsolete fashions fade away, but antique flowers never die. Although gardenias no longer adorn gentlemen's buttonholes, gardeners struggle to keep them living happily ever after on their windowsills.

LEAD: Karon Cooney's article, ''Failing in Teaching'' (Opinion page, Jan. 1), speaks of passionless teachers, but I expect it will arouse the passion of all effective teachers who read it. Ms. Cooney lifts the burden of guilt for our children's ills from parents' shoulders and drops it on the most popular scapegoat of the 80's - our nation's teachers.
LEAD: FALLEN ANGELS By Walter Dean Myers. 309 pp. New York: Scholastic. $12.95. (Ages 14 and up)

LEAD: WHEN one of your favorite defensive systems runs into trouble, the solution is quite simple: Don't play it. Yet it is just amazing how player after player can look down at the floor when the handwriting is on the wall.

LEAD: Michael T. Kaufman's article about hand-kissing delighted me (About Men: ''Kissing Customs,'' Dec. 11). Indeed, my mother always said that a communist government could take all material things away from you, but it could not deprive you of your education or your manners.
LEAD: In the Communist world, the underground joke is often the best index of conditions. ''What is Communism?'' asks one that has recently been making the rounds.

LEAD: CHIEFTAINS IN MONTCLAIR The Chieftains - the Dublin-based ambassadors of traditional Irish music whose repertory of reels, jigs, airs and ballads are the product of centuries - will appear Thursday evening in Montclair.

LEAD: Anatoly N. Solovyev, 45, is chief doctor at a big hospital in the center of Moscow. Neither his wife, who is also a doctor, nor his son, who is studying to be a doctor, is a party member. He joined the party in 1970 and recently defeated two other candidates in an election for the Moscow City Council.

LEAD: George Bush has the best handwriting of all the Republicans who vied for the Presidency last year, according to the National Coalition to Stamp Out Chicken Scratching. The ''coalition'' is the creation of a ball-point pen manufacturer, whose not-so-hidden agenda is to promote them. But, commerce apart, the stamper-outers have a legitimate cause: in the age of word processors, penmanship is getting sloppier.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Steinbrenner's battles with Winfield are merely a result of his understandable frustration and boredom after years with a losing team. The obvious cure is for the compassionate city of New York to take up a collection and send Our George to Los Angeles, where he can once again pursue his favorite pastime: destroying a winning team.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In recent years, the name of Idi Amin has cropped up mainly as a symbol of a tyranny nearly as bizarre as it was brutal. Once the self-proclaimed President-for-Life of Uganda, whose whim meant death to thousands and exile to hundreds of thousands, he fled in 1979 and was given sanctuary in Saudi Arabia - on condition that he stay out of the public eye.
LEAD: SHOULD a deaf person be barred from serving on a trial jury?

LEAD: The owner of a company under criminal investigation for its role in the supply and construction of a suspected chemical weapons plant in Libya has denied the assertions.
LEAD: George Sleeman, the former superintendent of Bennington schools who was convicted of embezzlement, was sentenced Wednesday to a minimum of two years in jail.

LEAD: At Temple Beth El in Portland, Me., Leah Beth Goldfarb, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew S. Goldfarb of Portland, was married last evening to Michael Lubin Byer, a son of Hope L. Byer of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., and Charles H. Byer of Philadelphia. Rabbi Harry Z. Sky and Cantor Kurt Messerschmidt performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It is the destiny of Ferruccio Busoni's music to be perpetually revived and re-examined, never established in the repertory yet not forgotten, either. The composer guaranteed such a state of affairs; whatever cravings he had for popular success were more than gratified by his long career as a piano virtuoso, and he composed his music for a self-selecting audience of the curious and intelligent.
LEAD: AIDS AND ITS METAPHORS By Susan Sontag. 95 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.
LEAD: In one of his first official acts, Vice President Dan Quayle will meet with anti-abortion leaders Monday at the request of President Bush, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Derrick McQueen shrugged off foul trouble in the second half and scored a career-high 20 points today as Wake Forest defeated No. 1 Duke by 75-71 in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.
LEAD: Carl Furillo, the right fielder for the Brooklyn Dodgers during their glory years in the late 1940's and 50's, died yesterday at his home at Stony Creek Mills, Pa. He was 66 years old.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Dorfman of Brooklyn have made known the engagement of their daughter Diana Brooke Dorfman to Dr. James Alan Deutsch, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Deutsch of Brooklyn. The couple plan to marry in September.

LEAD: Something curious happened in early January. With little more than two weeks of his term remaining, President Reagan endorsed a Commerce Department finding that rising petroleum imports threaten to impair national security, leaving the West dependent on potentially insecure sources. Then, just a few hours after President Reagan's announcement, American Navy jets shot down two Libyan MIG's over the eastern
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Three bobsledders have been suspended from the United States team after testing positive for the use of steroids, and five others have been reprimanded for inadvertantly using over-the-counter medications banned by the International Olympic Committee. According to reports in The Lake Placid News and The Watertown Times, the one-year suspensions and the reprimands stemmed from tests administered at the world team trials in November.

LEAD: I have followed with interest and concern the plight of the Museum of the Amerian Indian. Those negotiating its fate should look for a solution that will insure the museum's ability to preserve its collection and maximize the accessibility of the collection to the widest audience. I believe there should be two facilities: a larger building in New York City, such as the Custom House, and another in Washington.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THERE I was, at 65, as close as I had ever been to serving on a jury. One woman among eight men, the first to be questioned by the two lawyers. Skipping from man to man, the lawyer for the defendant asked, ''Do you ride a bicycle?'' If the answer was yes, he wanted to know if it was a 10-speed. Eventually, the questioner stood in front of me.

LEAD: CENTURIES OF FEMALE DAYS: Englishwomen's Private Diaries. By Harriet Blodgett. (Rutgers University, $29.95.) On Oct. 23, 1848, Caroline Fox, the 29-year-old daughter of the eminent English scientist Robert Were Fox, noted succinctly in her diary, ''A wet day and all its luxuries.'' The following day she recorded as, ''A fine day and all its liabilities.

LEAD: Just as they were in 1982, when they defeated the Cincinnati Bengals, 26-21, the San Francisco 49ers are the team the American public wants to see win the Super Bowl.

LEAD: Anne Robin Kurz, a daughter of Ruth Kurz of Clifton, N.J. and the late Nathan Kurz, was married in Summit, N.J., last evening to Jeffrey Alan Zenn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Zenn of Millburn, N.J. Rabbi Steven Shaw performed the ceremony at the Summit Hotel. Mrs. Zenn is the associate director of resource development at the Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopedic Institute in New York.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: My day always becomes wonderful/when I see your/pretty face smiling so sweetly. . . . Such free-verse sentiment, printed against a background of pastel artwork, is a kind of signature for Blue Mountain Arts, a greeting-card company founded here in 1971.
LEAD: The Wicker Man Starring Edward Woodward, Christopher Lee, Diane Cilento, Britt Ekland, Ingrid Pitt. Directed by Robin Hardy. 1974. Magnum Entertainment. 102 minutes. $59.98. Rated R.
LEAD: CHOOSING sandpaper from among the many varieties stocked by hardware stores often perplexes amateurs, and not surprisingly.

LEAD: West Germany's diplomatic staff left Kabul today on orders from Bonn, and the Soviet press agency Tass reported that Moscow had begun an airlift of emergency food supplies to this beleaguered capital.

LEAD: In attempting to understand the controversy over Proposition 42, it is necessary to look to the reason behind it. Students who enter college without basic academic skills will not have the opportunity to succeed without assistance in acquiring those skills.

LEAD: Wende Ellen Sawyer and George Thompson Hutton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hutton of Greenwich, Conn., and Seattle, plan to marry in May. The engagement has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Sawyer of San Mateo, Calif.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A half century ago, George and Ira Gershwin, Cole Porter and Jerome Kern were frequent visitors to the 388-acre Dreyfus estate in southeastern Putnam County, now the subject of a proposal before the Town Board of Southeast to divide it into 139 home sites. The property features a three-story castle that evolved from an Italianate villa built in 1860 by Daniel Drew, the financier for whom Drew University, in Madison, N.J., is named.

LEAD: For the first time, the USA Cable network will televise the Ryder Cup matches back to the United States, Sept. 22-24, according to a source close to television negotiations for the biennial professional golf match between the United States and European teams.
LEAD: Winfield and Steinbrenner will never find peace.

LEAD: As an all-America cornerback with a bright professional future, Deion Sanders has apparently not put too much store in the academic side of things at Florida State. Indeed, according to rumors circulating in Tallahassee, after a stint at summer school to meet eligibility requirements for the fall season, Sanders, a fourth-year player, virtually dropped out of school during the football season and even skipped his final exams before playing against Auburn in the Sugar Bowl Jan.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Robert M. Weitman, a former film, stage and television producer, died Friday at his home in Beverly Hills. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: IF you've been running for five years or more, can't shake the injury syndrome, feel mentally stale or find your racing times at a plateau, the answer to your problems may be a revolutionary training system that is gaining acceptance among competitive runners across the country. Cut your running to a mere 20 miles a week.

LEAD: To some lawyers here, Anton Ronald Valukas, the United States Attorney in Chicago, is the Rudolph Giuliani of the Midwest. But others, including some people who work on his staff, scoff at the notion. Mr. Valukas, they say, has been even more aggressive than his counterpart in Manhattan.

LEAD: A Paris newspaper reported today that a report was sent to President Francois Mitterrand suggesting that one of his closest friends, Roger-Patrice Pelat, a businessman, bought 50,000 shares of Triangle Industries' stock just before Pechiney S.A. of France announced plans to acquire Triangle.

LEAD: A Supreme Court justice yesterday evening halted jury selection in the GAF Corporation's criminal stock-manipulation trial after the defendants complained that the trial would violate the double-jeopardy clause of the Constitution.
LEAD: The drought of 1988 has now reached into 1989.
LEAD: John Duka, a journalist who wrote with humor and grace about fashion, art and society, died Saturday morning at his Manhattan home. He was 39 years old.

LEAD: True to his word, Charles Z. Wick, the departing director of the United States Information Agency, is moving back to California, where he will be close to his friend, former President Ronald Reagan. But Mr. Wick is not turning his back on the capital completely. Last week Mr. Reagan appointed him to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts's board.The board meets three or four times a year.

LEAD: Shortly after his team had welcomed him back with a 59-55 victory over Connecticut Saturday, John Thompson, the basketball coach at Georgetown University, wiped his brow and said that it certainly felt good to be on the bench again.

LEAD: For 13 seasons, Randy Cross had played guard and then center for the San Francisco 49ers. He announced last week that Super Bowl XXIII would be the last game of his career, and for most of the game it was a nightmare.

LEAD: Martin Rogers said he remembers Superbowl Sunday in 1988 well. Not because of the game, he said yesterday, but because of what he called the ''sneaky'' way that New York City closed a Brooklyn firehouse.
LEAD: A woman recently bought an apartment in a pleasant Buenos Aires neighborhood for $33,000, paying for it in what the Argentines call ''greens'' -stacks of hundred-dollar bills.

LEAD: The Southmark Corporation, whose two top officers resigned under pressure from dissident creditors last week, said Friday that its directors had hired Drexel Burnam Lambert Inc. to advise the company on the sale of all or part of its assets.

LEAD: Barring sudden weakness in the dollar, credit market analysts predicted that interest rates should remain in a fairly narrow range for the next week or so. The next real test, they believe, will not come until mid-February, when the Treasury will hold its quarterly refunding auctions.

LEAD: Belying reports of an electronics industry slowdown, Motorola Inc. reported on Friday record results for the fourth quarter and the year that ended on Dec. 31. The LSI Logic Corporation, meanwhile, reported lower earnings for the quarter but higher profits for the year.

LEAD: For Prentice Hall, which next year will become the sole publisher of the Betty Crocker cookbooks, the challenge is a large one: to make a line that is already successful even more popular, at a time when there is a glut of cookbooks on the shelves.

LEAD: When Coach Al Arbour was told to prepare the Islanders for an 11 o'clock game in Philadelphia this Saturday, he was worried about his players being too tired so late in the evening. Then he found out the game was scheduled for 11 A.M., not 11 P.M.

LEAD: Carl (Moon) Mullins, a black man who came here 40 years ago from rural Georgia, found success and owns a string of shops. But he said he also found blacks being treated as second-class citizens, and that he discourages his 12 children from building their lives in Miami. ''I just don't see a future for them here, not here,'' he said.

LEAD: In a season of juicy scandals in France, politics, personal ambition and clashing visions of culture lurk at the heart of the angriest and nastiest scandal of all: the battle for control of the brand-new $350 million Bastille Opera.

LEAD: A Soviet military commander acknowledged today that his country's forces are leaving Afghanistan with something of a sense of failure. He also denied that the Soviets have resumed their pullout but said they still plan to be out of the country by Feb. 15.

LEAD: Machinists employed by The New York Times voted yesterday to ratify a six-year extension of a labor contract that expired nearly two years ago, thus becoming the last of 14 unions to approve agreements with the newspaper through March 1993.
